Bush has proposed that capital gains _ profits from the sale of real estate, stock and other investments _ be given preferential tax treatment compared with wages and other incomes. The plan the president outlined Monday would, when fully effective in 1993, tax only 70 percent of the profits from the sale of assets owned three years or more; 80 percent of assets owned more than two years, and 90 percent of profits from the sale of property held at least one year. Present law taxes 100 percent of gains. Bush said a tax break for capital gains would encourage investment that would create jobs and make U.S. businesses more competitive abroad. The House passed a capital gains tax cut last year, but Democratic leaders were able to kill it in the Senate even though most senators favored it. Opponents say 80 percent of the benefits from a capital gains cut would go to people with incomes over $100,000 a year. They contend it would worsen the budget deficit and lead to the undoing of the 1986 tax overhaul. The coalition expects to distribute more than 10 million brochures and addressed envelopes in February and March in an attempt to defeat the capital gains reduction. In contending that only the truly rich would profit from a capital gains cut, the campaign letter cites Bush and hotel owner Leona Helmsley, who was convicted of tax evasion, as examples. Mrs. Helmsley and her husband, Harry, saved $38 million in taxes in 1983 through 1985 because of an earlier capital gains break, the letter says. In 1986, Bush saved $129,000 in taxes because of his capital gains. The 58 organizations sponsoring the protest include the AFL-CIO, Children's Defense Fund, Consumer Federation of America and an arm of the United Church of Christ.

DOC.HEAD: Pension Investigators Ill-Equipped for Their Job, Watchdog Says
DOC.TEXT: Labor Department officers who police the nation's pension system are ``poorly equipped'' for their job, says the department's inspector general in questioning plans to add 100 agents to the unit. The officers don't ``have the mentality and the learning curve to know how to look and where to look'' for racketeers, Acting Inspector General Raymond Maria said Wednesday before a House panel studying the nation's $1.7 trillion private pension system. ``These types of complex cases generally require tips, informants and the execution of search warrants,'' Maria said, adding the department's officers are ``poorly equipped for these tasks.'' But David Ball, who heads the department's Pension Benefits and Welfare Administration, said those agents have closed 8,268 pension investigations in the past five years and recovered $480 million. The House Education and Labor subcommittee on labor-management relations is studying enforcement of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act, passed in 1974 to protect retirees from abuses in their pensions plans. Maria and the Labor Department have been feuding over the department's handling of pension investigations. Maria, who will not be permanently named to the inspector general's post, has insisted the department improperly relies on civil instead of criminal remedies and that problems with the pension system rival those blamed for the savings and loan crisis. Ball called the comparison to the S&L crisis ``inflammatory rhetoric ... It's like shouting fire in a crowded theater.'' Ball said the pension system, with assets that have grown from $290 billion to $1.7 trillion over the past 15 years, has ``never been healthier.'' He said there has been no evidence of widespread fraud in benefit plans. After the hearing, Maria said he was skeptical of department plans to add 100 enforcement officers without a change in the way investigations are pursued. ``If you don't have a sound game plan, why add more players?'' Maria said. The Labor Department's budget request for fiscal 1991 calls for increasing from 200 to 300 the number of pension enforcement. Ball said the addition of 100 enforcement officers would let the agency conduct an additional 1,000 investigations. He defended the department's pursuit of civil remedies and said criminal investigations are turned over to the Justice Department, where he said they belong. Using what will be one of his last appearances before Congress as acting inspector general _ President Bush is expected to nominate a replacement within a week or so _ Maria said department enforcement officers have not been trained to investigate ``professional racketeers.'' Maria also renewed his criticism of a Justice Department ruling that curtailed the investigative powers of inspectors general. The ruling prohibited the inspectors general from launching their own investigations of alleged violations of agency regulations. In essence, the ruling said the departments themselves were responsible for such enforcement and that the role of inspectors general was to investigate and analyze the departments' efforts. Maria wants Congress to pass legislation giving inspectors general broader powers and jurisdictions.

DOC.HEAD: Eased Voter Registration Bill Moving in House
DOC.TEXT: A bill to ease voter registration procedures across the country is moving forward in the House despite Republican warnings that it could generate fraud and complaints about the price tag. ``Let's look before we leap and we're leaping here today,'' Rep. Gerald B.H. Solomon, R-N.Y., said Wednesday as the House moved a step closer to floor action on the so-called motor-voter legislation. The bill calls for automatic registration of all eligible Americans applying for drivers' licenses. It also would mean registration by post card and at various government offices. The House, in a key procedural vote on Wednesday, upheld by 254-166 a rule requiring critics led by GOP Leader Bob Michel of Illinois to tie together all of their proposed amendments to the measure in one batch. The rule then provides for a single vote on the entire bundle of proposed amendments on Tuesday when the House is scheduled to take up the bill. Mainly Republican critics chafed at the rule, urging the House instead to junk all restrictions on how amendments may be offered. Their way would give individual amendments a better chance of acceptance by the House and also slow action on the bill. The bill emerged from the House Government Operations Committee last year with support from a number of Republicans, including Whip Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., and Rep. Bill Thomas, R-Calif. Sponsors hailed a new era of harmony on an issue that once spawned feuding between the parties. But feuding was in full swing on the House floor Wednesday with Rep. Al Swift, D-Wash., a chief sponsor, accusing Michel of violating bipartisan harmony. ``On Monday, the minority leader swooped into town and trashed the entire agreement,'' Swift said. Swift blamed Michel for the collapse of what he called a bipartisan agreement fashioned in the Government Operations Committee. A number of Republicans had backed the measure. Michel replied that he ``may have to share some of the blame for missed communication on my side ... I'm sorry the gentleman should have this feeling because, boy, there was nothing intended on my part to gut the gentleman and turn things on their head here.'' Rep. James Quillen, R-Tenn., publicly read a letter from the Bush administration on Tuesday, saying it shares the goal of eased voter registration but has qualms about the bill's specifics, including whether it could cause fraud. Proponents say voter registration remains an obstacle course in some states and thus dampens turnout. Republicans trooped to the microphones to complain about the rule regarding amendments, saying they needed more maneuvering room to combat burdensome procedures and high costs. And Rep. Lynn Martin, R-Ill., made clear she had no quarrel with the Bush administration's warning against a potential surge in fraud. ``I'm sure there are people in the United States where, if you tell them they can have motor voter registration, they'll be registering people in hearses before they get to the cemetery even,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Man Waited to Report Wife's Suicide 'Til After Super Bowl
DOC.TEXT: The husband of a woman who committed suicide waited to see the Super Bowl in his mother-in-law's home before reporting the death, authorities said. Gary L. Holloway told police his wife, Mary Helen Holloway, shot herself in the head after an argument, authorities said. The Clayton County medical examiner on Wednesday ruled the shooting a suicide. ``I can't explain this wild story. That game was so boring,'' said Jim Mabe, a medical examiner investigator. ``He was possibly a little intoxicated at the time, and maybe shocked,'' Detective Chris Butler said. Holloway's attorney, Charles Wrinkle, said Holloway was too upset to bring himself to tell his mother-in-law about the shooting. ``He just wasn't able to do it. He just didn't know what to do. It's not something you plan for,'' Wrinkle said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Actor Gary Coleman defeated his mother's effort to take control of his $7 million fortune, despite her claim that she only wanted the best for the diminutive 21-year-old. Edmonia Sue Coleman had asked a court conservator to take over Coleman's finances, saying the former ``Diff'rent Strokes'' star was unable to make decisions rationally because of the effects of a kidney disease and what she viewed as the bad influence of a close friend. But on Wednesday, Superior Court Judge Martha Goldin disagreed. ``The very things you claim he doesn't have, he's got,'' Goldin told an attorney for Coleman's mother. Coleman's attorney, Charles Wake, said the actor was pleased. ``It was an emotional experience for him,'' said Wake. Coleman, who played the precocious Arnold Jackson on the hit TV show, has filed a separate lawsuit alleging his parents and former business manager mishandled his money and funneled away more than $1 million for themselves. The lawsuit has yet to come to trial. Coleman's mother said she is worried that her son is getting poor advice from his friend and former chauffeur, Dion Mial, with whom he lives in Denver. ``Gary is my son and I love him very much, regardless of what Mr. Wake says,'' said Mrs. Coleman. ``And what I have done has been in Gary's best interest.'' Coleman was born with an atrophied right kidney and lost the other one when he was 5. He took immunosuppressive drugs for his condition and they stunted his growth at 4 feet, 8 inches.

Lily Tomlin, who gained national fame in the early 1970s on the TV show ``Laugh-In,'' says her career became more interesting when she began her ``Search for Signs of Intelligent Life in the Universe.'' Tomlin, who also has appeared in several movies, starred in the play on Broadway from 1986 to 1988, winning the Tony Award for best actress. She decided to take the show back on the road, including a two-week run in Denver. Tomlin portrays a variety of characters in the play, each of whom searches for meaning in their lives and the lives of those around them. Their collective search, handled deftly with humor and honesty in Jane Wagner's script, emulates real life, Tomlin said Wednesday. ``The play is so human, so funny ... it's moving, satiric, sharp, insightful, compassionate. Everybody sees someone they know in the characters,'' she said. ``It's challenging and so tough to do. But I love this play. It shows me the best of anything so far.''

Randy Travis swept into the finals for five country music awards, including entertainer of the year and No. 1 male singer. His other nominations announced Wednesday were for single of the year, ``It's Just a Matter of Time;'' best music video, for the same song; and album of the year for ``No Holdin' Back.'' Travis dominated the balloting among readers of the Music City News, a monthly country music publication in Nashville. Winners will be determined in a second round of voting and will be announced at the TNN-Music City News Country Awards show at the Grand Ole Opry House on June 4, to be broadcast on cable TV's The Nashville Network. Other finalists for entertainer of the year were Alabama, Ricky Van Shelton, the Statler Brothers and George Strait. The other top male singer finalists were Clint Black, Rodney Crowell, Shelton and Strait. Finalists among the women were Patty Loveless, Kathy Mattea, Reba McEntire, Lorrie Morgan and Tanya Tucker.

Jazz guitarist George Benson gave a pep talk to a would-be musician suffering a rare form of cancer. Then he backed up the kind words with a valuable gift. When 22-year-old David Romito talked with Benson after a show here last fall, it gave him hope. ``Benson talked with me a long time,'' Romito said this week. ``He knew I was sick, of course, and said he knew somebody who once was given only six weeks to live _ and the person is still living 10 years later.'' Romito admired Benson's guitar, a six-string Ibanez, and the singer offered to send him an identical one. The instrument arrived at Romito's home last month, he said. Romito plays guitar, sings and writes music. He was diagnosed in 1985 with rhabdomyosarcoma, a muscular cancer, but says he's continuing to focus on his musical career.

A composer who claims Julio Iglesias defrauded her out of royalties for a song they co-wrote more than a decade ago sued the Spanish singer for more than $50,000. In the lawsuit, Grecia ``Mimi'' Korman says Iglesias asked her in 1978 to write a Spanish adaptation of a French song, and she incorporated some lyrics Iglesias had written into her version of ``Me Olvide de Vivir,'' or ``I've Forgotten to Live.'' ``Me Olvide de Vivir'' has appeared on at least seven of Iglesias' albums, with Ms. Korman and Iglesias listed as the song's writers, the lawsuit says. But Iglesias entered into a contract with the French publishers of the song, presenting himself as the sole author and securing all royalties for himself, according to the lawsuit. Iglesias' manager, Joaquin Martorell, did not return a message late Wednesday seeking comment on the federal lawsuit. Iglesias is a part-time resident of Dade County.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 37,206.42, up 17.47 points, or 0.05 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: D.A. Calls for New Trial; Defendant Calls it Politics
LaserPhoto LA1
DOC.TEXT: The prosecutor in the nation's longest criminal trial says it will be an uphill fight to convict McMartin Pre-school molestation defendant Raymond Buckey at a new trial, but the case must be resolved. District Attorney Ira Reiner insisted that neither politics nor public pressure influenced his decision Wednesday to pursue charges in the 6-year-old case. ``This is not a political matter and it is not going to be treated as such,'' said Reiner, a candidate for California Attorney General in June's election. Buckey and his mother were acquitted Jan. 18 of 52 molestation counts after a 33-month trial. The jury deadlocked on 12 molestation charges and one conspiracy count against Buckey. Buckey, 31, will be retried on those charges. ``This case has gone on for many years,'' Reiner said. ``It must be resolved.'' Prosecutors said at least one child who did not testify at the first trial might testify at the second, but conceded they might lose as witnesses one or two of the five children named in the 13 counts. The judge has suggested dropping some of the counts to speed the March 9 retrial. If convicted on all 13 charges, Buckey could draw no more than 36 years in prison, Reiner said. But most defendants serve about half of their sentences, and Buckey already has been jailed with bail for five years, the equivalent of a 10-year sentence. Buckey said he was surprised by Reiner's decision, but expected acquittal. ``I believe the D.A.'s decision was based on political pressure from a few vocal parents of children not involved in this trial, rather than jurors' leaning toward acquittal,'' he said. In the two weeks since the acquittals, parents whose children attended the now-defunct McMartin nursery school mounted a strident campaign for a new trial. They appeared on TV talk shows, called news conferences and recruited politicians who vowed to take the case out of Reiner's hands if he failed to follow through. Reiner said his prime consideration was the feelings of parents and alleged victims, who now range from age 11 to 14{. ``This is a positive step for us,'' said Marymae Cioffi, a McMartin parent who led the campaign to retry Buckey. ``I'm going to run home and tell my kids we get another chance.'' Reiner said there remain ``serious evidentiary problems,'' which he blamed on his predecessor, Robert Philibosian. ``This is an uphill battle. There's no question about that,'' Reiner said. The former district attorney has said he takes no responsibility for the case, which he initially filed in 1984, with seven defendants under investigation. Five had charges dismissed after an 18-month preliminary hearing. Only Buckey, and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, 63, stood trial. The trial was the longest and costliest in U.S. history. Taxpayers have spent over $13 million on the case so far. Superior Court Judge William Pounders said the facts in the remaining 13 counts ``mitigate in favor of a long second trial.'' He said he hoped the charges could be ``scoped down'' to shorten the proceedings. Pounder urged a swift start because ``the range of emotions is very high. ... There are a lot of people still sitting in agony. We should seek an end to this as soon as possible.'' Buckey's attorney, Danny Davis, filed a motion denouncing the judge and seeking his removal for bias against him and Buckey. Another judge will have to rule on that motion, which could cause delays.

DOC.HEAD: New National Geographic Map of Soviet Union More Political
DOC.TEXT: The new National Geographic map of the Soviet Union is a more political document that gives a primer of Russian annexation over the centuries as well as clues to possible future troubles, the chief cartographer says. ``There are still 15 republics and they are still part of the U.S.S.R.,'' said John B. Garver Jr., chief cartographer of the National Geographic Society. ``But we are very excited at being able to put out a map when there is a possibility of change,'' he said, referring to unrest and secessionist movements in several Soviet republics. The new map doesn't show the latest protests and battles involving Soviet nationalities, but its charts, graphs, text and historical inserts can help readers follow and even predict trouble for the Kremlin. Next to the Soviet Baltic republics, mapmakers added a note in red ink: ``The United States does not recognize the 1940 incorporation of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania.'' Popular fronts in those republics are agitating to leave the Soviet Union, against the wishes of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Adjacent to the Kuril Islands in the Pacific, the map says: ``Formerly part of and still claimed by Japan, the disputed islands Kunashir, Iturup, Shikotan and the Habomais have been held by the Soviet Union since 1945.'' Tokyo has balked at improving relations with Moscow until the two settle the issue of the islands, which are occupied by Soviet troops. Such disputes are grist in the mill of Garver, a former Army colonel and West Point professor who is helping shift the focus of National Geographic magazine to current events. The flip side of the new map tells an even more graphic political tale. ``We did away with the pictures and replaced them with a map of Russian historical annexation over the centuries. It's sort of a primer,'' said Garver. ``If you read the text and examine the map, you see that the Soviet Union has expanded, mostly by conquest'' since the 14th century. The map shows that over the centuries the princes and czars of ancient Moscow gobbled up adjoining territories in Europe, Siberia and Central Asia, and that, at the close of World War II, the Soviets occupied Eastern Europe and annexed parts of Poland, Czechoslovakia and Romania. A demographic map shows that ethnic Russian colonists spread East from Moscow, and bar graphs depict some trends from the 1989 Soviet census that are unsettling for the Kremlin. The entry under Soviet Tadzhikistan says that ``if current trends continue ... the U.S.S.R. could be a predominantly Muslim country within a century,'' trouble for a government that is officially atheist. The bar graphs, Garver said, show ``that the Turkish, Central Asian and Islamic populations are increasing. The Russian and other European populations are increasing at a much slower pace.'' The map took a year to complete, in part because of the need to reconfirm the location of the 5,000 cities, lakes, rivers and mountains that dot the 8.6 million square miles of the Soviet Union. That's more than twice the area of the United States, with 3.6 million square miles. Among the most striking changes in the new map is the shrinking of the Aral Sea, down 40 percent since the last National Geographic map of the Soviet Union was produced in 1977. The Amu Darya and Syr Darya rivers that once fed the Aral no longer flow into it because their waters have been diverted to irrigate cotton fields. The falling water level of the Aral moved it from fourth to sixth place among the largest lakes of the world, according to the February edition of National Geographic magazine, which described it as one of the globe's worst ecological disasters.

DOC.HEAD: Off to a Slow Start, 200 Years Ago Thursday
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court turns 200 today, marking the bicentennial of what by all accounts was ``indeed a slow start.'' It took the justices two years to announce their first decision, and by that time Chief Justice John Jay was moved to call life in the backwater of Washington ``intolerable.'' Indeed, the high court couldn't even get a quorum on Feb. 1, 1790. Jay had to put off the court's first meeting until the next day. But it didn't really matter. No case had arrived. The 15th man to succeed Jay, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, recently acknowledged the court had gotten off to what was ``indeed a slow start.'' But he said the court ``eventually picked up the necessary speed to evolve into a truly coequal branch of the federal government.'' The Constitution, written in 1787 and ratified by the requisite number of states the next year, called for ``one supreme court'' but President Washington did not nominate justices to the bench until late 1789. The next February, only three of the six showed up at the Royal Exchange Building in New York, then the nation's capital. One, Justice William Cushing of Massachusetts, appeared in a powdered wig _ a British judicial custom that failed to catch on in the new nation. The next day, Justice John Blair of Virginia arrived and they had a quorum. The court appointed a clerk, admitted some lawyers to practice before it and, after some other administrative chores, adjourned its first term Feb. 10. The second term lasted two days later that year. They were still waiting for a case. These days, a court term lasts nine months or so and presents some 5,000 new cases. The court now announces about 150 decisions each term. Noting fewer than 70 decisions were issued in the court's first decade, retired Chief Justice Warren E. Burger said recently, ``I suspect that members of the court would like the docket to move in that direction.'' By the time the court announced its first decision in 1792, Chief Justice Jay found life in the capital ``intolerable.'' Two years later, he took a leave of absence from the court to become a special ambassador to England. In 1795 he quit the court to take what he considered a more prestigious job, to which he had been elected during his absence _ governor of New York. Much has changed besides the court's caseload in the last two centuries. Since 1869, there have been nine justices. Since 1935, the court has had its own building. Since 1981, members of the court have not addressed each other as ``Mr. Justice.'' That ended shortly before Sandra Day O'Connor joined the bench. Other things are as they were when the nation was young. The chant that ends with ``God save the United States and this honorable court'' still opens each session. The brass spittoons are still hidden behind the bench. Quill pens are still given to each lawyer appearing before the justices. And absent justices can still be a problem. The Supreme Court held its 200th birthday celebration Jan. 16 because eral members said they'd be out of town Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Grandson Debuts in State of Union Script
With PM-State of Union Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Most grandfathers are content with describing the new baby, showing a few pictures, bragging a little. Not George Bush. He worked little Charles Walker Bush into the script. ``When I held the little guy for the first time, the troubles at home and abroad seemed manageable _ in perspective,'' said the president, giving a personal touch to his State of the Union speech Wednesday night. In the gallery, proud parents Margaret and Marvin Bush beamed. And so did Barbara Bush, who became a grandmother for the 12th time when that son and daughter-in-law adopted the boy late last year. ``Now, I know you're thinking that's a grandfather talking,'' said Bush. ``Well, maybe you're right.'' That may have sounded spontaneous, but it too was in the script. In his first State of the Union speech, Bush appeared a little nervous and hurried. He raced past some of the best lines in the speech, depriving his Republican supporters of rising in noisy approval. Not until he was halfway through did that opportunity come. It happened when Bush declared that his budget proposal, sent to Capitol Hill on Monday, will bring the deficit down and balance the budget by 1993 ``with no new taxes.'' The Republicans rose as one. And when there was no response from the Democrats on the other side of the aisle, they motioned ``get up, get up.'' A few did, but most stayed put. A few minutes later, Bush touched on a sensitive issue, the attempt by Sen. Daniel Moynihan, a New York Democrat, to cut Social Security taxes. ``The last thing we need to do is mess around with Social Security,'' said Bush. Republicans shouted, ``Hear, hear,'' and stood. There was a confused silence among the Democrats until some realized how bad their restraint might look on national television. Finally, they joined their Republican colleagues in the standing ovation. Even Moynihan applauded. All the senators and congressmen, it seemed, had the speech text in hand and pages turned in unison. There were no texts for the hundred members of the diplomatic corps, who left their cars at the White House and were bused to the Capitol. But Soviet Ambassador Yuriy V. Dubinin got a copy from a reporter he recognized in the White House press pool. ``It's much more important to have 100 friends than 100 rubles,'' said the delighted ambassador. ``Now I have the text, like nearly every lawmaker.''

DOC.HEAD: Military Ruler Says Exiles Can Come Home, Take Part In Free Elections
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Lt. Gen Prosper Avril says the political leaders he exiled last month in a crackdown on the democratic opposition are now free to return and take part in free elections he's promised for October. ``I hope they have learned their lesson,'' Haiti's military ruler told a news conference Wednesday at the National Palace. Two days earlier, he had lifted a 10-day state of siege. When the emergency was declared on Jan. 20, police rounded up 50 opposition activists. Seven leading government critics were exiled. Most of the others later were released but said they were beaten, as did the exiles. France, the United States, Canada and the European Community condemned the crackdown. France, a former colonial ruler and Haiti's major donor, suspended foreign aid and negotiations for $500 million more in assistance over the next two years. Avril said Wednesday that the crackdown was necessary ``to work rapidly to disarm'' subversive elements and ``block the escalation of murder.'' ``We recognize that things got out of hand'' and police committed some abuses, Avril said. ``But it is not only in Haiti that such things occur.'' The state of siege was declared a day after gunmen killed army Col. Andre Neptune. Critics accused Avril of orchestrating the killing to blame it on the opposition and renege on his promises to hold the fall presidential vote. Avril said the exiled opposition leaders can return and ``will have all necessary guarantees to participate in elections.'' They include Louis Roy, the principle author of Haiti's constitution; conservative politician Hubert de Ronceray; prominent businessman Antoine Izmery; Communist Party deputy leader Max Bourjolly and three leftist militants. Roy, 74, said in a telephone interview from Washington that he preferred to ``die in exile if necessary. I will never return to compromise with those whose law is the violation of the constitution and whose morality is contempt for human dignity.'' Roy, de Ronceray and Izmery issued a statement in Washington Tuesday that denounced Avril's ``regime of terror'' and said free elections were not possible as long as he remained in power in this impoverished Caribbean nation. In an interview with Radio France Internationale monitored in Puerto Rico, Bourjolly said from Paris earlier this week that he would return if allowed but would not take part in elections. Louis Dejoie, a prominent centrist who traveled to Puerto Rico the day before the crackdown, said he would not take part in elections or return to Haiti until Avril steps down. ``A singed cat fears the fire. We don't trust Avril or the army high command. Avril has zero credibility,'' he said. Avril said he would not oppose international supervision of elections. ``We are not hanging on to power,'' he said. Several opposition leaders have charged that Avril will rig the elections. The crackdown included a weeklong censorship of radio news. The censorship was lifted Monday, but by Wednesday only two of eight private stations in the capital were broadcasting news. Avril rose to power in a September 1988 coup led by noncommissioned officers who professed disgust with the state terrorism under the military man they ousted, Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy. He had led the military junta that assumed power when President-for-Life Jean-Claude Duvalier fled to exile in France in February 1986 during a popular uprising, ending the harsh 27-year Duvalier dynasty. Presidential elections were held on Nov. 29, 1987, but aborted after thugs, protected by soldiers, massacred at least 34 voters at polling stations. Civilian Leslie Manigat won army-run elections in January 1988 and was overthrown by Namphy that June.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Sets Deadline to Reduce US Troops in Panama to Pre-Invasion Level
With PM-State of Union Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is promising to reduce the U.S. military presence in Panama to its pre-invasion level of about 13,000 troops ``well before the end of February,'' but without giving an exact timetable. Bush won a standing ovation from a combined House and Senate audience when he declared in his State of the Union address: ``One year ago, the people of Panama lived in fear, under the thumb of a dictator. Today, democracy is restored _ Panama is free.'' In the nationally televised address Wednesday night, Bush declared that ``Operation Just Cause,'' the code name for the Dec. 20 invasion that toppled the government of Manuel Antonio Noriega, ``has achieved its objective.'' Noriega, whom Bush did not mention by name, is in a Florida jail awaiting trial on drug trafficking charges. Bush's comments suggested that about 3,000 additional troops would soon be brought home. At the peak of the U.S. intervention last month, 27,000 U.S. troops were there. The United States already has brought 11,000 home. Twenty-three American servicemen were killed in Panama and more than 300 were wounded. Before the Dec. 20 invasion, about 13,000 U.S. troops were stationed in Panama _ the number that will remain after the withdrawal is completed. With Noriega's surrender, the military operation achieved all its objectives, Bush said. ``The number of military personnel is now close to what it was before the operation began,'' Bush said. ``And tonight, I am announcing that, well before the end of February, the additional numbers of American troops, the brave men and women of our armed forces who made this mission a success, will be back home.'' Bush's remarks underscored comments in Panama over the weekend by Vice President Dan Quayle that the remaining U.S. troops would be brought home in ``weeks rather than months.'' However, it still was not clear whether the additional U.S. troops would be out of Panama by Feb. 15, the date of the drug summit in Colombia. The president of Peru, Alan Garcia, and other Latin American leaders have protested the U.S. invasion. Garcia called on Bush to remove the forces before the drug summit and at one point suggested boycotting the Colombia meeting in pst. Bush also read a touching letter written by PFC James Markwell, a 20-year-old Army Ranger medic who died during the first hours of the invasion. Markwell, and others in his company, all had wrsuch letters a few days before they were sent into action _ letters only to beiled if they were killed in acti ``Sadly, Private Markwell's mother did receive this letter. And she passed it on to me,'' said. Bush met with Markwell's family during a Jan. 12 tripetown of Cincinnati. ``Here is some of what he wrote,'' Bush said and quoted from the letter: ``I have never been afraid of death, but now he is waiting at the corneen trained to kill and to save, so has everyone else. ``I am frightened of what lays beyond the fog, yet ... do not mourn for me, revel in the life that I have died to give you. ... But most of all, don't forget the Army was my choice. Something that I wanted to do. ``Remember I joined the Army to serve my country and ensure that you are free to do what you want and live your lives freely.'' Bush then added: ``He knew what he believed in. He carried the idea we call America in his heart.''

DOC.HEAD: `I Thank God for This Miracle,' Says Woman Whose New Family Survived
DOC.TEXT: For seven hours after Avianca Flight 52 crashed, Aleta Heidt didn't know whether her husband and two newly adopted children from Colombia had survived. When she finally found her husband in a hospital, he couldn't speak. But he picked up a pencil, and scrawled, ``2 kids?'' Yes, she told him. They survived. And he cried. Mrs. Heidt said in an interview at her husband William's bedside in the intensive care unit at Nassau County Medical Center that she thanked God all three were alive. ``He saved three people for me,'' she said. One week ago today, Mrs. Heidt was holding two new ski jackets for the children at Kennedy International Airport, waiting to meet them for the first time. Instead, her meeting was in a hospital, where they were treated for injuries and trauma. Seventy-three people died and 85 others were injured when the Boeing 707, en route from Bogota, Colombia, apparently ran out of fuel and crashed in Cove Neck, northeast of the airport. After being informed of the crash, the tall, slender piano and voice teacher recalled reaching for a crucifix in her pocketbook and clutching it tightly. ``I just kept saying The Lord's Prayer over and over,'' Mrs. Heidt said Wednesday as she looked down at her husband's broken and bruised body. ``I thank God for this miracle.'' Eleven-year-old Pedro, whom the couple renamed Peter, injured an eye and broke an arm; he has been having nightmares, she said. Blanca, a 13-year-old now called Bianca, has two broken hips and is ``psychologically very bad,'' Mrs. Heidt said. ``She fades in and out and still thinks she's in Colombia with her friends in the orphanage.'' Both of her legs are in traction and one leg may end up shorter than the other, Mrs. Heidt said. The siblings were placed in a home several years ago after their mother died in an accident. Mrs. Heidt said they were the youngest of seven children and their father could not care for them. Of the three, Heidt's injuries were the most serious. His body is rigged with wires and tubes. Metal spikes hold his fractured neck in place. His body is black and blue from head to toe. Dried blood remains under his fingernails. But he is alive, in fair condition with multiple fractures at Hackensack Medical Center, where he was transferred late Wednesday. Both children also were scheduled to be transferred to the New Jersey hospital. Heidt _ burly, with a thick mustache and black hair peppered with gray _ spoke haltingly and with difficulty about the ordeal. ``I was lying there. There was screaming all around me but the children weren't near me. I couldn't find them. There were pieces of metal all over me. I hadn't the strength to pull it off. I was pinned,'' he said. ``I knew we were going to crash,'' he whispered. ``It happened so fast, there wasn't time even to grab the kids. The plane just lost power.'' Heidt, 51, carrying pictures of his wife and home, flew to Colombia on Jan. 21 to bring the children back to the couple's Wyckoff, N.J., home. During the four days he spent with them in Colombia, Heidt became papa Willy and his wife, mamalita. Heidt, a machinist supervisor, and his wife, who is in her 40s, married five years ago after meeting at an opera. Both are amateur opera singers. Two years ago they learned they could not have children and began trying to adopt. They found Peter and Bianca through an agency. Mrs. Heidt, who had taped her crucifix above her husband's hospital bed, said she has doesn't feel any bitterness about the crash. She believes the tragedy will ``bond us closer together as a family.'' Heidt faces a long road to recovery, which he said would take patience. But he said there was a lot worth waiting for. ``I want us to get on with the rest of our lives as a family,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up In Tokyo, Stocks Rise Marginally
DOC.TEXT: The dollar inched up against the Japanese yen in Tokyo Thursday, while the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rose marginally. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average gained 17.47 points, or 0.05 percent, ending the day's trading at 37,206.42. On Wednesday, it dipped 26.72 points. The dollar closed at 144.50 yen, up 0.10 yen from Wednesday's 144.40-yen finish. It opened at 144.45 yen and ranged between 144.35 and 144.63 yen. ``Following the dollar's surge yesterday, trading was very quiet here today, and the dollar-yen rate hardly moved,'' said Junko Namba, a trader with Daiwa Bank. However, participants actively bought the West German mark against the yen, she said. Ms. Namba said trading was light because dealers were waiting for the release of U.S. unemployment figures on Friday. On the stock exchange, the Nikkei rebounded quickly in response to a big gain of 47 points in the Dow Jones industrial average on Wall Street overnight and the yen's stability against the dollar. ``Prices were higher almost across the board as soon as the market opened, but the trend didn't last long, because market players soon stepped off to the sidelines and stopped buying,'' said Kazuyuki Suzuki, a trader with Daiwa Securities Co. ``The majority of market players were still not in a mood to buy,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Troop Cut Proposal Disarms Democrats, May Ease Pressure on Gorbachev
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's show-stealing proposal for deeper troop reductions in Europe disarms Democratic critics at home and may help ease pressures in Moscow on Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Gorbachev has been hit with blow after blow, from the demise of the Soviet empire in Eastern Europe to the bloody uprising in Azerbaijan. His economy is sick and his reform program of perestroika has not eased consumer shortages or improved standards of living. Next week, Gorbachev's authority is expected to be challenged at what promises to be a fiery meeting of the Communist Party's Central Committee, the one body with the official power to remove him as party leader. Against that landscape, Bush made a point in Wednesday night's State of the Union address to say, ``It's time to build on our new relationship with the Soviet Union, to endorse and encourage a peaceful process of internal change toward democracy and economic opportunity.'' Bush, responding to the political upheaval in the once-solid Soviet empire, announced a proposal to cut U.S. and Soviet combat forces in Central Europe to 195,000 on each side. It was a followup to a U.S. offer last year to reduce troops throughout Europe to 275,000 for each superpower. ``We are in a period of great transition, great hope, yet great uncertainty,'' Bush said, adding that the Soviet military threat in Europe was diminishing. The troop-cutting proposal is likely to win favor from Gorbachev, eager to save money from military spending. After all, it was Gorbachev who spurred conventional arms cuts beginning with his surprise announcement in 1988 that he was reducing global Soviet troop strength by 10 percent and withdrawing six tank divisions from Europe. When Bush proosed the cutback last year to 275,000, Gorbachev said ``fine'' and readily agreed to cut back the number of Soviet tanks that could be used for a surprise attack. Pressures continue to build for Gorbachev to do more. Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia have announced troop cuts of their own and asked the Kremlin to withdraw all its forces from their territory. And the leader of East Germany has said that all superpower troops could be out of Europe by the year 2000. A senior administration official, explaining Bush's new offer, said it was a response to ``this sort of rapidly falling deck of cards'' of hardline communist regimes. ``It appeared that in the area of arms control, specifically conventional arms control in Europe, that events were running ahead of the negotiations,'' said the official, who commented only on condition of not being identified by name. In recent days, Bush has offered a number of extraordinary political endorsements of Gorbachev and has refused to criticize his military crackdown in Azerbaijan. At one point, Bush said of Gorbachev, ``I hope that he not only survives but stays strong.'' A day later, he said Gorbachev was ``really the best hope for what our interests are.'' Bush is counting on Gorbachev to help him seal a treaty to slash conventional forces in Europe and to cut strategic weapons and chemical weapons. Before he announced his plan to the nation, Bush called Gorbachev in Moscow with a preview of the proposal. Asked how Gorbachev responded, Bush said, ``I can't characterize it, but I can just simply say that he was receptive, but I don't know whether he's supportive or not.'' It was clear, however, how Congress felt. It was all cheers and standing ovations from Republicans and Democrats alike when Bush announced his plan in a packed House chamber. ``A good idea,'' said Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee. ``Very positive,'' said Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee. ``Just when you thought you had a Cold War budget _ boom,'' exclaimed Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., a frequent Pentagon critic and advocate of reduced U.S. forces in Europe. ``I'm really delighted. There's hope.'' However, the cheery reaction surely will fade if the administration tells Congress that a yet-to-be-negotiated proposal to scale down troops will not provide a desired ``peace dividend'' of reduced defense spending. Moreover, from tax cuts on capital gains to bills dealing with crime, child care and clean air, there are plenty of areas of disagreement to ensure an abundance of election-year battles between the White House and the Democrats who control Capitol Hill.
DOC.NOTE: EDITORS NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Terence Hunt has covered the presidency since 1981 and is The Associated Press' chief White House correspondent.

DOC.HEAD: Freighter Fired on by Coast Guard Held in Mexico
DOC.TEXT: The Mexican government promised an ``exhaustive inspection'' of a Cuban-owned freighter that drew machine-gun and cannon fire from a Coast Guard cutter after refusing to stop for a drug inspection. The 250-foot Panama-registered freighter, the Hermann, took several hits from the cutter Chincoteague as the vessels steamed across the open Gulf of Mexico, Coast Guard spokesman Joe Gibson said. The ship was hit 50 times by Coast Guard fire, but there were no injuries, a Mexican official said. The vessel escaped into Mexican waters, but two Mexican navy ships seized the Hermann and escorted it to Tampico, about 300 miles south of the U.S. border. ``The situation is not over. There's action still being taken,'' Coast Guard Lt. Steve Koska said late Wednesday. ``I can't go into it, but there are things we can do. We can go through diplomatic channels.'' Mexico's Foreign Ministry said in a statement that authorities began the ``exhaustive search'' of the vessel in Tampico. The inspection, expected to take at least 24 hours, was to include a search for drugs and an examination of the ship's navigation diary, said Javier Trevino, a spokesman with Mexico's embassy in Washington, D.C. The Cuban government, which had demanded that the United States not attempt to board the ship, has made a formal complaint to the State Department over the incident, said a Cuban diplomatic representative in Washington. The official called the incident a provocation. ``This deed demonstrates once more that the United States intends to behave as owner of the world and with its proverbial barbarism appears willing to obstruct normal commerce between Cuba and Mexico,'' said an official quoted by Cuba's official news agency, Prensa Latina. Secretary of State James A. Baker III disagreed. ``It was not an attack and a provocation,'' Baker said. ``We were engaged in a legal law enforcement activity.'' State, Defense Department and National Security Council officials held three meetings before giving permission to use disabling fire against the Hermann, said Jack O'Dell, a Coast Guard spokesman in Washington. The Coast Guard obtained permission from Panama to fire on the ship, Gibson said. He said it is protocol to request permission to stop a vessel from its country of registry. The Hermann has a Cuban crew, is owned by a Cuban company and originated from a Cuban port, Coast Guard officials said. Koska said the decision to board the ship was made because the vessel fit the profile of a narcotics-smuggling ship, but he declined to elaborate. ``The profile of a vessel that is engaged in illegal activity is when you ask them to stop and they don't stop,'' he said. ``Wouldn't you say that's a pretty good indication?'' Cuba's news agency, monitored in Mexico City, said the ship had a 12-man crew, a cargo of 10 tons of chromium and was operated by the Guamar Shipping Co. of Cuba. The incident lasted from early Tuesday, when the Chincoteague spotted the freighter, until 5 a.m. Wednesday, when the shots were fired about 45 miles east of Tampico. The Coast Guard cutter, a 110-foot patrol boat with a crew of 16, is based in Mobile, Ala. It has two M-60 machine guns and one 20mm cannon.

DOC.HEAD: Snowfall Leaves 27 Dead in South Korea, 18 Injured in Japan
DOC.TEXT: Snow blanketed much of Japan and South Korea today, the latest assault in a week of storms that have snarled transportation and claimed more than two dozen lives, officials said. Tokyo, a city unused to anything more than a dusting of snow, woke up to find nearly 3 inches on the ground and more falling. By dawn, more than 3 inches had fallen in adjacent Yokohama and 7.5 inches in Mito, 60 miles northeast of Tokyo, the Meteorological Agency said. In South Korea, about 10 inches of snow had fallen by early today in Seoul, the capital city of 10 million people. Police reported hundreds of casualties in snow-related traffic accidents, including 27 deaths Tuesday when snow first began piling up. Damage was estimated at $6 million nationwide. Villages along the east coast and nearby mountains were hit hardest with up to 5 feet of snow since Tuesday afternoon. About 40,000 government officials and police were ordered out today to clear Korean streets of snow and open traffic to isolated villages after forecasters said the worst was over, officials said. In Japan, Tokyo's international airport at Narita was closed for an hour today for snow removal and other airports in the country experienced dozens of flight cancellations. ``Bullet'' trains were running at a reduced speed of 106 mph due to the snow, railway officials said. The intercity trains usually run at 130 mph.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: A retired Army sergeant nearly flipped his lid when he received a baseball cap from President Bush to add to his collection. ``I was shaking while I opened it. That's how excited I was,'' said Jay Mundy of Ormond Beach. Inside the first-class package was a letter from the president and a cap that says ``White House Tennis'' on the front. Known around his neighborhood as ``the cat with the hats,'' Mundy wrote Bush after his collection of 1,027 baseball caps was featured in the Daytona Beach News-Journal. His hats are tacked to the wall of his garage in four neat rows. Mundy, 61, claimed he wouldn't stop stockpiling the brimmed bonnets until he topped off his exhibit with Bush's fishing cap. The president explained in the letter that arrived Monday that he couldn't part with his fishing hat: ``I was reluctant to send you one of my favorite fishing caps _ you know how we fisherman are about luck, and I need all the help I can get. While the enclosed is not one of my `best' fishing caps, I hope you'll enjoy it in your collection.'' But Mundy's wife Dottie doesn't think the collecting is over. ``The man can't turn down a hat,'' she said.

The Denver Broncos have been swamped in three of the last four Super Bowls, but Theresa Collurafici has had better luck, twice delivering Super Bowl babies on days the Broncos lost the big one. While the New York Giants defeated Denver 39-20 on Jan. 25, 1987, Mrs. Collurafici gave birth to Amanda Lauren. On Sunday, when the San Francisco 49ers whomped the Broncos 55-10, she delivered 7-pound, 5-ounce Marissa Erin. Amanda is fine and her parents are happy, but befuddled. ``I don't know what's going on here,'' said husband Anthony Collurafici, 30. ``It just seems kind of strange, you know?'' Collurafici said he wasn't too worried because he knew there were televisions at Christiana Hospital in Stanton _ even one in the labor room. ``In between contractions, we watched some of the game,'' said Mrs. Collurafici, 30, who said she was not too concerned about who won. Her husband said he had a small wager on the game, and won the bet. ``I came up a winner in more ways than one, I guess,'' he said. The Broncos lost Super Bowl XXII to the Washington Redskins in 1988.

Pawtucket won't haul residents into court if their lawn gets a little shaggy _ not just yet, anyway. City officials, looking for a way to force property owners to keep their yards in better shape, had proposed a maximum grass height of 5{ inches. Anyone allowing their lawn to reach an unsightly half-foot faced a city mowing crew _ and a city bill _ to keep their grass at regulation length. But a City Council committee told the zealous bureaucrats to holster their tape measures until the ordinance had a chance to be reviewed. Planning Director Roger Giraud admitted Wednesday that the proposal has been the subject of ridicule but it is intended to deal with a potentially serious problem: overgrown, rat-infested yards that pose a risk to public health. Giraud said he wanted to deal with nuisance properties before they became health hazards. He said he had no interest in becoming a lawn cop.

DOC.HEAD: Kenya Seeks Help From Jewish Lobby
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `arap' is cq
DOC.TEXT: Kenya's President Daniel arap Moi is calling on American Jewish leaders to help get increased U.S. aid for his country. Moi, speaking to representatives of 50 major Jewish organizations on Wednesday, also said Jewish leaders should influence the U.S. government to provide funding to projects for developing semi-arid areas in Kenya with expertise from Israel. Kenya last year resumed diplomatic relations with Israel, which had been severed in 1973 under heavy pressure from the Arab world. Moi is in Washington on a private visit to attend the National Prayer Breakfast today. Moi said relations between his country and the United States had improved greatly under the Bush administration, but that Kenya still needs help in improving contacts with Congress. U.S. aid to Kenya has declined in recent years.
DOC.HEAD: AFL-CIO Backs Moynihan's Social Security Proposal
DOC.TEXT: The AFL-CIO is lining up behind a plan by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan to return Social Security to a pay-as-you-go basis and take its surplus off the federal budget. ``This plan would reduce the tax burden on working men and women, whose tax share has become disproportionate to that of the wealthy,'' the federation of 14.1 million union members said Wednesday in a statement. ``As it is, the growing Social Security surplus is being used to mask budget deficits that have been exacerbated by unbalanced and unwise spending and revenue policies. The Moynihan proposal has exposed this scam for all to see.'' Moynihan said he was heartened by the federation's support, which came after a meeting Wednesday with 20 member union leaders. Last week, Moynihan introduced a bill to cut the Social Security tax from the current 6.2 percent to 5.1 percent by next year. This would cost the Social Security trust fund $55 billion but would save a working couple up to $600 a year. The measure would stop building up a huge trust fund surplus which Moynihan says is wrongly being used to mask the true size of the federal deficit. The AFL-CIO differed with Moynihan over how much the trust fund surplus should be allowed to grow before repealing the Social Security tax increase. The federation believes the surplus should reach 125 percent to 150 percent of one year's benefits while Moynihan's legislation would make the cuts when the fund reaches 100 percent.
DOC.HEAD: GOP Chairman Lends Name to North Fund-Raiser
DOC.TEXT: Republican National Committee chairman Lee Atwater says he makes ``no bones about'' his support for Oliver L. North and is happy to allow his name to be used in connection with a fund-raiser for the Iran-Contra figure. Atwater is one of 25 people _ including conservative fund-raiser Richard Viguerie and Equal Rights Amendment foe Phyllis Schlafly _ on the host committee for the March 3 ``Salute to Oliver North.'' The event is organized by the Legal Affairs Council of Chantilly, Va. North was convicted last May of three felonies in the Iran-Contra affair. Arguments in his appeal will be heard Tuesday in federal appeals court in Washington. ``I don't mind at all being counted among his supporters; I make no bones about it,'' Atwater said Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Conference Committee Approves Food-Hauling Bill
DOC.TEXT: Trucking companies that use the same trailers to haul food one way and garbage another would face stiff fines, vehicle forfeitures and license suspensions under a proposed state bill. A joint House-Senate panel Wednesday voted unanimously for the bill that is expected to win approval by the General Assembly before the end of the week. Investigations into the garbage-hauling industry showed that some trucking companies, after unloading food shipments, filled trucks with garbage for the return trip. It was also found some trucks carried juice on one trip and chemicals on the way back. The practice was first reported last year by the Centre Daily Times in State College.

DOC.HEAD: Dance Theater of Harlem Cancels N.Y. Season; Lays Off Crew
DOC.TEXT: A financial crisis has forced the Dance Theater of Harlem, the first American ballet company to tour the Soviet Union, to cancel its New York City season and lay off its 51 dancers. The layoffs, which include 15 technical workers and some of the staff, will take effect after the company's engagement at Washington's Kennedy Center for Performing Arts in March, said artistic director Arthur Mitchell. For two decades, the company has performed on stages around the world, winning rave reviews in dozens of languages. Mitchell said Wednesday that sponsors at the last minute canceled two major tours _ a five-week run in England and a week in San Diego _ contributing to a projected deficit of $1.7 million in the fiscal year. The vibrant and youthful troupe was in San Diego as part of a West Coast tour when Mitchell told them the bad news. ``Naturally they were stunned,'' he said in a telephone interview from Pasadena. ``But what was so pleasing was the solidarity. Yes, we must stick together. They have a vested interest in what we are about _ not just as performers but as human beings. ... They put in the extra hours, the extra time; they do lectures and community outreach projects for which they're not paid.'' Mitchell said the company has had previous layoffs but never to this extent. ``We've always been very fiscally responsible. Our accumulated deficit for 20 years is about $400,000.'' The group's dance school in New York will remain open, but the New York season, which was scheduled to begin in May, and the summer course will be canceled. Corporations underwrite master classes, lecture demonstrations and other educational projects that do not generate a profit, but the company receives little corporate support for performances. The group's problems are shared by most in the arts community. For the past decade, many of the nation's leading orchestras have cut back, some theater groups have disappeared and a few dance companies have gone out of business. ``In general, what you're seeing is true throughout the arts: a decline in funding due to the economy, the mergers and acquisitions phenomenon and to a change in priority in some companies who now have an emphasis in the environment, education and social causes at the expense of the arts,'' said Betsy Hopkins, executive director of the fund-raising organization Corporate Fund for Dance. Hopkins said that in general, the nation's 400 or so dance companies were healthy and not any worse off than other art forms. ``There's a heightened interest in dance in this country,'' she said. ``But dance companies just don't tend to have big endowments.'' Two decades ago, Mitchell, a talented and brash principal dancer from the New York City Ballet, sliced through the barriers that had kept blacks from succeeding in classical ballet and founded the vibrant and youthful company. Mitchell, who retired from the City Ballet in 1970, has led the troupe to international renown. The company prides itself on preserving American dance repertory. It also demonstrates a variety of styles and moods, from the classical ``Swan Lake'' to Balanchine's neoclassical ``Allegro Brillante'' to the Mitchell's modern work, ``Holberg Suite,'' to the folk ballet ``John Henry.'' In 1988, the troupe captivated audiences in the Soviet Union with its magical retelling of John Taras' stunning ``Firebird,'' set to the original Igor Stravinsky score. After engagements in Berkeley, Calif., and Portland, Ore., the Dance Theater of Harlem returns to New York on Feb. 24, and will launch a major fund-raising campaign in the spring.

DOC.HEAD: Court Orders Eviction of Elderly Squatter From Proposed Park
DOC.TEXT: A judge ordered the eviction of a 72-year-old woman who has lived in a squalid homestead for 19 years after the state demolished her house to make way for a seaside park that has yet to be built. Superior Court Judge Karen Sequino said Wednesday that Doris Gagnon had no right to remain on the land along Long Island Sound while the state converts it into a park, which officials said could take two to three years. The state's plans to build the park are about 20 years old. The eviction order carried an automatic 20-day stay, and the judge said it was likely that Gagnon could qualify for a stay of up to nine months, if she pursued her resettlement in public housing. Gagnon showed no emotion as Sequino ordered her eviction. But the plucky, 4-foot-10 woman let the chairman of the Milford Housing Authority, Keith Rubinstein, have an earful when he approached her after the hearing. Gagnon scolded him for testifying that he could get her moved ahead of other people on the waiting list for public housing. She said that would not be fair, and called it an example of the government corruption she has been fighting. ``I am sorry our system is this way and our average citizen cannot get justice,'' she said, adding: ``I don't want people to feel sorry for me. I want people to respect me.'' Gagnon, whose only income is $4,000 annually in Social Security, had testified she was not interested in public housing because she needs room for a garden and her pets, which now include three cats, three dogs, two geese, 12 ducks and about 50 chickens. Gagnon's homestead consists of a collection of shacks and aging trailers with no electricity, no telephone and no running water. Assistant Attorney General Grace Dodier said that any hardships Gagnon was suffering were self-imposed. Her attorney, Karen Torre, said the state's treatment of Gagnon had been ``shameful and disgustful,'' and represented ``government at its worst, when it doesn't care.'' Torre asked that Gagnon, who has been battling cancer but appeared quite energetic at the hearing, be allowed to remain in her homestead until the bulldozers are ready to begin preparing the parkland for recreational use. The state moved to evict Gagnon last year after Milford health inspectors found bags of human sewage piled up behind her living quarters.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Drug Agent Slaying, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0475,0661
DOC.HEAD: Former Mexican Police Officials Indicted in Camarena Slaying Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Both were ...' to CORRECT to 1988, sted last year
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY10
DOC.TEXT: The indictment in the 1985 torture-slaying of a U.S. drug agent expanded to include two of the highest police officers in the previous Mexican administration and two powerful drug dealers. They were among six new names in a 19-person indictment Wednesday that updates charges related to the slaying of Enrique Camarena Salazar and his Mexican pilot, and the killings of two U.S. citizens in Guadalajara, Mexico. Manuel Ibarra Herrera, former head of Mexico's Federal Judicial Police, roughly equivalent to the FBI; and Miguel Aldana Ibarra, who headed the Mexican branch of Interpol, the international police agency, were charged with participating in a cover-up to protect drug smugglers in Mexico. Both were officials in the administration of President Miguel de la Madrid, who completed his term in office in 1988. They were among 15 people named in the indictment who are not in U.S. custody. Camarena and his pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar, were killed after the Drug Enforcement Administration agent led raids on marijuana plantations allegedly operated by Guadalajara drug cartel chief Rafael Caro Quintero. His body was found March 5, 1985, on a ranch 65 miles southeast of Guadalajara. As head of Interpol in Mexico City, Aldana had access to foreign police intelligence on drug and arms trafficking. He also led Operation Pacifico, a drug task force. Camarena had investigated reports that Aldana leaked information about forthcoming police raids to drug traffickers, according to the book ``Desperados,'' an account of Camarena's slaying by Elaine Shannon. In Mexico, Aldana said Wednesday he would sue U.S. authorities for indicting him, the government news agency Notimex reported. Aldana, who now heads a lawyers' association, led attempts to discredit Camarena after NBC-TV's ``Drug War'' miniseries broadcast last month. He reiterated his claim that Camarena was in the marijuana trade and may not really be dead. Caro Quintero and Ernesto Fonseca Carrillo were sentenced by a Mexican court in December to 40 years in prison without parole for their role in Camarena's slaying, and 10 other men also were sentenced by Mexican courts. But U.S. officials have said for some time they believed high-level Mexican authorities were involved in covering-up Camarena's slaying. ``We want the message to be clear that anyone who kills one of our agents will be hunted down and brought to justice by the DEA,'' said Ralph Lochridge, agency spokesman in Los Angeles. Other new names on Wednesday's indictment included a Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain; Mexican drug lord Miguel Angel Felix Gallardo; and Honduran drug kingpin Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros, both of whom are already in prison. Matta was sentenced last month to life in prison without possibility of parole by a federal judge in Los Angeles. His extradition to the United States from Honduras in 1988 sparked riots in which five people died and an annex of the U.S. Embassy was burned. Gallardo's arrest by Mexico in April was applauded by U.S. officials as a sign President Carlos Salinas de Gortari was serious about the drug war. In a sixth new indictment, Antonio Vasquez Ochoa faces two counts of committing violent crimes in aid of racketeering for the slayings of John Walker and Alberto Radelat on Jan. 30, 1985, in Guadalajara. The indictment alleges Vasquez Ochoa and others participated in the slayings of the two Americans ``to maintain and further the purposes'' of the Guadalajara cartel. Among those named earlier in the indictment was Ruben Zuno Arce, a millionaire Mexican businessman and brother-in-law of Luis Echeverria, Mexican president from 1970-76. Arce was arrested in Los Angeles on Dec. 9 and charged with committing violent crimes in aid of racketeering and conspiracy to kidnap a federal agent.

DOC.HEAD: Pilot Mourned; On-Sight Probe of Crash Ends
With PM-Jetliner-New Family, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: After the veteran pilot of Avianca Flight 52 was eulogized at a simple funeral Mass, officials drove his body to where he had tried to land a week before: Kennedy International Airport. The remains of Capt. Laureano Caviedes Hoyos, mourned Wednesday at a service at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church, were to be flown today to Colombia for burial. The mourners, who took up only three pews, listened intently as Associate Pastor Rev. Jeffrey Johnston offered them comfort. ``One who spent so much of his time in his life among the stars, now rests beyond them,'' he said. Caviedes, 56, was an Avianca pilot for 28 years. He was survived by his wife and two sons, ages 13 and 14, who live in Bogota, Colombia. The Mass was arranged by Caviedes' sister-in-law, Yolanda Munoz Todd, who lives in nearby Great Neck with her husband and son, Johnston said. The captain was one of 73 people killed Jan. 25 when the Boeing 707 he was flying apparently ran out of fuel and crashed in the small enclave of Cove Neck on Long Island. Another 85 people were injured. National Transportation Safety Board investigators have not said who or what was to blame for the crash. They wrapped up their on-site probe Tuesday and gave Avianca permission to haul away the wreckage. Caviedes, who was flying into Kennedy under heavy fog and rain, radioed controllers that he needed ``priority'' landing because he was low on fuel, but never used the word emergency, investigators said. As a result, Flight 52 was switched from a holding pattern to an approach pattern, but was placed behind several other incoming planes. ``The pilot apparently thought when he came out of the holding pattern that he had enough fuel and that's why he appears (on taped conversations) to be calm and cool,'' said NTSB investigator Barry Trotter, who is handling the crash probe. Trotter left New York for Washington on Wednesday, accompanied by aides who carried fuel gauges taken from the cockpit. ``We have gathered much of the facts, now we've got to sit down and analyze to determine exactly what happened that night,'' Trotter said. ``There's no simple answer.'' NTSB investigators will fly to Bogota next week to review the plane's maintenance records and gather information about the employment records and personal habits of Flight 52's crew, including what each Avianca employee did the night before the fatal crash, Trotter said. In coming months, investigators will try to recreate Flight 52 down to the most minute detail. A full report is expected in nine to 12 months.

DOC.BYLINE: Study Predicts Wide Screening for Carriers of Cystic Fibrosis Gene ^By DANIEL Q. HANEY
DOC.TEXT: A study today raises the possibility of population-wide screening for carriers of cystic fibrosis, but some worry about what will happen to parents who ignore the knowledge that they can pass on the disease. Making the test mandatory ``has the potential for grave danger,'' warned Dr. Harvey R. Colten of Washington University. ``Even voluntary screening programs carry considerable economic and social risk.'' Cystic fibrosis is the most common fatal genetic disease of young Americans. It occurs most frequently among whites, striking about one of every 2,500 white newborns in the United States. For the first time, scientists can delve into grownups' genes and spot those likely to bear children with the inherited illness. While the test is still too crude for routine use, doctors believe that within a year it will be able to detect 95 percent of all carriers of cystic fibrosis. ``People for years have realized that if we had a good carrier test for cystic fibrosis, there would be the potential to test everyone before reproduction to see if they were a carrier or not,'' said Dr. Arthur L. Beaudet, of Baylor College of Medicine in Houston. ``The evidence is at hand that such a carrier test will soon be available.'' Beaudet described the results of the currently available screening test in a report in the New England Journal of Medicine. His team found that it can identify 76 percent of all carriers. One in 25 white Americans carries one copy of the cystic fibrosis gene. They are healthy, but if they marry another carrier, there is a 1-in-4 chance that their children will have cystic fibrosis. Last summer, Drs. Lap-Chee Tsui of the Hospital for Sick Children in Toronto and Francis S. Collins of the University of Michigan pinpointed the genetic error responsible for most cases of cystic fibrosis. The latest study looked at what happened when doctors screened people for this single defect. Scientists at about 40 labs around the world are cooperating to track down the half dozen or so other mutations within the gene that also can cause the disease. Collins predicted that the mutations will be identified within the next year. Then, doctors should be able to offer highly accurate screening tests. Specialists hope that adults will use the test results for family planning. If couples learn that both are carriers, some might decide to adopt rather than run the risk of having a child with cystic fibrosis. Others might opt to have artificial insemination with sperm from an anonymous donor who is not a carrier. If they decide to have a pregnancy, the test can be performed on the fetus. If the fetus turns out to have the disease, parents can then decide whether to have the baby or to get an abortion. The disease causes a variety of symptoms, including abnormal mucous secretion that results in lung infections. While doctors can ease many of the symptoms and extend lives, there is no treatment for the underlying disease. Collins noted that if everyone in the United States gets the screening test, it will turn up 8 million Americans who carry the cystic fibrosis gene. ``If this program is successful, every one of them deserves to sit down with someone and find out what that means,'' he said. ``We don't by a long shot have the means to do that. Physicians are uncomfortable with that role, and there aren't enough genetic counselors to do the job.'' In an editorial in the journal, Colten raised the possibility that insurance companies might refuse to pay the bills of children with cystic fibrosis if their parents knew before the pregnancy that they were carriers. Dr. Henry Dorkin of New England Medical Center in Boston said that while he supports widespread screening, carriers should be allowed to make their own decisions about whether to have children. ``We have to give people as much information as possible about the risks and pitfalls that lie ahead of them,'' he said, ``and after informing them, we should support their decision, whatever it is.'' Other questions involve at what age people should be screened and whether the tests should be routinely offered to non-whites, who have a much lower risk of cystic fibrosis.

DOC.HEAD: Ted Turner: `How Can You Scoop a Rumor?'
DOC.TEXT: CNN chief Ted Turner says a report by his network that Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev was considering resigning as leader of the Communist party was a rumor, not a scoop. ``How can you scoop a rumor?'' Turner said Wednesday at an Atlanta Press Club luncheon. ``If rumors become scoops, then every media will have one.'' But another network executive said Cable News Network stood by the reporter, Steve Hurst. Hurst, who has been assigned to Moscow for 12 years, said the story he filed Tuesday was culled from ``a well-informed and usually reliable Communist party source.'' CNN continued to broadcast the report Wednesday after Gorbachev denied it, although it added what Hurst said he initially heard ``could be a trial balloon ... or just a rumor by people opposed to Gorbachev rule.'' ``We believed in Hurst's source because I have great confidence and faith in him,'' said Ed Turner, executive vice president of news gathering for CNN. ``He knows when he thinks he has a solid story. All you can do is trust your people.'' Other news organizations carried the report but did not confirm it. Instead they attributed it to CNN. Ted Turner, meanwhile, belittled the report's importance and rapped other news organizations for their reaction. ``You shouldn't credit someone for breaking a rumor,'' he said. ``Anyone can break a rumor.''

DOC.HEAD: Substance Cripples AIDS Virus Growth In Test Tube
DOC.TEXT: Scientists said today that a new class of chemicals can cripple the AIDS virus in the test tube at extremely low doses, but other researchers said its potential for therapy is not yet known. The new substances appear to be the most potent yet studied for stopping the virus from reproducing, scientists said in the British journal Nature. Human tests for effectiveness were still being planned, but six healthy men tolerated one of the substances without major side effects, according to researchers from the Rega Institute for Medical Research in Leuven, Belgium; the Janssen Research Foundation in Beerse, Belgium, and in Spring House, Penn. They conducted laboratory studies of compounds called TIBO derivatives. In their tests, the compounds inhibited reproduction of the AIDS virus at concentrations that were 10,000 to 100,000 times lower than what is needed to kill cells. That compares to concentrations of 100 times to 10,000 times lower than a cell-killing dose required for AZT, the only approved drug for treating acquired immune deficiency syndrome, and for the experimental drugs dideoxycytidine and dideoxyinosine, the researchers said. This test-tube potency of the new compounds may bode well for avoiding side effects, but nobody knows what would happen in humans, cautioned AIDS researcher Jay Levy of the University of California at San Francisco. Many drugs that look promising in the test tube turn out to have unpredicted side effects, he said in a telephone interview. And higher potentency in the test tube does not necessarily mean greater effectiveness in people, he said. Jeffrey Laurence of the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center said he was concerned that the compound highlighted in the study did not work against close relatives of the AIDS virus, including HIV-2 and a monkey-carried version of the AIDS virus. That suggests the AIDS virus might become resistant to it by mutating only slightly, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Union Carbide Announces First Full-Scale Plastics Recycling
DOC.TEXT: One of the largest plastics producers in the United States unveiled plans to open the nation's first multi-material, comprehensive plastic recycling plant. Union Carbide Chemicals and Plastics Inc. said Wednesday the facility would be the first in the nation to recycle the ubiquitous plastic bags. The plant also will recycle plastic beverage containers. The recycling center is expected to open next year in converted space at the company's central New Jersey manufacturing plant at Piscataway. The effort was praised by state officials and legislators but environmental groups were skeptical, saying the recycling plans might be little more than a bid to keep plastic-banning lawmakers at bay. Union Carbide officials said the project was aimed at making money as well as easing a nationwide garbage problem that is particularly acute in densely populated New Jersey. ``These cost a lot of money,'' company vice president Gordon Mounts told a Statehouse news conference as he gestured toward a display of plastic bags and containers. ``We really don't believe we can use them just once.'' Only about 1 percent of the 60 billion pounds of plastic produced in the United States is being recycled now. Union Carbide officials said the new plant will demonstrate that plastic can be re-used on a far wider scale. Environmentalists said readily recyclable glass and naturally degrading paper are better for the environment than plastic. ``I don't doubt Union Carbide does want recycling, but ... they are doing it as much for the public relations as for the profitability of the venture,'' said Lisa Collaton, a solid waste specialist for the Washington-based group Environmental Action. But Assemblyman Robert Smith, chairman of the lower house's environment committee, said the effort appeared genuine and will ``dramatically change the approach government takes to the plastics problem.'' He said ``there's now a real alternative'' to several state bills that propose restricting or banning plastic packaging, though none have passed. Plastics industry officials say more than 350 legislative initiatives have been introduced at the federal, state and local levels around the country to curb the use of non-recyclable plastics. The plant's breakthrough, Union Carbide officials said, was its ability to accept plastic bags. The so-called plastic ``films'' now are recycled in Europe but not in the United States, said Keith Atkins, director of new business for the company's polyolefins division. About 20 percent of the soft-drink containers used in the country also are being recycled, but the percentage is nowhere near as high with other types of plastic. Union Carbide officials said the new plant would melt the bags down like other types of plastic. The material will be fashioned into pellets to be sold to plastic packaging manufacturers. The new plant will be able to handle 40 million pounds, out of more than 1 billion pounds of plastic garbage generated in New Jersey each year. But company officials said their project at least would demonstrate that comprehensive and profitable plastic recycling is possible.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Takes Stand, Identifies Defendant as Attacker
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents
