DOC.TEXT: An 8-year-old boy recounted how a man raped him and cut off his penis in an attack that has pushed legislators to draft tough new laws on sex predators. Embarrassed but determined, the boy, who was 7 at the time of the attack, identified in court Wednesday the man accused of the crime. The boy did not look at the defendant, Earl Kenneth Shriner, but pointed toward Shriner at the defense table and said, ``Yes ... over there.'' Shriner, 40, has pleaded innocent to first-degree attempted murder, first-degree assault and two counts of first-degree rape. During 30 minutes on the witness stand in Pierce County Superior Court, the boy told of the May 20 attack. Judge Thomas R. Sauriol limited attendance in the courtroom during the testimony to about 15 friends and relatives of principals in the case and 10 reporters. The boy's testimony was not announced in advance ``to avoid hoopla as much as possible,'' Deputy Prosecutor James Roche said. Deputy Prosecutor Barbara Corey-Boulet had the boy identify the small red bicycle that he rode into a wooded area near his home the day of the attack. ``Did something happen to you the last time you rode this bike?'' she asked. ``Yeah,'' the boy answered. She asked if he met anyone in the woods. ``A guy,'' said the boy, who nodded when Corey-Boulet asked if the man did something to him. ``Did the guy do some things that you are embarrassed about?'' Corey-Boulet asked. ``Uh huh,'' he said. He then described the attack. The boy said the man was wearing ``a fishing coat ... green and white.'' Under cross examination from defense lawyer Lloyde Alton, the boy repeated his description of the jacket. The jacket introduced into evidence and described by detectives as the one Shriner likely wore is gray with a maroon lining. The savageness of the case has sparked proposals in the Legislature for dealing with predatory sex offenders that range from civil commitment to castration. The trial, which began Monday, is expected to last about three weeks. Prosecutors have said they would seek a life sentence for Shriner, who has a history of sexual attacks and completed a 10-year prison term shortly before the boy was attacked. He was imprisoned for the kidnap and assault of two teen-age girls.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Lawsuit Said to Target Longshoremen
DOC.TEXT: The federal government plans an attempt to gain control of several locals of the International Longshoremen's Association allegedly controlled by corrupt leaders, a Justice Department source said. A lawsuit is expected to be filed next week in federal court in New York, the source said on condition of anonymity. It would be filed under the Federal Racketeer Influenced, Corrupt Organizations Act. ABC News reported Tuesday that the department would seek to have a trustee run the union because of accusations it is controlled by organized crime. The government has sought trusteeships in other cases where mob influence was alleged, including against the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. Labor investigators said the New York and Newark, N.J., longshoremen locals are considered to be among the most influenced by organized crime. Spokesmen for the Department of Labor and the New York harbor commission each reported their organizations were investigating the union in the New York area. New York prosecutors have been investigating the union for several months, said Thomas W. Gleason Jr., counsel for the union. ``We have fully cooperated,'' said Gleason, son of the union's former leader. He said he knew of no plans to bring the union into court. Deborah Corley, a spokeswoman for U.S. Attorney Otto Obermaier, said she could not confirm or deny reports the office was preparing a lawsuit against the union. The union, with 90,000 members nationwide, was expelled from the American Federation of Labor for corruption in 1953, and has been the subject of many investigations over the years. A spokesman for the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor, created in 1953 to probe mob connections on the docks, said his organization had been conducting an investigation into the union for several years. The spokesman, Jerome J. Klied, would not confirm the nature of the investigation. The Labor Department also is conducting an investigation into the ILA, said New York spokesman Randy Wilson. He said further information would be forthcoming next week when the Justice Department takes action. He declined to elaborate.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``A swift conclusion to our arms control talks _ conventional, chemical and strategic _ must now be our goal. That time has come.'' _ President Bush in his first State of the Union speech.

``There are so many stars like the sun that it's impossible to think the sun is the only one that has life on an orbiting planet.'' _ Raul Colomb, director of Argentina's Institute of Radioastronomy, which plans to launch a U.S.-built high-tech radio signal analyzer to expand the search for signals from intelligent aliens in space.

``In a way, it's one of our imperialistic beliefs that everybody wants to be American but they haven't been allowed to. That's not necessarily true, but it makes us feel good. It's like, `Wow, McDonald's. What's next? Maybe they'll start building Fords.''' _ Harriet Kuhr of the Friendship Force of Atlanta, which pioneered exchanges betweens U.S. and Soviet citizens, on the opening of Moscow's first McDonald's.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Navaho Chairman Tried With Co-Defendants
DOC.TEXT: Suspended Navajo Chairman Peter MacDonald said he was disappointed by a tribal judge's decision to try MacDonald with his co-defendants. ``Everybody likes to be tried on their own,'' MacDonald said Wednesday after Judge Robert Yazzie of Window Rock District Court made his ruling. Yazzie consolidated trials for MacDonald and his son, Peter ``Rocky'' MacDonald, and suspended Vice Chairman Johnny R. Thompson. He ordered three separate trials for the defendants on fraud and other charges related to the tribe's purchase of a ranch; for election-code violations; and for bribery and kickback _ but each trial will involve two of the defendants. Also Wednesday, Yazzie refused to order MacDonald to surrender his U.S. passport; told MacDonald's attorney he would have to remain on the case despite the uncertainty of compensation; and refused a motion that he step aside for another judge. Meanwhile, a judge in Phoenix on Wednesday allowed the tribe to go ahead with its $24 million civil racketeering suit against MacDonald and about 70 other defendants. Judge John Foreman of Maricopa County Superior Court rejected a defense contention that his court had no jurisdiction because tribal sovereignty prevents the tribe from suing a Navajo in a state court. The civil suit in Phoenix and some of the 107 criminal counts facing MacDonald allege that he swayed the Tribal Council to spend $33.4 million on the Big Boquillas Ranch near Seligman in July 1987. The non-Indian company which sold the ranch had paid $27.2 million for it less than a day before. Phoenix land broker Byron ``Bud'' Brown, another defendant in the civil case, testified before a U.S. Senate committee last February that MacDonald was to receive one-third of the $7.2 million profit and actually got $50,000 in cash; a $25,000 wire transfer; the lease of a luxury automobile, and vacation trips before the scheme was discovered. The Tribal Council suspended MacDonald a few days later and Thompson on March 10. Yazzie set a May 1 trial date on the election-code violations alleged against MacDonald and Thompson. The trial on bribery and kickbacks, with MacDonald and Rocky MacDonald as defendants, is scheduled for May 23; and the two are defendants in the Big Boquillas ranch trial scheduled to begin June 20. In denying the prosecutors' request that MacDonald surrender his passport, Yazzie said MacDonald had attended all previous hearings and that he saw no reason to limit his travel. In a separate matter, MacDonald wanted the judge to disqualify himself, contending that Yazzie would be biased against him because he once tried to deny Yazzie a permanent judgeship. Yazzie said there was no evidence to support the contention. Val Jolley of Farmington, N.M., an attorney for Peter MacDonald, had filed a motion for a ``limited appearance'' based on a January start of trial. But Yazzie ruled that a limited appearance was unethical and a ``restriction on the court.'' Jolley has said he was concerned about MacDonald's ability to pay him for services in a lengthy case.

DOC.HEAD: Assembly Sets March 21 as Independence Day; Arrest Procedure Debated
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers have voted unanimously to declare Namibia independent in mid-March, ending the territory's status as the continent's last colony after 75 years of South African rule. Leaders of the South-West Africa People's Organization, dominant in the Constituent Assembly, said Wednesday that March 21 was chosen unaninimously in part because the United Nations recognizes it as the ``International Day for the Elimination of Apartheid.'' For many years, South Africa's apartheid policies of racial segregation were imposed on Namibia's blacks. South Africa agreed to grant independence to Namibia, also known as South-West Africa, under a regional peace treaty. More than 6,000 United Nations military and civilian personnel have been supervising the process since April 1989. The 72-member assembly this week has been debating each article of a democratic, Western-style constitution and has agreed on all the major principles. It is likely to formally approve the document on Friday or Monday. The assembly on Wednesday eliminated a provision that would have allowed for detention without trial under some circumstances. SWAPO favored keeping the provision, but agreed to drop the measure when the opposition parties objected. Also, a proposal that guarantees fundamental rights even during times of war and states of emergency was approved. All decisions on the constitution require a two-thirds' majority. The document has declaration of fundamental rights, including freedom of movement, speech, and a free press. It also envisions a multiparty democracy, regular elections, an independent judiciary and an executive president limited to two five-year terms. Leftist-oriented SWAPO, which waged a 23-year bush war against South African rule, captured 41 seats in the assembly and will form the first government. SWAPO's leader, Sam Nujoma is expected to be the countary's first president. The Democratic Turnhalle Alliance, a multiracial coalition that favors a free enterprise economy, has 21 seats. The 10 remaining seats are divided among five parties. South Africa captured Namibia from the Germans in 1915. In December 1988, it agreed to grant independence as part of a regional treaty that also calls for phased withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola, Namibia's northern neighbor. More than 6,000 U.N. military and civilian personnel have been supervising the transition process since last April.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Leader Found Dead at Mosque
DOC.TEXT: A Moslem prayer leader who was found dead at his mosque had been warned of death threats recently by the police, an associate of the slain man said. Rashad Khalifa, 54, died early Wednesday after a shooting was reported at the mosque he founded near the University of Arizona, authorities said. ``There is a possibility that motives may include political and religious problems,'' said Tucson police homicide Sgt. Charles Armijo, who declined to confirm whether Khalifa was shot or to specify the cause of death. The FBI was called in to investigate the death. Khalifa founded a group in 1978 called the ``Right'' or ``True'' Moslems, said Edip Yuksel, an assistant to Khalifa. Yuksel said Khalifa had received death threats because of his beliefs that most of the Islamic world was a version of the Koran that contained satanic verses. He said police had warned Khalifa of the threats. He said Khalifa had published views which contended most Moslems were idol-worshippers of Mohammed, who according to Islamic belief had the holy book revealed to him by Allah. Yuksel said Khalifa was prominent in Moslem circles worldwide and estimated that he had at least 10,000 followers. Khalifa came to the United States from Egypt in 1959. One of his followers was onetime National Football League star receiver Bobby Joe Moore, who adopted Khalifa's first name in becoming Ahmad Rashad.

DOC.HEAD: President Roh's Governing Party Dissolved
DOC.TEXT: President Roh Tae-woo's governing party was formally dissolved today to form a new broad-based coalition with two moderate opposition parties. At a hurriedly called national convention, more than 6,000 party delegates endorsed the merger and disbanded the Democratic Justice Party by clapping hands. No vote was taken. In an address read by party chairman Park Tae-joon, Roh hailed the dissolution as ``a historic turning point'' and urged his followers to continue to support him to lift South Korea to the ranks of industrialized nations before the end of the century. ``We should turn ourselves into a huge furnace which burns out all past remnants of conflicts and confrontation,'' he said. Roh announced last week that his governing party would merge with the country's No. 2 and 3 opposition groups to form a huge new conservative party. Kim Young-sam's second-largest opposition group, the Reunification Democratic Party, resolved Monday to disband in favor of the new party, tentatively called the ``Democratic Liberal Party.'' The third largest opposition group, the New Democratic Republican Party led by former premier Kim Jong-pil, is scheduled to hold a national convention next Monday to dissolve and endorse the merger. The merger, expected to formally take effect around Feb. 15, will restructure South Korea's faction-ridden four-party system into a bipartisan one. The new expanded ruling group will control 221 seats in the 297-member National Assembly and will dwarf Kim Dae-jung's opposition group, the country's largest and most radical, the Party for Peace and Democracy. Kim Dae-jung's party has 71 seats. The merger was not without friction but is expected to be carried through as scheduled. Several lawmakers of Kim Young-sam's party, including parliamentary floor leader Lee Ki-taek, seceded to form a new opposition party.

DOC.HEAD: Continental Jet Nearly Hits Second Jet on Runway
DOC.TEXT: One Continental Airlines jet missed colliding with another Continental plane by ``20 or 30 feet'' after it broke through low clouds for a landing only to see the plane on the runway, one of the pilots said. ``It was really a miracle that he didn't hit us. He went right over the top of us, and all we saw was his tailpipe through the windshield,'' said Capt. Jim Lowry, pilot of the plane that was on the runway at Houston Intercontinental Airport. The Houston Chronicle reported Wednesday that the Continental plane had to abort its landing Jan. 3, when it spotted the other plane on the runway. Jack Sinon, manager of the Federal Aviation Administration's air traffic control facility at the Houston airport, said Wednesday the matter is under FAA review. He declined to provide further details. Continental spokesman Ned Walker confirmed details of the incident, but he would not identify the pilot of the second plane, which was flying in from Albuquerque, N.M. ``We've been told by the FAA that they're investigating this as a possible air traffic control operational error and that the Continental actions and aircraft positions were as they had been instructed,'' Walker said. The close call was the scariest incident in his career, said Lowry, a 25-year pilot with Houston-based Continental. Lowry said he warned the tower controller that his plane was still on the runway about 20 seconds before the other plane roared over. The foggy and overcast day was turning dark as Lowry and his crew sat in the plane awaiting air traffic control instructions for a takeoff to Phoenix, Ariz. ``We sat on the runway for a good while. Then we heard an airplane being cleared to land on the runway that we were on,'' he said. ``We called the tower and advised the controller that we were still in position on the runway.'' The tower, he said, acknowledged the call. But the crew soon heard the roar of the other plane. ``As he came over us, he was bringing the nose back up and we saw him through the windshield. He probably missed us by 20 or 30 feet,'' Lowry said. ``... It was terrifying.''

DOC.HEAD: Cardinal Says Bishop Never Condemned Governor to Hell
DOC.TEXT: Cardinal John J. O'Connor defended a bishop who was quoted as saying Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was ``in danger of going to hell'' because of his abortion beliefs. ``What the bishop told me he actually said was that the governor is `quite possibly contributing to the loss of his soul.' To me that sounds significantly different from `cursing' or `condemning' the governor to hell,'' O'Connor said. Auxiliary Bishop Austin Vaughan, 62, had talked to a newspaper reporter from jail, where he served 10 days for blocking the entrance to an Albany Planned Parenthood clinic last March. Vaughan was released on Jan. 24. The New York Post had quoted Vaughan Jan. 23 as saying Cuomo was ``in danger of going to hell if he dies tonight.'' ``I think for a believing, educated Catholic to take the position he's taken, he takes a very serious risk of going straight to hell,'' the Post reported Vaughan had said. O'Connor had refused comment until he could speak to Vaughan. On Wednesday, he said in a column published in Catholic New York that Vaughan assured him he was misunderstood. The governor responded to O'Connor's column with a two-sentence statement: ``The cardinal says the bishop was misquoted. I'm glad.'' The Post's state editor, Fred Dicker, said, ``I read the cardinal's comments to be much more an objection to the governor's characterization than to what we had reported the bishop actually said.'' Cuomo has said that he and his wife accept the church's teaching on abortion in their private life, but that as governor he recognized the constitutional right of choice and a legal obligation to make the choice available to the poor. Cuomo originally had responded to the published comments by saying: ``Does any bishop, any rabbi, any citizen have the right to curse a politician, curse them even to hell? In this wonderful country the answer is yes.'' O'Connor said Vaughan, by issuing a warning to the governor from jail, had followed in the footsteps of St. John the Baptist, St. Thomas More and other religious leaders who had issued warnings to public officials from prison. ``Among other differences, of course, is that Bishop Vaughan will get to keep his head,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Valdez 8 Inches Away from Setting Season Snowfall Record
DOC.TEXT: For the man with the biggest roof in Valdez, this year's snows come with a steep price: He's paid $5,000 to have it cleared. Dennis Holtz, owner of the FoodMart supermarket, said Wednesday it took two men with snowblowers a couple of weeks to finally get all the snow off. ``My roof is 21,000 square feet,'' Holtz said. ``We had 400 tons of snow up there. It's built to hold 140 pounds per square foot and we had 100 pounds per square foot. ``It took over $5,000 to get the nine feet of snow on the roof blown off,'' he said. ``I guess that's just one of the costs of doing business.'' Holtz said Valdez is pretty much back to normal after getting almost 4 feet of snow on Jan. 16, when a single-day-record of 47{ inches was set. More than 13 feet of snow fell in January, leaving just the rooftops visible on one-story dwellings. A city storage building collapsed last week from the weight of snow. Jeff Bailey of the National Weather Service said Valdez is 8 inches away from passing the season record for snowfall accumulation of 384.7 inches, set in 1986-87. At the airport, which has been shut down twice this winter because of snow buildup, maintenance crews are bulldozing snow off taxiways and parking ramps. ``We had so much precipitation down here we work 32 hours a day to keep ahead of it,'' said Elmer McCain. ``We can't keep it (ice) off, so we just scar it for better traction.'' Harry Rogers, superintendent of schools, said children no longer play ``king of the hill'' but ``man on the mountain'' at the elementary school, where snow is piling up on a corner of the playground. ``The biggest pile we've got is approaching 50 feet,'' he said. ``The most serious problem we've got is keeping the kids off. That's a high pile of snow out there.''

DOC.HEAD: Sets Sights on Soviet Union in Final Season With Chicago Symphony
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT that comments were made Wednesday sted Tuesday.
DOC.TEXT: Sir Georg Solti hopes his last year as director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra includes the group's first tour of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. ``America has here a messenger, in this orchestra, that is unparalleled by any politician, unparalleled by any ambassador,'' Solti said Wednesday when he unveiled plans for his 22nd and farewell season. ``(It) is essential that we show them what we can produce _ not in armaments, and not in missiles _ but in Beethoven and Shostakovich,'' the 77-year-old Solti told reporters. The Chicago Symphony performances in the Soviet Union would be part of an exchange that would bring the Leningrad Philharmonic to the United States. The hoped-for tour would include a performance either in Moscow or Leningrad and stops at Vienna, Austria, and at Solti's birthplace of Budapest, Hungary. Logistical problems, including uncertainties over lodging and food, have made the plans tentative, but the orchestra hopes to reach a decision within two weeks. If all three stops cannot be arranged, the tour will not take place, officials said. The trip would come during the ensemble's centennial season, which will run from September through April 1991. ``Something is quite wonderful, to be part of an orchestra which will be 100 years old,'' said Solti, who selected about two-thirds of the musicians currently playing. ``One-fifth of the existence of this orchestra, I have been honored to be its music director,'' he said. ``It's remarkable, and I feel very, very rich.'' Crowning the program for the season will be Verdi's opera ``Otello,'' with Luciano Pavarotti in the title role for the first time, Solti said. The maestro, who has won a record 29 Grammy Awards and built the Chicago Symphony into one of the world's best, also promised to return to Chicago as a guest conductor. Solti also said the orchestra this spring will make its third trip to the Orient. Six conductors, including Solti, and Daniel Barenboim, his successor-designate in Chicao beginning in the 1991-92 season, will lead 12 concerts in Japan during April. The trip will be funded largely through a $750,000 gift _ the single largest corporate donation the orchestra has ever received _ from Motorola Inc., said Richard L. Thomas, chairman of the Orchestral Association. Japanese audiences received the orchestra enthusiastically during its previous trips there, the last in 1986, and Solti said he loves the opportunity to showcase U.S. orchestral excellence. ``In many fields, to my great sadness, America is going down,'' he said. ``Here is where neither the Japanese nor the Germans can compete with us, and this is one point when we should feel very proud.''

DOC.HEAD: General Suggests Some Journalists Knew Of Panama Invasion Plans
DOC.TEXT: Some journalists may have been tipped to top-secret military plans of the invasion of Panama hours before the action began Dec. 20, but no one reported it before troops began landing, an Army general says. ``I had strong indications, based on people I talked to, that the press had a pretty strong indication about Tuesday (Dec. 19) as to what was going to happen, and they didn't run it,'' Army Lt. Gen. Thomas W. Kelly told an audience Wednesday at the University of Notre Dame. ``So I think they earned a big plus for being good Americans and not breaking the story.'' Kelly, director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, did not specify who may have known of the top-secret plans or how word might have leaked. He refused to accept reporters' questions and confined his remarks to an informal talk before an audience of about 1,000, mostly university ROTC cadets. Broadcast news reports the evening of Dec. 19 reported American planes landing every 10 minutes at the U.S. base in Panama. Reports also indicated troops had left Fort Bragg, N.C., but did not indicate where they were going. Since the invasion, there have been reports that strongman Manuel Antonio Noriega, who was deposed after the U.S. troops arrived, had been tipped to an imminent invasion but refused to believe it. During his wide-ranging talk, Kelly defended the invasion, castigated Noriega's leadership of the Panamanian Defense Forces and discussed tactics. ``We wanted to go in at 1 o'clock in the morning because we own the night,'' said Kelly. ``Our forces train at night, and just about no one else's do. `We have night vision devices that no one else has.'' The Pentagon reported scattered resistance from Noriega loyalists up to a week after the invasion. About 14,000 soldiers joined 12,000 troops already stationed in Panama in the invasion ordered by President Bush, who said the operation was undertaken to protect American lives, safeguard the Panama Canal and hunt down Noriega. Kelly said the invasion, announced under the code name Operation Just Cause, was planned under a more innocuous name _ Blue Spoon. ``Blue Spoon was a sort of covering,'' he said. ``If you had come across it on a piece of paper, you wouldn't think anything of something called Blue Spoon.''

DOC.HEAD: OCAW Rejects Amoco Contract, Threatens Strikes
DOC.TEXT: The clock ran out as some 300 contracts between companies and oil workers expired just after midnight today, with union leaders threatening to strike individual companies if negotiations snag. ``It is our intention not to call a national strike,'' said Robert E. Wages, vice president and bargaining coordinator for the 40,000-member Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union. ``We may give strike notices to certain companies,'' he said, referring to the contracts that expired at 12:01 a.m. The union rejected the oil industry's two-year contract offer Wednesday and continued talks with all companies, but said it could call a strike at any one wwith 24 hours' notice. Calls to OCAW's Lakewood-based headquarters and officers' homes late Wednesday night for comment were not answered. Major companies that could be struck include Amoco, Texaco, Chevron, Mobil, Shell, Atlantic Richfield and Unocal. In San Francisco, two OCAW locals agreed to a rolling contract extension, with talks to continue until one party or the other gives 24-hour notice. The agreement was confirmed by Jim Payne, secretary-treasurer of OCAW Local 1-5, representing workers at Chevron, Tosco and Shell, and by Rick DeLege, president pro tem of OCAW Local 1-326, which represents Unocal workers. Earlier in the day, the union's national bargaining committee decided not to call an industrywide strike but to strike individual major companies should impasses develop. Wages said the union would extend the negotiations because ``there is at least some reason to believe all of the majors are interested in talking about the issues.'' OCAW officials said the contract offered by Amoco Corp., the pattern contract for the industry, fell short of union demands on pay, health benefits and environmental concerns. Telephone calls to Amoco headquarters in Chicago were not returned. The average refinery worker's wage now is $15.18 an hour. The union seeks $1.25 hourly wage increases in each year of the two-year pact, about twice what the union says Amoco is offering; establishment of an independent environmental monitor at each plant; and increases in the company share of medical insurance costs. Talks began Jan. 1.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Seeks Major US, Soviet Troop Reductions in Europe
DOC.NOTE: EDs: To UPDATE with Soviet, NATO reax, INSERTS 2 grafs 5th graf pvs bgng, Bush said ...; INSERTS 1 graf after 10th graf pvs bgng, Foley ignored; edits 11th graf pvs, But lawmakers... for transition, picking up 12th graf pvs, ``It was ...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, winning bipartisan acclaim in Congress, is proposing further deep cuts in U.S. and Soviet troop strength in Europe and declaring ``that time has come'' to swiftly conclude agreements limiting conventional, strategic and chemical weapons. ``Today, with communism crumbling, our aim must be to ensure democracy's advance,'' the president said Wednesday night in a State of the Union speech that blended his new troop withdrawal proposal with a pledge to withdraw the remainder of the U.S. invasion force from Panama by the end of the month. In a surprise overture, Bush proposed cutting military manpower in Europe to 195,000 troops on each side, down from the 275,000 figure that was the U.S. bargaining position at conventional force negotiations in Vienna. The president said he called Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev earlier in the day to inform him of the offer, which already had been endorsed by NATO allies. The move, Bush said, was a response to ``the revolution of '89'' in which he said the United States ``stands at the center of a widening circle of freedom.'' Bush said Gorbachev seemed ``receptive'' to the idea and was studying it. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said on ABC-TV this morning that the Kremlin was ``satisfied'' with Bush's troop cut proposal ``as a beginning.'' But he said the Soviets want all foreign troops out of Europe and, ``if that's Bush's bottom line, it is unfortunate.'' In Brussels, Belgium, NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner said the allies offered their ``broad support in principle'' for Bush's proposals. ``These new steps take account of new political developments in the East, while remaining consistent with the needs of the alliance's strategy of deterrence.'' The surprise overture was the centerpiece of an address that also promised to ``invest in America'' through savings incentives, research and improved education, and called on citizens to ``confront and condemn'' racism and hate. Bush also renewed his call for a capital gains tax cut, slapped down by Democrats last year, and called on lawmakers to pass clean air, child care, crime and drug legislation. But while Congress applauded the troop cuts _ and the savings they eventually would produce _ Democrats said Bush's rhetoric on domestic issues did not match the budget he sent to Capitol Hill just two days earlier. On education, ``the president's words seem to agree with us, but his actions say something else,'' said House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., delivering his party's formal response to Bush's prime-time televised speech. Foley ignored the troop proposal in his formal remarks, instead focusing on the domestic issues congressional Democrats have decided to make their theme for this election year. ``In the 1990s, and well into the next century, the central challenge for America will be economic, not military,'' he said. Foley raised the troop cut proposal this morning on NBC's ``Today'' show, saying Democrats are ``in agreement that we ought to reduce our troops in Europe. I think everyone see3s there is a change in need there,'' Foley said. Lawmakers in both parties saw the troop cut as a welcome development, with many characterizing the move as an attempt to catch up with events that outpaced the arms talks. ``It was a very good move on his part, because we were falling behind the curve of popular will,'' said Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine. ``He had to get way out front. If we didn't make these kinds of proposals, we'd be seen as being irrelevant to the process.'' ``He is rushing to catch the reality of Eastern Europe,'' said Rep. Pat Williams, D-Mont. ``Events in Eastern Europe are pulling the Pentagon and the president toward decisions they wouldn't otherwise make.'' The cuts would place a heavier burden on the Soviet Union, which has 565,000 troops in Central Europe compared with the U.S. level of 305,000. But the offer could come as a welcome relief for Gorbachev, who is under heavy popular pressure to unilaterally remove Soviet troops from Warsaw Pact countries which are shedding their ties to Moscow. The proposal reflects advice of top military strategists, would sustain NATO's needs and would help push peaceful change forward, Bush said. ``A swift conclusion to our arms control talks _ conventional, chemical and strategic _ must now be our goal. That time has come,'' he said. However, Bush's budget provides continued buildups for most nuclear weapons systems and the Star Wars missile defense, a reflection of what the president called Moscow's continued modernization effort in that area. In the only other concrete announcement in his speech, Bush said he would pull back the remaining U.S. troops sent to Panama for the December invasion by the end of February. The Pentagon said Wednesday that troop levels now are about 16,000, or about 3,000 more than the pre-invasion number. Amid the agreement, there also were signs that a tough year lies ahead. When Bush repeated his ``no new taxes'' pledge and again when he vowed to seek a cut in tax rates for capital gains, Republicans in the House chamber erupted into applause, while Democrats sat silent. And Foley's only mention of foreign policy came in two areas where Democrats take issue with the administration: South Africa and China. Condemning Bush's earlier veto of a bill to protect Chinese students in the United States from deportation, Foley said, ``No Congress and no president should be timid in the defense of freedom.'' In his speech, the president condemned racially motivated mail bombings, saying the nation ``must confront and condemn racism, anti-Semitism, bigotry and hate.'' And he said, ``Our hearts go out to our hostages _ our hostages who are ceaselessly on our minds and in our efforts.'' Bush also expressed concern over the nation's health care, and directed Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan to review recommendations on the quality, cost and accessibility of the health care system.

DOC.HEAD: Ethnic Conflict Worsens In South As Rallying Slavs Vow To Take Up Arms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with report of tanks moving toward province, government CORRECTS that 18 killed, sted 19, warning of full-scale uprising. Pickup 8th, `The province's ...'; DELETES last 3 grafs to trim.
DOC.TEXT: Protests by ethnic Albanians in the province of Kosovo have caused a backlash in other parts of the country, including demands by thousands of Slavs to be given weapons so they can go fight the Albanians. State-run television said the province was on ``the verge of civil war.'' Travelers today reported seeing large columns of army tanks heading toward Kosovo from the direction of Serbia. Tanks also were deployed in February and March 1989, when trouble last flared in the region. Three ethnic Albanians were reported killed Wednesday in Kosovo, bringing to 18 the death toll in rioting that began eight days ago in the poor southern province governed by the Serbian republic. Fifty-four demonstrators and 44 policemen have been injured, said Jorgovanka Milojevic, a spokeswoman for the provincial government. A previous report that a policeman was killed was erroneous, the government said. Authorities warned that traveling through Kosovo was dangerous, and there were reports of young ethnic Albanians armed with guns, stopping cars and checking identities. The ethnic Albanians, who outnumber Slavs 9-1 among Kosovo's 1.9 million inhabitants, want to regain the autonomy lost when Serbia took control of the republic's police, judiciary and education system last year. The ethnic Albanians are demanding an end to political trials, the release of political prisoners and the lifting of a year-old state of emergency. Ethnic Albanian leaders of Kosovo's independent groups urged federal authorities to avoid a full-scale uprising by holding immediate talks with ethnic Albanians. ``Ethnic Albanians are not terrorists. They are subjected to terror by the state,'' a statement by the groups said. The province's Slavic minority, mostly Serbs and Montenegrins, contends the Albanians are trying to force them from their homeland, which borders Albania. Yugoslavia is a loose, multi-ethnic Balkan federation of six republics and two semi-autonomous provinces. In addition to its ethnic and considerable economic troubles, the non-aligned Communist country is in the throes of a political crisis that principally pits Serbia, the largest republic, against liberal and Westward-looking Slovenia to the north. Serbia is controlled by hard-line Communists who are resisting the democratic reforms the more prosperous Slovenia is already implementing. The dispute has led to a serious rift in the ruling Communist Party. In the Montenegrin republic's capital of Titograd on Wednesday, up to 100,000 Slavs rallied and some fired guns into the air. Some demanded they be given weapons and volunteered to go to Kosovo to fight the ``Albanian nationalists.'' The state news agency Tanjug said three people were killed Wednesday and five wounded in Glogovac, a village 12 miles south of Pristina, Kosovo's capital. It said police there used a helicopter to disperse ``several thousand aggressive'' protesters. Belgrade television showed the huge rally of Slavs in Titograd. Gunfire could be heard and speakers implored demonstrators to stop firing handguns. One speaker said Montenegrin volunteers were signing up to fight in Kosovo and would travel there unless the authorities ``use all available methods, including repression,'' to end ``the Albanian uprising.'' In Ivangrad, a Montenegrin town, 10,000 people also demonstrated against ``Albanian separatists and Slovenian and Croatian leaders supporting them,'' Tanjug said. Slovenia, and to a lesser extent Croatia, have sided with the ethnic Albanians and the rally in Titograd had anti-Slovene overtones. Slovenian police units have reportedly refused to serve in Kosovo. In Belgrade, the federal and Serbian capital, crowds estimated in the thousands held rallies. The demonstrations were purportedly anti-Albanian, but protesters also chanted ``Down with Communism!'' and ``Down with Tito,'' the late Yugoslav president held responsible by the Serbs for originally giving wide autonomy to Kosovo. Ethnic Albanians began protesting a year ago when Serbia made constitutional changes to take firmer control of the province. At least 28 people died in violence in Kosovo over the issue last year.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Says Civil Servants Misled Her Over Dirty Tricks
DOC.TEXT: A government-sponsored dirty tricks campaign in Northern Ireland began against the Irish Republican Army in the 1970s but later extended to smearing top British politicians, a former army press officer said today. Colin Wallace has long maintained he was dismissed in 1975, four years before Mrs. Thatcher became prime minister, for threatening to expose the program. His dismissal is now under review. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on Wednesday admitted she had wrongly denied the existence of the campaign in the past, but she blamed it on information she received from civil servants. On Tuesday, her government confirmed the existence of a covert program codenamed ``Clockwork Orange'' to feed lies to journalists reporting from Northern Ireland, where the IRA is fighting to end British rule. Defense Secretary Tom King planned to make a statement to Parliament today about the dirty-tricks campaign. The government has confirmed that a covert disinformation campaign was waged against the IRA, but it has always insisted there is no evidence to support Wallace's broader allegations: that the campaign extended to smearing liberal politicians as Soviet stooges and sympathizers, and that Wallace was framed on a manslaughter charge to silence him. Wallace says smear targets included the prime minister at the time, Harold Wilson and his predecessor, Edward Heath. The former army press officer says that in addition to his regular army duties, he led a secret psychological warfare unit in Northern Ireland in the 1970s. His claim was backed up by his superior officer. Wallace says ``Clockwork Orange'' began as an attempt to discredit the IRA through false stories, such as the claim the guerrillas had Soviet rockets armed with unstable explosives. He says he also was supposed to spread disinformation designed to create the suspicion inside extremist groups that they were being infiltrated. The smear campaign ``gradually drew in Northern Ireland politicians and eventually some of those at Westminster (London),'' Wallace said. Merlyn Rees, Labor's Northern Ireland Secretary at the time, displayed a pro-IRA statement he said was doctored to include his name. The intention was to paint Labor as sympathetic to terrorism, he said on BBC-TV Wednesday night. Author Paul Foot _ in his book ``Who Framed Colin Wallace?'' _ says Wallace was given detailed briefings by the MI5 counterintelligence agency. He said the aim of the campaign was to prevent Labor from being re-elected in 1974 and to depose Heath and former Northern Ireland Minister William Whitelaw from top positions in the Conservative Party. Foot says the MI5 briefings enabled Wallace to make allegations about homosexuality, bogus bank accounts, corrupt earnings and Communist sympathies. Tony Benn, a former Labor Cabinet minister, told the House of Commons that former Prime Minister James Callaghan also was targeted. Foot's book includes the Rev. Ian Paisley, the militant Protestant leader in Northern Ireland, and former Cabinet ministers. Mrs. Thatcher said Wednesday, in a letter to a Conservative legislator, that a re-examination of government papers ``has brought to light information which shows that there were a number of statements in my letters, and in other ministerial statements and official correspondence, which were incorrect or require clarification.'' She said the government was already investigating how the errors in the handling of the papers occurred. ``But of course the matters with which they deal originated under previous administrations, and present ministers can only deal with them on the basis of information made available to us,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Charles Dickens Indicted on Christmastime Bank Robbery Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd-3rd grafs with 2 grafs to CORRECT name of story `A Christmas Carol,' add date he is alleged to have robbed Home Savings. Picks up penultimate graf.
DOC.TEXT: The bank tellers of Christmas past are haunting Charles Dickens. Dickens _ a namesake but not a descendant of the author who wrote of Christmas ghosts in ``A Christmas Carol'' _ was indicted Tuesday by a federal grand jury on charges of robbing three banks and trying to hold up a fourth during the holidays. Dickens, 36, is accused of taking $1,776 from a PSFS bank on Dec. 21; $2,316 from a Germantown Savings branch Dec. 26 and $950 from the same branch on Jan. 2; and $1,305 from a Home Unity Savings and Loan branch Jan. 6. He also is charged with unsuccessfully trying to rob the United Valley Bank on Jan. 2. Dickens has been jailed without bail after a teller from an earlier holdup saw him three weeks ago in front of a bank. Court records show that other tellers have identified Dickens as the man who robbed their banks.

DOC.HEAD: 62 Killed As Aoun's Forces Battle Militia for Control of Christian Zone
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE casualty toll and State Dept. calling on Aoun to step down. Pickup 8th, `The fighting...'
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces fought from house to house under raining shells today in a showdown for control of Lebanon's Christian enclave. Police said at least 62 people had been killed and 216 wounded. Hundreds of thousands of civilians huddled in basements and bomb shelters with dwindling water supplies as troops loyal to renegade Gen. Michel Aoun fought for a third day with militiamen of the Lebanese Forces. Christian radio stations said a new cease-fire, the third in 24 hours, was called for 9 a.m. in response to renewed Vatican appeals. But shellfire and bursts of gunfire persisted in Beirut's burning Christian sector well after the truce deadline, although police reported a slight decrease in hostilities that allowed some casualties to be evacuated. Conflicting victory claims made it difficult to determine who held the upper hand in the fighting, which left fires raging out of control and morgues packed with bodies. Lebanese Forces commander Samir Geagea blamed the confrontation on Aoun's ``power lust,'' and Aoun blamed the United States. ``America has engineered this collision, but we shall surmount it soon,'' Aoun said in a statement on his television station. He did not elaborate. The U.S. State Department on Wednesday said Aoun should step down. ``Gen. Aoun must realize that his bellicose behavior does not advance the interests of the Christians or any other community but only benefits those who want to see Lebanon continue in anarchy and turmoil,'' the State Department said. ``We reiterate our call for Gen. Aoun to step aside and to do it now.'' The fighting in the Christian zone was the worst since February 1989, when Aoun's 20,000 troops last moved against the 6,000-strong Lebanese Forces. More than 80 people were killed and 200 wounded in that four-day conflict. The battle could break the stalemate over an Arab League peace plan aimed at ending a 15-year-old civil war that has cost 150,000 Lebanese their lives. Aoun opposes the accord, worked out in October, because it does not guarantee withdrawal from Lebanon of Syria's 40,000 troops, which he calls an occupation force. Aoun also refuses to recognize President Elias Hrawi, who was elected as part of the accord. Geagea has neither accepted nor rejected the peace accord, but has recognized Hrawi as president. He and other right-wing Christians oppose Aoun's rebellion. Aoun, increasingly isolated and facing the prospect of a Syrian-backed assault by the 22,000 soldiers loyal to the Hrawi government, apparently felt he had to secure control of the Christian sector. The casualty count includes victims felled by stray morder rounds that exploded in Moslem west and south Beirut, which have not been involved in the inter-Christian clashes. It also includes 15 people, mainly children, wounded when a shell fired by Aoun's gunners blasted a government-owned secondary school in Jemmayzeh district, a stronghold of the Lebanese Forces. The school has been used as a shelter by several Christian families who sought refuge in it to avoid shelling. The three daily newspapers operating in Christian east Beirut failed to publish due to the clashes. Shiite Moslem militias, meanwhile, fought Wednesday in southern Lebanon, continuing the latest round of their intermittent struggle for supremacy among the 1.2 million Shiites, the largest sect in the country of 3.5 million people. Four people were reported wounded, raising the toll to 98 killed and 280 wounded in the battle that began Dec. 23 between the fundamentalist Hezbollah, which is loyal to Iran, and Amal, a mainstream militia backed by Syria. Police said Aoun's mainly Christian troops, spearheaded by the U.S.-trained 8th Brigade, scored initial successes Wednesday when they overran four Lebanese Forces barracks on the coastal highway linking Beirut and north Lebanon. But the militia outflanked Aoun's army with tank-led assaults, seizing his naval base in Kasslik, the armor base of Sarba in Jounieh and the main air base in Halat, said a police spokesman. That reasserted the Lebanese Forces' control of the enclave's 30-mile-long Mediterranean coast and restored their supply lines, said the spokesman, who cannot be named under standing rules. The police spokesman said the focal point of ground fighting early today was a cluster of government buildings housing the ministries of finance and justice close to Beirut's dividing Green Line. ``There is house-to-house combat there. Buildings are frequently changing hands in attacks and counterattacks,'' the spokesman said. Hrawi called on Aoun's troops to ``disobey and rebel'' against the general, whom he fired as army commander a few hours after being elected by Parliament and sworn in Nov. 24. ``The army's mission is to protect the citizens, not to kill them,'' Hrawi said in an interview broadcast by Moslem and Christian radio stations, indicating he has thrown the weight of his internationally recognized government behind Geagea in a bid to oust Aoun from the presidential palace. The telephone operator at St. George Greek Orthodox Hospital in Ashrafiyeh said the facility, one of the two main hospitals in east Beirut, was ``packed with casualties.'' ``The morgue is full of bodies. The wounded are on stretchers in the corridors. The upper floors have been evacuated due to the fierce shelling duels.'' ``There are not enough surgeons to operate on the wounded,'' he said. He would not give his name.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Ends Trip With Appeal for Solidarity with Africa
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with pope leaving for Rome. Pickup 5th graf, `In the...
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II ended an eight-day African tour today with a plea for regional and international cooperation to eliminate war, discrimination and human rights abuses on the continent. ``Solidarity between peoples has no borders,'' the pope said. ``The great changes under way in Eastern Europe should not divert attention from the south, especially from the African continent.'' John Paul made the appeal in a speech to diplomats at the end of his trip to five countries of the impoverished Sahel region. President Hissene Habre and the pontiff spoke at the airport for 10 minutes before the papal aircraft departed for Rome at 1:55 p.m. Before leaving, the pontiff celebrated Mass at a soccer stadium and met with Moslem leaders and other N'Djamena residents at a hippodrome. In the address to the diplomatic corps, the pope noted that Chad is now enjoying relative peace after years of civil war but said various conflicts afflicting Africa continue to cause ``sufferings which seem to have no end.'' ``I think of Ethiopia, Sudan, of other countries exposed to racial discrimination, of others where ethnic rivalries sometimes lead to violence,'' he said. The pontiff called on all parties to examine the root causes of the conflicts, including the oppression of minorities. ``One must also have the courage to shed light on the role exercised by all parties, starting with the most powerful who have control of the economy, military aid and alliances.'' ``We must manage to recognize the errors, the abuses of power, the injustices, the exploitation ... We should always have as the first objective the respect of the rights and the dignity of man.'' John Paul praised Africa's charter of human rights, but urged leaders to ``reduce the distance between words and action'' in strictly applying the terms of the document. He singled out the plight of African refugees forced to flee their countries because of violence or hunger. ``The problem goes beyond the field of action of specialized organizations...It involves men who should meet their brothers in humanity.'' The pope reiterated his appeal for rich countries to provide economic aid that doesn't enslave Third World recipients. He said the developed world should also share its scientific and technical know-how and help poor countries protect the environment and improve health services. John Paul also challenged African nations to collaborate more closely among themselves in fields such as energy production, transport, agriculture and industry. African organizations should be more active as ``true instruments of promotion of peace and development to the benefit of all their members,'' he said. In his homily during the Mass, the pope urged married couples to observe fidelity and respect ``the woman's vocation to be a mother.'' In the ceremony at the hippodrome, he encouraged Chadians in their effort to build up the country after the long years of civil war and fighting with neighboring Libya. Without mentioning Libya, he invited Chad to offer ``gestures of solidarity with the African countries which surround you.'' Aside from Chad, the pope's sixth voyage to Africa took him to Cape Verde, Guinea-Bissau, Mali and Burkina Faso.

DOC.HEAD: Declaration of Independence Brings $1.6 Million
DOC.TEXT: An auction record was set for a single printed piece of Americana when a copy of the first printing of the Declaration of Independence was sold for $1.6 million, Sotheby's announced. A Chicago rare book and manuscript dealer, Ralph G. Newman, bought the document Wednesday. He now holds one of only two copies remaining in private hands, said Laura Stewart, a spokeswoman for the auction house. Twenty-three copies are known to exist. Its pre-sale estimate was $400,000 to $600,000. Also Wednesday, George Washington's own copy of the Federalist Papers sold for $1.4 million to a private American collector, who bid by telephone and did not want to be identified, Stewart said. The papers are a set of 85 articles written by Alexander Hamilton, James Madison and John Jay, published in 1787 and 1788 analyzing the Constitution and urging its passage. The price was more than triple the pre-sale estimate and set a record for an association copy _ something whose value is enhanced by having belonged to someone famous, Stewart said. The items were part of a two-day sale of Americana and American and children's literature from the library of H. Bradley Martin, a noted book collector who died in 1988 at age 82. All prices quoted include the 10 percent fee paid by the buyer to the auction house on top of what he or she bid.

DOC.HEAD: Feb. 22 Launch on Target Despite Engine Repair, NASA Says
DOC.TEXT: NASA decided to replace a fuel turbopump in space shuttle Atlantis but said the repairs probably will not delay the shuttle's launch, now set for Feb. 22. Technicians began the week-long job of replacing the turbopump, located in one of the spaceship's three engines, late Wednesday, according to Conrad Nagel, who leads a NASA team readying Atlantis for launch. Nagel said the repair work was not expected to interrupt flight preparations although the schedule is ``a little soft. If things go well, there shouldn't be any impact to the launch date,'' Nagel said. Atlantis is scheduled to carry a secret cargo into space for the Department of Defense. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has not set an official launch date, but the liftoff is targeted for Feb. 22. The turbopump became a concern after the failure of an unrelated fuel pump duct during a routine pressure test at the engine's manufacturer, the Rocketdyne Division of Rockwell International in Canoga Park, Calif. The failure was in a titanium weld done outside the factory, according to Nagel. An in-flight failure could hinder the flow of fuel to the engine. ``That lead us to inspect other such welds, and this turbopump is suspect,'' Nagel said. ``We don't think we have a problem with it, but safety first.'' NASA's concern for safety also lead engineers to order the replacement of a seal in an ignition controller on one of Atlantis two solid-fuel booster rockets. That work, announced several days ago and planned for Sunday, was not expected to cause a launch delay either, according to Nagel. Post-flight inspections of the reusable rockets used to boost Columbia into space Jan. 9 showed a tiny void in an identical seal. The void is located in a backup seal on a gasket attached to a device on the cone-shaped portion of the rocket. It was missed during tests at the booster's manufacturer, Thiokol Corp. in Utah, according to Nagel. ``You would be hard pressed to see it with the naked eye,'' he said, but technicians will replace the Atlantis seal to be ``ultra-conservative.''

DOC.HEAD: Woman Accused Of Bigamy Pleads to Lesser Charge _ `Unlawful Imprisonment'
DOC.TEXT: A woman charged with bigamy for marrying two men in eight months pleaded to the lesser charge of unlawful imprisonment and was put on six months' probation. When asked how he selected the lesser charge, Assistant District Attorney Thomas Lenkiewicz replied, ``Obviously you've never been married,'' drawing a chuckle from spectators in the courtroom Wednesday. ``If bigamy is unlawful imprisonment, is a legal marriage lawful imprisonment?'' mused James Resti, who represented Debra Sprague, 23, of Syracuse. City Judge Jeffrey Merrill said if Ms. Sprague remains on good behavior for six months, he will dismiss the charge. Ms. Sprague declined to comment, other than to say that she is estranged from both husbands. She left the court with a boyfriend. Ms. Sprague was charged with bigamy in September 1988 for her marriage to Renzie T. Jay in July 1988. She had married William C. Sprague in December 1987. Sprague told Syracuse police he and his wife lived together off and on for about three weeks after their wedding before she began leaving home for weeks at a time. In August 1988, he found out from her mother that his wife had married again and contacted police. Neither husband was present in court Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Planetary Society Expands Its Quest for Alien Civilizations in Space
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `META II...,' to CLARIFY that McDonough works for Planetary Society sted SETI.
DOC.TEXT: A sophisticated radio receiver soon to be installed in Argentina will help scientists scan the whole universe as they expand their search for signals from intelligent aliens in space. ``One of the fundamental questions that has faced the human species throughout history is, `Are we alone? ... What is our place in the cosmos?''' said Louis Friedman, executive director of the non-profit Planetary Society. Tim Lynch, the group's program director, called the search for extraterrestrials ``almost spiritual because if we find there is another civilization somewhere else, it's evidence this planet can survive as well.'' The Planetary Society _ a Pasadena-based group that advocates space exploration _ raised $150,000 from its 125,000 members in 70 countries to pay for the high-tech radio signal analyzer, named Megachannel Extraterrestrial Assay II. META II, the size of two large refrigerators, will be flown to Argentina's Institute of Radioastronomy in two to three weeks, said Thomas McDonough, who coordinates the Planetary Society's part of the worldwide Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence program, known as SETI. Two Argentine engineers have been building the device at the Harvard-Smithsonian Oak Ridge Observatory in Harvard, Mass., west of Boston. Since 1985, the society's identical META receiver at the observatory has scanned the space visible from the Northern Hemisphere seeking a radio signal from an alien civilization. Steven Spielberg, director of the film ``E.T., the Extra-Terrestrial,'' donated $100,000 for the first META project. Since 1960, astronomers have conducted more than 50 separate but mostly limited searches for any radio waves that may have been intentionally beamed into space by extraterrestrials. Almost all previous searches listened to space visible from the Northern Hemisphere, with only brief, partial scans of Southern Hemisphere skies from Australia and the Argentine institute, located in a park 30 miles southeast of Buenos Aires. META II tests will start in June after the 8.4 million-channel receiver is hooked to one of the institute's two dish-shaped, 98-foot-wide radiotelescope antennas. By its dedication on Oct. 12 _ the holiday commemorating Christopher Columbus' discovery of the New World in 1492 _ the device will spend at least 12 hours daily for three or more years listening for signs that humanity is not alone. With both META receivers working, the Planetary Society will be conducting ``the first systematic search of the universe as a whole for signals from another civilization,'' McDonough said. ``This could be the system that makes the first contact with another civilization.'' ``There are so many stars like the sun that it's impossible to think the sun is the only one that has life on an orbiting planet,'' said Raul Colomb, director of the Argentine institute. Colomb discussed the META II project during visits to the Planetary Society on Tuesday and to NASA and the SETI Institute in Mountain View on Wednesday. Speaking in somewhat broken English, Colomb joked: ``I hope if we make contact, they (extraterrestrials) can understand Spanish, too.'' Scientists would know they discovered an alien civilization if they found an ultranarrow frequency signal that laws of physics say couldn't come from any natural phenomenon or Earthly source, McDonough said National Aeronautics and Space Administration scientists plan a more sophisticated SETI effort. They plan to start listening to the Northern Hemisphere in 1992 and the Southern Hemisphere no earlier than 1995, said Nick Renzetti, who heads the radioastronomy effort at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. But the 10-year, $100 million effort may lag because NASA budget increases are smaller than proposed, he added.

DOC.HEAD: Cosmonaut Takes Test Ride on `Space Motorcycle'
DOC.TEXT: Cosmonaut Alexander A. Serebrov cruised through space today on a special motorcycle designed to rescue spacemen in distress. It was the cycle's maiden voyage, and Soviet officials said it performed well. Soviet television interrupted its regular programs several times during the day for special coverage of the space ride, which took Serebrov as far as 33 yards from the orbiting Mir space station. Live pictures showed Serebrov attached to a tether anchored on Mir as he prepared to ride the cycle, which looks more like a floating armchair than a motorcycle. The device, formally known as the Cosmonaut Movement System, is similar to the Manned Maneuvering Unit that U.S. space shuttle astronauts have used, Soviet space officials say. It weighs 484 pounds, has 32 motors, and is designed to repair satellites and rescue spacemen. It can move to a maximum distance of 50 yards from Mir. The cycle was delivered to Mir on Dec. 6. Mission commander Alexander S. Viktorenko, 42, stayed at Mir's exit hatch and monitored the cycle's operations. He and Serebrov, the flight engineer, have been aboard Mir since September. The 20-ton Mir was launched in February 1988 and was designed to be permanently manned, but it was mothballed in April for four months because a module and another add-on were not ready, and because it would have cost too much money to keep a crew aboard. Mir already is joined with Kvant, an astrophysics laboratory.

DOC.HEAD: China's Communist Party Expels Leading Intellectual
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party has expelled a leading intellectual for joining in the spring pro-democracy movement, according to an official report that reached Beijing today. Wen Yuankai, a professor at the Chinese University of Science and Technology in the central city of Hefei, was expelled late last year, according to a local radio broadcast of Jan. 20. The broadcast was reported today by the British Broadcasting Corp.'s monitoring service. Wen made a speech in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in May supporting the students camped there to demand democratic change. He and other intellectuals urged the government to talk with the students. After the government imposed martial law in Beijing on May 20, he and other professors at his university appealed for it to be lifted. ``Wen Yuankai has obstinately adhered to the stand of bourgeois liberalization,'' the radio said. Bourgeois liberalism is the official term for Western democratic ideas. ``He went all out to advocate the need to increase openness and promote political restructuring,'' it said. ``He also vigorously plotted and egged on riots in the Hefei area. Both the nature and consequences of his mistakes are extremely serious.'' The radio said he had been expelled from the party in order to purify it. The Hong Kong newspaper Ming Pao reported recently that Wen was not under arrest but had to obtain permission to leave campus, and was writing a self-criticism, an essay that sets out one's thoughts and actions and expresses contrition. So far, the 48 million-member ruling party has publicly announced the expulsions of only about half a dozen prominent members due to their roles in the protests that were crushed in June. However, in many places party members are being required to re-register, giving party officials a chance to review their rolls and drop any members considered unacceptable. Top party leaders have stressed repeatedly since June the need to strengthen party discipline and expel any members who do not adhere to the party line. Party membership can be essential to professional advancement. Others who have been expelled from the party include Wan Runnan and Yan Jiaqi, who fled abroad and have helped form an exile organization to promote democratic reform in China.

DOC.HEAD: Three Supreme Court Members Present at State of Union
With PM-State of Union
DOC.TEXT: Only three of the Supreme Court's nine members showed up for President Bush's first State of the Union address. Four men in black robes were on hand for the speech Wednesday night, but they included retired Justice Lewis F. Powell. He was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices William J. Brennan and Antonin Scalia. No one at the court today could remember the last time the court lacked a quorum, six members, for the annual ceremony. The court is not in session this week, and Justices Byron R. White, Harry A. Blackmun, Sandra Day O'Connor and Anthony M. Kennedy are out of town. Justice Thurgood Marshall is here but chose to pass up the event.

DOC.HEAD: Tibetans in Delhi Demonstrate for Independence
LaserPhoto DEL1
DOC.TEXT: Scores of Tibetans held a demonstration in the capital today, demanding the withdrawal of Chinese troops from their homeland and the release of political prisoners. Carrying placards saying ``Tibet for Tibetans'' and ``Lift Martial Law in Tibet,'' the demonstrators gathered near Parliament House and burned the Chinese flag. The demonstrators later presented memorandums to Prime Minister V.P. Singh's office and the Chinese Embassy in New Delhi. China invaded Tibet in 1949 and annexed it a year later. The spiritual leader of Tibet, the Dalai Lama, fled to India after an abortive uprising against Chinese rule in 1959 and set up a government-in-exile. The Dalai Lama, who was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1989, lives in Dharamsala, a northern Indian town on the foothills of the Himalayas, along with about 100,000 followers. Martial law was imposed in Tibet on March 8, 1989, in an attempt to put down an uprising by pro-independence demonstrators. At least 20 people are believed to have been killed in the rioting and hundreds arrested.

DOC.HEAD: Construction Spending Shows Lowest Increase in Seven Years
DOC.TEXT: Construction spending, held back by severe weather, fell 0.6 percent in December, reversing a November gain and ending 1989 with the lowest increase in seven years, the government reported today. The Commerce Department said residential, non-residential and government construction spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $414.6 billion in December, the lowest rate since last June's 1 percent decline. For the year, spending totaled $414.7 billion, up 1.2 percent from 1988. The increase was the lowest since a 5.1 percent decline in the 1982 recession year. Spending increased 3 percent in 1988. Residential spending was pushed down 0.7 percent in December by a 2.8 percent decline in multi-family construction. Single-family spending was up 0.4 percent. Residential spending represents about 50 percent of the total. Non-residential spending was off 4.3 percent while government spending, which represents about 20 percent of the total, was up 2.9 percent, boosted by a 9.3 percent increase in highway and street expenditures. The decrease in December spending offset a 0.7 percent advance in November, which followed a 0.4 percent decline in October. The Novemer increase was revised downward from the 1.5 percent gain originally reported. For the year, residential spending declined 1.1 percent, non-residential gained 2.4 percent and government spending was up 3.8 percent. In addition to the effects of the unusually cold weather in December, construction was constrained throughout much of the year by high interest rates and fell to a yearly low of an annual rate of $410.3 billion last July. But as the Fed appeared to succeed in driving down inflation, it permitted rates to fall gradually in recent months and analysts have been saying the lower rates should result in increased construction. Residential spending in December totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $191 billion, including $134.9 billion on single-family housing and $20.6 billion on multi-family construction. Non-residential construction totaled $96.7 billion and government spending, $91.1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Clinic Blockades Don't Violate Women's Civil Rights
DOC.TEXT: Anti-abortion protesters who blockade entrances to women's clinics are not violating the civil rights of all prospective patients trying to get inside, a federal judge ruled. U.S. District Judge A. Wallace Tashima on Wednesday said clinics and pro-choice activists failed to prove in their lawsuit that the anti-abortion blockades were aimed at all women. ``The allegations ... clearly show that the (intent) is directed at women seeking abortions and not at pregnant women generally or at women as a class,'' Tashima said in an eight-page ruling. Tashima ruled in September that civil rights law did not protect women seeking abortions. Carol Sobel, an attorney with the American Civil Liberties Union, then amended the complaint to allege that the blockades violate the civil rights of all women, who would be discouraged from entering medical clinics offering services besides abortions. ``Plaintiffs confuse effect with motive,'' Tashima said. ``The class must be based on (intent), not effect.'' Ms. Sobel said she would appeal the ruling to the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals this week. She also vowed to request an emergency stay of Tashima's ruling, which lifted an order issued in March barring the blockades. ``I think the judge is wrong,'' Ms. Sobel said. ``You're talking about a conspiracy to deprive women of medical care that relates only to women.'' Operation Rescue, the anti-abortion group that staged clinic blockades nationwide, applauded the ruling, saying it affirmed the group's argument that its actions are aimed at abortion, not all women, said Victor Smith, an attorney for the group.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Say Bush Troop Proposal Step in Right Direction But Not Far Enough
With PM-State of Union, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's proposal for deeper troop cuts in Central Europe was a step in the right direction, but it failed to go far enough, Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said today. In a surprise overture, Bush proposed in his State of the Union message Wednesday a cut in military manpower in Europe to 195,000 troops on each side. The previous U.S. bargaining position at conventional force negotiations in Vienna was 275,000 on each side. ``It's a good sign that things are changing for the better,'' Gerasimov said in a news briefing. ``Some observers note that the events in Europe run ahead of the slow diplomatic negotiations.'' Gerasimov criticized the proposal for not going far enough. ``You can note in his speech that he needs American troops in Europe from here to eternity _ 125,000 or about this figure. This is not a good sign.'' ``We together with Les Aspin (chairman of the U.S. House Armed Services Committee) feel it must be the ceiling, not the floor.'' Bush said in his speech that he and the United States' European allies agree ``that an American military presence in Europe is essential _ and that it should not be tied solely for the Soviet military presence in Eastern Europe.'' Gerasimov also complained that the proposal applies only to troops in Central Europe and would leave the United States with 30,000 or more troops in Britain, Greece and other countries in Europe. ``So it comes out that the U.S. is to have 235,000 troops,'' Gerasimov said. This will have to be considered at the conventional arms talks in Vienna, he said. Gerasimov also complained that Bush seemed to take credit for the ``revolution of 1989,'' as the American president called it. He said attempts to show these events as a triumph of U.S. ideals and a failure of communism ``are a relic of the Cold War.'' He added that the U.S. invasion of Panama was further evidence of this attitude. In his speech, Bush said that the remarkable events of 1989 ``validate the long-standing goals of American policy _ a policy based on a single, shining principle: the cause of freedom. America _ not just the nation _ but an idea, alive in the minds of people everywhere.'' Overall, however, Gerasimov repeated that, ``We want to see in Bush's address a signal to use to the maximum the unique chance of 1990 to improve Soviet-American cooperation.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Troop Plan Welcomed in Western Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Soviet comment today. Pickup 5th graf, `British Prime ...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-State of Union, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: West European leaders today generally welcomed President Bush's proposals for troop withdrawals from Europe. But the West Europeans stressed that they wanted a continued U.S. military presence, and Britain said it hoped no further cuts were planned. In Moscow, the Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, Gennady Gerasimov, today called the proposal a step in the right direction, but he criticized it for failing to go far enough. ``You can note in his speech that he needs American troops in Europe from here to eternity _ 125,000 or about this figure. This is not a good sign,'' Gerasimov said. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said in a statement that she attached ``great importance to President Bush's assurance that the new figure will be a floor and that no more reductions are envisaged.'' ``This will ensure a continued strong American presence in Europe,'' the statement added. Thatcher aides said Bush telephoned her on Saturday to discuss the proposal. ``We indicated our support,'' the Downing Street statement said. Bush, in his State of the Union message Wednesday, proposed that Washington and Moscow cut troops levels in Central Europe to 195,000 on each side _ below the 275,000 figure being negotiated at talks in Vienna. The United States has 305,000 troops in Central Europe, and the Soviet Union has 565,000. Another 30,000 U.S. troops in Britain and southern Europe are excluded from the Bush proposal. A U.S. official has said Bush sent Lawrence Eagleburger, his deputy secretary of state, and Robert Gates, the deputy national security adviser, to present his plan to the leaders of Britain, France, West Germany and Italy. Having secured endorsement from these major West European nations, Bush then called Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev to inform him of the proposal. In West Germany, where most of the U.S. troops are deployed, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher called Bush's proposal ``an important step forward.'' West German Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg called it ``a balanced combination of disarmament policy and unequivocal recognition of the West's defense readiness and alliance solidarity.'' The enthusiasm reflected the eagerness with which West Germany is seeking reunification with East Germany. The caution in Britain and some of the other NATO allies in Europe underlined anxieties about the prospect of the American troops leaving, and about German reunification. There are 380,000 Soviet troops in East Germany. Manfred Woerner, secretary general of the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization, said in Brussels that the European allies offered their ``broad support in principle.'' Woerner said the Bush plan was consistent with U.S. promises ``to maintain significant military forces in Europe as necessary to alliance security.'' In Paris, French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas called the proposal ``an important step on the road to disarmament... Bush set an objective that takes into account at the same time Europeans' desire for disaramament and their security concerns.'' Some smaller West European nations followed Mrs. Thatcher's basically cautious line. ``There have to be talks on the withdrawal of troops, and I oppose a unilateral initiative,'' said Belgian Foreign Affairs Minister Mark Eyskens. Last week Belgium said it is considering pulling its troops out of West Germany because of the demise of hard-line Communist leaderships in countries across Eastern Europe. Dutch Foreign Minister Hans van den Broek considered a cutback to 195,000 troops would be the ``minimum level'' needed, Dutch television reported. A Dutch Foreign ministry statement said the proposed reductions were ``feasible'' because of the developments in Eastern Europe, but stressed the Soviets must match the American withdrawals. Norway's Foreign Minister Kjell Magne Bondevik said in a radio interview that ``the presence of U.S. troops in Europe is still needed. We don't see it as a problem if their presence would be at a lower level than now.''

DOC.HEAD: Stray Bullet Hits Man Watching `Rescue 911'
DOC.TEXT: Roy Lee Snelling Sr. was watching the television program ``Rescue 911'' when a stray bullet crashed through a window, an interior wall and his chair and struck him in the back. Moments later, his wife was calling 911. ``I was standing right beside him doing some ironing, when we heard a shot. My husband grabbed his chest and said, `I've been shot.' I though he was kidding at first, then I saw the blood,'' said his wife, Rosa Lee Snelling. The bullet narrowly missed Snelling's spine and lodged in his lower right lung, said Capt. Tim Martin of the Clay County sheriff's office. ``On television, they show them (medics) telling people to calm down and talk slowly. Well, they had to tell me to slow down, too,'' Mrs. Snelling said. Snelling was in stable condition today at Humana Hospital in nearby Orange Park. The gunshot apparently was fired from behind the Snelling's rural home and police theorize that someone may have been shooting at a road sign.

DOC.HEAD: Rain, Winds, Waves in West; Cold in Plains
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with Texas flooding, Mich. snow plus strike, Mont. conditions, recast and tighten, picking up at the 13th graf pvs, `A few...'.
DOC.TEXT: Cold Canadian air crept eastward today from the Northern Plains, where high temperatures were below zero in Montana and northwestern North Dakota, and heavy rain caused flooding in Texas. The rain, which also extended into Arkansas, triggered street flooding today in northern Texas with the Johnson County town of Alvarado reporting water more than a foot deep in some areas. Police in the Dallas-Fort Worth area rescued several motorists who drove into deep water covering roads and streets. No injuries were reported. Farther west, a storm system spread rain and snow along the Pacific Coast with winds gusting to 60 mph. The National Weather Service in San Francisco called a flood advisory after automated buoys showed offshore waves as high as 29 feet.
