Rain soaked much of the northern and central Pacific Coast, with snow falling in mountains as far east as Wyoming and northern Colorado. Wind of 30 to 40 mph, gusting near 60 mph ,was forecast for the Washington coast. Snoqualmie Pass in Washington picked up an additional 8 inches of snow Wednesday, giving ski areas that had bare slopes in the early season nearly 6 feet in the past week. Highway crews in northwestern Montana on Wednesday rescued several motorists trapped behind an avalanche measuring 100 feet wide and 5 feet deep on U.S. 2 near the Continental Divide. Part of the highway remained closed today because of blowing snow. Up to 19 inches of new snow had fallen in the Columbia Falls, Mont., area by Wednesday afternoon, whipped by northeasterly winds up to 40 mph. An additional 6 to 12 inches of snow was possible today, with wind chills expected as low as 70 below. At 7 a.m. MST today, Cut Bank, Mont., had a wind chill factor of 49 degrees below zero. Along the Great Lakes, 10 inches of snow had fallen on Michigan's Upper Peninsula around Sault Ste. Marie, but streets and side roads remained unplowed today because 65 employees of the Chippewa County road commission went on strike at midnight in a contract dispute. State crews plowed highways. Most schools in the area were closed. A cold front that crossed the Southwest dumped snow on parts of Arizona and Utah on Wednesday. Flagstaff, Ariz., received 8 inches Tuesday night and Wednesday. A few showers and thunderstorms developed along a cold front over southern Florida. The nation's high of 85 degrees Wednesday was set in McAllen, Texas, and in the Florida cities of Fort Myers, Miami, Naples and Vero Beach. The coldest reading in the Lower 48 on Wednesday was 22 below at International Falls, Minn. Circle City, Alaska, though, was much colder: minus 61. In Valdez, Alaska, more than 13 feet of snow fell in January. The community on Prince William Sound weathered a record one-day snow of 47{ inches on Jan. 16 and, as of Wednesday, was 8 inches away from breaking the snowfall accumulation record of 384.7 inches set in 1986-87. Other reports at 3 a.m. EST today: _EAST: Albany, N.Y., 17 fair; Atlanta 45 fair; Boston 32 fair; Buffalo 28; Charleston, S.C., 47 foggy; Chattanooga 34 fair; Cincinnati 42 partly cloudy; Cleveland 38 partly cloudy; Detroit 31 foggy; Hatteras 54 fair; Jacksonville 57 foggy; Key West 75 partly cloudy; Knoxville 34 fair; Macon 36 fair; Miami 75 fair; New York 36 fair; Philadelphia 36 fair; Pittsburgh 33 fair; Portland, Maine, 20 foggy; Richmond 32 fair; Tampa 66 foggy; Washington, D.C., 36 fair. _CENTRAL: Birmingham 53 fair; Bismarck 9 snow; Chicago 44 rain; Denver 28 fair; Des Moines 46 cloudy; Fort Worth 55; Indianapolis 40 cloudy; Kansas City 51 windy; Little Rock 51 foggy; Louisville 36 cloudy; Memphis 56 cloudy; Nashville 50 cloudy; New Orleans 59 foggy; North Platte 15 fair; Oklahoma City 51 drizzle; Omaha 32 windy; Rapid City 4 snow; St. Louis 52 cloudy; Minneapolis-St. Paul 21 cloudy; Sault Ste. Marie 26 snow; San Antonio 70 cloudy. _WEST: Albuquerque 32 fair; Anchorage 4 fair; Boise 32 snow; Casper 21 fair; Fairbanks -30 fair; Honolulu 72 fair; Las Vegas 40 fair; Los Angeles 55 cloudy; Medford 37 fair; Pendleton 42 cloudy; Phoenix 53 fair; Portland, Ore., 40 partly cloudy; Reno 35 partly cloudy; Salt Lake City 28 fair; San Diego 54 fair; San Francisco 45 windy; Seattle 40 showers; Spokane 29 snow. _INTERNATIONAL: Calgary 21 windy; Montreal 25 partly cloudy; Ottawa 25 foggy; Regina 21 fair; Toronto 28 foggy; Winnipeg 17 cloudy; Kingston 77; San Juan 73.

DOC.HEAD: Dukakis Blasts Bush on Boston Harbor
DOC.TEXT: President George Bush's concern for the pollution in Boston Harbor ended when he moved into the White House, complains Gov. Michael S. Dukakis. Bush made headlines in the presidential race when he chartered a boat for a tour of the historic harbor and blamed Dukakis for its pollution, but his new budget, unveiled Monday, leaves out $20 million that Congress had authorized for cleaning up the waterway. The campaign talk was a ``fraud,'' Dukakis, the unsuccessful 1988 Democratic nominee, said Wednesday. ``It was just a lot of political talk,'' Dukakis said. ``When push comes to shove, no money for Boston Harbor. Isn't that sad.'' The state is under a court order to clean the harbor, where the city of Boston and surrounding towns have dumped sewage for hundreds of years. It has repeatedly been rated among the nation's most-polluted waterways. In September 1988 Bush hired a ferry, filled it with reporters and supporters and cruised the harbor, accusing Dukakis of dallying while it got ``dirtier and dirtier.'' ``Two hundred years ago, tea was spilled in the Boston Harbor in the name of liberty,'' Bush had said. ``If tea were spilled in the Boston Harbor today, it would dissolve in the residue of my opponent's neglect and delay.'' Michael Deland, chairman of the president's Council on Environmental Quality, blamed the omission of funds on the tight federal budget. ``If there were surpluses of money around, that would be one thing,'' Deland said. ``But there are not.'' Back in 1988, Bush brushed aside the fact that the Environmental Protection Agency had taken three years to act on the state's requests for help with the harbor, saying he was more interested in directing attention to what he would do if president. The $20 million Bush left out of his budget would pay for a tunnel that would carry sewage to a new treatment plant. Paul Levy, who heads the agency responsible for the $6 billion harbor cleanup, said the state will have to try to persuade Congress to put the $20 million back in the budget. If Congress doesn't approve the money again, the bill will go to Boston-area residents, who already face escalating water and sewer costs, because the court order requires the state to build the tunnel, with or without the federal money. Dukakis said he isn't bitter. ``That's water over the dam, if you'll pardon the pun,'' Dukakis said.

DOC.HEAD: 68-year-old Sentenced for Operating Statewide Prostitution Ring in Florida
DOC.TEXT: A 68-year-old man has been sentenced to seven years in prison after pleading guilty to operating a prostitution ring involving dozens of prostitutes in at least 12 Florida cities. Roy Spears pleaded guilty Wednesday to one count of racketeering and six counts of deriving support from prostitution in the operation of the ring that prosecutors said he ran from 1985 to 1988. In exchange for his guilty plea, prosecutors agreed to dismiss 64 other charges. Circuit Judge Giles P. Lewis sentenced Spears to seven years in prison on the racketeering charge and five years on each of the six other charges. The sentences will run concurrently. With the 15 months Spears spent in jail while awaiting trial, Spears could serve as little as six to eight more months, said John Matthews, his attorney. Authorities said Spears earned about $1 million in a 16-month period from the ring, which operated as the A-Able Escort Service. Spears' girlfriend and co-defendant, Michelle Marie de Laurie, was sentenced in 1988 to four five-year terms in prison, all to run concurrently, and 10 years' probation. During a six-month investigation, authorities arrested 60 people who police said worked for the escort service.

DOC.HEAD: Troop Cuts Would Hit West Germany Hardest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `There was ...' to UPDATE with German reaction.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-State of Union, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: West Germany would be dealt the hardest economic blow by the large-scale U.S. troop cuts in Europe that President Bush proposed in his State of the Union speech. Bush proposed that U.S. and Soviet troops be reduced to 225,000 in Europe _ down to 195,000 in Central Europe _ because of the dizzying collapse of East bloc Communist regimes. About 250,000 U.S. servicemen are based in West Germany alone, with another 55,000 in Britain, Italy, Turkey and Greece. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher called Bush's proposal ``an important step forward.'' West German Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg called it ``a balanced combination of disarmament policy and unequivocal recognition of the West's defense readiness and alliance solidarity.'' The Cologne-based German Economics Institute reported in a July study that West Germany earns $5 billion a year from U.S. military expenditures. It warned that a troop pullout would mean ``economic collapse'' for regions that are heavily dependent on the American presence. An extensive analysis of the U.S. bases was undertaken because of the growing public tendency to see American troops as a burden, institute director for economic and scientific affairs Otto Vogel said at the time. There has been increasing support in recent months for troop cuts as a way to reduce tensions in Europe and move the German states closer to reunification now that the Communists in East Germany no longer have a monopoly on power. East Germany is the Kremlin's most critical military ally, and about 400,000 of the 565,000 Soviet troops in Europe are stationed in the country. The Kremlin does not want to lose its front-line bases in East Germany, but it has indicated it could accept a neutral state. Communist Premier Hans Modrow was in Moscow meeting with Kremlin leaders this week but there was no word on whether they discussed the extremely sensitive topic of reducing Soviet troops in East Germany. As they move away from four decades of Kremlin domination, Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia are pushing for the complete withdrawal of Soviet troops from their territory. None of the three are considered nearly as crucial to Soviet security as East Germany. West Germany is under pressure to remain in NATO and keep troops as part of its commitment to the Western defense alliance. The troops, however, are an obstacle to reunification. Last May, Bush proposed a 275,000 ceiling on U.S. and on Soviet forces in Central Europe and said negotiations to reach that goal should be wrapped up within a year. Before now, Bush has said he would not support further cuts until the current talks were wrapped up. But, a senior administration official said, ``Events were running ahead of the negotiations.''

DOC.HEAD: Greensboro Celebrates 30th Anniversary of Woolworth Sit-Ins
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs the 20th-21st grafs, `Following today's...', with 2 grafs to UPDATE with march and dedication. Picks up 21st graf, `An awards...'. SUBS 8th graf, `We were...', to CORRECT `coke to `Coke.'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto GBO1
DOC.TEXT: The four blacks who were denied service at an all-white Woolworth lunch counter 30 years ago were greeted today by a black Woolworth vice president before sitting down to a breakfast of eggs, grits, bacon and coffee. David Richmond, Franklin McCain, Jibreel Khazan and Joseph McNeil entered the store at 7:30 a.m. and, surrounded by dozens of reporters and onlookers, ordered from two women who had been working there on Feb. 1, 1960. Three of the men wore business suits. Khazan, formerly Ezell Blair Jr., wore a white robe with a headband around his dreadlocks. They were greeted by Woolworth Vice President Aubrey Lewis, who noted that 30 years ago he, too, would have been denied service. ``I'm proud you had the courage to open the doors for a movement,'' Lewis said. While the four waited for their meals, some onlookers began singing ``We Shall Overcome.'' Outside the store there was more singing directed by the NAACP and some bystanders carried placards saying, ``Feb. 1, 1960. It seems like only yesterday but it could be tomorrow'' and ``The only thing that's worthwhile is change _ Remembering Feb. 1, 1960.'' Back in 1960, public buildings in Greensboro had separate water fountains for whites and blacks. Theaters had separate entrances for blacks, who were forced to sit in balconies, away from whites. Blacks had to step to the rear on city buses. When the four, all freshmen at North Carolina A&T State University, refused to leave the counter 30 years ago, their sit-in touched off protests in nine states and helped ignite the civil rights movement. ``We were scared,'' McCain recalled. ``I just wanted a Coke and a doughnut. That's all I wanted.'' ``We did get some encouragement on the first day and we got it from quarters you wouldn't ordinarily expect it to come from,'' he said. ``There was a little old white lady of oh, 75 years of age, who came over and placed hands on our shoulders and said to us, `Boys, I'm so proud of you. The only thing I regret is that it didn't happen 20 years earlier.' ``That was really a source of inspiration to us.'' Geneva Tisdale, a black working at Woolworth that day, said she never envisioned the scope of the events. ``I never thought they were serious,'' she said. The other counter worker, Ima Edwards, agreed, saying, ``I just thought they came in to try something. I didn't see it blossoming into this.'' Ms. Edwards, who is white, said that, in retrospect, the demonstrations were worthwhile. ``This is something that should be,'' she said. ``No race should be discriminated against where they can't come in somewhere to eat.'' In his book, ``Civilities and Civil Rights,'' Duke University historian William Chafe said the Woolworth sit-ins helped ignite the civil rights movement. ``The long road that would lead from Greensboro to Selma to Black Power and beyond had found its starting point,'' he wrote. Selma was the site of an important 1965 march for black voting rights. Chafe's 1980 book was the subject of a panel discussion at the University of North Carolina-Greensboro on Wednesday night, the start of a five-day commemoration. ``People are coming in from everywhere,'' said Hal Sieber, a member of the organizing committee. ``Everybody's all charged up and ready to go.'' Following today's re-enactment, about 400 people marched from North Carolina A&T State University to the Woolworth store, where a plaque and footprints were dedicated and the name of that section of street was changed from Sycamore to February One Place. Later in the day, organizers planned to unveil a sculpture marking the event at the university. An awards banquet and a jazz concert featuring trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie also were scheduled. Before going to Woolworths in 1960, the four agreed they would be courteous and would not miss any classes. They also agreed it would be a non-violent demonstration. They targeted Woolworths because it was a national chain that allowed its lunch counters to be segregated only in the South. The four were prepared to go to jail, but police allowed them to go back to school. That night, news about the sit-in spread quickly across the campus. The next day, more than two dozen male and female students showed up at the lunch counter. They, too, were denied service. On the third day, the demonstrations spread to the Kress five-and-dime down the street. The sit-ins quickly became national news. Gov. Luther Hodges was not sympathetic, calling the sit-ins ``counterproductive'' and a threat to law and order. Crowds began gathering outside the store to watch the students. Hecklers _ including some members of the Ku Klux Klan _ taunted them. For several months, the owners of downtown Greensboro restaurants refused to change their whites-only policy, fearing integration would drive away white customers. On July 25, 1960, Woolworth agreed to allow blacks at the lunch counter. Later accounts reported the chain lost about $200,000 in business during the sit-ins.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says Power Doesn't Bring Fulfillment
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III said today that after nine years close to Washington's power center, he has found ``power doesn't really bring the fulfillment that many think it does.'' Baker told a roomful of politicians and diplomats at the annual National Prayer Breakfast that ``inner security and true, real fulfillment comes by faith. It doesn't come by wielding power in a town where power is king.'' President Bush, in brief remarks at the breakfast where Baker was keynote speaker, said, ``I am convinced that the 1990s will be the decade of the rebirth ... of faith and hope.'' The rapid opening of communist nations in Eastern Europe helped lead to that conviction, he said. Bush also said, ``A truly religious nation is a tolerant nation. We cherish dissent. We cherish the fact that we have many, many faiths. And we protect even the rights of disbelief.'' Baker said he used to think that being a success meant never admitting hurt or problems, but that changed several years ago. He said at that time he was having a particularly difficult problem and his wife, Susan, helped him pray and see that ``I really needed to stop trying to play God and turn the matter over to faith.'' Baker, a former Treasury secretary and chief of staff under President Reagan, described his own religious feelings, revealing a seldom-seen side of a man with a smooth demeanor who usually seems to keep his feelings tightly controlled. Baker said he gains strength from prayer and from regular meetings ``for fellowship'' with a small group of ``very normal guys who just happen to hold positions of power and influence in Washington.'' The group supports one another in ``trying to live a life of faith,'' he said. Baker characterized himself as ``just one person genuinely struggling to put faith into practice in my life.'' Living in a city of power and politics, he said he has learned that ``Power, of course, can be intoxicating, it can be addictive and few doubt that .. power tends to corrupt and absolute power corrupts absolutely.'' ``Over these last nine years, I have had opportunities to participate in the exercise of more power than I ever would have imagined. I have felt the weight of responsibility that that brings and I have to admit to you as well that I have felt the temptations that are attendant to it,'' Baker siad. ``I found early on that having a position of power really doesn't bring the fulfillment that many people think it does,'' he said. ``Of course it does bring excitment. It brings a sense of satisfaction when things go well, disappointment when they don't, and it brings invitations to some of the most exclusive gatherings in the world.'' However, he said, ``For someone who likes to go to bed at 9:30 at night, that is not necessarily a plus.''

DOC.HEAD: Front Proposes Giving Interim Parliament Veto Power Over Its Actions
DOC.TEXT: The revolutionary government today proposed the creation of an interim ``mini-parliament'' with veto power over the ruling council until Romania's first free postwar elections May 20. The 11-member ruling council is the executive arm of the National Salvation Front, which took power in the vacuum after the December revolution that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. The front and 28 opposition parties clamoring for a share of power participated in talks which the leading body said were aimed at giving the opposition a role in the government. The National Salvation Front said it is ``to be open for participation by all parties.'' It also said the method of expanding it will be ``given the finishing touches'' during continuing talks with opposition groups. The front leaders said the ``mini-parliament'' would be composed of three members from each party and would have a majority-vote veto power over the decisions of the 11-member ruling council. In the communique, however, the front did not give any time frame for the establishment of the interim parliament body. Also today, testimony continued against four of Ceausescu's top aides during the fourth day of their trial before a military tribunal on charges of complicity to commit genocide. The four are former Communist Party Secretary Emil Bobu, third in the Ceausescu hierarchy after the dictator and his wife, former Interior Minister Tudor Postelnicu and former Politburo members Manea Manesacu and Ion Dinca. The charge stems from the shooting of demonstrators in Timisoara and other Romanian cities, causing the revolution that ousted and then executed Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, in December. The defendants face a maximum penalty of life in prison.

DOC.HEAD: $1.3 Million in Stolen Goods Recovered in Utah Police Sting
DOC.TEXT: The office that appeared to be a fencing operation for buying stolen goods and drugs was really an 18-month-long police sting that drew 135 suspects, officials say. About $1.3 million in stolen goods was purchased for $70,000 during the undercover operation run by several law agencies, officials said. Goods netted included 130 vehicles; more than $20,000 worth of jewelry; power tools; a pickup truck full of sportswear; appliances; about 100 firearms _including sawed-off shotguns, assault rifles and a hand grenade _ and a human eye. In all, 135 suspects were sought on state and federal charges, Tommy Wittman, agent in charge of the Salt Lake office of the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms said at a news conference where many of the confiscated items were displayed. West Valley City Police Department spokeswoman Marsha Campbell said today that at least 62 people had been served warrants since officers began issuing them early Wednesday. Half of the suspects were already in custody on other charges. The sting was run by the West Valley City and Salt Lake City police departments and the federal ATF bureau, with assistance from other agencies. It operated out of two phony businesses _ Industrial Motor Repair in South Salt Lake and Damaged Freight Haulers in West Valley. A stolen Christmas tree was fenced during the holiday season, and undercover officers buying morphine from a nursing student also bought a human eye that had been taken from the University of Utah Medical Center. The agents bought $16,445 in heroin, morphine, cocaine, methamphetamine, valium and marijuana and learned the locations of six methamphetamine laboratories in the area, Wittman said. Sgt. Charles Illsley of the Major Felony Unit said 95 percent of the suspects were trading in stolen goods to obtain money for drugs. ``Three had `priors' for homicide. ... The worst one had 11 felony convictions,'' he said. U.S. Attorney Dee Benson said the probe's 26 federal indictments all involved narcotics and firearms charges. The sting was the third in the county since 1985. In August 1986, a similar operation resulted in the arrest of 24 people and the recovery of more than $500,000 in stolen goods. The second sting ended in January 1988 with the arrests of 50 people and the recovery of more than $400,000. West Valley Assistant Police Chief Terry Keefe said undercover officers became friendly with many suspects, sometimes were introduced to their families and in one case helped them move in the middle of the night. A female officer portraying a receptionist got a marriage proposal from one suspect. Wittman said the suspects were not entrapped. ``Enticement yes, probably. But not entrapment,'' Wittman said. ``These people had already stolen the property when they came to us. We did not provide shopping lists.''

DOC.HEAD: Hakim Gets Two Years Probation; $5,000 Fine
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with amount to be returned, reax from Hakim
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge today placed Iran-Contra figure Albert Hakim on two years' probation and fined him $5,000. The businessman who controlled the money in the scandal agreed to hand over to the U.S. government $7.3 million from the secret arms sales to Iran frozen in Swiss bank accounts. U.S. District Court Judge Gerhard Gesell imposed probation following Hakim's Nov. 21 guilty plea to a misdemeanor charge of helping to supplement Oliver North's government salary by arranging to pay for a $13,800 security system at North's home. ``The American public has had enough of this soap opera,'' Hakim said after his court appearance. Hakim is another in a string of Iran-Contra defendants who have escaped prison time. ``Very substantial funds _ measured in the millions of dollars _ which have been frozen'' in Swiss bank accounts ``have now been released to the United States by you,'' Gesell announced. The amount to be turned over to the government is $7.3 million, said Mary Belcher, a spokeswoman for the office of independent counsel Lawrence Walsh. She said Hakim will retain $1.7 million, which he will split with Swiss-based lawyers Willard Zucker and Philippe Neyroud. Gesell also said the Iranian-born Hakim had secured the release of David Jacobsen, a U.S. hostage held in Lebanon, and is cooperating with Iran-Contra prosecutors in a new criminal investigative matter. Gesell noted that Jacobsen, the former hostage, had written the judge on behalf of Hakim. The judge said that while others ``have taken credit for'' freeing the hostage, it was Hakim's conduct that actually achieved it. At the request of the Justice Department, the Swiss government froze some $7.8 million held in accounts of the ``Enterprise,'' the maze of offshore companies and bank accounts Hakim and his business partner, retired Air Force Maj. Gen. Richard Secord, set up to handle money in the Iran-Contra affair. The money has accrued some $1.2 million in interest. Gesell placed one of Hakim's companies, Panamanian-based Lake Resources Inc., on probation and ordered that the corporation be dissolved. Lake Resources had pleaded guilty to a charge of theft of government property in the diversion of Iran arms sales profits to the Contras. Outside the courthouse, Hakim said, ``I have been abused by two presidents'' and criticized Iran-Contra prosecutors. ``I'm talking about President Reagan and President Walsh,'' he said, referring to the former president and Walsh, who directed Hakim's prosecution. ``Our judicial system has been used as a tool by the politicians for their own gain,'' said Hakim. ``On top of this list of the politicians is President Walsh and his Cabinet known as IC (independent counsel) and his staff.'' ``They accused me of being an arms dealer. I am not,'' said the businessman. Hakim's lawyer, Richard Janis said the prosecution of Hakim was ``an abuse. After 22 months of indictment and expenditure of $100 million they brought an indictment that no other prosecutor would have taken to court.'' Iran-Contra prosecutors filed a sentencing memo Monday saying Hakim has agreed to provide them with testimony in ``an anticipated future case'' being investigated by a grand jury outside Washington. The prosecutors did not elaborate, but called his cooperation ``of significant value.'' Gesell called Hakim's assistance to Iran-Contra prosecutors ``exceptional'' and ``in sharp contrast to any other of the defendants who have been at one time or another before me in ... the Iran-Contra ... case.'' The judge was referring to North, Secord and former National Security Adviser John Poindexter, who is scheduled to go on trial Feb. 20. ``You are the only one who ... was not an officer or former officer of the U.S. government,'' said the judge. ``Indeed, you were brought in ... by the U.S. government.'' The judge said Hakim's business interests have been hurt and that ``you have suffered substantially.'' The question of who owns the proceeds from the Iran-Contra affair has lingered since the scandal erupted in November 1986. In the secret Iran arms sales, the U.S. government was paid the cost of the weapons it sold to the Iranians. But the ``Enterprise'' charged Iran exorbitant prices for the arms, with the difference being kept in the accounts controlled by Hakim. Several million dollars were diverted to the Contras fighting the leftist government of Nicaragua. Other money was set aside for profits for Hakim, Secord and arms dealer Thomas Clines, congressional investigators found. Some of the money also was supposed to be funneled to other covert programs, according to testimony from North, the former White House aide convicted in the affair.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Offers Soviet Reformers Full Support
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III, bound for high-level talks next week in Moscow, today offered Soviet reformers the full support of the Bush administration in revamping their political and economic system. Baker told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that the democratic revolution sweeping eastern Europe could be stalled or even reversed ``if we fail to support the principles that brought us this far.'' Baker, who will hold talks next week in Moscow with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and possibly with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, outlined U.S. foreign policy objectives to the committee. The principal items on Baker's Moscow agenda are accelerating arms control agreements, seeking a solution to the war in Afghanistan between the Soviet-backed Marxist government and U.S.-armed Moslem Fundamentalist rebels, and human rights. ``We seek a more democratic Soviet Union where human rights gains are made permanent,'' Baker said. He told the committee the administration would offer technical cooperation to assist the Soviet perestroika program of restructuring the country's sluggish economy. ``In short,'' Baker said, ``we seek to probe for points of mutual advantage with the Soviet Union, turning areas of conflict into areas of cooperation wherever possible. In this way we will benefit ourselves as well as the reformers in Moscow.'' His testimony followed an announcement by President Bush Wednesday night in his State of the Union address that the United States is proposing to reduce U.S. and Soviet troops in Europe to 225,000 each with a sub-ceiling of 195,000 in central Europe. That could mean bringing about 80,000 American troops home. A differing view was voiced by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., who said Gorbachev was a ``colorful and adroit public relations man'' whose concept of reform excludes freedom. Helms said Gorbachev had delivered MiG fighter jets to Cuba and missiles to Nicaragua and, at home, had undertaken 15 strategic weapons programs as part of ``a massive military buildup.'' Baker sounded a note of caution, saying ``the old world of dogmatic dictatorships is on its way out. But the new world of secure, prosperous and just democracies is not yet here. It will not arrive automatically.'' ``If we fail to support the principles that brought us this far, we could end up living in a future that resembles the past _ the past of Cold War and the conflicts that preceded it,'' he said. In the text of his prepared statement, Baker criticized ``the tragic case of China'' as a place where democratic values were suppressed. However, when he read the statement to the committee, he skipped a reference to China in speaking of ``governments that try to shut out democratic values.'' On specific issues elsewhere in the world, Baker: _ Said he aimed in trying to set up Middle East negotiations to fulfill ``the legitimate political rights of the Palestinian people.'' Here, Baker gave no clues what the administration sought to accomplish for Palestinians or if he will be able to get the negotiations started. _ Said there would be no cut in U.S. aid to Israel and Egypt. Together, Baker said, they are due to receive $5.1 billion for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. That represents about 61 percent of the U.S. foreign aid budget.

DOC.HEAD: Premier Resigns, Reformers Split From Communist Party
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to ADD possible effect of Cabinet's resignation, number of Cabinet members. Pickup 9th pvs, `Atanassov, a...
DOC.TEXT: Premier Georgi Atanassov and his Cabinet resigned today, an official source said, in a development could lead to creation of a new government including opposition figures for the first time in more than 40 years. Atanassov was a holdover from the era of disgraced leader Todor Zhivkov and had come under increased pressure to resolve Bulgaria's labor strife. The resignation of Atanassov and his 22-member Cabinet was not announced publicly, and the source spoke on condition of anonymity. Also today, a spokesman for a reform-minded alliance in the Communist Party announced that his faction had given up trying to change the party from within and would break away to create a socialist party. The Alternative Socialist Alliance will formally create the Bulgarian Socialist Party at a special congress in Sofia on Feb. 11, said spokesman Nikolai Vassilev. Atanassov's resignation had been widely expected because of several personal attacks on him during an emergency Communist Party conference under way. It was not immediately known when a new government would be named. The president and Communist Party chief, Petar Mladenov, has held out the possibility of creating an interim government to share power with opposition groups before elections. However, the proposed government has not been made clear. The opposition Union of Democratic Forces has said the terms and power of such an interim Cabinet must be clarified before they would agree to participate. Opposition spokesman Petar Beron reiterated that today, but his comments were made before the report of the Cabinet's resignation. Until a new government is formed, the country will apparently be run by Mladenov and a rubber-stamp Parliament. Atanassov, a member of the Communist Party policy-making Politburo, became premier in March 1986. He survived the Nov. 10 ouster of Zhivkov, apparently because he sided with the Politburo colleagues who engineered the end of the authoritarian leader's 35 years in power. But Atanassov was not able to come up with an effective solution for Bulgaria's economic problems or escape the shadow of Zhivkov, now under arrest on criminal charges. Bulgaria has been hit during the last two weeks with uprecedented labor stoppages by workers demanding better pay. Demonstrators on Sunday demanded Atanassov's resignation and a government of ``national accord.'' Teachers walked out as the congress opened Tuesday. Miners who struck last week resumed work Wednesday but continued negotiations with the government. Doctors struck for one hour Tuesday, two hours Wednesday, and announced plans to quit working for three hours today. Official media carried a report quoting agricultural workers as saying they would strike Feb. 5 unless the state paid adequate prices for their crops. Despite Zhivkov's ouster, Bulgaria's Communists have given up relatively little power, compared with their comrades elsewhere in Eastern Europe. The party is bolstered by its roots in the nation's politics and by a relatively weak, although growing, opposition. But the emergency congress of the Communist Party, which resumed today, demonstrated the deepening gulf between the hard-line and reform camps who favor more drastic action to break with the past. ``Even before the congress it was clear to us because this is a lost congress,'' said Vassilev, a Sofia University philosophy and anthropology professor. ``We knew who the delegates were and how they were elected,'' he added. ``It was quite clear for us that a radical change to the left would be impossible.'' Poland's Communist Party suffered a similar division when the most radical reformers split from the mainstream at a congress that concluded Monday. Vassilev predicted that within three months, about 150,000 of the 980,000 Communist Party members in Bulgaria would rally around the new party. ``But the Communist Party will not only lose these people, it will also lose people who do not want to stay in any party,'' he said. The new party will have a socialist orientation, Vassilev said, adding, ``We seek our roots in the social practice and achievements of the socialist movement.''

DOC.HEAD: Expectant Mother Charged With Child Abuse Goes to Court
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with dismissal motion denied, CLARIFY in 11th graf pvs that arrests in other states in many cases were of new mothers, sted pregnant women. Picks up 12th graf pvs, `Some of...'.
DOC.TEXT: A judge refused today to dismiss charges against a pregnant woman accused of abusing her unborn child by consuming alcohol in spite of an earlier court order. At issue in the case is whether the legal system should protect fetuses from the actions of their mothers. Judge Robert Denhardt's refusal to dismiss the charge against Diane Pfannenstiel, 29, was at the start of a preliminary hearing that could last two days. The defense had argued that the child abuse statutes under which Pfannenstiel was charged do not apply to fetuses. Albany County Attorney Cal Rerucha alleged in the charge filed in early January that Pfannenstiel, who is four to five months pregnant, consumed alcohol ``in an excessive amount which she knows will cause serious physical injury upon her unborn child.'' But Mary Beth Galvan, attorney for Pfannenstiel, believes Wyoming's child abuse laws don't apply to fetuses and that the charges are unconstitutional. ``Whether or not a fetus is defined as a child is a question for the Legislature to decide, not for us,'' Galvan said in an interview this week. Galvan had asked Denhardt to dismiss the case on grounds of vagueness. But she said she was so intrigued with what prompted Rerucha to charge Pfannenstiel that she has subpoenaed him to testify about how he reached his decision. According to court records, the charge against Pfannenstiel was filed two months after another judge ordered her to remain alcohol-free. That judge's unusual intervention followed a previous pregnancy that produced a baby suffering from fetal alcohol syndrome, a leading cause of mental retardation and other developmental problems, according to court records. Robert Horowitz, associate director of the American Bar Association's Center for Children and the Law in Washington, said he was unaware of any similar cases that have led to convictions that have withstood appeal. Drug use, particularly cocaine, has led to arrests of pregnant women or new mothers in some states. Crack cocaine use by pregnant women has led to several arrests in Florida on charges of delivering cocaine to newborn babies since the first successful conviction in August. But that case is still on appeal. Some of those watching the case believe the woman should not be prosecuted because of an addiction, if one exists. Patricia Schene, director of the American Association for Protecting Children in Denver, said that rather than prosecuting Pfannenstiel, Rerucha should try to help her. ``She's as much a victim as the child,'' she said. Pfannenstiel was charged after going to police to have her husband charged with battery. While she was being treated at a hospital, a blood test revealed she had a blood alcohol level of 0.1 percent, Galvan said. That is level considered at which a person is considered intoxicated under state law. Asked if Pfannenstiel is an alcoholic, Galvan replied: ``There is no diagnosis in the record that I am aware of.'' Galvan wondered what would happen if Pfannenstiel is convicted and sentenced to five years in prison _ and five months from now gives birth to a healthy baby? She said Rerucha will be hard-pressed to prove his case. ``It requires that an actual injury be shown. Harm has to have resulted,'' she said. Rerucha maintained that prosecutors shouldn't have to wait until a child is born with defects. ``The damage is done by that time,'' he said in an interview.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors to Consider Death Penalty for Sims
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE lawyer saying woman has lost will to live, but request for postponement denied. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `We cannot...'.
DOC.TEXT: A judge refused today to delay a death penalty hearing for a woman convicted of the murder of her 6-week-old daughter after her attorney said she had lost the will to live. Madison County Circuit Judge Andy Matoesian said he believed Paula Marie Sims was capable of proceeding. ``The defendant wants to be sentenced to death and is therefore unable to assist in her defense,'' argued Mrs. Sims' attorney, Donald Groshong. ``She is substantially different since her conviction.'' Mrs. Sims, 30, was convicted Tuesday in the death of 6-week-old Heather Lee Sims. Jurors were to hear further arguments today before deciding whether to impose the death penalty or a lesser sentence. They deliberated about two hours Wednesday before finding Mrs. Sims eligible for the death penalty. Under Illinois law, prosecutors may seek the death penalty under certain circumstances, including cases in which the victim is under the age of 12, the killing is particularly brutal, or when there are multiple victims. Groshong asked today that the sentencing hearing be delayed until psychiatric evaluations of Mrs. Sims can be made. ``She still maintains her innocence, but says, `I don't have any reason to go on, I don't have any reason to live. Whether I'm innocent doesn't matter _ they can go ahead and execute me,''' Groshong said. But Matoesian said he has ``no bona fide doubt as to her sanity'' and denied the request. He also denied a defense request that a new jury be named for the death penalty hearing. Mrs. Sims, of Alton, contends a masked gunman abducted Heather Lee last year, just as her 13-day-old firstborn daughter, Loralei, was abducted three years earlier. No murder charges have been filed in Loralei's death. Assistant Madison County State's Attorney Donald Weber argued Wednesday that the death penalty was warranted in the April 29 suffocation of Heather because the slaying was planned and the crime was ``cruel, brutal, grossly ruthless and devoid of mercy and compassion.'' ``We cannot say the death of this child was premeditated, prolonged or torturous,'' Groshong told the jury. ``In the pecking order of evil ... smothering is usually considered more merciful than other forms of killing.'' The jury found Mrs. Sims guilty Tuesday of first-degree murder, obstructing justice and concealing a homicide in Heather's death. She also faces charges of obstruction of justice and concealment of a homicide in the death of Loralei. Weber said he thought the jury was strongly influenced by evidence Mrs. Sims and her husband, Robert, only wanted male babies. Their son, Randy, who turns 2 today, remains in the custody of Sims, 37, who has not been charged in either case. The Simses reported Heather was abducted April 29 from their home in Alton. Her body was found May 3 in a trash barrel across the Mississippi River in nearby West Alton, Mo. An autopsy indicated she had been suffocated and her body subsequently frozen. Loralei was reported abducted June 17, 1986, from the Simses' former home in Brighton. A badly decomposed body believed to be Loralei's was found a week later 150 yards from the house.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Warn of Pirated Report Cards After Teen Walks Off With Blanks
DOC.TEXT: School officials warned parents to closely inspect their children's report cards after a youngster strolled into city offices and persuaded a clerk to hand over a stack of blank report cards. School officials say the hoax started when someone identifying herself as a high school teacher called the city's general accounting office and said she needed 65 blank report cards. A teen-age girl then showed up at the office, announcing to an unsuspecting clerk, ``I'm here to pick up the report cards.'' The clerk handed over a stack of blank report cards. ``We're afraid report card security was breached,'' said school superintendent Guy DiBiasio. ``We want to be sure that parents aren't being fooled by a pirated copy.'' School officials were not sure if the stunt was part of a student's attempt to deceive her parents at report card time. In any event, DiBiasio advised parents that all official report cards bear the names of Mayor Joseph Santopietro, City Clerk Patricia Carrah and Comptroller Donald Reilly. ``We have reason to belive that is was a little `report card-gate,''' DiBiasio said.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Say Bush Address Shortchanges Domestic Needs
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs pvs grafs 7-8, Gennady Gerasimov, with Soviet reaction.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's call for faster troop cuts in Europe drew praise in Congress and abroad today, but House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said Democrats want a greater commitment at home to allow the United States ``to reclaim our place in the world.'' Democrats are ``in agreement that we ought to reduce our troops in Europe. I think everyone sees there is a change in need there,'' Foley said today on NBC's ``Today'' show. ``The question is, how are we going to fight the new battles of the new decade?'' Foley said. ``The challenges of the next decade, into the next century, are much more here at home.'' ``As Democrats, we're not satisfied with a trend that has seen this nation drop from first to sixth in standard of living,'' Foley said Wednesday night in the party's official response to Bush's first State of the Union message. ``I am heartened'' by the proposed troop cut, Senate Majority Leader George J. Mitchell, D-Maine, said today. He added that several Democrats had been calling for such reductions for months only to be rebuffed by the administration. On domestic issues, Mitchell said Bush has consistently employed good-sounding rhetoric in addressing education ``and just as consistently failed to match those words with deeds. It will be up to Congress to supply the deeds to match the president's rhetoric on education.'' Gennady Gerasimov, the Soviet foreign ministry spokesman, said Bush's proposal for deeper troop cuts in Central Europe was a move in the right direction, but did not go far enough. ``It's a good sign that things are changing for the better,'' Gerasimov said in a briefing in Moscow. But, he said, ``you can note in his speech that he needs American troops in Europe from here to eternity _ 125,000 or about this figure. This is not a good sign.'' In Brussels, Belgium, Manfred Woerner, secretary-general of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, said Bush's plan underscore the American commitment ``to maintain significant military forces in Europe as necessary to alliance security.'' ``These new steps take account of new political developments in the East while remaininig consistent with the needs of the alliance's strategy of deterrence,'' Woerner said in a statement. ``The allies are on board,'' White House Chief of Staff John Sununu said on ``CBS This Morning.'' In his speech Wednesday night, Foley promised that Democrats, who control both houses of Congress, will work with Bush ``wherever and whenever we can'' but will fight the president when necessary to protect ``the people who go to work and pay the taxes.'' He scoffed at Bush's call for a ``meager'' 2 percent rise in education spending, and said Democrats will battle the administration this year on legislation dealing with capital gains taxes, child care and clean air. Sununu this morning criticized Foley's comments on proposed education spending, calling it ``a perfect example of the quality of the criticism that's come forward. You had Speaker Foley on there talking about a 2 percent increase,'' Sununu said, maintaining that proposed spending for new programs is up 6 percent to 7 percent. ``The time has come for America to help herself, to rebuild, to re-energize, to reinvigorate our hopes, to gather together our talents and to reclaim our place in the world,'' Foley said Wednesday night. But Bush's 11th-hour addition of the U.S.-Soviet troop-cut proposal was widely lauded by lawmakers who had been deriding his new budget just two days earlier. ``Just when you thought you had a Cold War budget _ boom,'' said Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo. ``I'm really delighted. There's hope.'' ``Very positive,'' said Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee. Rep. Les Aspin, the Democratic chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said ``the president should be congratulated'' for the plan. ``Trying to negotiate lower limits on forces deployed in Europe is clearly a good idea,'' said the Wisconsin Democrat. Sen. John Warner of Virginia, ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee, said troop cuts would lessen tensions and ``pave the way for an eventual peace dividend.'' Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., said that after hearing the speech ``I felt better than I have in years.'' ``This was the real George Bush, talking about the real issues that concern the American people,'' said Sen. Harry Reid, D-Nev. ``I hope the people around the president don't try to interfere with what he's trying to do.'' Sen. Mark O. Hatfield, R-Ore., said Bush's speech was full of ``bold new initiatives'' on military forces, education and the environment. But many Democrats found plenty to criticize about Bush's domestic agenda. The capital gains cut ``is the clearest sign of the president's misplaced pririties,'' said Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass. ``Trickle-down economics is not the way to rebuild America's strength; investing in America does not mean tax cuts for the wealthy.'' Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., said Bush's agenda contains ``no bold initiatives, just tinkering,'' and little ``to reverse the drastic trend to leave behind a vast portion of America.'' On Social Security, ``the president's position is going to be clearly the only acceptable political position _ saying that nothing affecting benefits can be considered,'' said House Republican Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia. There was applause for Bush's statement that ``the last thing we need to do is mess around with Social Security,'' but lawmakers wondered about such specifics as the budget deficit. ``You're for motherhood and apple pie when you oppose cutting Social Security benefits,'' said Sen. Charles Robb, D-Va. But on the budget deficit Bush's ``credibility may take a beating,'' Robb aid. Bush's announcement of six national goals for improving education was praised, but Rep. Augustus F. Hawkins, D-Calif., said it wasn't backed up with the ``genuine commitment'' of money. Hawkins, chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee, said education took ``one step forward, two steps back'' in the Bush message. And Rep. John Lewis, D-Ga., said, ``We aren't going to do all these things without additional sources of revenue.''

DOC.HEAD: Three Saudi Embassy Officials Killed in Thailand
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 5-6, `The interior...Al-Basri,' with 2 grafs to CORRECT name of interior minister, names of three victims, ranks of three victims. Pickup 7th graf, `Early last...'
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen killed three employees of the Saudi Arabian Embassy today, shooting one in an apartment near the embassy and the other two in a car they were driving nearby, officials said. Police said all three victims were male Saudi nationals who worked in the embassy's visa section. They apparently had diplomatic status. One or more gunmen entered the apartment near the embassy compound in central Bangkok and killed one of the employees, police sources said. At about the same time, gunmen shot and killed the other two employees as they were driving an embassy car about half a mile away, near a residence of the Iranian Embassy, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The interior minister, Banharn Sipla-archa, said an undetermined number of gunmen worked in two teams and coordinated the attacks. Police said the diplomat shot in the apartment was a consular official named named Abdullah A. Al Desri. They identified the other two victims as Fahad Az Al Bahli, a second secretary at the embassy, and Ahmed A. Al-Saif, a telex operator. Early last year gunmen killed a third secretary of the Saudi Arabian Embassy near the compound. The victim also processed visa applications from the tens of thousands of Thais who travel to work in Saudi Arabia each year. The crime went unsolved, but police said some job placement agents were unhappy about the diplomat's strict application of regulations when processing visas for Thai workers. Workers going to the Middle East pay agents a fee for securing jobs and the necessary paperwork.

DOC.HEAD: Milton Gordon, Financier and TV Series Producer
DOC.TEXT: Milton A. Gordon, an early producer of television features and series, has died of a heart attack. He was 82. Gordon died Wednesday at New York Hospital. In 1945, Gordon joined Walter E. Heller and Co. in Chicago, where he devised new ways of raising capital for film production. In 1953, he and Edward Small, a Hollywood producer, formed Television Programs of America to produce and distribute new films for the market. The company developed ``Lassie,'' an instant smash. It sold the series for $3 million, but kept distribution rights. The firm also produced ``The New Adventures of Charlie Chan,'' ``Tugboat Annie'' and ``Private Secretary.'' Gordon bought Small's share of the firm in 1958 for $2 million, and sold the company the next year for $13 million to British interests. In 1969, Gordon bought the majority interest in Halle and Steiglitz, the Wall Street brokerage firm. In 1970 he became president and changed the firm's direction to corporate finance. His wife, Elinor, died in 1974. He is survived by a daughter, a son, a brother and four grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: NBC's `Today' Loses To ABC Rival In Ratings
DOC.TEXT: For the fourth consecutive week, NBC's ``Today Show'' was second last week to ABC's ``Good Morning America'' in ratings, with ``CBS This Morning'' still a distant third, estimates showed Thursday. However, the 4.3 average for ABC's show was down slightly, by one-tenth of a ratings point. The 4.0 average for NBC's show was up by the same slight margin. CBS' broadcast averaged a 2.6 rating. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes, according to the A.C. Nielsen Co. The longest previous winning stretch of `Good Morning America'' over once-dominant ``Today'' occurred in October and November 1987, when ABC's show won its morning time period for six weeks, an ABC spokeswoman said.

DOC.HEAD: One Killed, 100 Injured in Riot Over Umpire's Call
DOC.TEXT: An umpire's decision in a cricket match started a riot that killed one person and injured about 100 as police fired rifles and rival fans hurled firebombs and stones, police said Thursday. The rioters looted four shops and burned a dozen houses during the two-hour outburst Wednesday in Madanganj, 10 miles southeast of Dhaka, police said. The riot began after an umpire's decision during a match between two cricket teams, the Madanganj Welfare Association and the Farazikanda Eleven, according to the police, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The police said they did not know what the decision was, but fans poured away from the cricket grounds and into the town. Police opened fire with rifles as the rioters rampaged through houses and shops. One bicycle rickshaw driver was killed by police fire, they said. Most of the injuries were caused by the rocks and firebombs, they said, adding that seven police were among the injured. Seven people were arrested.

DOC.HEAD: Five More Arrested in Coup Plot
DOC.TEXT: Five men were arrested after trying to destroy evidence linking them to an alleged attempt to assassinate Flight Lt. Jerry Rawlings, the Ghananian leader, the Ministry of Defense said Thursday. The five, including three military officers, had been under surveillance since the arrest of seven officers in November on charges of planning to kill Rawlings, the Defense Ministry said in a statement released to the Ghanianian News Agency. One of the seven arrested last year hanged himself in jail, newspapers reported. A summary of evidence against the original seven said Maj. Courage E.K. Quashigah, once a close friend of Rawlings, organized the plot. Quarshigah was credited with intervening to block a coup attempt against Rawlings in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Court Says Japanese Can't Keep Foreign Swords
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Thursday ruled against a lawyer who wanted to keep two Spanish-made sabers as works of art, a court official said. Japanese law bans ownership of swords and handguns, although some can be kept if registered as valuable artwork. The court ruled the registration provision applies only to Japanese swords, said the court official. Lawyer Fumihiro Nishioka had argued that two sabers he brought from Spain in 1981 should be treated the same as Japanese swords, claiming the weapons, used in the 1936-39 Spanish Civil War, are valuable as art. A lower court had rejected that argument. A law adopted after World War II provides for up to 15 years in prison for illegal possession of swords and firearms. But a sword and gun registration law was adopted in 1950 to protect culturally valuable objects, which must be registered with the Education Ministry. A ministry official said 2.1 million guns and swords have been registered for private ownership. The swords must be Japanese and made in traditional ways. The guns must have been produced in Japan before 1867.

DOC.HEAD: Four Months after Storm, FEMA Still Gets 100 Requests a Day for Aid
DOC.TEXT: Disaster assistance applications from Hurricane Hugo victims continue to pour into the Federal Emergency Management Agency at the rate of 100 a day. ``What is so amazing is how long it is taking for the public to come in for help,'' FEMA spokesman Frank Mosco said. ``Normally following a hurricane, we are in and out of a site in four weeks _ five weeks tops. ``Just Monday, our Sumter office received first applications for three ... destroyed homes, and they were all uninsured.'' It has been four months since Hugo slammed into South Carolina, killing 29 people and causing an estimated $5.9 billion in damage. The agency has distributed $450 million in relief funds to 61,000 applicants. Mosco attributes the delay in filing for aid to the widespread destruction in rural areas, illiteracy and victims' unfounded fears that their social service benefits would be cut if they received disaster relief. Despite the continued requests for aid, FEMA is scheduled to close its two field offices in Sumter and Charleston within a week. It also will stop taking applications over its telephone hot line in a month, but the hot line will remain in operation to answer questions, Mosco said. Mosco said 13,000 aid requests are pending and will take a month more to process.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarian Minister Comes to U.S. for Help in East Bloc Reforms
DOC.TEXT: A Hungarian pastor who recently risked his life on a mission to Romania says the work he's doing during a brief stay in the United States is even more important. The Rev. Bertalan Tamas arrived Jan. 6 for a five-week visit sponsored by the Memorial Presbyterian Church of Grosse Pointe, a Detroit suburb. He is a pastor of the Reformed Church of Hungary and an Executive Committee member of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches. Tamas, in an interview Monday, said his message to Americans is this: Although the dictators in Eastern Europe may be gone, the struggle to build democracy in the East bloc is just beginning. ``Americans can sometimes forget. I must use this chance to describe what happened in Eastern Europe in the past, so it won't happen again,'' he said, referring to the more than 40 years of one-party rule that devastated the economies of Hungary, Poland, East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria and Romania. The church _ whether Roman Catholic, Reformed or Orthodox _ is one of few stable institutions remaining in the East bloc after the demise of the region's Communist parties, Tamas said. Thus the church will play a pivotal role in the transition from totalitarianism to democracy. He cited the Roman Catholic church in Poland, which was a major force along with the Solidarity trade union movement in ending Communist rule in that country. Another responsibility the church faces is that people expect it to provide material assistance as well as spiritual guidance, said Tamas, 49, who learned English in Great Britain. ``We need help from our friends in the United States,'' he said. ``Churches in Hungary, for example, are once again being allowed to run schools and hospitals, but they cannot do it properly because they no longer have the means to do so.'' In late December, the Synod, or governing body of the Hungarian Reformed Church, dispatched Tamas to Romania, which then was in the early stages of a violent revolution that ousted dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Tamas was seeking information about the Rev. Lazlo Tokes, an ethnic Hungarian Reformed pastor whose arrest in the western city of Timisora was believed to have sparked the Romanian revolt. Rumors that Tokes had been executed proved false, and Tamas found him alive and well. Tamas already had been threatened with retribution by the Ceausescu regime for his role in helping 40,000 Romanian refugees settle in Hungary. ``Because we knew the situation was horrible in Romania, we took the risk,'' Tamas said. ``I also felt I had to express solidarity with the Rev. Tokes.'' Tamas plans to travel to New York, Louisville, Ky., Princeton, N.J., and Decatur, Ga., before returning to Hungary on Feb. 12.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Says Eastern European Events Should Not Overshadow Africa
DOC.TEXT: Governments must not let the dramatic events in Eastern Europe dim their concern for Africa and other poor regions of the world, Pope John Paul II said Thursday. ``There should be no barrier to solidarity among nations,'' he told diplomats after an eight-day tour of the Sahel region. ``The monumental changes in Eastern Europe should not turn attention away from the Third World, and the African continent in particular.'' That was a recurring theme on his trip to five countries of the impoverished zone just south of the Sahara Desert. John Paul said in Guinea-Bissau that grinding poverty compromises freedom in Africa. Of an audience in Burkina Faso, the pope asked: ``How would history judge a generation that, having all the means to feed the Earth's population, refused to do so in fratricidal indifference?'' He spoke not only to the consciences of rich nations, but also of the need for cooperation within Africa. ``When it comes to movement of people and goods, of investment in training and research and rational planning of agriculture and industry, understanding among men can no longer be thwarted by borders that didn't even exist in the time of their ancestors,'' John Paul declared in N'Djamena, capital of Chad. In a thinly veiled reference to the autocratic behavior of some African leaders, John Paul said those in power should be humble enough to acknowledge their own errors and the abuse and injustice that often result. ``It is more important to work for peace and the well-being of all people than to bolster personal prestige,'' he said. John Paul urged urged African organizations to coordinate their efforts for the good of all member nations. ``The preparation together of concrete projects will enable them to form a common front in the bargaining'' with donor and lender nations and institutions, he said. Sustained development in Africa requires peace, he said, alluding once again to the role of political leaders in the often-fratricidal conflicts within nations. ``I have in mind Ethiopia, Sudan, people who are the subject of racial discrimination in their own lands and others who suffer from endemic ethnic rivalries that sometimes lead to violent confrontations,'' the pope said. In Chad, John Paul returned again and again to the theme of reconciliation in the nation of 5.5 million, where more than a decade of civil conflict destroyed the economy and produced a young generation deprived of regular education. Meeting with Moslem leaders at a dusty racetrack under a blazing midday sun, he said: ``After the trials of the past, Chadians must now concentrate on their own development.'' The pope put in a word for human rights, which often is at the bottom of a poor nation's priority list. ``It is well to remember that development is measured not only in economic terms, but in respect for the person in his whole human condition,'' he said. John Paul's sixth pilgrimage to Africa also included stops in Cape Verde and Mali.

DOC.HEAD: Will De Klerk Speech Signal End of Apartheid?
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk is to outline his plans for reform Friday in a speech that many South Africans hope will finally signal the end of apartheid and set their country on the road to peace. Expectation has ballooned around the world that de Klerk's speech will at least announce the release of Nelson Mandela, South Africa's most famous black leader, clearing the way for negotiations on solving the nation's problems. De Klerk, who already has dented the edifice of apartheid, has pledged to create a ``new dispensation'' in South Africa. Whites and blacks must solve their differences peacefully, and avoid what he says could be a race war that would last for 80 years. But political observers are warning that de Klerk's speech in Cape Town at the start of Parliament on Friday won't be the end of white rule. There are no signs de Klerk intends to surrender power or accept the democracy that is the goal of all groups fighting apartheid. White rule in South Africa is not going to collapse like the Berlin Wall and the Communist regimes of Eastern Europe, observers say; the quest for a solution to South Africa's problems is more likely to resemble the tortured search for peace in the Middle East and Northern Ireland. The government is in full control of the country, unrest is minimal and the African National Congress, the main black opposition group, admits its military campaign against white rule has been largely ineffective. While de Klerk does want to ease tensions, some critics say the president lacks a definite plan and is feeling his way, playing for time with moderate reforms to blunt domestic and international opposition and postpone any major confrontation. ``It has not been shown that Mr. de Klerk has either the vision or the courage to make this moment (on Friday) a moment for historic importance,'' said Rev. Allan Boesak, an anti-apartheid leader. The government rejects any suggestion of black majority rule and says the interests of the white minority must be ensured. De Klerk has given no sign of what he wants for the future beyond stressing that whites must have veto power in any future state. Black leaders say de Klerk must meet a number of basic expectations to clear the way for talks with the ANC, including lifting the state of emergency used to suppress dissent; release Mandela; legalize the ANC and other outlawed opposition groups and allow exiled black leaders to return. Critics say that de Klerk as leader of South Africa's Afrikaners cannot surrender white minority rule and accept black majority rule. The Afrikaners, whites of Dutch descent, have been ingrained with a sense of racial superiority for 350 years that makes it impossible for them to share power with non-whites, they say. Helen Suzman, who opposed the National Party throughout her 36 years in Parliament, said de Klerk was elected by the Afrikaners and his mandate is to protect the whites' interests above all other considerations. ``He would not interpret his mandate for reform as a mandate to jeopardize the political position of the white minority or to threaten its survival,'' she said in a recent lecture. Ms. Suzman said she believes de Klerk will end the worst aspects of the apartheid laws that deprive blacks of rights and ``excise much of the overt brutality inherent in the apartheid system.'' De Klerk, who took office in August, has freed several elderly black political prisoners and eased restrictions on anti-government protests after years of repression. He also has called for repeal of the law that allows segregation of municipal facilities. But the government has said it will not desegregate schools, hospitals and other public facilities and there are few signs that many white South Africans are ready to share power or amenities with non-whites. Nontheless, the government apparently hopes a moderate stance would ease political tension and encourage some black groups to take a softer line that could lead to a compromise in which white interests will be safeguarded. The government also is eager to end or weaken the economic boycotts imposed by many Western nations to protest apartheid. The boycotts, along with domestic economic problems, have sent the economy into a tailspin and created hard times for many whites. De Klerk hopes to ease the economic crunch by offering reforms to ease international sanctions and restore confidence in the economy by attracting new foreign investment.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Barry Renfrew is chief of the AP bureau in South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: President Offers Six Goals Towards ``Excellence in Education''
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with criticism of Bush on education, Cavazos defense
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XCAP3
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's exacting education goals for America's schools came under fire today from educators and Democrats in Congress demanding to know where the money would come from to make U.S. children the world's best in math and science. ``You can't become the education president ... by proposing a meager 2 percent increase in the education budget,'' said House Speaker Thomas S. Foley after Bush unveiled his goals in the State of the Union Address Wednesday night. Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, said, ``There is a yawning gap between the rhetoric of President Bush's education speeches and the funding levels he offers in his budget.'' But Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos, in a spirited defense of Bush's approach, said adding ``another billion and another billion ... is not going to solve the education deficit.'' ``It's not a matter of dollars,'' Cavazos said at a White House briefing. Nevertheless, he said his department's proposed $24.6 billion budget for fiscal 1991 ``is the largest education budget that this nation has had,'' and includes ``a very healthy 6.2 percent increase in discretionary programs.'' Asked why the overall growth was less than the 3 percent that the whole federal budget rose, Cavazos said his department was paying lower interest rates on student loans. ``The way that you really become the education president ... is to change the educational system so it's a positive system, it's an effective system,'' said Cavazos, who said real spending on the schools surged 26 percent after inflation in the 1980s. Bush, in his address, unveiled six goals hammered out in concert with the nation's governors. They include slashing the dropout rate and making U.S. children the best in the world in math and science by the turn of the century. ``Real improvement in our schools is not simply a matter of spending more. It is a matter of asking more _ expecting more _ of our schools, our teachers, of our kids, and our parents and ourselves,'' Bush said. Some education leaders and Democrats were not impressed. Richard Miller, executive director of the American Association of School Administrators, said he was ``encouraged'' by the first draft of the goals, but ``we want to get beyond rhetoric. ... His budget proposal for education is at odds with the goals.'' ``Nobody could be against education or providing a home for the homeless. But there was nothing there except generalities,'' Rep. Robert Matsui, D-Calif., said after Bush's speech. Rep. Pat Williams, D-Mont., said, ``American parents and students need to have explained to them: how is a 2 percent increase for the Pentagon a major cut while a 2 percent increase in education is a major increase?'' But Sen. John Warner, R-Va., praised the president's math and science goals, saying they could give the nation a ``technological edge and an economic edge to compete worldwide.'' Here are what Bush called ``America's education goals:'' 1. ``By the year 2000, every child must start school ready to learn.'' 2. ``The United States must increase the high school graduation rate to no less than 90 percent.'' 3. ``In critical subjects _ at the 4th, 8th and 12th grades _ we must assess our students' performance.'' 4. ``By the year 2000, U.S. students must be first in the world in math and science achievement.'' 5. ``Every American adult must be a literate worker and citizen.'' 6. ``Every school must offer the kind of disciplined environment that makes it possible for our kids to learn _ and every school in America must be drug-free.'' He unveiled them four months after agreeing with the governors at an education summit in Charlottesville, Va., to draft the first performance goals for the nation's schools. He saluted four of the governors who spearheaded the joint effort and who were on hand to watch the speech from the House gallery _ Terry Branstad of Iowa, Bill Clinton of Arkansas, Carroll Campbell of South Carolina and Booth Gardner of Washington. Cavazos has said American pupils' achievement levels are intolerably low. He and other experts cite studies showing: _South Korean 13-year-olds finished first and Americans last in a math test given to pupils in six countries last year. _Fewer than 1 percent of U.S. students take physics and chemistry, while up to 25 percent of 18-year-olds in Canada and Norway take the two subjects for two years each. Nearly 30 percent of American teen-gers now drop out of high school, although some return to get their diploma or equivalency degree. Minnesota traditionally has been the only state with a 90 percent graduation rate.

DOC.HEAD: Exponent of Roman School of Painting Dies at 82
DOC.TEXT: Alberto Ziveri, a leading exponent of the Roman school of painting, died Thursday after suffering a stroke. He was 82. As an apprentice painter, Ziveri tried his hand at impressionism but later turned to realism together with others in the Roman art world that flourished between 1930 and 1945. He spiced his realist works with a touch of satire and was known for his use of deep reds and greens and other ``hot colors.'' The late Italian artist Renato Guttuso had once written Ziveri to praise the ``rigor and poetry'' of his works and described his paintings as ``heavenly.'' Last year, Ziveri was awarded the Viareggio Prize in recognition of his life's work.

DOC.HEAD: Glemp Suffered Cardiac Shock, Newspaper Reports
DOC.TEXT: Cardinal Jozef Glemp, the leader of Poland's powerful Roman Catholic church, remained hospitalized in serious condition Thursday, and a newspaper said he had suffered cardiac shock after massive bleeding brought on by a perforated ulcer. The cardiac shock caused a collapse of blood circulation that cardiologists had to struggle to get under control Wednesday, said the newspaper Zycie Warszawy, citing ``unofficial sources.'' Glemp, 61, remained in serious condition, according to a spokesman at the primate's household. Glemp underwent one operation Tuesday and a second early Wednesday. He was taken to a Warsaw hospital Tuesday after complaining of feeling faint. During surgery, it was discovered he had suffered a massive hemorrhage of the digestive system. President Wojciech Jaruzelski visited Glemp in the hospital Tuesday night. Glemp, primate since 1981 and a cardinal since 1983, is spiritual leader to the more than 90 percent of Poland's 38 million people who regard themselves as Roman Catholic.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Fails to Get Aoun's Man Out of Lebanese Embassy
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration stepped up its verbal attack on Lebanese Gen. Michel Aoun on Thursday, demanding he relinquish his remaining hold on power in Lebanon and appealing to the Supreme Court to evict his envoy in Washington. However, Justice William J. Brennan rejected an emergency request in which government lawyers said Ambassador Abdallah Bouhabib's continued occupation of Lebanon's Embassy ``is causing increasingly serious adverse consequences for the nation's foreign relations.'' The State Department is seeking Bouhabib's eviction at the request of Lebanon's new government led by President Elias Hrawi, who was elected in November with the backing of the 22-nation Arab League. The United States recognized the Hrawi government last November and has been conducting its business with a Hrawi-appointed ambassador rather than with Bouhabib. Aoun, who controls Lebanon's Christian sector with about 1 million residents, refuses to recognize the Hrawi government and continues to hold out with 20,000 troops at the presidential palace in Beirut. Over the past three days, his forces have been engaged in fierce battles with a small, rival Christian militia for control of the sector. Dozens have been killed and wounded. In Beirut, Aoun blamed the United States for the fighting. ``America has engineered this collision, but we shall surmount it soon,'' he said in a statement on his television station. He did not elaborate. As for the legal struggle over the embassy in Washington, Aoun and Bouhabib last week obtained a temporary restraining order from U.S. District Judge Harold H. Greene blocking the eviction. A federal appeals court Tuesday refused to set aside Greene's order, and on Thursday Brennan also refused. Judge Greene is expected to make his final ruling in the dispute this week. In the emergency request denied by Brennan, Bush administration lawyers said Greene's restraining order ``is utterly without legal support and intrudes into the core powers of the president to receive ambassadors, recognize foreign governments and conduct foreign relations.'' Noting that the Hrawi government has asked that Bouhabib be removed, the request submitted to Brennan said, ``The United States considers itself obligated to render that assistance immediately.'' In a strong statement regarding the fighting in Lebanon, the State Department called on Aoun to step aside immediately. ``This latest outburst must be laid at the seat of Gen. Aoun,'' the statement said. ``It follows his earlier outrageous decision to cut the water to West Beirut and to clamp down on the press.'' ``Gen. Aoun must realize that his bellicose behavior does not advance the interests of the Christians or any other community but only benefits those who want to see Lebanon continue in anarchy and turmoil,'' the State Department said. ``We reiterate our call for Gen. Aoun to step aside and to do it now.''

DOC.HEAD: House Democrats Honor Rosa Parks
DOC.TEXT: Rosa Parks, whose refusal to move to the back of the bus 35 years ago was a key moment in the civil rights struggle, was honored Thursday by House Democratic leaders, who said she had changed the nation. ``Rosa, let me thank you personally for sitting down so long ago so I could stand here today,'' said Rep. Bill Gray, D-Pa., the House Democratic whip, who credited her with triggering changes that have allowed blacks such as himself to attain high office. Mrs. Parks' 77th birthday on Sunday will be marked by a black-tie national tribute at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. In anticipation of that event, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley and other House Democrats appeared with Mrs. Parks at a news conference. ``Sometimes it takes one person to say no, and a whole series of events follow,'' said Foley. ``There are few people that can say they changed the nation. Rosa Parks changed the nation,'' Foley said. Mrs. Parks' refusal to surrender her seat to a white passenger on a Montgomery, Ala., city bus on Dec. 1, 1955, led to a city-wide bus boycott that last 381 days. The boycott triggered other protests and propelled Martin Luther King Jr., a preacher who was a spokesman and leader of the boycott, to national attention and to the leadership of the civil rights movement. Since 1965, Mrs. Parks has lived in Detroit and worked in the office of Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich..
