For the last three years she has run the Rosa and Raymond Parks Institute for Self Development, whose aim is to help young people. ``I'm very, very grateful to be here and happy to be able to stand before you and say how great it is I am being honored,'' Mrs. Parks said in her brief remarks at the news conference. ``It is an extension of the dream that I have to help motivate and train and encourage youth to reach their highest potential in life.''

DOC.HEAD: Couple Suspected in String Of Robberies Arrested In Connecticut
DOC.TEXT: A middle-aged couple suspected of carrying out more than two dozen holdups throughout New England were arrested today after a robbery at a shoe store in which a clerk was stabbed, police said. Edward M. Aranjo, 46, and Ellen M. Marks, 50, were stopped in Milford about 11:15 a.m. after a description of their vehicle was broadcast by police in neighboring Orange, where the robbery occurred, said Officer Edward Kelly, a Milford police spokesman. Kelly said Aranjo had blood on him when he was arrested, and that a blood-stained knife was also found in the couple's car. The couple, who had been dubbed the ``Bonnie and Clyde'' robbers though far older than the notorious Depression-era robbers, did not offer any resistance when they were stopped, Kelly said. The stabbing victim, identified as an owner of the shoe store in Orange, suffered lacerations to both hands and was taken to Yale-New Haven Hospital for treatment. The victim's identity was not immediately released. Orange police said the stabbing took place during a struggle after the male robber held a knife to the clerk's throat. The couple were being held early this afternoon in the Milford lockup while charges were being drawn up, Kelly said. Police in Old Saybrook, a shoreline community about 40 miles east of here, had sought warrants Wednesday for the arrest of the couple in connection with an armed robbery two weeks ago of a gift shop. Aranjo and Marks are suspected of at least 28 armed robberies since Dec. 26 in Connecticut, New York, Rhode Island, Massachusetts and New Hampshire, police said. The robbery in Orange was believed to be the third time they struck in Connecticut since Jan. 8. Nearly all of the robberies took place at small towns at small stores where only one clerk was working. In most cases, the male robber brandished a knife and tied up the clerk, then grabbed the money while the woman started up the getaway car.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Forecasts Likely Soviet Withdrawal from Eastern Europe
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2 new grafs after 6th graf pvs, bgng, ``I think ... to UPDATE with White House comment; picks up 7th graf pvs, Although Bush ...
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney predicted today that the Soviets will likely withdraw from Eastern Europe by the middle of the decade, but warned against any drastic changes in U.S. strategy. ``I do believe caution is still in order until we have these agreements signed, sealed and delivered,'' Cheney told a congressional panel in his first appearance since President Bush's surprise announcement of deeper cuts in the levels of U.S. and Soviet combat troops in Central Europe. The president's proposal for the ongoing conventional arms control talks in Vienna calls for 195,000 troops for each superpower _ a reaction to the tumultuous changes in Eastern Europe and the apparently diminishing Soviet threat. ``The likelihood of a Warsaw Pact attack into NATO these days is fairly remote,'' Cheney told the Senate Armed Services Committee. The defense secretary said the United States can begin to plan for ``the possibility that the Soviets will be out of Eastern Europe or virtually out of Eastern Europe five years hence, that the governments of Eastern Europe will be democratically-elected, non-Communist regimes.'' ``I think that's a very real possibility,'' Cheney said. At the White House, Chief of Staff John Sununu rejected any suggestion that the troop-cut plan was intended to prop up a politically weakened Gorbachev as he faces a critical meeting next week of the Communist Party Central Committee. ``If the cutting of troops would have been an advantage for Mr. Gorbachev, then Mr. Gorbachev would probably have announced them earlier himself, thereby getting both the advantage, the pressuring of the United States to do it and whatever international political benefits that come in that direction,'' Sununu said. ``So that was not part of the consideration.'' Although Bush is calling for a drastic troop reduction, uncertainty still exists over the final number of U.S. troops and equipment that will remain in Europe, the defense secretary said. ``We have not finalized the work within the NATO alliance about how we will allocate the cuts within the alliance,'' he said. ``There are significant questions as yet unanswered about what NATO strategy will be like in a post (conventional forces agreement) environment.'' The troop reduction plan drew praise from the ranking members of the Senate Armed Services Committee. ``I applaud the president for his new proposal,'' said Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., the panel's chairman. ``It is much more relevant to the changes in Eastern Europe and the budget at home.'' Sen. John Warner of Virginia, the committee's ranking Republican, called Bush's initiative ``a bold, new move.'' Cheney reiterated his warning against the United States abandoning its plans to modernize its strategic forces, noting that the Soviet Union is continuing to upgrade its class of high-tech weapons. The defense secretary still faces complaints from lawmakers over his $292.1 billion military budget. Cries of political foul play surround the proposed list of base closures and realignments, with many lawmakers arguing that significant reductions in big-ticket strategic weapons are the proper response to a lessening Soviet threat. The budget calls for five B-2 stealth bombers at a cost of $5.5 billion and an increase of nearly $1 billion in spending on the Strategic Defense Initiative to $4.5 billion. Those totals have raised red flags on Capitol Hill, where the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., predicted that it was highly unlikely that the administration would get what it is seeking. The budget would continue financing of two land-based nuclear missiles, with $2.8 billion to fund rail-basing for the multiple-warhead MX missile and $202 million for the truck-based Midgetman missile. The plan also calls for canceling some 20 small weapons systems, such as the Marine Corps' V-22 Osprey and the Army's M-1 tank, in an attempt to save $2.9 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Crossing Guard Back on Duty Hours after Giving Birth
DOC.TEXT: Crossing-guard Sandra Carter was on the job in front of Pine Estates Elementary School the day before she gave birth to her fifth child. And she was back helping youngsters cross the street just hours after she delivered a 6-pound, 3-ounce boy. ``I didn't think it was any big deal. I didn't mind doing it. It wasn't anything I couldn't handle,'' she said. Mrs. Carter's husband took over her morning patrol duties on Jan. 12, the day their son, Hananiah, was born shortly after midnight. She was discharged from the hospital in the morning, and was back at work for the afternoon shift. Police Officer T.Y. Tyson said all 28 crossing guards he supervises are dedicated, but Mrs. Carter is in a class by herself. ``The amazing part is that she never said anything about it. And when I asked her why ... she just said, `It wasn't that bad.'''

DOC.HEAD: Aspen Mayor Seeks to Buy, Set Free Fur-Farm Foxes
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Bill Stirling wants to buy foxes from a Wyoming fox ranch in order to set the animals free. But the fur farm's owner calls the scheme crazy. ``They wouldn't last three days in the wild. These foxes were born and raised in a cage for generations. They couldn't find food,'' said Jack Hendrickson, owner of Arrow Fur Ranch outside Buffalo, Wyo. Stirling has sponsored a city ballot question to ban the commercial sale of wild-animal furs in Aspen. Residents vote on the measure Feb. 13. Stirling's crusade, which has fueled a recall campaign against him, drew the attention last month of Dexter Butterfield, who lives next door to the fur ranch in Wyoming. Stirling and his wife, Katharine Thalberg, founder of the Aspen Society for Animal Rights, visited Wyoming at the invitation of Butterfield, who has complained about foul odors and screams and yelps from the ranch. ``The reality of that fox farm was useful in educating our electorate here about the realities of life for a wild animal on a fur ranch,'' Stirling said this week. ``They're in these miserable little cages all their lives. ``Then we thought, `What about freeing the ... animals?''' Since then, Stirling has sent offers to Hendrickson, seeking to buy out his inventory of 68 silver foxes at $50 to $100 per animal. Thalberg's group aims to help defray the cost by selling $100 ``fox futures.'' A Rocky Mountain Humane Society veterinarian is working with wildlife biologists on a release plan, Stirling said. ``I'd talk to him for $100 (per animal), but I don't expect to hear from him again,'' said Hendrickson. ``And he wants me to agree not to raise (more foxes) for a year ... but I wouldn't even deal with that.''

DOC.HEAD: Disney Asks Anti-Porn Group to Drop Founder's Quote From Brochure
DOC.TEXT: The Walt Disney Co., which fought Mickey Mouse's appearance on a day-care wall and Snow White's performance at the Academy Awards, wants an anti-pornography group to quit quoting its founder. ``Our greatest natural resource is the minds of our children,'' Walt Disney once said. The Greater Orlando Coalition Against Pornography used that quotation in a pamphlet outlining the group's purpose. Last week, the group received a letter from Anne Nielsen, a Disney attorney, asking them to delete any reference to Disney from the brochure. She said the quotation ``conveys to the public the impression that there is an association or connection with the Walt Disney Co.'' But the coalition's executive director, Don Pinkston, says it's all a misunderstanding and he hopes to settle the issue with Disney. The group's lawyer, Darryl Bloodworth, defended the use of the quote. ``Mr. Disney was a public figure, and that simply was a quote of a public figure, much as the newspaper quotes public figures all the time,'' he said. But Disney spokesman Charles Ridgway disagreed, saying the group was not a newspaper and the company owns the rights to the name of Walt Disney. In recent years, Disney has threatened legal action when it believed its property rights over Disney names and charaters were being violated. Last year, a south Florida day-care center had to remove wall paintings of Disney characters, the Academy Awards producers were rebuked for using the Snow White character without permission and a Kissimmee gift shop using the name ``Mickie's'' was challenged.

DOC.HEAD: East German Premier Urges `United Fatherland'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 22 grafs to UPDATE with Kohl rejecting idea of military neutrality for reunified Germany. Pickup 21st graf pvs, `Gorbachev's top...' Delete last 3 grafs to trim.
DOC.TEXT:
East Germany's Communist premier today urged talks with West Germany toward an eventual ``united fatherland'' that would be independent of military blocs and governed by a joint parliament in Berlin. The two Germanys must work out a common approach to reunification to calm the unease of their European neighbors, Premier Hans Modrow said at a news conference in which he unveiled his plan for unification. The Communists, beset by a crumbling economy and a damaging Westward exodus of thousands of East Germans, until recently had opposed talk of reunification. This week for the first time they endorsed the concept, and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev softened his view, calling a united Germany inevitable. Modrow said he could give no time frame for reunification because it depends on the pace of European unity and the attitudes of Germans in both states. He said he would push for a slower tempo in inter-German relations to avoid instability, and called for an interim confederation with West Germany that could work out a measured and logical program for ``growing together.'' ``Germany should once again become a united fatherland of all citizens of the German nation,'' Modrow said. ``Responsibility, caution and understanding are demanded in order to ensure that there is never any danger to the lives and well-being of neighbors.'' Modrow called for negotiations with Bonn soon to devise a joint plan on reunification, but made clear that he had not previously discussed his views with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Reacting to Modrow's proposal, Kohl said he was ready to discuss reunification steps immediately after a new government takes over in East Germany following March elections, but he rejected the idea of military neutrality. ``Such a proposal contradicts the logic of the pan-European process of unification,'' Kohl said at a news conference in Bonn. He said a single German state in the heart of Europe could not afford to be isolated. American and West European allies have indicated that they would accept reunification as long as Germany stays within the NATO alliance. But East Germany is host to about two-thirds of the Soviet Union's 600,000 troops in Central Europe, making the state shaken by democratic upheaval the Kremlin's most crucial defense partner in the seven-nation Warsaw Pact. The Kremlin has said German reunification must occur within the European framework, meaning that divisions would have to be erased between the two rival military blocs, NATO and the Warsaw Pact. Modrow said elections in both Germanys would be necessary to seat a joint parliament in Berlin. And he indicated that in his view ``joint executive bodies ``could also function in certain areas.'' Modrow said both states must ``step by step'' proceed toward neutrality. His plan appeared to reject a unity plan offered Wednesday by West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, who envisioned West Germany remaining loyal to NATO alliance while making what is currently East Germany neutral. Reflecting Bonn's optimism about eventual reunification, Genscher today praised as ``an important step forward'' President Bush's proposal for sharp reductions in U.S. and Soviet forces in Central Europe. Bush's proposal Wednesday night in his first State of the Union address to limit each superpower to 195,000 troops in the region also was welcomed by West Germany's defense minister, Gerhard Stoltenberg. He called it ``a balanced combination of disarmament policy and unequivocal recognition of the West's defense readiness and alliance solidarity.'' In a speech to the Evangelical Institute in Tutzing, near Munich, Genscher outlined what he sees as a security guarantee for Moscow and a compromise that could appease Washington as well. Genscher suggested that the territory now constituting West Germany could remain in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, while the area east of the Elbe River, East Germany, would not host any military facilities. Gorbachev acknowledged in talks with Modrow on Tuesday that a single Germany likely is inevitable, but cautioned that a headlong plunge toward reunification could destabilize Europe.
Gorbachev's top adviser on German affairs told West German television late Wednesday that the Soviet Union considers neutrality the best path to a united Germany. Nikolai Portugalov told the WDR network that weapons reductions already under way in both German states are tantamount to an acceptance of military neutrality. Bush's troops reduction proposal would most directly affect West Germany, as about 250,000 of the United States' 305,000 European-based troops are deployed in West Germany. Support for union with prosperous West Germany has surged among East Germans in recent weeks as the country's political and economic crisis have deepened. Weekly pro-democracy rallies in Leipzig and other major cities have taken on a clear pro-reunification atmosphere recently.

DOC.HEAD: Mama Midler Says no TV or Junk Food for Her Sophie
DOC.TEXT: Actress-singer Bette Midler won't let her 3-year-old daughter, Sophie, watch television, eat junk food or stay up late because she doesn't want her to ``be jaded at 8.'' ``I've got to say we're on the pompous side,'' she said of herself and her husband, Harry Kipper, in an interview in the Feb. 2 edition of USA Weekend. ``At first, I thought, `Well, gee, everyone's going to think I'm a jerk.' And then I thought I don't care what they think. I want her to have a foundation in things the world considers good and artful,'' she said. Midler said she nixed television because the programming is too violent and the commercials are too sexual. ``We just do stuff together. We do a lot of construction paper, a lot of drawing, a lot of chatting, a lot of dancing around and making up stories and games and stuff,'' she said. The Divine Miss M, whose fashion sense leans heavily toward the outrageous, says she also plans to send her offspring to a school where uniforms are required. ``I've had enough of these trendy clothes. These are years when they should be absorbing as much as they possibly can and not thinking about stupid things like, `What do I look like?' and `I want that jacket because Bobby has that jacket.'''

DOC.HEAD: Communist Premier Calls For Reunification Talks
LaserPhoto BER8
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's Communist premier on Thursday appealed for negotiations with West Germany to forge a ``united fatherland'' that eventually would be neutral and governed from Berlin. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl welcomed the call to discuss reunification, but rejected the call for military neutrality. ``Such a proposal contradicts the logic of the pan-European process of unification,'' Kohl said. He added that a single German state in the heart of Europe could not afford to be isolated. East German Premier Hans Modrow called for ``a reasonable time horizon'' for reunification to be mutually determined, apparently hoping to gain control over the galloping pace of events drawing the two Germanys together. His announcement marked a turnaround in the Communist-dominated government's position on the German question. The East Berlin leadership had previously resisted reunification efforts as premature and destabilizing. But mounting economic woes and an accelerating exodus of thousands of skilled workers to the West are forcing the nation's interim leaders to address public pressure for a merger with prosperous West Germany. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev also has softened his view on the issue; earlier this week he said reunification was inevitable. At a news conference to announce his plan, Modrow rejected suggestions that he was angling to win votes for the Communist Party, which is threatened by opposition groups in East Germany's first free elections set for March 18. Kohl flew to West Berlin to meet with East German opposition leaders to discuss possible campaign assistance for their challenge of the Communists. He said he would discuss reunification with the new government elected in March. Modrow cautioned that German reunification must be carried out carefully to avoid stirring up fears among neighboring nations that a powerful German state would rise and threaten them. ``Nothing can occur that runs counter to the process of overcoming the division of Europe or that would create new dangers,'' he said. He titled his proposal ``For Germany, a United Fatherland,'' a slogan touted repeatedly by reunification advocates at weekly rallies in Leipzig and other major cities. ``Germany should once again become a united fatherland of all citizens of the German nation,'' he said. ``Responsibility, caution and understanding are demanded in order to ensure that there is never any danger to the lives and well-being of neighbors.'' Modrow's plan calls for an initial ``treaty community'' to draw the two German states closer together, then a confederation status that would create some joint executive and parliamentary committees. The final step, to be endorsed in a national referendum, would seat a joint parliament and government in Berlin and draft a joint constitution. Modrow did not make say what would happen to Bonn, the West German capital that has endured a provisional status through 40 years of hope for an eventual return to Berlin. Modrow made clear that the unified German state he envisions must be free of ties to both military blocs. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher on Wednesday proposed a compromise that he suggested would provide a security guarantee for the Kremlin, which depends heavily on East Germany as its front line against the West's NATO alliance. Genscher proposed that the territory now constituting West Germany remain loyal to NATO, while the area east of the Elbe River, East Germany, be militarily neutral. U.S. ambassador to West Germany, Vernon Walters, said loyalty to NATO was one of the conditions for German reunification, but he left unclear whether it would also include the military integration into the alliance of what is now East Germany. Walters made the remarks in a speech in Stuttgart. About two-thirds of the 565,000 Soviet troops deployed in Eastern Europe are based in East Germany. Likewise, West Germany is host to most of the 305,000 U.S. troops stationed in central Europe to defend against a possible attack by the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. President Bush's proposal Wednesday for deep cuts in those forces _ down to 195,000 for each superpower _ drew praise in both Germanys. Kohl heralded the White House initiative as ``the right signal at the right time,'' and said he considered the call for sharp reductions ``a pathmark to a new European security structure.'' East Germany also welcomed the proposal and expects it to help lead to an agreement at Vienna arms talks to reduce conventional forces in Europe, government spokesman Wolfgang Meyer said.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Seeks Coast Guard Records in Hazelwood Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with judge taking requests under advisement. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Potential jurors...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AG1
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys for fired Exxon skipper Joseph Hazelwood are seeking transcripts of conversations after his tanker ran aground and other documents that the Coast Guard doesn't want to release. The attorneys want records of alcohol tests administered to Hazelwood and members of the tanker crew the day of the crash; background information about crew members and two Coast Guard officials; records of ice conditions and communications between Hazelwood and the Coast Guard. Anchorage Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone heard arguments this morning on the requests but said he would not rule until Friday at the earliest. Jury selection resumed after the hearing on the complex arguments. The Coast Guard, claiming sovereign immunity as a federal organization, has said it cannot be forced to provide information for a state court proceeding. But Hazelwood's attorneys said they need the information for his defense, and that it has been given to state prosecutors. Johnstone said that before ruling on Hazelwood's arguments, he would attempt to sort out exactly what information had been provided to prosecutors. A companion defense request argued before Johnstone today asks that information about the sobriety test Hazelwood failed after the crash be prohibited as evidence if the Coast Guard is not required to provide the details. Potential jurors questioned on Wednesday said they read and heard little about the March 24 accident that spilled about 11 million gallons of crude oil into the Prince William Sound. Many of the 15 people questioned also said they didn't necessarily believe the scant publicity to which they were exposed after the accident. Hazelwood is charged with criminal mischief, a felony; and with operating a vessel while intoxicated, reckless endangerment and negligent discharge of oil, all misdemeanors. He could face seven years in prison if convicted of all the charges. Jury selection began Tuesday. Johnstone expects to assemble a jury of 12 plus several alternates in time for attorneys to present opening arguments in the case on Monday. Fourteen of the 25 people questioned in the first two days of the selection process were excluded. The court summoned 91 people as potential jurors in the trial, expected to last at least six weeks. Those examined Wednesday and still in the running include a former oil spill worker, an airline pilot and a grocery manager. Johnstone dismissed several people, including a church business manager he said had ``too much contact and too many opinions'' to remain under consideration. Attorneys for Hazelwood and the state can exclude up to 20 candidates through peremptory challenges. They used six challenges Wednesday. Those rejected in that manner include a former Exxon employee who called the company arrogant.

DOC.HEAD: HUD Suspends California Company, Among Largest Public Housing Landlords
DOC.TEXT: The Department of Housing and Urban Development said today it has suspended a California company and more than 40 affiliates because of evidence of ``irregular activities.'' The companies, which together control some 50,000 federally assisted housing units and are among the largest subsidized housing landlords in the country, denied any wrongdoing and accused HUD of acting vindictively. HUD suspended the companies last Friday, notifying them in a letter that department officials made available today. It was addressed to the Santa Monica-based Housing Resources Management Inc. but also applies to nearly four dozen related development companies. Among the related companies is the parent enterprise, Associated Financial Corp., also of Santa Monica. Housing Resources Management is one of the companies that manages properties controlled by AFC and its affiliates. The action came as HUD, at the direction of Secretary Jack Kemp, continues a department-wide review prompted by disclosures last year of mismanagement and influence-peddling during the tenure of former Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. ``The Department of Housing and Urban Development has information indicating irregularities of a serious nature concerning Housing Resources Management Inc.'s dealings with the government,'' HUD Assistant Secretary C. Austin Fitts said in a letter addressed to Deane Earl Ross, HRM president. ``The department has been informed that HRM and its affiliates are under investigation by the government.'' An investigation alone is grounds for HUD to place a company on suspension, department officials said. The letter said HUD also had ``adequate evidence'' that HRM had been involved in ``irregular activities'' at properties it manages in Oklahoma, the District of Columbia, and New Orleans. HUD alleged the company had made or caused to be made requests for subsidies for vacant apartments, that it misused reserve funds and security deposits and that it caused a false repair invoice to be submitted to the government. Kemp visited the Washington property, Tyler House, shortly after taking over HUD and pronounced conditions at the development ``scandalous.'' Fitts' letter said HRM had misused reserve funds at Tyler House. HUD previously had suspended AFC and its affiliates from HUD-related business in just the Washington and Oklahoma areas. AFC is controlled by A. Bruce Rozet, a prominent Democratic Party fund-raiser who is often relied on by Congress for advice on housing policy. AFC has specialized in taking over deteriorating housing developments and those with major drug infestation. It has had several disputes with HUD over the past decade, and in late 1987 a HUD committee voted to prevent AFC and its affiliates from buying additional HUD-assisted properties. But the committee reversed itself after Fitts' predecessor, former Assistant Secretary Thomas Demery, told the committee he did not favor the sanctions.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used a0724, AM-VA Nurses transmitted Jan. 31 under a Washington dateline, are asked to use the following story.
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press erroneously reported Jan. 31 that Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico is a Democrat. Domenici is a Republican.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 6 grafs new to include source saying no letter of reproval being issued. Picks up 6th graf pvs, When the.
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Gus Savage, D-Ill, said today the House ethics committee has dismissed a complaint that he sexually assaulted a Peace Corps worker in Zaire. Savage, a black Chicago Democrat, blamed allegations against him on a ``racist attack'' by white government officials and white-owned news media. The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct said Wednesday that it had finished its preliminary investigation against Savage, but did not immediately issue its findings and refused to reveal its conclusions. Committee spokesman Mark Davis would not comment on Savage's remarks, made in a House floor speech. Savage denied a report in The Chicago Tribune that the committee issued a ``letter of reproval'' against him _ the mildest sanction available to the panel. A House source with knowledge of the investigation also said no letter of reproval was being issued. The newspaper quoted Rep. John Myers of Indiana, the ranking committee Republican, as saying the panel ``clearly disapproves'' of Savage's actions and believes he ``used bad judgment.'' When the ethics committee finishes a preliminary inquiry, it can charge a member of Congress with specific violations or it can simply end the case without proceeding further. In ending an investigation without charges _ for example, because of lack of evidence _ it can criticize a lawmaker's behavior. In another ethics case, the committee said it is dismissing a complaint filed against Rep. Roy Dyson, D-Md., more than a year ago by Republicans in his Maryland district. The panel wrote him a two-paragraph letter Wednesday saying the complaint had been ``considered and dismissed.'' Republicans in Dyson's district asked the committee on Sept. 26, 1988, to investigate allegations that he violated House rules. The complaint, filed a few weeks before Dyson was narrowly re-elected in 1988, cited the lawmaker's fund-raising activities and the operation of his office. ``I particularly urge my black colleagues to publicly stand up to this racist attack, in order that our white colleagues who choose to can stand with us,'' Savage said. He said that ``sensational exaggerations'' of the incident ``exploded on white television and in white newspapers'' and contended he and other black leaders have experienced ``racist viciousness'' at the ``hands of the white American mass media, Justice Department and the FBI.'' The committee considered allegations that Savage assaulted the female Peace Corps volunteer while on an official trip to Zaire last March. The worker contended Savage fondled her for more than two hours in the back of a chauffeur-driven embassy car in Kinshasa, the capital of Zaire, according to several government officials who confirmed an account originally published in The Washington Post. Three of Savage's Democratic colleagues _ Reps. Patricia Schroeder of Colorado, Matthew McHugh of New York and Barney Frank of Massachusetts _ formally requested the ethics investigation. ``Believe it or not, among these self-appointed guardians of personal morality was one who since has admitted keeping and prostituting a homosexual,'' Savage said. ``As for the other two, so-called white liberals, their sensitivity to racism and their respect for fairness must be questioned.'' Frank, D-Mass, has said he is homosexual. The ethics committee is conducting a preliminary inquiry into allegations by a male prostitute that Frank allowed a prostitution ring to operate from his home and that the lawmaker had sex with the prostitute in the House gym. Frank has admitted a sexual relationship with the prostitute, but denied allowing a prostitution ring to operate in his home and having sex in the House gym. Dan Buck, an aide to Ms. Schroeder, said he had no comment. Spokesmen for the other two lawmakers were not immediately available for comment. Savage said the ethics committee ``after a preliminary examination of witnesses, apparently decided that the evidence was insufficient even to warrant further investigation. Not even a slap on the wrist.'' Savage said that if ``anyone was honestly offended'' during the trip to Zaire, ``it was the American State Department because I have persuasively opposed our neo-colonialist foreign policy all over Africa and in many other Third World nations.''

DOC.HEAD: Punxsutawney Phil, Other Weather Lore Not All Hogwash
DOC.TEXT: Doubters beware. Like other weather lore, Punxsutawney Phil, America's best-known and best-kept woodchuck, isn't entirely hogwash, according to folklorists. ``A great many folk beliefs have a certain logic behind them. It may not be scientifically verifiable, but they're often not completely random and I think this is one of them,'' said Erika Brady, assistant professor in programs in folk studies at Western Kentucky University. ``We're always kind of taking a look at folk wisdom to see if there is some basis in fact for it,'' agreed Tim Clark, executive editor of The Old Farmer's Almanac. ``The lasting lesson is not to underestimate our ancestors. They were not dumb people.'' Barring calamity, at sunrise Friday, fat, furry Punxsutawney Phil will be pulled from a manmade burrow atop Gobbler's Knob, about a mile outside town. If the critter sees his shadow, tradition has it there will be six more weeks of winter. If he doesn't, spring is supposedly around the corner. ``If you're a groundhog or a person and you come out of your warm, snug haven that you've made for the winter and get fooled by the sunlight into thinking it's spring, you're going to be in trouble,'' Clark said. ``So it says the groundhog is not fooled. ``I think it's no coincidence the spring equinox comes about six weeks after Groundhog Day.'' The legend actually has roots in Christianity. Groundhog Day falls on Feb. 2, also the Christian holiday of Candlemas, when the infant Jesus first was taken to the temple. An old Scottish couplet claims: ``If Candlemas be fair, there'll be two winters in the year.'' Punxsutawney's German-born farmers borrowed the legend and on Feb. 2, 1887, began turning to local woodchucks for a clue to the upcoming weather. Groundhogs, part of the rodent family, usually hibernate by December and stay underground until April or so, but sometimes venture out early if the weather is mild. The Punxsutawney Groundhog Club heralds Phil as the seer of seers, sage of sages, weather prophet extraordinare. Phil has predicted an early spring a scant nine times over the past century. The last time was in 1988. ``Phil's never been wrong,'' boasted Jim Means, 66, the club's president and member of the group's exclusive Inner Circle. Actually, the 14 local businessmen in the Inner Circle decide the forecast well in advance. The group even holds rehearsals before Groundhog Day, when members don top hats and tails and join about 1,500 people gathered in the dark atop Gobbler's Knob. And every day except Groundhog Day, Phil lives in town in a heated, air-conditioned hutch at the library with two other groundhogs, known to some as Philomena and Barney.

DOC.HEAD: Uncharacteristically Personal, Baker Speaks of God's Love
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III proposed Thursday that world leaders build relations ``rooted in trust and in love and in understanding'' and said his own life had improved when he stopped ``trying to play God.'' Baker said he had to learn that God ``loves me even as I fail to become the man that he wants me to be.'' Uncharacteristically personal, Baker gave the keynote remarks to the National Prayer Breakfast sponsored by Congress. He was given a standing ovation. President Bush also spoke briefly, and Vice President Dan Quayle read a New Testament passage. Bush proclaimed his conviction that the 1990s ``will be the decade of the rebirth ... of faith and hope.'' Baker, one of President Bush's closest friends and advisers, usually maintains a genial but reserved demeanor. He said that during nine years in high-level administration posts he has found that power does not bring fulfullment. ``I found early on that having a position of power really doesn't bring the fulfillment that many people think it does,'' he said. ``Inner security and true, real fulfilment come by faith. It doesn't come by wielding power in a town where power is king.'' He told the audience of legislators and ambassadors that ``spiritual values are important in the pursuit of world peace.'' ``The Bible tells us that where the spirit of the lord is there is liberty. So, my friends, I believe that as leaders we can build relationships around the world that are rooted in trust and love and understanding, And I believe that we can go beyond rhetoric to discover concrete ways to express this reality.'' Baker characterized himself as ``just one person genuinely struggling to put faith into practice in my life.'' He recounted an instance several years ago ``when I was really struggling with a particular problem.'' He said he found strength in praying about it with his wife, Susan, and realizing that he had to turn the problem over to God. ``Susan helped me to see that I really needed to stop trying to play god and turn the matter over to faith.'' The 59-year-old secretary also said he meets regularly ``for fellowship'' with a group of men he described as ``very normal guys who just happen to hold positions of power and influence in Washington.'' ``Power, of course, can be intoxicating; it can be addictive. And few doubt that .. power tends to corrupt, and absolute power corrupts absolutely.'' ``Over these last nine years, I have had opportunities to participate in the exercise of more power than I ever would have imagined. I have felt the weight of responsibility that that brings and I have to admit to you as well that I have felt the temptations that are attendant to it,'' he said. But power is fleeting, he said, noting how quickly eminent people lose the trappings of prestige when they lose their positions. ``Having a position of power does not bring inner security or fulfillment. That comes only, I think, by developing a personal relationship with God, which for me is personified by Jesus Christ.'' Baker said his ``journey of faith'' began when he started reading the Bible. He also talked of the importance of friendship and told how Bush and his wife, Barbara, had helped him through the painful period before and after the death of his first wife, Mary, who died of cancer in 1969.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Say Troop Withdrawal Possible Soon in Baku
LaserPhoto PRI2
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet military commandant expressed hope Thursday that by mid-February troops could begin returning home and authorities could lift a curfew imposed after violent ethnic clashes in Azerbaijan. Representatives of Armenia and Azerbaijan prepared to open peace talks Friday across the Soviet Union in Riga, capital of the Baltic republic of Latvia. A spokesman for the Azerbaijani People's Front accused President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of caving in to Communist hard-liners by sending troops to occupy Baku, and added: ``Gorbachev's hands are now bloody.'' Lt. Gen. Vladimir S. Dubinyak told the first foreign journalists permitted to visit Baku since the military seized control of the city Jan. 20 there are ``many positively inclined forces trying to noralize the situation and end the curfew.'' He said the 11 p.m.-5 a.m. curfew might be lifted within two weeks. He said tensions would have to ease further, including an end to leaflets appealing to Baku workers to strike to protest the military presence. At night, during the curfew, military trucks and armored personnel carriers stand at most intersections between Baku airport and the center of the city. Soldiers guarding the intersections wear helmets and carry automatic weapons. Red flowers mark where Azerbaijanis died fighting the military intervention. On Jan. 13, Azerbaijanis attacked ethnic Armenians and drove them from their homes in Baku, an oil center and the capital of the republic of Azerbaijan in the southern Soviet Union. Soviet troops stormed Baku a week later. The official Soviet news agency Tass reported the death toll in Baku alone since the troops moved in at 139. That includes 106 civilians, 28 soldiers and five policemen. As many as 498 people were wounded, Tass said. Iran on Thursday offered to send doctors, nurses and medicine to neighboring Soviet Azerbaijan, whose residents are primarily Shiite Moslem, like most Iranians. The offer was reported by Tehran television, monitored in Cyprus. Iran has condemned the use of force in Azerbaijan. Dubinyak said regular army soldiers, making up 5,000 of the 17,000 troops now committed to Baku, could be sent home, military equipment could be removed from the streets, and the remaining Interior Ministry soldiers could patrol the streets without weapons. Dubinyak said he would welcome talks with the Azerbaijan People's Front, a group that Defense Minister Dmitri T. Yazov has said the military is trying to crush as a nationalist movement. Dubinyak said the people's front has not proposed talks, but a spokesman for the group interrupted to say such discussions could begin any time. The People's Front spokesman, Nadchov Nadzhavov, editor of the group's banned newspaper, charged that soldiers were sent into Baku in part to prevent the front from making a strong showing in local elections. The date for the elections is to be set this month, and they must take place within three months. ``I can make the prognosis that they won't leave before the elections,'' Nadzhavov told reporters. He also criticized Gorbachev's handling of the crisis in Azerbaijan, saying the Kremlin leader had given in to reformers by not cracking down on an independence movement in Lithuania and then had given in to Communist hard-liners by sending troops into Azerbaijan. ``Gorbachev's hands are now bloody,'' he said. Lt. Gen. Mikhail P. Kolesnikov, a representative of the Soviet army serving under the commandant, told reporters that the military had been affected by the ``Tblisi syndrome.'' He said criticism that followed the crushing of a nationalist demonstration in the Georgian capital on April 9, 1989, had demoralized the military and hindered decision making. ``We saw outrages,'' he said. ``We saw instances of blood-letting, but we couldn't do anything.'' Azerbaijani representatives arrived in Riga for peace talks with a three-man delegation of the Armenian All-National Movement. ``Maybe the first steps toward dialogue with the Armenians will take place. We are counting on that,'' the chief Azerbaijani delegate, Khikmet Khazhizade of his republic's People's Front group, told The Associated Press. The talks are sponsored by the Baltic Council, a grouping of the three people's front organizations in Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania. Organizers said they hoped the talks could start Friday morning. The Baltic activists cautioned against expecting quick results. ``Such talks could help, but we need two or three months, as the problems are very deep,'' said Edvin Inken, a Latvian People's Front leader who recently visited Baku.

DOC.HEAD: Khomeini's Son Urges Continued Hostility to United States
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Iranians gathered at the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's tomb Thursday, the 11th anniversary of his return from exile, and his son preached continued hostility to America, Tehran radio said. On the first anniversary since the revolutionary patriarch's death June 3, Ahmad Khomeini said his father, known as the Imam, constantly defied ``global arrogance,'' an Iranian phrase for United States and its allies. ``We must always remain on the Imam's path,'' he said at a ceremony beginning a 10-day celebration of the Islamic revolution. Ahmad Khomeini said his father warned that, ``if we show the slightest bit of complacency, America will deliver its final blow against us. You, the people, must prepare for struggle against America.'' The radio the younger Khomeini, a leading radical, praised his father's successor as spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, for ``treading the same path as the Imam.'' His exhortation for no compromise with the United States was seen as a warning to President Hashemi Rafsanjani, leader of the so-called pragmatist faction in Iran. Rafsanjani, who attended the ceremony Khomeini's golden-domed tomb in the Behesht Zahra cemetery, seeks better relations with the West in order to obtain help in recovering from eight years of war with Iraq. The first part of Rafsanjani's 5-year development plan, calling for up to $20 billion in foreign investment, got Parliament's approval Wednesday over opposition from radicals who want state control and no foreign involvement. Tehran television showed throngs at the cemetery chanting ``Death to America!'' and ``Death to Israel!'' Iranian officials paid their respects at the tomb and promised to safeguard Khomeini's ideological legacy, the radio said. ``At a time when the government was in the hands of the enemy, the Imam's coming from a safe place to the center of the danger was an act rooted in the immense power of the Lord,'' Rafsanjani said at the graveside, the radio reported. Khomeini returned from 14 years of exile Feb. 1, 1979, after Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi was forced to flee. Ten days later, the government he left behind collapsed and Khomeini proclaimed the Islamic republic, Rafsanjani said: ``The Iranian people have proved that if a nation is resolute in its stand, and if it has courage and spirit, it cannot be defeated.'' He said recent changes in Eastern Europe and elsewhere were ``a small example of what the people of Iran achieved 11 years ago, and these popular rebellions are the legacy of the people of Iran.'' Khamenei, the nation's spiritual leader, told another gathering in Tehran: ``The future belongs to Islam, the Moslems and the freedom-loving nations of the world,'' the television reported. ``In the confrontation with the organizations of the satanic powers (the West), it will be Islam which triumphs.'' Despite the fiery rhetoric, this year's anniversary of the revolution differs from past observances. It reflects the more more relaxed character of Rafsanjani's government, formed in August, and an easing of Islamic rigidity. While Khomeini was alive, the anniversary was a time of rallies to show support for him, and of reruns on state television of bloody clashes between revolutionary zealots and the shah's forces. On Thursday, television showed film of Khomeini arriving in Tehran in 1979 on a chartered Air France jet, but comedy and children's shows dominated the morning programming. The official Islamic Republic News Agency said music would be part of the celebrations this year for the first time. Khomeini felt good Moslems should shun music.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Announces Proposed Increase in Salvador Aid
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 6th, 7th grafs pvs, Cristiani planned ... with 6 grafs to UPDATE with meetings with Congress, Bush; picks up 8th graf pvs, But administration ...
DOC.TEXT: The State Department announced today a proposed $55 million increase in economic assistance for El Salvador as Salvadoran President Alfredo Cristiani headed into high-level meetings here. Before the formal announcement, an administration official had confirmed a published report that an aid cut was planned, but the official figures showed $284 million proposed for El Salvador for fiscal 1991 compared with $229 million for the current year. The official was unavailable afterward to explain the discrepancy. Other Central American countries, however, were cut back as part of a general reordering of priorities the administration is undertaking in light of additional claims on the aid program in Panama and Eastern Europe. Military aid to El Salvador would undergo a slight increase in fiscal 1991, to $91.4 million from the current level of $84.6 million. The administration has been concerned that Congress may impose sharp cutbacks on El Salvador in response to continuing human rights abuses in that country. Bush reiterated his strong support for Cristiani during a photo session at the White House. In the face of congressional criticism over alleged military involvement in the slaying of six Jesuit priests, Bush praised Cristiani for arresting four officers and four soldiers in the case. ``I know of his commitment to democracy,'' Bush said. ``I have been very impressed with the courage he has shown in going after those who have broken the law in his country,'' he said. Cristiani earlier went to Capitol Hill for a meeting with key House Democrats including Speaker Tom Foley, D-Wash, Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., and Rep. Moakley, D-Mass., head of a House task force looking into El Salvador. Moakley described the meeting as ``friendly,'' but said the congressmen ``let him know what our people are thinking'' about the human rights situation, particularly the murder of the priests in November. While none of the congressmen threatened directly to cut off aid, some members told Cristiani ``votes for El Salvador aid have been diminishing over the years,'' Moakley said. But administration officials believe Cristiani may have defused a potential rebellion in Congress with the arrests a month ago of eight Army personnel, including a colonel, who were wanted in the killings. Some members of Congress are skeptical about the ability of El Salvador's criminal justice system to punish those responsible, noting that tens of thousands of politically motivated killings in El Salvador remain unsolved. But administration officias said Wednesday that any congressional attempt to link U.S. aid to a successful prosecution of the Jesuit priests' case probably would not take effect for at least a year. This would give Cristiani time to move ahead on that issue, on negotiating peace with leftist rebels and on restoring vigor to a declining economy. On Friday, Cristiani is to meet with members of the U.S. Catholic community in an attempt to reassure them his efforts to solve the killings of the Jesuits are serious. Some of the exasperation of members of Congress, particularly Democratic liberals, is based on what they perceive to be the meager rewards of more than $4 billion in U.S. economic and military outlays for El Salvador over the past decade. El Salvador has held a number of multi-party elections since then, but the country seems no closer to a peace settlement with the rebels and still has been unable to overcome its reputation as one of the most lawless nations in the hemisphere. On the other hand, Cristiani, with strong administration support, is convinced that his country continues to be victimized by Nicaraguan and Cuban attempts to support the leftist rebel movement. Cristiani discussed that issue on Wednesday when he met with U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar in New York.

DOC.HEAD: All White House Press Will Be Allowed To Go to Colombia
DOC.TEXT: The entire White House press corps will fly into Colombia when President Bush attends a drug summit there Feb. 15, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Thursday. The administration had considered taking most of the press corps to a different site outside Colombia for security reasons. But that has been ruled out, and the press corps will fly into Barranquilla, a Caribbean coastal town about 60 miles northeast of the Cartagena summit site, Fitzwater said. ``We're going in,'' Fitzwater said. As usual, a small pool of reporters will fly with Bush aboard Air Force One and accompany him to Cartagena. Upwards of 100 or more reporters, photographers and television crew members fly on a separate press charter wherever the president goes. He provided no other immediate details and did not say how Bush himself would get to Cartagena. The White House has said it will keep open several options on Bush's itinerary and make a final decision as the event draws near. Bush will meet with Colombian President Virgilio Barco and officials from Bolivia and Peru.

DOC.HEAD: Western Europe Supports Bush Proposals
DOC.TEXT: Western European leaders on Thursday supported the U.S. proposal for significant new troop withdrawals from Europe but, amid hints of anxiety, stressed they want a continued American presence. Britain said it hoped this was the last reduction planned by Washington. The Soviet Union welcomed as a sign that ``things are changing for the better'' the proposal by President Bush to cut troop levels in central Europe to 195,000 for each superpower _ below the 275,000 being negotiated at talks in Vienna. But Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov complained the plan did not go far enough, adding, ``We must continue to have as our goal no foreign troops on foreign soil.'' ``It must be the ceiling, not the floor,'' said Gerasimov. ``You can note in his (Bush's) speech he needs American troops in Europe for here to eternity. ... This is not a good sign.'' Some analysts said the Bush plan signaled the beginning of the final withdrawal of American troops from Western Europe _ dreaded by many of the U.S. allies in NATO _ as well as the departure of all the Soviets. ``I personally would be suprised if the Soviets have anything like 195,000 soldiers left in East Germany within the next two to three years,'' said Francois Heisbourg, director of the London-based Institute of Strategic Studies. ``I think the Soviets will be lucky if there is a symbolic contingent left; a Soviet Guantanamo,'' he said, referring the U.S. base in Cuba. In London, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said Britain attached ``great importance to President Bush's assurance that the new figure will be a floor and that no more reductions are envisaged.'' ``This will ensure a continued strong American presence in Europe,'' added the statement from her No. 10 Downing St. office. Thatcher aides said Bush telephoned her Saturday to discuss the proposal, and ``we indicated our support.'' Bush sent two senior aides to put this plan to the leaders of the four major Western European powers, Britain, France, West Germany and Italy. The United States has 305,000 troops in central Europe, and the Soviet Union has 565,000. Another 30,000 U.S. troops in Britain and southern Europe are excluded from the Bush proposal. West Germany, where most of the U.S. troops are deployed, hailed the proposal. Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg called it ``a balanced combination of disarmament policy and unequivocal recognition of the West's defense readiness and alliance solidarity.'' West German enthusiasm for troop pullouts by both sides reflected eagerness for unification with East Germany, where 380,000 of the Soviet troops on foreign soil are stationed. Two other East bloc nations, Czechoslovakia and Hungary, have demanded that the Soviet forces leave their soil. Other European NATO allies are concerned about being dominated by a powerful, single German state. The fears are heightened on a continent that was overrun by Nazi Germany in World War II. They are also worried about the United States detaching itself from Europe as the Soviet military threat diminishes with the collapse of a string of Communist governments in 1989. Belgium and the Netherlands followed Mrs. Thatcher's cautious line. ``There have to be talks on the withdrawal of troops, and I oppose a unilateral initiative,'' said Belgian Foreign Affairs Minister Mark Eyskens. Dutch Foreign Minister Hans van den Broek said 195,000 U.S. troops would be the ``minimum level'' needed, Dutch TV reported. Both Belgium and the Netherlands, however, have said they are studying the possibility of withdrawing their forces from West Germany because of the diminished Soviet threat. ``Some of the smaller NATO countries weren't all that firm in their commitment anyway,'' said Mark Fielder, an analyst at the Royal United Services Institute in London. ``Now with the Bush proposal they'll have the best excuse in the world to say, `Let's have a race to see who can get out first.''' Manfred Woerner, secretary-general of the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization, said in Brussels the Bush plan was consistent with U.S. promises ``to maintain significant military forces in Europe.'' French President Francois Mitterrand's spokesman, Hubert Vedrine, said the Bush proposal came ``at an opportune moment'' _ accelerating the Vienna conventional arms talks. Italy, Portugal and Norway all said the Bush proposal was welcome as another initiative toward disarmament. The Italian Communist Party, the biggest in the West, called for an immediate 4 percent cut in Italian defense expenditure and said Italy need not accept a wing of U.S. F-16 fighters due to be redeployed from a Spanish base.

DOC.HEAD: Baker: US Could Recognize Managua Government Under Certain Conditions
With AM-Troop Cuts Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States is prepared to normalize relations with Nicaragua if this month's elections are certified free and fair and if the Sandinista government halts its support for leftist guerrillas in neighboring El Salvador, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Thursday. ``If we determine that it is free and fair ... and we determine that they have indeed stopped their support of subversion in neighboring countries or in other places in Latin America, then we'd be prepared to normalize our relations with that government,'' Baker told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Baker said, however, that it was important that the Sandinista government relent and admit members of President Bush's congressional observer team to watch election preparations and the Feb. 25 balloting. So far, the 20-member team has been denied visas because the Managua government contends the United States cannot be an impartial observer. Without the observer group there, ``it's going to be hard for us to make the judgments required,'' Baker said. He added that there also must ``be some period of time during which we can satisfy ourselves, if the suggestion is made to us, that they have indeed stopped shipping SA-7 (Soviet-made antiaircraft) missiles and other miliary equipment to the FMLN (Salvadoran guerrillas). We're going to have to know that's a fact before we can begin to normalize.'' During a two-hour session with the Senate committee, Baker outlined budget initiatives the administration is seeking in fiscal 1991 and reiterated U.S. support for reforms being pressed by Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. Baker leaves Monday on a trip that will take him to Moscow for meetings with Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and perhaps Gorbachev. ``We seek to probe for points of mutual advantage with the Soviet Union, turning areas of conflict into areas of cooperation wherever possible,'' he told the committee. ``In this way we will benefit ourselves as well as the reformers in Moscow.'' Primary items on Baker's Moscow agenda are accelerating arms control agreements, seeking a solution to the war in Afghanistan between the Soviet-backed Marxist government and U.S.-armed Moslem fundamentalist rebels, and human rights. Baker's testimony followed President Bush's announcement Wednesday of a new troop-cut proposal in Central Europe, and the secretary said it was hoped the troop-reduction plan could be incorporated into a new conventional forces agreement to be concluded this year. He sounded a note of caution, saying ``the old world of dogmatic dictatorships is on its way out. But the new world of secure, prosperous and just democracies is not yet here. It will not arrive automatically.'' Members of the Senate panel barely mentioned the most recent point of foreign-policy conflict with the administration, China. And Baker, as he read from his prepared text, skipped over a sentence referring to ``the tragic case of China,'' mentioning only Cuba as an example of ``governments that try to shut out democratic values.'' Baker also used his appearance to renew an appeal to Congress to curb its practice of earmarking foreign aid money for specific countries, saying the practice has led to an 86 percent cut in aid to African nations for the current year and sharp reductions in help to countries like Jamaica that are cooperating with the U.S. war on drugs and should be able to expect larger rewards. And he complained again that ``we have no flexibility'' to meet unforeseen needs like the $500 million rebuilding program proposed for Panama. There, Baker said, ``what we need to do is throw a little money at the problem'' because ``we're the ones that did a lot of the damage.''

DOC.HEAD: Neediest Countries Often Ignored in Aid Program
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is proposing that more than half of next year's $14.8 billion foreign aid request be spent on strategically-placed allies at the expense of the world's poorest countries. The emphasis on catering to key allies is consistent with the longstanding U.S. view that security concerns must be given priority over humanitarian concerns in the distribution of aid. If Congress approves the administration's fiscal 1991 foreign aid request, the largest individual recipients of economic and military support would continue to be Israel, with $3 billion, and Egypt, with $2.2 billion. Those grants, accounting for more than a third of U.S. foreign aid, reflect U.S. interest in maintaining stability in its two closest Mideast allies. Almost half of the $1.5 billion proposed for Latin America and the Caribbean would be allocated for three small Central American countries _ El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras _ where the United States has been trying to help consolidate stable democratic rule in the face of leftist opposition. These countries, accounting for perhaps 2 per cent of the population of the region, would receive about $673 million in economic and military aid. This equals more than 80 per cent of the total for the 44 countries of sub-Saharan Africa. Writing in Thursday's editions of The Washington Post, the president of the African Development Foundation, Leonard H. Robinson, expressed amazement at the quick congressional approval given in 1989 to a large-scale three-year aid program for Poland and Hungary. ``Where did the $900 million come from?'' he asked. ``Why did it take only days to secure? As an Africanist, I want to know. So do the people of Africa.'' Citing the various environmental and economic calamaties which have befallen Africa in recent years, Robinson said, ``You have to wonder why Western nations have not rushed to Africa's aid with the same degree of alacrity witnessed in Poland and Hungary.'' Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., said Thursday that African countries often are cut back by an administration when funds are needed to help out new claimants on the U.S. aid program. ``We raid the accounts of the poorest countries,'' Kassebaum said during a Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing. In one key assistance category, she said, Africa was cut back from $99 million in 1989 to $14 million currently. The broad outlines of the overall program were released Monday when the administration's 1991 budget proposal was made public. The details were disclosed Thursday. Among countries with which the United States has military base agreements, the Philippines would receive $649 million in economic and military aid compared with $540 million for the current year while Portugal would get $172 million, compared with $127 million. Turkey would receive $598 million in economic and military aid compared with the current $515 million. Greece would get $345 million in military aid, down $4 million from this year. Greece gets no economic aid. The administration asked Congress for $532 million to combat drug smuggling, with about 80 percent of that going to Bolivia, Colombia and Peru. The total for anti-smuggling efforts this year is slightly under $300 million. President Bush will be traveling to Colombia in two weeks to confer with leaders from those three countries.

DOC.HEAD: Actress Lee Remick to Recieve Jack Lemmon Award
DOC.TEXT: Lee Remick, who played Jack Lemmon's alcoholic wife in the 1963 film ``Days of Wine and Roses,'' for which both actors were nominated for Academy Awards, has been chosen to receive the Jack Lemmon award for her contribution to performing arts. The award, created in 1988 by Boston's Wang Center for Performing Arts, is presented annually for outstanding contribution to the performing arts by a current or former resident of Massachusetts. The first award was given to Yo Yo Ma, the cellist. Remick, a Boston native and a part-time resident of Cape Cod, also has received six Golden Globe nominations and five mentions for Emmy awards for her performances in ``The Blue Knight'' in 1973, ``Jennie, Lady Randolph Churchill'' in 1975, and ``Nutcracker'' in 1987, among others. Lemmon, who was born in Andover, has won two Academy Awards, including best actor in ``Save the Tiger'' in 1973 and best supporting actor for ``Mister Roberts'' in 1955.

DOC.HEAD: Gorillas May Be Headed for Love Match
DOC.TEXT: Monkey love may be blossoming at long last, more than 18 months after Colossus _ billed as the largest gorilla in captivity _ met a female of the species for the first time. When they were introduced in June 1988, Muke (pronouced Moo-key) was the first gorilla of any kind that Collosus had seen since he was captured as an infant in the jungles of Africa 21 years earlier. He led a solitary existence at a New Hampshire attraction until he was purchased by The Zoo in this Florida Panhandle city three months before Muke's arrival on breeding loan from the St. Louis Zoo. Since then the 23-year-olds have shared the outdoor gorilla compound during the day but did little more than stare across the courtyard at one another and tangle in an occasional spat. They slept in separate cages at night until last week, said Zoo Director Pat Quinn at a news conference Wednesday. Love did not fill the air during their first night together. Muke emerged covered with dung. ``I guess he just spent the night flinging dung at her,'' Quinn said. But Quinn is encouraged that Colossus, who weighs more than 550 pounds, and Muke, a dainty 300-pounder, may mate. The week of sleeping together has awakened ``primeval desires'' in Colossus, Quinn said. Colossus is paying more attention to Muke and she is menstruating regularly, something she wasn't doing before, said Jean Benchimol, general curator at the The Zoo. ``I think we need to give them some time,'' Quinn said. ``Once they find they can live together ... there's a good possibility they will breed.''

DOC.HEAD: Washoe County Jail Inmates Go Cold Turkey Under No-Smoking Policy
DOC.TEXT: Some inmates of the Washoe County Regional Jail went cold turkey Thursday and sheriff's department workers were forced to cut down on cigarettes under a new strict no-smoking policy. The policy, banning smoking in jail facilities and desginating only a few smoking areas for employees, was intended ``to provide a smoke-free and healthy environment'' in the department's four main buildings. Undersheriff Dan Coppa said a few inmates and workers don't like the new rules, but crowded working conditions and an overcrowded jail have been making it more difficult for non-smokers to breathe. ``What we have found is there is a handsome body of inmates and employees that don't smoke and things were getting complicated by crowded conditions,'' Coppa said. ``We were getting ventilation problems and complaints.'' The federal Centers for Disease Control reported last July that Nevada had the second-highest lung cancer death rate in the nation, based on 1986 figures. The CDC reported Nevada's rate was 68.3 deaths per 100,000, compared to the national average of 52.1. The jail, built for 458 inmates, held 638 Thursday when the no-smoking policy went into effect following a gradual decrease in cigarette sales in the facility to encourage people to start cutting back, Coppa said. Connie Brown, dispatch supervisor at the sheriff's Incline Village substation, has endured restricted smoking areas for more than a year ahead of the new department-wide, no-smoking policy. ``I have to go outside the dispatch area in the receiving room to smoke,'' said Mrs. Brown, who has been lighting up for 37 years and said she has no plans to quit. Mrs. Brown said she has gone from smoking about one and one half packs of cigarettes a day to about one pack since tobacco use was limited in her substation. Nevada prohibits cigarette use in most public access local and state government buildings except in designated areas. The state's prison system doesn't have a no-smoking policy for inmates, some of whom have sued in the past, seeking a court order requiring their custodians to separate smokers from non-smokers. But the lawsuits have been dismissed and prison officials have said it would be too much of a burden to separate smokers from non-smokers when deciding which prisoners should bunk together.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards $500,000 to Former Honeywell Employee
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 2 grafs to CORRECT Corp. to Inc. and add that Honeywell based in Minneapolis.
DOC.TEXT: Honeywell Inc. has been ordered to pay a man $500,000 for urging a rival company to fire him. An Allegheny County jury Wednesday awarded Joseph Collincini, 42, of Crafton $100,000 in compensatory damages and $400,000 in punitive damages. Collincini, who worked for Minneapolis-based Honeywell for 12 years, claimed the company lobbied American Technical Systems to fire him in a series of letters to the company. He was fired in April 1987. Honeywell, which plans to appeal, said the letters notified ATS that Collincini was using information he obtained while working at Honeywell and asked him to stop. Honeywell said ATS fired Collincini because of financial difficulties at ATS. Collincini lost his job as a salesman for industrial equipment when Honeywell cut back on employees in the Pittsburgh area in October 1986. He was hired by ATS in a similar position in December 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Frantic 911 Call Recounts Shooting
DOC.TEXT: A 911 call recorded part of a violent family argument in which a son allegedly slashed his mother's throat, shot his father and said: ``That'll take care of both of you.'' Police released the 911 tapes, but have refused to give other details about what led to the confrontation Tuesday, except to say that it was apparently caused by a dispute over money. Joan Amos, 54, died about an hour after paramedics found her bleeding in an upstairs bedroom. Charles Amos, who was in serious condition Thursday at Bayfront Medical Center, had called 911 only seconds after he was shot in the stomach. He stayed on the phone for about five minutes while an emergency dispatcher tried to keep him calm. ``Oh God. My stomach is hurting like hell,'' said Amos, 49. ``OK. Relax, relax,'' the dispatcher responded. When police arrived, Amos, who is disabled, was unable to move from a recliner to the door to let them in. ``Break down the door and come on in!'' Amos yelled. ``I can't get there.'' After paramedics arrived, Amos told police he had been shot by his son, Jonathan, 26, who he said used a handgun wrapped in a towel, according to arrest warrants. Jonathan Amos and a companion, 19-year-old John DeHate of Largo, were arrested a few hours later in Sumter County following a chase along Interstate 75. Both were charged with first-degree murder and attempted murder. They remained in the Pinellas County Jail on Thursday without bond.

DOC.HEAD: Cosmonaut Takes Test Ride on `Space Motorcycle'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with later news reports on space walk. Picks up 4th graf pvs, ``It's not ...''
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet cosmonaut took a spin in space Thursday on a special motorcycle designed for rescuing spacemen, and officials said the vehicle's maiden journey outside the orbiting station Mir was a success. Flight engineer Alexander A. Serebrov rode the cycle as far as 30 yards away from the giant station, while mission commander Alexander S. Viktorenko stayed at Mir's exit hatch and monitored the cycle's operations. Soviet TV interrupted its regular programs several times during the day for special coverage of the five-hour spacewalk. Live pictures showed Serebrov, 45, attached to a tether anchored on Mir as he prepared to ride the cycle. A taped report showed the cosmonaut, with his left side in the sun and right in shadow, slowly riding away from Mir, his image growing smaller. A correspondent emphasized the drama of floating in space while connected to Mir only by a rope. He told viewers in the nighttime newscast ``Vremya'' it was ``risky and dangerous work.'' But Tass said the results of the 30-yard test ride and three five-yard trips were good. ``Its easy operation and good maneuverability were confirmed,'' the news agency said. Further tests are planned Monday. It's not much of a motorcycle by Earth standards; it actually looks more like a floating armchair, weighing 485 pounds with 32 motors. The cycle is designed for repairing satellites and rescuing spacemen in distress. It can rotate and move to a maximum distance of 50 yards away from Mir. The device, formally known as the Cosmonaut Movement System, is similar to the Manned Maneuvering Unit that U.S. space shuttle astronauts have used, Soviet officials say. The cycle was delivered to Mir on Dec. 6, after two delays. It originally was scheduled to blast off last April but it wasn't ready, and a second launching planned for September was scrapped because of problems with its electronic docking system. The 20-ton Mir was designed to be permanently manned, and was host to a record yearlong flight by two cosmonauts in 1988. But it was unexpectedly mothballed in April because the module and another add-on were not ready and keeping a crew aboard would have cost money when legislators and ordinary Soviets were demanding that space rubles be spent on Earth. The four-month vacancy was only the second time since Mir was launched in February 1986 that it was unmanned. Mir already is joined with Kvant, an astrophysics laboratory. Viktorenko and Serebrov have been aboard Mir since September and are scheduled to be replaced later this month by another crew.

DOC.HEAD: Crews Remove Wreckage of Flight 52
DOC.TEXT: Workers used chainsaws to hack through the wings of Avianca Flight 52 on Thursday as crews began clearing the wreckage from the crash that killed 73 people. ``This has been a terrible experience. We're anxious for them to get rid of this plane,'' said Samuel Tissenbaum, whose Glen Cove home narrowly avoided destruction in the Jan. 25 crash. The plane's nose remains stuck in the deck of his home. Avianca hired Charlotte Aircraft Corp. of Charlotte, N.C., to remove the wreckage, and a half-dozen workers were on hand Thursday afternoon sawing the wings into 5-foot pieces and loading them into a truck. National Transportation Safety Board officials wrapped up their on-site investigation Wednesday. Seventy-three people died and 85 were injured when the plane, heading to John F. Kennedy International Airport from Colombia, slammed into a hillside after apparently running out of gas. Tissenbaum, who lives with his wife, said his house suffered structural damage in the crash. The removal of the wreckage will go a long way toward returning his life to normal, he said. ``We're constantly reminded of the disaster,'' he said. Before workers began cutting up the plane, the scene appeared frozen in time since the night of the crash, with hunks of twisted metal, seats and other debris scattered on the hillside. The cleanup could take up to three weeks because the wooded site can only be reached by a single winding road, said police Sgt. John Woodworth. Nassau County police were also at the scene collecting any remaining luggage, property and other personal effects of the passengers. New York Telephone and the Long Island Lighting Co. workers removed downed wires and cut down trees. The body of the plane's captain, Laureano Caviedes Hoyos, was returned Thursday to Colombia after a funeral service on Long Island a day earlier. Caviedes, 56, was an Avianca pilot for 28 years. He was survived by his wife and two sons, ages 13 and 14, who live in Bogota, Colombia. NTSB investigators, who have not declared the cause of the crash, will fly to Bogota next week to review the plane's maintenance records and other information.

DOC.HEAD: Critics See Gap Between Goals, Greenbacks
DOC.TEXT: Education leaders and Democrats in Congress decried on Thursday a ``yawning gap'' between President Bush's soaring goals for America's schools and the 2 percent increase in his education budget. They asked where the money would come from to meet Bush's aims of reducing the dropout rate drastically and making U.S. children world-beaters in math and science by the turn of the century. ``There is a yawning gap between the rhetoric of President Bush's education speeches and the funding levels he offers in his budget,'' said Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers. Rep. Pat Williams, D-Mont., said that parents and students ``need to have explained to them: How is a 2 percent increase for the Pentagon a major cut while a 2 percent increase in education is a major increase?'' Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos defended Bush's approach, insisting, ``It's not a matter of dollars.'' ``We could keep on adding ... another billion and another billion. That is not going to solve the education deficit,'' Cavazos told reporters at a White House briefing on Bush's six education goals. The way math and science are taught must be radically changed, he said. Just putting more dollars into the current system ``is not going to make good mathematicians'' of students, said Cavazos, adding, ``They probably won't be able to add it.'' Bush unveiled the goals four months after agreeing at the education summit with the 50 governors in Charlottesville, Va., to produce the first performance goals for the nation's schools. The National Governors Association will not vote on the end product until their winter meeting at the end of this month, but Cavazos said the goals have the backing of a governors' task force on education. Those governors _ Terry Branstad of Iowa, Bill Clinton of Arkansas, Carroll Campbell of South Carolina and Booth Gardner of Washington _ attended the State of the Union and Bush saluted them for their role. ``We still have a lot of work to do'' in drafting detailed objectives on how to reach Bush's lofty goals, said Cavazos, but he added that he expects no major changes. Despite his insistence that more money is not needed to meet Bush's goals, Cavazos stressed that the Education Department's proposed $24.6 billion budget for fiscal 1991 ``is the largest education budget that this nation has had,'' and includes ``a very healthy 6.2 percent increase in discretionary programs.'' Overall, Bush sought $500 million, or 2 percent, more for the Education Department. He also requested an extra $500 million for Head Start, which is in the Department of Health and Human Services budget. Asked why the education budget would rise at a slower pace than the 3 percent rise in overall federal spending, Cavazos said his department is paying lower interest rates on student loans than it once was.
