He denied that aid to college students was being reduced. ``The way that you really become the education president ... is to change the educational system so it's a positive system; it's an effective system,'' said Cavazos, who said federal, state and local spending on schools surged 26 percent after inflation in the 1980s. Bush, in his address, said, ``Real improvement in our schools is not simply a matter of spending more. It is a matter of asking more _ expecting more _ of our schools, our teachers, of our kids, and our parents and ourselves.'' Some education leaders and Democrats were not impressed. Richard Miller, executive director of the American Association of School Administrators, said, ``We want to get beyond rhetoric. ... His budget proposal for education is at odds with the goals.'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, commenting after Bush unveiled the goals in Wednesday's State of the Union Address, said, ``You can't become the education president ... by proposing a meager 2 percent increase in the education budget.'' Cavazos said that ``when you compare our students against their peers (in) the industrialized nations of the world, we come out at the bottom in math and almost at the bottom in science.'' ``We have an attitudinal problem that we have to face,'' he added, citing surveys that show American students think they are good in math when in fact they are mediocre. Students in countries such as South Korea who shine in math take the opposite attitude, underrating their ability. Nearly 30 percent of American teenagers now drop out of high school, although some return to get their diploma or equivalency degree. Minnesota traditionally has been the only state with a 90 percent graduation rate. the presiden's goal for the nation.

DOC.HEAD: No Smear Campaign Against Politicians in 1970s, Thatcher Says
DOC.TEXT: Newly discovered documents about covert attempts to discredit the IRA in the 1970s contain no evidence of a smear campaign against leading politicians, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said Thursday. Lawmakers who claim they were targets pressed for a full inquiry despite the denial, on grounds the allegations would not disappear otherwise. ``The time has come for a full, open and honest uncovering of these things so that people in Northern Ireland can know that this has come to an end, the dirty tricks that were carried on,'' said the Rev. Ian Paisley, a militant Protestant leader in the province. Paisley, who has been described as a target of smears, led opposition to British government policy during the 1970s. For years, Mrs. Thatcher has denied allegations by Colin Wallace, a former army press officer, of a ``dirty tricks'' campaign against the Irish Republican Army and some politicians. In a letter Wednesday to a lawmaker of her Conservative Party, she acknowledged her statements were based on false information from civil servants. British ministers are not allowed to examine papers of former administrations and must rely on facts given them by civil servants. Her letter was released one day after her government confirmed the existence of a covert operation, codenamed ``Clockwork Orange,'' that fed lies to journalists reporting from Northern Ireland, where the Irish Republican Army is fighting to end British rule. Mrs. Thatcher and her defense secretary, Tom King, repeated Thursday that the documents unearthed in the bureaucracy provided no evidence the campaign was extended to politicians. The prime minister told the House of Commons she stands by her statement in May 1987 that there was ``no evidence of misuse of information by any member of the security services.'' In particular, she said, there was no evidence of a plot to undermine the 1974-76 Labor Party government of Prime Minister Harold Wilson, as alleged in ``Spycatcher,'' the memoirs of former MI5 agent Peter Wright. ``My own statement of May 6, 1987, was not affected by the new information, nor does the new information provide any evidence of attempts to undermine or discredit ministers,'' Mrs. Thatcher said. Wallace says he was dismissed in 1975, four years before Mrs. Thatcher became prime minister, for threatening to expose the campaign. In addition to his regular army duties, Wallace says, he led a secret psychological warfare unit in Northern Ireland in the 1970s. His superior officer backed up the statement. According to Wallace, ``Clockwork Orange'' began as an attempt to discredit the IRA through false stories, such as a claim the guerrillas had Soviet rockets armed with unstable explosives, and was expanded later to smear politicians such as Wilson and his predecessor, Edward Heath. Tony Benn, a former Labor minister, said former Prime Minister James Callaghan also was a target. Sir David Steel, former leader of the Liberal Party, added his own name to the list and said a Parliament committee should investigate. Paul Foot said in his book ``Who Framed Colin Wallace?'' that Wallace was given detailed information from the MI5 counterintelligence agency that enabled him to make allegations about homosexuality, bogus bank accounts, corrupt earnings and Communist sympathies. Foot, a journalist, said the campaign was intended to keep Labor from being re-elected in 1974 and to remove Heath and former Northern Ireland Minister William Whitelaw from top positions in the Conservative Party. Heath and Whitelaw had made contact with the IRA as part of the government effort to solve the problems of the troubled province. Wallace said the campaign also involved preparing forged documents to smear the Labor Party. Merlyn Rees, Labor's Northern Ireland secretary at the time, said a pro-IRA statement was doctored to include his name and suggest he was sympathetic to terrorism. Confirmation of ``Clockwork Orange'' came during an announcement by Armed Forces Minister Archie Hamilton of an investigation of the Defense Ministry decision to fire Wallace. The government accused Wallace of passing a restricted document to a journalist. After appealing, he was allowed to resign. Wallace took a public relations job, but in 1981 was convicted of the manslaughter of a friend and served five years in prison. Foot's book focuses on that killing and suggests Wallace was framed. ``A Clockwork Orange'' is the title of a novel by Anthony Burgess, published in 1962, about extreme forms of mind control in a totalitarian state. A movie based on it was released in 1971.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Willing To Meet de Klerk, Mandela Separately
With AM-South Africa Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will invite both Nelson Mandela and F.W. de Klerk to pay separate visits to the White House if and when South African authorities free Mandela from prison, a spokesman announced Thursday. Bush, through his press secretary, praised de Klerk's ``courageous and important steps'' to end apartheid and move toward ``a democratic and non-racial South Africa.'' Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater revealed plans to proffer the invitations amid news reports that Mandela's release after 27 years in prison could come as early as Friday. But Fitzwater said, ``I have no independent information on his release.'' Mandela, 71, leader of the outlawed African National Congress, has been imprisoned for more than 27 years for sedition for planning the start of the ANC's guerrilla campaign. De Klerk is scheduled to deliver a major address to Parliament on Friday. Aides have denied reports that he personally met with Mandela earlier in the week to discuss terms of Mandela's release. They did meet last Dec. 13 and since then, both the white minority-ruled government and Mandela's ANC movement have given increasingly serious consideration to the possibility of negotiations. Fitzwater said in a statement: ``The president has been closely following the situation in South Africa. He believes that President de Klerk has taken a number of courageous and important steps aimed at ending apartheid and moving toward a democratic and non-racial South Africa. ``Should Mandela be released, the president would plan to invite both Mandela and de Klerk separately to meet with him at the White House so the president can determine how the U.S. can best help South Africa move forward toward a non-racial government and society.'' Earlier, Fitzwater told reporters Bush would invite Mandela ``to Washington for a visit as soon as it is convenient for him.'' ``We will certainly support his release. We're hopeful he will be,'' said Fitzwater. Mandela's release is seen as necessary before black leaders will enter negotiations. South Africa's 5 million whites have maintained control through apartheid laws that severely restricted the political and economic rights of the country's 26 million blacks. But the apartheid system, buffeted by international condemnation and protests from within, has begun to weaken in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: Man Becomes Grandfather Same Hour Wife Gives Birth to Fourth Child
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rennee is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Pregnant women may eat for two, but Ygnacio Haro found himself pacing for two at Fresno Community Hospital. His wife and daughter gave birth within an hour Wednesday, making Haro the father of a 6-pound, 3-ounce girl at 10:15 p.m. and grandfather of a 6-pound, 15-ounce girl at 10:58 p.m. ``We didn't think they would both give birth the same day _ it just turned out that way,'' Haro said. ``My daughter was married last April and my wife and I talked about having another kid, and it just came to pass.'' The infant girl is the fourth child for Haro and his wife, Betty, who have a 10-year-old son and a 15-year-old daughter, in addition to their oldest daughter, Rennee Carrillo. The baby girl is Carrillo's first. At 41, Haro said he's looking forward to having an infant in the house again. ``Half the fun of having kids is taking care of them and seeing them grow up and be on their own,'' Haro said. But he said, ``I think this will be our last one. My wife is 40 and I think we're getting a little old _ there's nothing wrong, just a little old. ``But anything is possible,'' Haro added.

DOC.HEAD: President to Visit California, Nebraska and Ohio
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will visit California, Nebraska and Ohio next week on a trip combining visits to military installations with fund-raising efforts for Republican candidates. The White House said Thursday Bush will fly to Barstow, Calif., on Tuesday to watch battlefield maneuvers at the National Training Center at Fort Irwin, then attend a major fund-raiser that night in Los Angeles for Sen. Pete Wilson, who is running for governor. On Wednesday he will visit the University of California's Livermore Laboratory before addressing the Commonwealth Club in San Francisco. He then will fly to Omaha, Neb., for the night. After attending a fund-raising breakfast for Gov. Kay Orr on Thursday, Bush will visit the headquarters of the Strategic Air Command, then fly to Columbus, Ohio for a GOP fund-raising dinner there that evening before returning to Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Kennedy Calls for Deeper Defense Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Edward M. Kennedy proposed Thursday a five-year, $139 billion cut in defense spending below the levels President Bush wants. Kennedy said the savings should go to reducing the deficit and financing domestic programs. The Massachusetts Democrat said improvements in East-West relations justify a siphoning of defense dollars into education, environment, anti-drug and other social initiatives. Kennedy, a senior member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, did not say where the defense cuts should be made. He said that, ``just as starters,'' he would favor cuts in the Strategic Defense Initiative, the MX mobile missile and the B2 stealth bomber. ``What America needs now is bold leadership on defense, not cold leftovers from the right wing's Cold War kitchen,'' Kennedy told reporters. ``And if President Bush won't supply that leadership, Congress should.'' Kennedy proposed cutting defense spending in fiscal 1991 to $292 billion in outlays, $11 billion lower than Bush proposed in the budget he released Monday. Kennedy said he wanted spending to decline gradually to $274 billion in fiscal 1995. Under Bush's plan, military spending would be $319 billion in 1995. Kennedy said he hoped that his proposed defense cuts would permit tax cuts, as well as shrink the federal deficit and better finance domestic programs.

DOC.HEAD: Darman, King Urge AARP to Fight Moynihan Tax-Cut Plan
DOC.TEXT: Budget director Richard G. Darman called on the nation's largest senior citizen organization Thursday to help fight a proposed Social Security tax cut that he said would inescapably threaten benefits. ``I would urge you all to consider ever so seriously what really is at stake here,'' Darman told leaders of the American Association of Retired Persons. ``This is not something to play around with.'' The administration is fighting a proposal by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., that would roll back the Social Security tax increase that took effect Jan. 1 and further reduce the levy next year. The tax was raised from 7.51 percent of the first $51,300 of wages to 7.65 percent, with the employer paying an equal amount. Moynihan wants it rolled back to 5.1 percent eventually. A principal aim of the proposal is to prevent the government from using surplus Social Security taxes to make the overall federal deficit appear smaller than it is. Darman told the AARP's 38-member legislative council that Moynihan's plan would do nothing to solve the deficit problem yet would be ``inescapably a threat to Social Security benefits.'' He asked the group ``to draw upon the enormous respect that you command, that we do not command,'' to lobby Congress against the plan. Darman was followed to the lectern by Social Security Commissioner Gwendolyn King, who made a promise when she was sworn in six months ago to snarl ``like a junkyard dog'' if anyone threatened Social Security. ``The junkyard dog is going to do a little bit of growling,'' Mrs. King told the group. ``I shouldn't have to remind this group how important the trust fund is.'' Mrs. King urged the AARP to speak out strongly against the Moynihan proposal. The AARP's legislative council on Friday will make policy recommendations to the organization's executive committee. ``I'm not going to press you, but I do want you to know how important it is that you not leave me out here by myself, that you not cop out of this debate,'' she said. Mrs. King said that if the payroll tax were reduced, ``it's not far down the road, I can assure you, that somebody's going to come back and suggest benefit cuts.'' The AARP council heard from Moynihan, who also sought its support, earlier this week. He disputed administration claims that his plan would threaten benefits. The arguments from both sides were politely received, but council members divided on who is right. Dennis Crites, a council member from Norman, Okla., said Moynihan's plan had helped draw attention to the budget problems, but he said ``it develops a life of its own, it may be damaging.'' Lou Schwartz of Teaneck, N.J., said he likes Moynihan's plan because it would ``lower the taxes on those who can least afford to pay it and open the door to have the people that can afford to pay it pay it.'' The administration lobbying effort came just one day after President Bush urged Congress to keep hands off Social Security. However, two Republican lawmakers introduced bills Thursday that are variations of the Moynihan proposal. The two proposals: _By Sen. Robert Kasten, R-Wis., to reduce Social Security taxes in three steps to 6.75 percent in 1992. That would mean a three-year tax cut totaling $519 for a high-earning worker. Social Security surpluses would no longer be considered in calculating the federal deficit; the 1993 target date for balancing the budget would be extended to 1997. _By Rep. Hank Brown of Colorado, senior Republican on the House Ways and Means subcommittee on Social Security, to repeal this year's tax increase; take Social Security out of the deficit calculations, and require the government to report annually on whether the pension system is sound enough to provide benefits for future retirees. Brown's bill also would increase to $15,000 a year the amount of wages a person between the ages of 65 and 69 may earn without losing any Social Security benefit. Present law takes away $1 of pension for each $3 of wages above $9,360. Kasten said Congress is almost certain to at least repeal this year's Social Security tax increase. He predicted lawmakers will reject the ``politics of fear,'' which he described as allegations that cuts in taxes would lead to reductions in benefits.

DOC.HEAD: Boxes Offered as Shelter for Homeless
LaserPhoto PN1
DOC.TEXT: Some homeless people are testing portable cardboard shelters manufactured by an Illinois company for use by those who live on the streets. Three of the prototype Porta-Sleeper Shelters were given to homeless people by the Rev. Gerald Roseberry, who operates a ministry for the homeless. The 14-pound tent-like cardboard shelters are about 3 feet high and 3 feet wide and are coated to be water-resistant. The one-person shelters fold up and can be carried with a built-in handle. The shelters were proposed by Robert Silvert, a salesman for Gaylord Container Corp. of Deerfield, Ill. The company hopes to mass-produce them, but has yet to set the price, said a spokesman at Gaylord's headquarters. One of those testing the shelters, Leah Wilson, 21, approved of the sleeping box. ``So far it's all right. No problem,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: California County Gives Emergency Workers Anti-AIDS Drug
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters, police officers and health workers exposed to the AIDS virus on the job can get free doses of the drug AZT in a pioneering program in one California county, officials said Thursday. Orange County officials said they believe it is the first organized program nationwide to offer emergency workers access to the AIDS-fighting drug. ``Health care workers are not the only people who get exposed (to AIDS),'' said Dr. Tom Prendergast, chief epidemiologist for the county south of Los Angeles. Paramedics, police and others who risk exposure also should have use of AZT, he said Thursday. The program, implemented in September, was discussed by county AIDS coordinator Penny Weismuller at an AIDS conference Wednesday. Under the program, five public safety workers took AZT immediately after potential exposure to the virus, Ms. Weismuller said. Animal studies indicate that infection may be prevented if the drug is administered within 96 hours of exposure, she said. The therapy was suggested in August by researchers with the National Institutes of Health and the University of California, San Francisco, who have developed AZT programs for their health-care workers. The program is intended for workers involved in incidents which would put them at serious risk of exposure if the other person turned out to be infected with AIDS, Ms. Weismuller said. Examples would be cases where the worker is actually stabbed by a needle, or directly exposed to blood. The first person to take AZT under the Orange County program was a police officer who cut his arm while scuffling with a man, Ms. Weismuller said. Blood from a cut in the man's scalp dripped directly into a wound the officer sustained during the fight. ``The city called us right away, which was good, because we knew this suspect and knew he was (AIDS virus) positive,'' Ms. Weismuller said. The officer took the drug for the recommended four weeks and continues to test negative for the virus, she added. The four other workers given AZT took it for less than four days, she said. They stopped using the drug after the people they were exposed to tested negative for the virus. Anaheim Fire Chief Jeff Bowman said Thursday the AZT program must be viewed cautiously. ``I'm very much in favor of it, but it's not a cure-all,'' Bowman said. There are concerns about AZT side effects, which include nausea and headaches, and about long-term consequences such as cancer, he said. ``The best thing is prevention,'' Bowman said, noting that masks and gloves intended to prevent exposure to the AIDS virus have become standard gear for paramedics. The most common type of exposure occurs when workers handling needles contaminated with blood from an AIDS patient accidentally prick themselves, officials said. ``When you're working a car accident in the middle of a street at night, needles are flying everywhere,'' Bowman said. Orange County pays for the AZT therapy, but asks reimbursement from cities or worker-compensation plans, Ms. Weismuller said. The drug costs about $200 for the month-long period. Only about 4 percent of those who are directly exposed to the AIDS virus on the job develop the disease, said Julie Gerberding, a UC researcher. Orange County, population about 2.2 million, had an AIDS rate through November 1989 of 54.6 cases per 100,000 population, Prendergast said. That compares to a national rate of 45.3 cases per 100,000, he said.

DOC.HEAD: VOA Eliminating Turkish, Greek, Lao, Slovenian, Uzbek, Swahili Services
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government radio station Voice of America informed employees Thursday that budget cuts will silence six of its 43 language broadcasts on three continents. ``We are doing to ourselves what 30 years of Soviet jamming couldn't do,'' VOA Director Richard W. Carlson told hundreds of broadcasters, editors and engineers. ``This is the toughest and saddest day of my professional life.'' Going off the air by April 1 will be the Turkish, Greek, Slovenian, Lao, Uzbek and Swahili services. The 57 employees of those services will lose their jobs. Elimination of the six services will save VOA $2.9 million, officials said. VOA, which has been providing news and entertainment to millions of listeners since 1942, has been grappling with budget cuts for several years. Since 1987 it has laid off more than 200 people, shut down five bureaus in the United States and abroad, and eliminated hundreds of radio hours in various languages. ``If we don't get budget relief, more cuts could be possible,'' said Carlson. Carlson said VOA and its parent, the U.S. Information Agency, had decided that ``amputation'' of several services was preferable to ``dismemberment'' of broadcast departments across the board. The selection of the services to be eliminated was made in accordance with a list of priorities that takes into account the geopolitical importance of the targeted countries and the availability of other foreign media there. Radio Free Europe, the U.S.-funded, Munich-based radio network that broadcasts only to Eastern Europe, has an Uzbek service. The British Broadcasting Corporation broadcasts in Slovenian, as well as in Greek and Turkish. Laos, a landlocked, impoverished communist country, is the only one of the six which does not receive foreign language broadcasts. ``This will cripple our efforts at a time of unprecedented change and opportunity,'' Carlson said. He praised the employees for helping fan the winds of revolution blowing throughout the world. The elimination of the Slovenian service comes as residents of Slovenia are leading the surge of reform in Yugoslavia. But most Slovenians speak Serbo-Croatian, a VOA service which continues to air, Carlson said. VOA's problems were compounded this week when the administration's 1991 budget proposal released to Congress mandated the addition of a Tibetan language service. VOA officials estimate that if they air two hours a week of Tibetan programs, the new service will cost $1.5 million. VOA's operating budget for 1990 was about $170 million, and the budget for 1991 is expected to be $174 million. Carlson said this includes a 3.5 percent wage increase and still leaves VOA $1.5 million short. After announcing the cuts to the employees, Carlson read the names of each of the employees who will lose their jobs. Many of them have worked for VOA more than 20 years.

DOC.HEAD: CBS News Hires Drug Expert
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT Stutman's name to Robert, sted David.
DOC.TEXT: CBS News said Thursday it is hiring Robert M. Stutman, head of the Drug Enforcement Administration's office here, as its consultant on stories about drugs and crime after he retires from the DEA. Stutman, a 26-year veteran of law enforcement, plans to retire Feb. 28, and will start his job in news March 1, CBS said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls Cristiani `Shining Example' of Democrat Commitment
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday called El Salvador's President Alfredo Cristiani ``a shining example to all of us'' of democratic commitment, as the administration proposed a $62 million boost in aid to the Central American nation. The State Department said the administration is proposing $284 million for El Salvador in economic aid for fiscal 1991 compared with $229 million for the current year. Military aid would rise slightly, to $91.4 million from the current $84.6 million, if Congress approves. There is concern within the administration that congressional skepticism about human rights abuses in El Salvador, and in particular the slaying of six Jesuit priests last fall, might prompt a scaling back of El Salvador's aid package. Officials hope the arrest of eight military men in the case by Cristiani's government will diffuse the criticism. Bush sought to make clear Thursday that he is squarely behind Cristiani, praising him at a photo session for his diligence in the Jesuits' case. ``I know of his commitment to democracy,'' Bush said. ``I have been very impressed with the courage he has shown in going after those who have broken the law in his country. And he's been a shining example to all of us. ``I support him now. I will support him in the future. And the success of democracy in El Salvador is a very important thing to us, to this coutnry. While Bush and Cristiani met, a small group of protesters marched in front of the White House against continued U.S. aid to El Salvador. One carried a sign reading, ``kinder-gentler death squads,'' a reference to the right-wing groups _ linked in the past both to the military and to Cristiani's political party _ that have carried out many killings and tortured leftists in El Salvador. Cristiani said his talks at the White House and on Capitol Hill did not focus on the aid question as much as on efforts to restart peace talks with the leftist guerrillas battling his government. However, he told reporters, any cut in aid by Congress would send ``negative signals'' to the rebels that would impede efforts for peace talks. On Capitol Hill , Cristiani met with key House Democrats including Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash.; Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., and Rep. Jospeh Moakley, D-Mass., head of a House task force on El Salvador. Moakley said the congressmen ``let him know what our people are thinking'' about the human rights situation, particularly the Jesuit killings. While none of the congressmen threatened directly to try to cut off aid, some did tell Cristiani that ``votes for El Salvador aid have been diminishing over the years,'' Moakley said.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Relaxes Curfew Rules, Correspondents Given Orders to Leave
DOC.TEXT: The government further relaxed curfew restrictions in violence-wracked Kashmir Thursday and claimed the situation was improving, but a former chief minister said the Moslem agitation for secession was far from over. ``Kashmir is sitting on a volcano,'' said Farooq Abdullah, who resigned as chief minister, or the state's top elected official, on Jan. 19. ``We do not know if it will simmer down or blow up.'' Abdullah called on the government to initiate talks with militants seeking independence for the strategic northern state, which is claimed by both India and Pakistan. Since the government launched a crackdown on the secessionist movement Jan. 20, at least 72 mostly Moslem protesters died in confrontations with security forces. On Thursday, authorities lifted the curfew until evening and there were no reports of violence. When the curfew was reimposed, the last two reporters for foreign news media known to be in Srinagar received letters from a local official ordering them to leave the city. However, it remained to be seen whether the orders would be implemented. With the curfew back in force overnight, as it had been for the past 12 days, everyone in the city of 1 million was ordered to stay indoors. There were no flights out of Srinagar, virtually inaccessible by road, until Friday afternoon. The orders were issued to Dilip Ganguly of The Associated Press and Anil Penna of Agence France-Presse, both Indian citizens. The orders, issued in the name of the Srinagar district magistrate Ghulam Abbas, said the reporters' presence was ``adjudged prejudicial to the security of the state.'' At least six foreign journalists were expelled from Srinagar last weekend after receiving similar letters. The administration prepared for another possible showdown with the militants on Friday, the Moslem sabbath. New road blocks were erected in Srinagar on Thursday, and the deployment of troops increased. In Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, the Organization of Islamic Conference condemned the intervention of Indian police in Kashmir. The 46-member group that is an official forum for the world's predominantly Moslem nations, called on the Indian government to end what it said were repressive acts against Moslems. The Moslem movement for independence of Kashmir dates to 1947 but flared in recent months, bolstered by charges that Abdullah was incompetent and corrupt. Militants angered by his rule and what they called subservience to New Delhi threatened to kill him. Abdullah resigned in protest a day after the federal government appointed Jagmohan, a Hindu with only one name, as state governor. Jagmohan then assumed the administrative powers that revert to the governor in the absence of an elected state government and ordered a crackdown on the militant movement. Meanwhile, the government said it will release 10,000 copies of this week's edition of Newsweek magazine after taking ``corrective action,'' United News of India reported. The news agency said a map of Kashmir that appears in the current issue would be stamped ``Incorrect,'' because it depicts large parts of the state in Pakistan. Indian-held Kashmir is now part of Jammu-Kashmir state, the only Indian state with a Moslem majority. At least 64 percent of the state's 5 million people are Moslems. Nationwide, Moslems form 12 percent of the country's 880 million people, and Hindus 80 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Playwright Dennis McIntyre Dies of Stomach Cancer
DOC.TEXT: Dennis McIntyre, author of such plays as ``Split Second,'' ``Modigliani'' and ``National Anthems,'' died Thursday of stomach cancer. He was 47. McIntyre, who was born in Detroit, gained his biggest successes off-Broadway with ``Modigliani,'' produced in 1980, and ``Split Second,'' done in 1984. Several of his plays were presented at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, Conn., including ``National Anthems,'' and a recent workshop production of his last play, ``Established Price,'' starring Jason Robards. The Long Wharf production of ``National Anthems'' may be presented off-Broadway in the spring. McIntyre, who attended the University of Michigan and Carnegie-Mellon University, taught a playwriting seminar at the University of Michigan for three years. The school has established a Dennis McIntyre Playwriting Award in his memory. Survivors include his mother, Kathleen McIntyre of Detroit; a brother, John, of Texas, and a long-time companion, Karen Riedel, of New York. Funeral arrangements were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: Former Offer Changes Plea to Guilty in Spy Case
DOC.TEXT: A former military communications officer accepted a plea bargain with the government Thursday on charges he passed secret information to the Soviet Union. Frank Nesbitt pled guilty to an espionage charge, reversing an earlier plea that could have sent him to jail for life if convicted. The new agreement means a maximum prison term of 10 years. ``Did you do it?'' U.S. District Judge T.S. Ellis asked Nesbitt, 45. ``Yes, sir,'' Nesbitt said calmly. The judge set sentencing for March 16. The agreement does not entitle Nesbitt to parole. He also could be fined up to $250,000. According to earlier testimony by the government, Nesbitt went to the FBI last October to tell of an odyssey that led him through Central and South America and on to the Soviet Union and back. His attorney claimed Nesbitt simply wanted ``some excitement in his life.'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Mark Hulkower said Nesbitt passed on information to the Soviets later determined by the National Security Agency to be classified. He was indicted in November on espionage charges. Nesbitt testified Thursday that he did not realize that the material was classified. ``It was my true and honest effort not to do that,'' he responded to the judge's questions. FBI Special Agent Lizzie Cassell testified in October that Nesbitt left his wife and two children in Millington, Tenn., last June. He left behind a note saying: ``Don't look for me. I'm gone.'' Nesbitt said Thursday he decided to go to the Soviet Union during his travels in Bolivia last year. In the Soviet Union he was kept in a safe house for a few days until he failed a lie detector test. The Soviet KGB agents broke off the contacts, he said. He said he had agreed to cooperate with the Soviets after they showed him a picture of his two children taken outside his Tennessee home. Nesbitt said two Soviet agents followed him back to the United States. He later went to the FBI. Ms. Cassell said Nesbitt, who was not charged at the time, ended the questioning. A few days later he was arrested at a Virginia hotel. Nesbitt served from 1963 to 1966 in the Air Force's Electronic Security Command in West Germany and from 1969 to 1979 in the Marine Corps, where he dealt with classified communications gathering. He also worked at the Los Alamos National Laboratories from 1983 to 1984. In all his jobs he maintained a top secret code word clearance. His attorney, David Hopkins, responded to a reporter's question about why Nesbitt accepted the guilty plea by saying: ``A recognition of the strength of the government's case. This is 10 years, the other is life. It's enough to give anyone pause.''

DOC.HEAD: Treasury Secretary Hails Third World Debt Strategy
DOC.TEXT: Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady on Thursday said he was satisfied with the achievements of the administration's much-criticized Third World debt strategy and predicted more success in the coming year. Brady said that the first agreement, with Mexico, would be signed this Sunday and he predicted that another agreement would be finalized by mid-month with the Philippines. He said that an agreement with Costa Rica was expected before the end of March and that later in the year debt reduction packages could be reached with two of the Third World's largest debtors, Venezuela and Brazil. ``I am very pleased with the progress that we have made in the attempts to alleviate Third World debt,'' Brady said in answer to a question before the Senate Budget Committee. ``I think a pattern is beginning to emerge whereby we can deal with these problems.'' The administration's debt strategy, often referred to as the Brady debt plan, was unveiled by the Treasury secretary in March 1989. It had an initial goal of cutting the commercial bank debt of 39 countries, chiefly in Latin America, by 20 percent. The plan envisioned using incentives supplied by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank to entice commercial banks to voluntarily forgive a portion of their old debt in exchange for guarantees that the reduced debt would be repaid. Critics, however, said the deal with Mexico, considered a test case for the Brady plan, produced debt relief far below what had been hoped and that other countries were even further from reaching agreements with commercial banks. But Brady said the debt plan, while setting ``enormous goals,'' had been working well in producing a variety of debt reduction packages that will soon be signed. ``Starting from scratch this past year, we now have some of the machinery down, working rather smoothly so that we don't have to re-invent the wheel every time we do one of these transactions,'' he said. On another topic, Brady acknowledged that the administration's proposal to cut the tax on corporate profits envisoned that the measure would be enacted by March 1, 1990, a goal that Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., called totally unrealistic. If it does not go into effect until later in the year, it will reduce by a significant amount the $4.9 billion in revenues the administration is anticipating receiving from persons selling off their assets to take advantage of the lower tax rate. The $4.9 billion represents the biggest revenue measure in the administration's 1991 budget, which was unveiled on Monday. Sasser said that enactment of the capital gains cut would not come before September or October at the earliest. Brady said that a delay in enacting the proposal would cut into the revenues the administration is counting on to reduce the budget deficit and ``we will have to figure out a way to make up the shortfall.'' Brady refused to answer a reporter's question after the hearing about where the administration might look to make up the lost revenue. Asked by reporters about repeated rumors that he is considering resigning, Brady termed such reports ``absolutely untrue'' and compared the rumors to recent resignation rumors involving Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. ``I am delighted to be included in the same category as General Secretary Gorbachev,'' Brady said.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Parents Killed Son for Insurance Money
DOC.TEXT: Parents who allegedly plotted with their son to kill his ex-wife for insurance money later turned on their offspring, helping shoot and kill him for a $70,000 policy, authorities said Thursday. The father taped the son's hands and drove him to his death, and the mother followed behind in a getaway car, said Broward Sheriff's Office spokesman George Crolius. The father, Theron Morris, 76; the mother, Leila Mary Morris, 62; and the victim's roommate, Martin Wayne Rector, 34, were all in the Broward County Jail on Thursday charged with first-degree murder. The body of Christopher Morris, 42, was discovered in his car Jan. 9, Crolius said. ``Homicide detectives determined that the victim had developed a plan to murder his ex-wife and 10-year-old daughter for $35,000 in insurance,'' Crolius said. Rector was to do the killing, with the proceeds divided among him and the Morris family, authorities said. ``But when it was learned that the insurance policy had lapsed, the parents and Rector then devised a plan to murder Chris Morris for a $70,000 policy on his life,'' the spokesman said. Rector was arrested Wednesday, and he implicated the parents, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Sudan Says It Takes Two Towns from Rebels; Mercy Flight Thwarted
DOC.TEXT: The government said Thursday its forces recaptured two southern towns _ Yei and Lanya _ lost to rebels of the Sudan People's Liberation Army in a recent, violent step-up of the civil war. No word on the claim came from the rebels, who have reported seizing 12 towns in the south the last few months. The armed forces general command also announced its troops killed 95 rebels in an attack on a base in the Upper Nile region, north of Equatoria. Its communique said seven soldiers died in the ``intensive and successful mop-up operation,'' but gave no date. In Nairobi, capital of adjacent Kenya, relief workers said Sudanese air traffic controllers denied landing permission Thursday to an plane ferrying emergency food to Juba, the beleaguered capital of the Equatoria regional that is 750 miles south of Khartoum. ``It seems the civil aviation people in Khartoum didn't get details of the aircraft,'' said Bob Koepp of the Lutheran World Federation. ``We got permission and everything.'' Koepp said the Hercules C-130 returned to Nairobi in the morning with its cargo of 15 tons of corn donated by the Italian government. ``We are at them and hope to fly tomorrow,'' said Koepp, whose Nairobi office is responsible for the Lutheran group's activities in southern Sudan. Koepp said that a Boeing 707 leased by the Lutherans from Sudan Airways was permitted to deliver 30 tons of corn to Juba Thursday. The army command announced recovery of Yei, lost to the rebels in December, in a statement published by the military's newspaper, Al-Kuwat Al-Musallaha. It did not say when the army recaptured Yei, 80 miles southeast of Juba. The report said the rebels suffered heavy casualties, but gave no figures. Mop-up operations cleared the areas around Yei, it said. The official Sudan News Agency (SUNA) quoted military officials as saying government troops on Wednesday recaptured Lanya after ``a fierce battle.'' Lanya, about 30 miles southwest of Juba on the road linking that city with Yei, had fallen to the rebels last month. The officials were quoted as saying ``great numbers of rebels were killed or wounded'' and that eight soldiers died. Large quantities of arms and equipment were seized, including a Soviet-made T-55 tank and launchers for rocket-propelled grenades, they said. SUNA quoted an official as saying seizure of the tank ``proves the interference of a neighboring country alongside the rebels in the fighting in both eastern and western Equatoria.'' He did not identify the country but was believed referring to Marxist-ruled Ethiopia, frequently accused by Sudan of aiding the rebels. The Sudan People's Liberation Army has been fighting since early 1983 against the Moslem-dominated Khartoum government for administrative and economic reforms in the south, inhabited mostly by Christians and animists. Recent evacuees say that Juba's estimated 300,000 residents are prevented by armed soldiers from leaving. Juba, on the west bank of the White Nile river, is ringed with land mines planted by both soldiers and rebels. The rebels have subjected Juba to sporadic artillery bombardment and have virtually cut all land routes to the city. Koepp said his organization has 2,500 tons of Italian-donated corn awaiting delivery to Juba and expects to receive additional food from other donors soon. Only the Lutherans have delivered non-Sudanese government food supplies to Juba since Khartoum banned relief flights Nov. 3 after an informal cease-fire with the rebels broke down. Lam Akol, a Liberation Army spokesman, said on Wednesday in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, that relief flights ``fly at their own risk.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Makes Nomination for EPA Post
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday said he would nominate Erich W. Bretthauer to be assistant administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency for research and development, a position he now holds in an acting capacity. Bretthauer, 52, has worked for EPA since 1968, with two years off in the early 1980s to serve as a staff assistant with the Senate Enviornment and Public Works Committee. He has been acting assistant administrator since 1988. From 1985 to 1988, he headed the EPA's environmental monitoring laboratory in Las Vegas, where he maintains a residence. Bush also announced he would nominate Glen L. Bower of Effingham, Ill., to be chairman of the Railroad Retirement Board. Bower, 59, is currently general counsel for the Illinois Department of Revenue. If confirmed by the Senate, Bower would succeed Thomas J. Simon for the remainder of a term that expires Aug. 28, 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Burley Tobacco Quota Up 2.5 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Burley tobacco farmers will have a 1990 national marketing quota of 602.3 million pounds, up 2.5 percent from last year's 587.6 million pounds, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter announced Thursday. Burley tobacco is grown primarily in Kentucky, Tennessee and surrounding states. The following provisions also were announced: _Price support for the 1990 crop will be $1.558 per pound, up 2.6 cents from the 1989 level. _Each farm's basic quota will increase about 2.5 percent from last year. _The effective quota nationally, which takes into consideration undermarketings and overmarketings, will be about 743 million pounds, up 82 million from last year. _Price support loans to producer associations will be subject to a 1.4 percent reduction under the budget deficit sequester order. _The no-net cost assessment to finance the program will be announced later.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Say U.S. Troop Cuts Aren't Enough, Upset by Bush Speech
With AM-Europe-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's proposal for deeper troop cuts in Central Europe was a step in the right direction but did not go far enough, Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said Thursday. In a surprise overture, Bush proposed in his State of the Union message Wednesday a cut in military manpower in Europe to 195,000 troops on each side. The previous U.S. bargaining position at conventional force negotiations in Vienna was 275,000 on each side. ``It's a good sign that things are changing for the better,'' Gerasimov said in the regular news briefing. ``Some observers note that the events in Europe run ahead of the slow diplomatic negotiations.'' Gerasimov also complained that Bush seemed to take credit for the ``revolution of 1989,'' as the American president called the democratic reforms that have occurred in much of Eastern Europe since last summer. He said attempts to show these events as a triumph of U.S. ideals and a failure of communism ``are a relic of the Cold War.'' He added that the U.S. invasion of Panama last December was also proof of this attitude. Gerasimov criticized the Bush proposal for not going further. ``You can note in his speech that he needs American troops in Europe from here to eternity _ 125,000 or about this figure. This is not a good sign.'' ``We, together with Les Aspin (chairman of the U.S. House Armed Services Committee), feel it must be the ceiling, not the floor,'' Gerasimov said. Bush said in his speech that he and America's European allies agree ``that an American military presence in Europe is essential and that it should not be tied solely to the Soviet military presence in Eastern Europe.'' Gerasimov also complained that the proposal applies only to troops in Central Europe and would leave the United States with 30,000 or more servicemen in England, Greece and other countries in Europe. ``So it comes out that the U.S. is to have 235,000 troops,'' Gerasimov said. This will have to be considered at the conventional arms talks in Vienna, Austria, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Former AID Official Pleads Guilty
DOC.TEXT: A former Agency for Internatiional Development official pleaded guilty Thursday to illegally receiving $80,000 from a laboratory that received malaria research grants from the agency. James M. Erickson, 42, who was head of AID's communicable disease division and manager of the malaria research project, faces a possible 10 years imprisonment on his guilty pleas to three felony charges, the Justice Department said. Erickson pleaded guilty to one count of making a false statement, a count of receiving illegal gratuities and a charge of filing a false tax return, the department said. U.S. District Judge Claude M. Hilton of Alexandria, Va., scheduled sentencing for April 6. Erickson, who agreed to cooperate with the continuing investigation, admitted receiving $88,000 in payments from KT&R Laboratories of Stillwater, Minn., which received research grants from the malaria program, the department said. Erickson also admitted accepting unlawful gratuities totaling more than $20,000 from the sale of monkeys used in malaria research. The false statement conviction stemmed from Erickson's admission that he failed to disclose his financial interest in a company called IIR&D-Guatamala, which was set up to receive the payments from KT&R, the department said. He also admitted failing to declare $68,000 in income on his 1986 income tax return.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Announces Civilian Drug Testing
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force has specified some 24,000 civilian workers holding sensitive jobs as eligible for random drug testing and expects to begin the tests by the end of the month, the Pentagon announced Thursday. ``We're looking at testing approximately 6,000 employees per year,'' said an Air Force spokesman, Maj. Lou Figueroa. Employees who test positive will not be allowed to remain in their jobs and will be referred to a substance-abuse counseling program. They will also be subject to ``appropriate disciplinary action,'' which could include a written reprimand, suspension or firing, a Pentagon statement said. The program is designed ``to ensure employees refrain from using illegal drugs on or off duty,'' and also will include applicants for the posts deemed to be sensitive, the Pentagon statement said. All of the tests will screen for marijuana or cocaine use. Tests for amphetamines, opiates and PCP can be ordered, the spokesman said. The Air Force has some 566,000 military personnel and 260,000 civilian employees. All active-duty military personnel have been subject to random drug tests since 1981. The Air Force has begun bargaining with the affected labor unions on the matter, the statement said. The program is designed to affect those civlians occupying or applying for positions that directly relate to ``the public health and safety, the protection of life and property, law enforcement and national security,'' the statement said. Example of those positions include firefighters, police, medical personnel, criminal investigators, air traffic controllers, aircraft mechanics, employees associated with nuclear weapons or those with access to sensitive national security information, the statement said. All other civilians could be subject to testing if there is a ``reasonable suspicion'' of illegal drug use, or following accidents, safety mishaps or as a follow-up to a rehabilitation program for illegal drug use. Figueroa said such a suspicion could be based upon such things as the direct observation of drug use or possession by an employee, abnormal conduct or erratic behavior, or arrest or conviction of a drug-related offense. The Army has been testing its civilian workforce since 1986, but the Navy isn't conducting random tests of its civilian employees because of a lawsuit. Pentagon spokesman William Caldwell said civilians in the Office of Secretary of Defense have been randomly tested for drugs since April 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Withdraws Silverman Nomination After Critics Hit No-Job Portfolio
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has withdrawn the nomination of GOP fund-raiser Joy Silverman as ambassador to Barbados in the face of complaints from Capitol Hill that she lacked qualifications. Instead, Bush named Mrs. Silverman to the board of trustees of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. Mrs. Silverman, a New Yorker, was one of several Bush ambassadorial appointees who critics said were being rewarded for her contribution to Bush's political campaign. She had no job history. Sen. Paul Sarbanes, D-Md., last year produced a list of $300,000 worth of political contributions by Mrs. Silverman, her husband, Jeffery Silverman and her husband's wood products company, Playgem, to Republican campaigns. Federal Election Commission records show she gave $100,000 to the Republican National Committee in 1988. Ambassadorial appointments require Senate confirmation. The Kennedy Center post does not. Officially, the White House said that Mrs. Silverman asked that her name be withdrawn ``for family reasons.'' ``The president remains fully confident in Mrs. Silverman and her capacity for pulic service, and is pleased she has agreed to devote her considerble energy to the Kennedy Center,'' the White House said in a statement. After the Senate sent Mrs. Silverman's nomination back to Bush last year, the White House did not resubmit it for another fight this year. She worked full time on Bush's campaign in New York, and was a member of the Advisory Councl to the New York state Commission on Bicentennial of the United States Constitution in 1987-88. She also was a member of the New York City Mayor's Commission for Protocol. The Barbados ambassador is accredited also to Dominica, Saint Lucia, and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines.

DOC.HEAD: Most VMI Cadets Seek To Remain A Breed Apart
DOC.TEXT: The federal government wants Virginia Military Institute to admit women, but some cadets said Thursday that would destroy a proud 150-year tradition of discipline and unity among the student body. ``I kind of felt all along it would be inevitable, hoping that it wouldn't,'' said Tony Marro, 20, of Ilion, N.Y. The U.S. Justice Department announced Wednesday it would bring a sex discrimination lawsuit against VMI if the college _ part of the state university system _ doesn't agree by Feb. 20 to admit women. But state Attorney General Mary Sue Terry has said she would defend the school if it continues to turn away women. ``There are viable defenses to VMI's admission policy,'' said Bert Rohrer, a Terry spokesman. ``If they chose to continue the policy, she would defend it.'' The Justice Department said its investigation concluded the policy violates the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the 14th Amendment to the Constitution, which guarantees every citizen equal protection under the law. The investigation was prompted by a written complaint in March from a female high school student who wanted to attend the college, known for the military-style discipline of its uniformed ``cadets,'' though it isn't part of the military. Gov. L. Douglas Wilder refused to say whether he supports admitting women to VMI. ``The ultimate responsibility as to what takes place rests with the board of visitors,'' Wilder said, referring to the school's appointed governing body. The VMI board of visitors' next scheduled meeting is March 29-31, well after the Justice Department deadline, said Tom Joynes, the school's public affairs officer. No special meeting has been scheduled, Joynes said. VMI officials said it would be inappropriate to comment about the federal government's action and referred all questions to Terry's office. The school reaffirmed its single-sex policy in 1986 and told the Justice Department in April that coeducation would undermine its mission. But most cadets oppose the admission of women, said Benjamin Dorman, a 20-year-old cadet. ``The system functions better with men only. To allow women would cause too many changes,'' he said. ``I don't think they could cut it, physically.'' But Dorman, like many of the other cadets, believe the campus will soon be coeducational. ``I just got clobbered by my roommates for saying what I think,'' said Jim Blankenship, a 19-year-old sophomore from Roanoke. ``I think women should come.'' But another cadet overheard the comment and yelled as he walked away, ``Maybe I should buy you a skirt, Blankenship.'' The 1,200-student college in Virginia's western mountains, which offers bachelor's degrees and is known for its engineering program, is one of just two state-supported all-male military schools left in the country. The other is the Citadel in South Carolina. As at military prep schools, cadets wear military-style uniforms, and many join the service after graduation. The schools, supporters say, instill discipline, pride and self-reliance, and forge bonds among the cadets. All of VMI's cadets live in a three-story dormitory in spartan rooms with standard cots, shelves and desks. They wake to reveille and the freshmen, called ``rats'' by upperclassmen, have to keep their heads shaved and be ready at any time for inspections. Marro said the unity would suffer if women are admitted. ``The whole system takes place in the barracks,'' he said. ``The thing with rats coming together as a class, I think that would be affected. If they build a separate barracks for women it will be hard to maintain unity.'' Meantime, state Sen. Emilie F. Miller has introduced a bill in the General Assembly that would force VMI to admit women. ``I would hope that the state would not go to court, that we would do the right thing,'' she said. But Sen. Elmon T. Gray, D-Waverly and a VMI graduate, said the state should fight the Justice Department. ``I've never felt VMI is in violation,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Reaction to Bush Troop Cut Proposal
With AM-US-Troop Cuts Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Some reaction to President Bush's proposal that Moscow and Washington seek agreement on deeper troop cuts in Europe:

``We must continue to have as our goal no foreign troops on foreign soil. ..You can note in his (Bush's) speech he needs American troops in Europe for here to eternity. ... This is not a goo sign.'' _ Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov.

Britain attaches ``great importance to President Bush's assurance that the new figure will be a floor and that no more reductions are envisaged. ... This will ensure a continued strong American presence in Europe.'' _ Statement from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain.

``An important step on the road to disarmament. ... Bush set an objective that takes into account at the same time Europeans' desire for disaramament and their security concerns.'' _ Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France.
``A balanced combination of disarmament policy and unequivocal recognition of the West's defense readiness and alliance solidarity.'' _ Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg of West Germany.
``The presence of U.S. troops in Europe is still needed. We don't see it as a problem if their presence would be at a lower level than now.'' _ Foreign Minister Kjell Magne Bondevik of Norway.

``Caution is in order. ... The Soviet Union remains the only nation on Earth capable of destroying the United States.'' Defense Secretary Richard Cheney cautioning that even if all Soviet troops leave Eastern Europe, Moscow would retain its geographic advantage in the event of a European crisis.

Soviet troops are ``going to get out of Eastern Europe whether they like it or not without any agreement with the United States. They're going to kick them out. And we're waiting here to do things until we have the agreement. ... I'm not saying strip until we're naked. I'm saying do sensible things now here in our country even without agreements.'' _ Sen. Alan Dixon, D-Ill.

``While we will reduce the number of our forces in Europe, there is nothing whatsoever on the horizon that indicates to me that we can disengage from the continent entirely.'' _ Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
``Just when you thought you had a Cold War budget _ boom. I'm really delighted. There's hope.'' _ Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo.
``Trying to negotiate lower limits on forces deployed in Europe is clearly a good idea.'' _ Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of House Armed Services Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Oilseed Farmers Losing Market Share; Want In Farm Program
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration will give Congress some guidelines for writing the 1990 farm bill, including ideas for stimulating oilseed production, but won't introduce legislation of its own, a Senate committee was told Thursday. Foreign competition and restrictions in the American farm program that discourage crop rotation have caused declines in U.S. production of soybeans and sunflowers, according to industry experts and commodity groups. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter will spell out the administration's proposals in an appearance before the Senate Agriculture Committee next week, said Assistant Secretary Bruce Gardner. Bush's proposed 1991 budget called for cutting spending on farm commodity programs by $1.5 billion, but the administration didn't suggest how the reductions would be made. Gardner refused to divulge any of the administration's ideas in advance Thursday, despite complaints from Democratic members of an Agriculture Committee subcommittee on production and price stabilization who questioned the president's interest in farm policy. ``You are going to have a lot to work off of,'' said Gardner, who contended Bush ``is interested in farm policy as much as any other president has been.'' Most recent presidents have introduced their own farm bills, said Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., who noted that Bush mentioned the issue only in passing during Wednesday's State of the Union address. The administration believes the 1990 farm bill should give farmers more flexibility to rotate crops from year to year, which could encourage producers to plant more soybeans, sunflowers and canola rather than program crops like corn, said Gardner. ``The key word there is flexibility, but the question is how to achieve it,'' Gardner said. Restrictions in the 1985 farm bill discourage farmers from planting non-program crops, while at the same time lower production costs in South America and heavy European subsidies have combined to cut into the U.S. share of the world oilseed market, industry experts told the committee. ``World trade has leveled off since 1980 causing a 19 percent decline in U.S. soybean acreage while soybean acreage inother areas of the world, especially South America's acreage, has increased,'' said Purdue University economist J. William Uhrig.

DOC.HEAD: States Decry Proposed Cut in Poor's Fuel Aid
DOC.TEXT: The recent surge in heating oil prices and record cold makes this the wrong time for the Bush administration to seek a 25 percent reduction in a program to help the poor pay heating bills, state officials told Congress on Thursday. Even the current appropriation of $1.39 billion for the 1990 fiscal year is barely adequate to meet the needs of the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program, state regulators and community activists told a House Education and Labor subcommittee hearing. President Bush proposed as part of his fiscal 1991 budget on Monday that the Department of Health of Human Services make a $350 million cut in the aid plan, which served 5.9 million households last year. Administration officials said the energy ``crisis'' that spawned the program no longer existed. The aid program began in the wake of rapid increase in energy costs in the late 1970s, and after reports of the deaths of an elderly Syracuse, N.Y., couple who froze to death in an unheated house. The program provides funds to states for heating and cooling assistance, and weatherization. Lynda Crandall of the Michigan Department of Social Services told the subcommittee on human resources that high energy costs were largely a responsibility of the federal government. She said new program cuts ``will increase homelessness and otherwise threaten the health and safety of low income citizens. ``While Michigan stands ready to contribute its fair share, the federal government must take the lead in solving the low income energy assistance problem which results from national economic and energy policy,'' she said. In Pennsylvania, community activist Janet Parrish said the December cold snap and temporary jump in home heating oil prices _ as high as $1.62 per gallon _ worsened backlogs in processing aid applications. Already, Pennsylvania and other states have struggled to compensate for previous program cuts by using state oil overcharge funds. ``Congress needs to take a stand on behalf of the needy,'' said Dick Sievers, executive director of Mid-Sioux Opportunity Inc., a community action group in Remsen, Iowa. Eunice Thomas, acting assistant secretary at the Family Support Administration of HHS, said home energy costs did not fluctuate as often in the 1980s as in the 1970s, and ``the national crisis has long passed.'' When temporary price increases occur as in December, she said the problems were generally confined to a specific area or fuel and could be dealt with at the state level.

DOC.HEAD: Three More Killed in Kosovo; Serbs Evacuated
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with seven grafs to UPDATE with additional death, details. Picks up 5th, `Tanks also ... with minor editing thereafter to trim and conform
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos PRI2,3,5,9
DOC.TEXT: Trainloads of Serbs fled Kosovo province as protests by ethnic Albanians resulted in three more deaths Thursday, the official news agency Tanjug reported. The nine-day toll now stands at 21. Soviet-made T-54 and T-72 tanks patrolled streets and air force jets and helicopters filled the skies as demonstrators gathered at noon in towns across Kosovo, an impoverished region adjacent to Albania where 90 percent of the 1.9 million people are ethnic Albanians. Two deaths occurred in Podujevo, 20 miles north of the provincial capital of Pristina, during a five-hour demonstration, Tanjug said. The protesters were killed as demonstrators attacked a column of military and police vehicles, the Belgrade daily Borba reported in Friday editions. The third death Thursday occurred in Magura, a village near Lipljan, 11 miles south of Pristina, Tanjug said without giving particulars. An Associated Press reporter saw columns of army tanks and armored personnel carriers approaching from the direction of the the Serbian republic, of which Kosovo is an autonomous province. Military jets flew overhead. Tanjug said about 700 Serbs were evacuated Thursday, including 400 children. Tanks also were deployed in February and March 1989, during a spasm of ethnic violence connected with constitutional changes made by Serbia in an attempt to gain greater control over Kosovo. Twenty-eight people were reported killed last year. Two shifts of miners refused to enter pits Thursday at the Stari Trg mine at Trepca near Titova Mitrovica, 25 miles north of Pristina, as a gesture of homage to dead protesters, Tanjug reported. The agency said they also signed a human rights declaration. Last year's ethnic strife began with a sit-in at the mine in February. During the miners' protest, police fired tear gas to prevent about 2,000 ethnic Albanians massed at the outskirts of Titova Mitrovica from entering the city, the news agency reported. Before the latest deaths were announced, the provincial government said 18 ethnic Albanians had been killed since the violence began Jan. 24. It said 54 ethnic Albanians and 45 policemen had been injured. Ethnic Albanians want more autonomy, a halt to political trials, release of political prisoners and an end to the year-old state of emergency. Official media have described the region as verging on civil war. Yugoslavia's central government said Thursday the situation is ``further deteriorating,'' and the official news agency Tanjug called it ``dramatic.'' The government also said a ``dialogue should be opened with democratic forces in Kosovo.'' Leaders of independent groups in Kosovo issued a statement Thursday urging federal authorities to negotiate with ethnic Albanians in order to avoid a full-scale uprising. ``Ethnic Albanians are not terrorists,'' the statement said. ``They are subjected to terror by the state.'' Violence in Kosovo has caused a backlash in some other parts of Yugoslavia, a loose federation of six republics and two autonomous provinces, including demands by Slavs for weapons so they can fight in Kosovo for the Slavic minority. Thousands of Serbs held anti-Albanian demonstrations in their republic Thursday, including about 5,000 in Novi Sad, 30 miles north of Belgrade, capital of both Yugoslavia and Serbia. As many as 100,000 Slavs, some firing guns into the air, rallied on Wednesday in Titograd, capital of Montenegro. Some demanded weapons and volunteered to fight ethnic ``Albanian nationalists'' in neighboring Kosovo. Thousands of Serbs demonstrated in Belgrade on Wednesday, chanting ``We'll walk over Albanians!'' and ``We'll Burn Mosques!'' Islam is the predominant religion of ethnic Albanians and Kosovo is a former heartland of Christian Serbia. Police moved in with truncheons when the crowd in Belgrade began shouting ``Down With Communists!'' Several demonstrators were injured and at least 20 arrests were reported.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Bulgaria's Premier, Communist-Controlled Cabinet Resign
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to UPDATE with first gov't to resign since 1947, details. Picks up 4th, `Atanassov's departure...'
DOC.TEXT: Premier Georgi Atanassov, a holdover from the era of disgraced leader Todor Zhivkov, resigned along with his 22-member Communist-controlled Cabinet, Bulgarian state radio said late Thursday. The resignation was the first by a government since 1947, when the Communist Party consolidated power in postwar Bulgaria, according to the state news agency BTA. The government has been under severe pressure to resolve Bulgaria's labor strife and other economic ills. Their departure clears the way for creation of an interim government to run Bulgaria until elections this year. The Communists have proposed such a government to share power with the opposition. The state news agency said the resignations became known Thursday night during an emergency, closed-door Communist Party congress. The government will continue to serve until parliament accepts its resignation, the agency said. No date was given. ``The motive adduced for the resignation is the necessity to form a cabinet on a broad national basis,'' BTA said. Atanassov's departure was earlier reported by an official source, speaking on condition of anonymity. Delegates to the party congress remained in session and were expected to continue meeting into Friday. On Thursday, they approved moderate reforms before starting the secret session to elect the party leadership. Also, a reform faction of the Communist Party decided it would split off and form a new socialist party, a spokesman said. Atanassov, the No. 2 man in the government after President Petar Mladenov, had come under fire for failing to curb unprecedented labor unrest. His resignation was widely expected because of several personal attacks on him during an emergency Communist Party conference currently under way. At the congress Thursday, delegates adopted a new party platform that confirmed the relinquishment of the Communists' monopoly on power, as approved by Parliament last month. Delegates also accepted Mladenov's proposal to separate the party leader's position from the presidency. Mladenov currently holds both positions and is expected to retain the presidency. The changes were not enough to keep the party together. A reform-minded faction announced Thursday it had given up trying to change the conservative party from within and would form its own socialist party. The creation of the Bulgarian Socialist Party will be formalized at a special congress in Sofia on Feb. 11, said spokesman Nikolai Vassilev. It was not clear when a new Cabinet would be created, but it presumably will run the government at least until elections that are expected as early as May. Mladenov and other Communists have spoken vaguely of creating a government of ``national concord,'' but they have not been specific on what powers they might be willing to give up. The opposition Union of Democratic Forces has said the composition of such a government must be clarified before they agree to participate. Opposition spokesman Petar Beron reiterated that Thursday, but his comments were made before the report of the Cabinet's resignation. Atanassov, a member of the Communist Party policy-making Politburo, became premier in March 1986. He survived the Nov. 10 ouster of Communist Party head Tudor Zhivkov, apparently because he sided with the Politburo colleagues who engineered the end of the authoritarian leader's 35 years in power. Despite Zhivkov's ouster, Bulgaria's Communists have given up relatively little power, compared with their comrades elsewhere in Eastern Europe. The party is bolstered by roots in a century of the nation's politics and relatively weak opposition. However, Atanassov was not able to escape the shadow of Zhivkov, now under arrest on criminal charges, or effectively deal with economic problems that have led to widespread strikes. In general, Bulgaria is suffering the same problems as other East bloc countries with centrally planned economies. The foreign debt is estimated at $11 billion, and there have been allegations by the opposition of mismanagement of Western credits. Vassilev, the leader of the reform faction, said he had expected a party split even before the congress began Tuesday. A similar split occurred this week in Poland, when reformers broke away from the main Communist Party at a congress that concluded Monday. Vassilev, a Sofia University philosophy and anthropology professor, said his new party will be socially oriented. He predicted that within three months, about 150,000 of the 980,000 Communist Party members in Bulgaria will join it. But the leader of another reform wing in the party, economist Alexander Tomov of the Movement for Democratic Socialism, was not optimistic about the prospects for a breakaway party. ``Even if the Atlernative Socialist Alliance splits away, I am almost certain that they will not win, not only because they have organizational problems but because their basis is a quick political and not an economic reform,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Chief See Soviet Forces Out of Europe by Mid-1990s
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 4th graf: ``The State,'' to explain difference between Cheney's 225,000 figure and the 195,000 figure used by Bush
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union is likely to pull all its troops from Europe by 1995, but the Western allies must remain wary of ``the only nation on Earth capable of destroying the United States,'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told Congress on Thursday. Cheney said President Bush's new proposal that Moscow and Washington seek agreement on deeper troop cuts in Europe than previously contemplated would ``preserve ... a viable, useful'' American military presence on the continent. Bush in his State of the Union speech Wednesday proposed reducing U.S. and Soviet combat forces in Europe to no more than 225,000 for each side _ a drop of 50,000 from the previous U.S. proposal at East-West troop reduction talks now under way in Vienna. The State of the Union address spoke of a U.S. troop ceiling of 195,000, but that number would apply to NATO's ``central front,'' basically Germany. The 225,000 ceiling would be for all Europe, including U.S. forces in Turkey, Greece, Italy, Spain and Britain. Bush said that with ``communism crumbling'' in Eastern Europe, the time had come to swiftly conclude agreements limiting conventional, strategic and chemical weapons. In testimony before the Senate Armed Services Committee, Cheney said ``caution is still in order'' in considering relaxing U.S. defenses, even though Moscow is reducing its military spending and is unlikely to initiate an attack on NATO territory. ``The Soviet Union remains the only nation on Earth capable of destroying the United States,'' Cheney said, adding that even if all Soviet troops leave Eastern Europe, Moscow would retain its geographic advantage in the event of a European crisis. He said it was important not to drop below a certain troop level in Europe. Sen. John Warner of Virginia, the ranking Republican on the committee, sought and received an assurance from Cheney that the adminstration would not consider going beyond Bush's latest troop-cut proposal in the foreseeable future. ``This is the worst possible time to contemplate changes in strategy,'' Warner said. Cheney estimated that the 225,000 U.S. troop level in Europe could be achieved ``within a year or two certainly'' after an agreement is ratified. But he said the troops would be sent elsewhere and not removed from military service. However, Sen. Alan Dixon, D-Ill., pressed Cheney as to why the Bush administration would wait for an arms control agreement before reducing U.S. troops in light of moves by American allies to cut their forces and pressures in the Eastern bloc for the Soviets to leave. ``They're going to get out of Eastern Europe whether they like it or not without any agreement with the United States,'' Dixon said. ``They're going to kick them out. And we're waiting here to do things until we have the agreement. ``I'm not saying strip until we're naked. I'm saying do sensible things now here in our country even without agreements,'' Dixon said. Cheney said the administration is not oblivious to the need to reduce U.S. forces overseas, and has plans to end U.S. operations at several foreign bases. But to ensure the NATO alliance and a peaceful process, ``we should not unilaterally bring them home until we've got an agreement,'' Cheney said. At the White House, Chief of Staff John Sununu said Bush's new troop-cut proposal was not intended to prop up a politically weakened Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev as he faces a critical meeting next week of the Communist Party Central Committee. ``If the cutting of troops would have been an advantage for Mr. Gorbachev, then Mr. Gorbachev would probably have announced them earlier himself, thereby getting both the advantage, the pressuring of the United States to do it and whatever international political benefits that come in that direction,'' Sununu said. ``So that was not part of the consideration.'' While acknowledging dramatic changes in the political landscape of Eastern Europe, Cheney said the Soviets are continuing to modernize their strategic nuclear arsenal and will be more capable in the 1990s to adapt new technolgies to weapons systems. Cheney said the Pentagon would present to Congress within a few months a revamped five-year plan for troop levels, deployments, weapons requirements and other strategic issues in light of the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe. Among the assumptions used in this planning, he said, is that ``the Soviets will be out of Eastern Europe or virtually out of Eastern Europe five years hence, that the governments of Eastern Europe will be democratically elected, non-communist regimes.'' He called this ``a very real possibility.'' Remarks to the committee by Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, appeared aimed largely at heading off any political momentum toward an immediate, radical reduction in U.S. military capabilities. ``We must not shatter the armed forces,'' Powell said. ``We must not make them a shadow of strength.'' Powell said the Pentagon's latest assessment of the overall Soviet threat to U.S. security was based on acknowledgement of a ``a dramatic diminution'' in the possibility of East-West conflict but also an unsettling uncertainty about the future. ``It is still too soon to make sweeping changes to strategy, force structure and posture, and modernization,'' he said. ``There is simply too much risk in such precipitous change.'' Powell also said he would ``stand like a stone wall'' against any pressure for a total pullout of U.S. combat forces from Europe, even if all Soviet forces withdrew. ``While we will reduce the number of our forces in Europe, there is nothing whatsoever on the horizon that indicates to me that we can disengage from the continent entirely,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Udall Praises Lujan for Tightening Federal Mining Regulations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 5th graf, bgng: ``We sat xxx to include comment from Lujan spokesman.
DOC.TEXT: The House Interior Committee chairman, Rep. Morris Udall, praised Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. on Thursday for reversing several Reagan administration policies on mining coal from federal lands.
