Critics have said the Reagan policies favored private interests over the environment. ``It appears to me that in this area there is a much greater concern and responsiveness to the public interest, a more open attitude and a more balanced approach to environmental and conservation issues than has been evident in the previous Republican administration,'' Udall, an Arizona Democrat, said in a letter to Lujan. Udall, a tenacious protector of public lands who is in his 13th year as chairman of the Interior Committee, was consistently at odds with interior secretaries James Watt and Donald Hodel, who served under Reagan. Lujan served on the Interior Committee while in Congress and was ranking Republican on the Interior committee for several years. ``We sat side by side for a good number of years,'' Udall commented Thursday. ``We both know we'll disagree again along the way, but when an old friend is doing a good job, I feel moved to tell him.'' ``We have been plugging along for 12 months trying to get people to notice that things are different at Interior and there is an environmental tilt,'' said Steve Goldstein, chief spokesman for Lujan. ``This is beyond what we expected.'' Goldstein said that when Lujan reviewed some of the Reagan policies, he decided they did not fit into the ``new environmental ethic'' he and Bush wanted for the department. ``Lujan is doing a pretty good job,'' agreed Skip Deegans, coordinator of the surface mining project at the National Wildlife Federation. But he said, ``You have to put it in perspective. Under Reagan they had an agenda to decimate the surface mine regulations.'' ``A lot of it is that they are waking up to the political realities that the public is interested in having the environment protected,'' said Deegans. ``The situation on coal issues was so antagonistic during the Reagan administration that nothing was getting done. We were constantly in litigation with the Office of Surface Mining.'' Udall, who sponsored the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act, cited five areas for praise: _Improvements in the computerized system designed to prevent violators of the act from obtaining additional mining permits. The Reagan administration was put under court order to make improvements, but never did, said Deegans. _Abolishing a Reagan administration proposal to reduce the royalty rate paid the government on underground coal. It would have saved the coal industry money but cost the taxpayers. _Reversal of a Reagan administration decision that eliminated certain fees from the royalty base rate paid on coal. That had cost taxpayers about $70 million, said Udall. _Disapproval of a proposed amendment to a Wyoming regulatory program that would have relieved coal companies of having to return surface-mined lands to their original contours. _Action to stop mining companies from abusing the law that allows coal to be taken at a cheaper rate if it the company happens to mine it when looking for another mineral in the vicinity. Companies were pretending to be mining principally for cheaper minerals in order to get coal, said Udall.

DOC.HEAD: Chairman of New York Stock Exchange to Retire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout, moving up reference to rumors Phelan considered for Treasury Secretary and adding six grafs of quotes and background on Phelan's career at end. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: New York Stock Exchange Chairman John J. Phelan Jr. announced his retirement Thursday, capping a tumultuous seven-year tenure in which the nation's biggest securities market grew explosively, suffered a devastating crash and struggled to recover. Phelan announced the departure, effective at the end of this year, at a news conference in the NYSE's Wall Street headquarters after the close of the day's trading. He said he had considered retirement for about a year, but hadn't felt he could leave amid the continuing debate over market volatility and the uncertainty raised by an Oct. 13 mini-crash. ``I did it because I thought the exchange was in good shape,'' Phelan said of his decision. Phelan declined to specify what he might do next and no replacement was named. The NYSE board of directors said it named a special committee to oversee a transition and help pick a successor, and said the panel expected to make its recommendations in the fall. There had been rumors for days that Phelan might be tapped to replace Nicholas Brady as Treasury Secretary. Phelan said he hadn't been contacted about a government job and wasn't considering one. Brady has denied that he plans to resign. Phelan is perhaps best known as one of the cool heads at the helm Oct. 19, 1987, when the market plunged out of control in a selloff that erased 508 points from the Dow Jones industrial average. The 58-year-old chairman and chief executive officer, who has spent more than half his life in the securities business and took the Big Board's top job in 1984, presided over the most dramatic expansion in the NYSE's history. Since then the value of all stocks listed on the Big Board, as it is commonly known, as grown from $1.6 trillion to more than $2.4 trillion. The NYSE ended 1989 with 1,721 listed companies, making it the world's second-largest exchange behind Tokyo. Since the 1987 plunge, the NYSE and the securities industry have been fighting a slump, hurt by investors who fled the market and have been afraid to return, despite a number of reforms Phelan and other industry leaders devised to lure them back. Phelan had said previously he didn't expect to be chairman for life, but he was expected to remain at least until 1992, the 200th anniversary of the stock market, founded when two dozen traders gathered under a buttonwood tree on Wall Street. The most contentious issue he has faced recently is the price zigzags that have characterized some trading days, especially last Oct. 13 when the Dow Jones industrial average lost 190 points and a subsequent session that had an 80-point single-day rise. Many traders have blamed the volatility on computerized program trading, a practice in which millions of dollars worth of stocks are traded instantaneously. Phelan has been reluctant to restrict program trading, although he supported limits on it during times of heavy price fluctuations. He was one of the first to warn that some kinds of program trading could lead to a market disaster. ``I'm convinced there is a cure for intra-day volatility or intra-hour volatility,'' he said Thursday. ``I'm not sure what it is, but I'm sure there is a cure for it.'' Phelan said he considered his main achievement the installation of modern trading technology in the exchange, where average daily volume climbed from about 20 million shares in the mid-1970s to more than 600 million shares during the Black Monday crash. He credited that technology for helping the exchange handle the huge volume that deluged the market during the crash. Before he was named chairman and chief executive officer, Phelan served as NYSE president and chief operating officer for four years and as vice chairman for five years before that.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney: Contra Leader Ordered Killing of U.S. Citizen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 7-8, `Bermudez could ... Nicaraguan rebels,' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Contras' response. Pick up 9th graf pvs, `But Thursday...'
DOC.TEXT: An attorney charged Thursday that new information points to Contra military leader Enrique Bermudez as the official who ordered the killing of a U.S. volunteer building a rural dam in Nicaragua. Benjamin Linder, 27, of Portland, Ore., died April 28, 1987, when the U.S.-backed rebels attacked the hydroelectric dam in northern Nicaragua. His family contends the engineer was abducted, tortured and executed, but the Contras said he was armed, and died in a firefight between rebel and Sandinista government troops. The family has filed a $50 million wrongful death suit in federal court in Miami against the Contras and their leadership, including Bermudez. The Contras at one time had a headquarters in Miami. ``This was not just an attack on a dam ... this was an attack to assassinate a man,'' family attorney Michael Ratner told U.S. District Judge Stanley Marcus. ``Linder was taken alive and executed subsequently, and Enrique Bermudez gave the order.'' The charge was based on a deposition from Fermin Cardenas, former head of operations for the Contras, and later given amnesty in Nicaragua. Cardenas, who died shortly after giving his statement, said Bermudez had ordered Linder killed to sabotage the dam project, and congratulated the patrol's commander afterward. Bermudez continues to head the rebel military. Thursday's hearing came on the family's request to amend the suit with the Cardenas deposition, thus making it more specific, instead of basing it on general claims that the Contras routinely conducted such raids against civilian workers. The Contras' Miami spokesman, Alejandro Acevedo, strongly denied Thursday that Linder was targeted by Bermudez or the Contras. ``We emphatically reject that,'' Acevedo said. ``It isn't our custom to attack civilians, much less foreign citizens.'' He said Linder was wearing a military uniform and was with Sandinista troops at the time of the battle. Bermudez could not be reached for comment. A woman who answered the phone at his Miami residence said Bermudez was in Honduras and unavailable. The Contras in the past have vehemently denied targeting Linder or intentionally killing civilians, painting the lawsuit as an effort by people opposed to U.S. policy in Central America to embarrass the Nicaraguan rebels. But Thursday, their attorney John Kirkpatrick stuck to legal arguments aimed at showing Marcus had no jurisdiction in a war fought on foreign soil, and that there was no chance for the Contras to get evidence to defend themselves. ``I find it difficult to believe that (Nicaraguan President) Daniel Ortega is going to subject himself to a deposition'' by the Contras, Kirkpatrick said. Marcus said he had been close to ruling on the jurisdiction issue prior to the plaintiff's request to amend the suit with the new evidence, and would take the case under advisement. ``I have struggled with this case for a long time,'' the judge told the attorneys. ``There are some very difficult issues.'' Marcus seemed skeptical of the Linder family's suit, questioning whether there were adequate legal standards to define the crime, whether the defense would have access to Nicaraguan witnesses, and worrying that the broad-based suit intruded on the executive and legislative branches.

DOC.HEAD: Lebanese Christians Rivals Fight to Standstill, Declare Truce
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with new casualties, Aoun station conceding loss of three bases, details. Pickup 10th `Fighting noticeably...' EDITS thereafter to trim and conform
DOC.TEXT: Rebel Gen. Michel Aoun failed to crush a rival Christian force and struck a truce Thursday after a three-day battle that killed at least 70 people, police reported. The two sides had pounded each other with tank and artillery barrages and shells inevitably went astray, smashing homes, schools, hospitals and churches. ``It's a death machine,'' a woman said. ``Victims are lying in the streets everywhere, yelling for help, but no one dares approach them.'' Most of the fighting centered on a cluster of government buildings in Christian east Beirut that house the Justice and Finance ministries. Much of the combat was house-to-house and some shell-pocked buildings changed hands several times. Police said at least 70 people were killed and 250 wounded since fighting began Tuesday between Aoun's soldiers and Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces, the largest Christian militia. They said hospitals were packed with casualties and short of doctors and blood. Aoun, who has been dismissed as army commander but clings to his command of about 20,000 soldiers, attacked on Tuesday to try to gain full control of the 310-square-mile enclave north and east of Beirut where 1 million Christians live. Geagea has 6,000 militiamen bolstered by several thousand reservists. Aoun was fired by Moslem President Elias Hrawi, elected in November under terms of an Arab League-brokered peace plan aimed at shifting political power to the Moslem majority and ending a 15-year-old Christian-Moslem civil war that has left 150,000 people dead. Aoun says the plan, approved by Parliament in October, provides no fixed withdrawal timetable for Syria's estimated 45,000 troops. Geagea has neither accepted or rejected the peace accord, but has recognized Hrawi as president. About 22,000 soldiers are loyal to Hrawi. Police said Aoun's soldiers tried to advance behind a fierce howitzer barrage Thursday but could not breach militia defenses on the southern edge of the Ashrafiyeh quarter. They said the apparent aim was to seize the main Lebanese Forces ammunition depot in Ashrafiyeh. Shortly before dusk Thursday, Christian radio stations said Aoun and Geagea agreed to the truce after a ``telephone discussion'' to begin a truce at 4:15 p.m. According to police, the Lebanese Forces kept control of the Ashrafiyeh quarter and port area of east Beirut when the agreement was reached, with secure supply lines to their main bases in the Byblos region on the 30-mile coastal highway north of the capital. The Lebanese Broadcasting Corp., Geagea's television station, showed Aoun's navy, armored and air bases north of Beirut that were captured by the Lebanese Forces. Aoun's Channel 5 TV station conceded the loss of the three bases, claiming militiamen took the families of the officers in each base hostage to force them to surrender. Police said Aoun's forces controlled the eastern and northeastern flanks of east Beirut and the wooded Metn mountains to the northeast. It was not immediately clear who had come out ahead in the fighting. Fighting ``noticeably decreased'' after the cease-fire agreement, ``but we still have intermittent mortar and machine gun exchanges in east Beirut and its northern suburbs,'' said a police spokesman, who cannot be identified under standing regulations. It was the fourth call for a truce since the battle began, and the first to have an effect. The United States blamed Aoun for the worst fighting in the Christian zone for nearly a year, and said he should step aside. ``Gen. Aoun must realize that his bellicose behavior does not advance the interests of the Christians or any other community, but only benefits those who want to see Lebanon continue in anarchy and turmoil,'' the State Department said. Thousands of families hid in bomb shelters and basements. Thousands more streamed into Moslem west Beirut during a lull in the fighting, figuring they would be safer there. Christian housewife Ilham Jiha crossed the dividing line from Ashrafiyeh with her husband and two children. Mrs. Jiha, who compared the battle to ``a death machine,'' said Aoun's men ``shelled almost every building in Ashrafiyeh. Several people were killed at the entrances to buildings.'' President Hrawi told all hospitals to treat casualties at government expense. But an official of the Saint George Greek Orthodox hospital in Ashrafiyeh said: ``The problem is not one of money. We don't have enough surgeons. ... We don't have enough blood. We don't have ambulances. We don't have enough space. The upper floors have been shelled.''

DOC.HEAD: Deputy Premier Denies Involvement in Influence-Peddling Scandal
DOC.TEXT: Alfonso Guerra, the deputy prime minister, told Parliament on Thursday he had nothing to do with any influence-peddling by his brother. ``I assume responsibility for each and every one of my actions, but none of those that may have been committed in my name,'' he said. After the session, Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez told reporters he also would resign if Guerra was forced to quit. Guerra accused the opposition and media during the debater of exaggerating the scandal since it arose a month ago. The reports allege that Juan Guerra, a door-to-door book salesman when the Socialists formed their first government in 1982, traded on his brother's name to build a real estate fortune and operated from a government office in Seville. Gonzalez told reporters the opposition could ``kill two birds with one stone: the resignation of Alfonso Guerra and the resignation of Felipe Gonzalez.'' He said he planned to sue a Madrid daily that implied the Cabinet, in 1986, knowingly favored Juan Guerra by approving a government subsidy for a real estate company with which he was said to be associated. The prime minister, who won a third four-year term Oct. 29, condemned what he called unfounded press reports accusing political figures or their family members of corruption. He said he favored extending influence-peddling legislation, which now covers only government employees, to private citizens. Provincial prosecutors in Seville and Cadiz are investigating some of Juan Guerra's business activities. Socialist parliamentary spokesman Eduardo Martin Toval noted that no party officials had been convicted of corruption despite numerous opposition accusations the past seven years. Alfonso Guerra said he was not aware of Juan Guerra trading on his brother's position during his seven years as the deputy prime minister's aide in Seville, the family hometown. Reports of the scandal have damaged the Socialists, who have 166 deputies in the lower house, half the 332 allotted after the Oct. 29 elections. Another 18 are vacant pending court-ordered repeat elections in three districts. The conservative Popular Party, the largest opposition group with 99 seats, and the Communist-led United Left, with 17, joined several smaller regional parties in demanding the deputy premier's resignation. In a 20-minute speech, Alfonso Guerra acknowledged the party employed his brother from July 1982 to May 1989, but denied knowing of any misuse of the Seville office. ``The deputy prime minister does not have any knowledge that that office was used for activities other than those that were supposed to take place there,'' the deputy premier told Parliament. He said he never had used his influence to obtain money or encouraged Juan Guerra or anyone else to do so. ``From the facts, we must conclude that there has been no injury to the public interest,'' he said. Guerra denied that he, the government or the Socialist Party bore any responsibility for any illegal acts his brother may have committed. ``As far as the rest is concerned, the appropriate administrative and judicial bodies must establish if the law was infringed by the activities of the private citizen Juan Guerra,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Czech Secret Police Disbanded, Intelligence Records Secured
DOC.TEXT: Interior Minister Richard Sacher on Thursday disbanded Czechoslovakia's secret police and said commissions are being set up to decide the fate of former members, the official CTK news agency said. Sacher ordered police records safeguarded against moves to destroy them, began collecting officers' weapons and said state TV could have a look at intelligence headquarters Monday, to show citizens the changes under way since the democratic revolution here last November. CTK quoted Sacher as saying, ``Having abolished the department of internal intelligence earlier, I have abolished the remaining components of the secret police today.'' Last month, Sacher fired all leading officers of the secret police and replaced them with members of the police force considered reliable. He disbanded the internal intelligence service, which spied on Czechoslovaks. ``As of 9 a.m. today the process of confiscating of private and service weapons belonging to members of these departments is under way ... ending tomorrow at 3 p.m.,'' Sacher was quoted as saying Thursday. Sacher last week asked all citizens to hand in privately owned weapons and declared gun permits invalid. He acted to secure police records, saying as of Friday, ``safes with written materials will be sealed off as well as the rooms they are in.'' As of Monday, specially appointed staff members ``will secure measures vital to the state's security. ... Other staffers will not be allowed to enter their offices.'' ``We shall say goodbye to those who broke the laws in various areas of security work, who acted against the principles of intelligence ethics,'' Sacher said. ``These matters will be consistently judged by commissions of experts and citizens ... ``In no way do we want a witchhunt.'' Rumors that a coup was being organized by secret police and sympathetic Communists circulated during the week. Sacher decided on Monday to strengthen regular police patrols with soldiers of the Interior Ministry wearing an insignia to show loyalty to the new regime. The minister called the secret police ``a product and a tool of the old totalitarian regime'' who were used against the people. It is estimated that the service had up to 100,000 employes. ``As of today, there is a brand new structure of the security forces controlled by the Ministry of Interior,'' Sacher said. ``It is the intelligence service, office for the protection of the constitution and democracy, department for the protection of constitutional officials, bureau of investigation, passport service and foreigners' office, and the immediate deployment force.''

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Representative Named in Dispute Between Guyana, Venezuela
DOC.TEXT: Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar on Thursday appointed a special representative to help settle a dispute between Guyana and Venezuela over a region rich in natural resources. The governments of Guyana and Venezuela have agreed to participate in U.N.-sponsored mediation to settle the dispute over the Essequibo region, known to have extensive mineral deposits and possibly oil. Perez de Cuellar named Alister McIntyre to head the U.N. effort to end the controversy that dates back to when Guyana was ruled by Britain and Venezuela by Spain. McIntyre has been vice chancellor of the University of the West Indies in Jamaica since September 1988. Prior to that he was assistant U.N. secretary-general for development and international economic coordination. Since the last century, Venezuela has claimed sovereignty over the Essequibo region, 34,000 square miles located in what is now west-central Guyana. The Venezuelan government bases its claim of sovereignty over the region on colonial documents signed when Venezuela was part of Spain's empire and before Britain took control of territory that is now Guyana. In 1966 Venezuelan and Guyanese authorities agreed to settle the conflict peacefully. No settlement had been reached by March 1983, so the matter was taken to the U.N. secretary-general.

DOC.HEAD: Iran-Contra Figure Hakim Gives Up $7.3 Million, Gets Probation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITS a0750 to fix wirtethru slug and to incorporate first reference to Jacobsen from a0738.
DOC.TEXT: Iran-Contra middleman Albert Hakim was placed on two years probation and fined $5,000 Thursday after giving up his claim on what prosecutors said was $7.3 million in arms-deal profits now frozen in Swiss accounts. The Iranian-born businessman, who pleaded guilty Nov. 21 to illegally helping supplement Oliver North's government income with a $13,800 home security system, bitterly attacked the government after his sentencing. ``I have been abused by two presidents,'' Hakim said after his appearance before U.S. District Court Judge Gerhard Gesell. ``I'm talking about President Reagan and President Walsh,'' he said, the latter referring to independent counsel Lawrence Walsh, who directs the Iran-Contra investigation. ``The American public has had enough of this soap opera,'' Hakim said. Hakim, who could have been sentenced to up to a year in jail and a $100,000 fine on the misdemeanor charge, is the sixth person sentenced in the Iran-Contra affair. No one has been sent to jail. Richard Janis, Hakim's lawyer, said his case was ``a monument to the hypocrisy of a system that permits individuals'' to face criminal charges after they ``in good faith carried out the requests of their government.'' He called Hakim ``a fall guy,'' a term that former White House aide North has used to describe himself in the affair. Former Reagan National Security Adviser John M. Poindexter still faces trial, on Feb. 20. Shortly after the Iran-Contra affair erupted in November 1986, Swiss authorities placed a hold on $7.8 million contained in accounts of ``the Enterprise,'' a financial network of offshore companies Hakim helped set up for use in the affair. With interest, that amount has grown to $9 million. Hakim and two Swiss-based lawyers working with him are claiming part of the money, said Mary Belcher, a spokeswoman for the Iran-Contra prosecutor's office. He agreed to let the U.S. government have $7.3 million, while he will split $1.7 million with the two lawyers, Willard Zucker and Philippe Neyroud. The Justice Department approved the deal Monday. Zucker says he is owed $800,000 while Neyroud says he is owed $120,000, said Belcher. The U.S. government now will try to persuade the Swiss to unfreeze the accounts. Belcher said $7.3 million was all that could be identified as Iran arms sale proceeds and that ``we are satisfied with the agreement,'' despite the fact that Hakim and his lawyers stand to collect the remainder. Gesell also placed one of Hakim's companies, Panamanian-based Lake Resources Inc., on probation and ordered that the corporation be dissolved. Lake Resources had pleaded guilty to a charge of theft of government property in the diversion of Iran arms-sale profits to the Nicaraguan Contra rebels. According to Hakim, North and others in the affair, the arms sales to Iran were aimed at winning the release of U.S. hostages in Lebanon while aid was channeled to the Contras to help them against the leftist government in Nicaragua. Hakim became involved in the Contra resupply operation in 1984 when North enlisted the help of Hakim's business partner, retired Air Force Maj. Gen. Richard Secord. North said he contacted Secord for the Contra operation at the suggestion of CIA Director William Casey, whose agency was barred by law from providing military aid to the rebel force. Reagan authorized the idea of keeping the Contras in operation. Hakim and Secord, who later were brought into the Iran arms operation as well, set up ``the Enterprise,'' ``Very substantial funds _ measured in the millions of dollars _ which have been frozen'' in Swiss bank accounts ``have now been released to the United States by you,'' Gesell told Hakim. Hakim stated in court papers that other participants in the affair have become wealthy, an apparent reference to North who has benefited from fund-raising efforts and big-fee speaking engagements. Gesell said Hakim's cooperation with Iran-Contra prosecutors was ``in sharp contrast to any other of the defendants who have been at one time or another before me in ... the Iran-Contra ... case.'' The judge was referring to North, Secord and Poindexter. North was convicted of three felonies and was fined and ordered to perform community service; Secord pleaded guilty to making a false statement in connection with North's security system and was put on two years probation. Former hostage David Jacobsen said in an interview with Cable News Network that Hakim ``actually believed that he was operating with the highest authority given, and for him to be put through this turmoil, to be put into bankruptcy, to have his personal life destroyed, I think that's a real shame.'' Hakim asserts that only about $1.3 million from Enterprise money was transferred to him for his Iran-Contra activities in 1985 and 1986, much of it for expenses. Although a private businessman who did not have a security clearance, Hakim had access to an astonishing amount of sensitive information, his lawyer disclosed in court papers this week. In connection with the Iran-Contra affair, Hakim received top secret communications equipment from the National Security Agency and was made privy to classified intelligence information. He also was provided with account numbers of CIA bank accounts and was referred to CIA proprietary companies overseas. One item of classified information which Hakim listed in the document is so sensitive that government security officers deleted it from the court filing.

DOC.HEAD: Truant Lawmaker Demands, Gets Apology for Prank
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to ADD lawmaker's comments blaming absences on illness, saying she didn't recognize longtime colleague because of impaired vision, ADD further comment from legislator who played prank. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A lawmaker who missed more sessions than she attended last year demanded an apology Thursday after a eight-year incumbent was introduced to her as a newly elected legislator, and she fell for the prank. Rep. Ethel Terrell issued a news release saying she refused to attend House sessions until she received an apology from Reps. Jerry Bartnik and Philip Hoffman. The two promptly apologized publicly to her and anyone else they may have offended, after expressing disbelief that she had issued the statement. `We're not here for jokes,'' Terrell said later. ``I thought it was in very bad taste.'' Terrell said her fellow lawmakers were able to pull off the joke only because impaired vision is among the medical problems that keep her away from Lansing. She declined to further describe her medical problems. The prank was pulled Jan. 24, a week after D. Roman Kulchitsky won a special election to fill a vacant seat. House members had juggled a few seats, and four-term Hoffman ended up sitting between Terrell and Bartnik. Bartnik told Terrell he'd introduce her to the House's newest lawmaker, but it was actually Hoffman who shook her hand. She smiled, welcomed him, and asked him if he had a tough campaign. Not only have Hoffman and Terrell served together for eight years in the 110-member House, but they've been on the seven-member Corrections Committee together for four years. Also, Hoffman noted, he's the only red-headed man in the Legislature. ``I'm not unnoticeable. I thought she was joking.'' Terrell, who lives in the Detroit suburb of Highland Park, said later that she was awaiting a personal apology, but would resume attending sessions. ``When my brother Democrat approached me I thought he was telling the truth. I took for granted another legislator was making an honest introduction,'' Terrell said. House Speaker Lewis Dodak said Terrell was satisfied with their statements and would attend session again, perhaps next week. Terrell, 63, was first elected to the House in 1978. Terrell attended 56 of 119 sessions during 1989, an attendance rate of 47 percent. Average House attendance is more than 80 percent. Terrell said her office runs efficiently even when she's away, and that she is constantly in touch. ``My voters are satisfied because they know I'm a conscientious worker,'' she said. ``I know they were just as upset about this joke as I was.'' ``A little lightheartedness kind of breaks the ice in an otherwise serious business. If she doesn't have a sense of humor, I'm sorry,'' Hoffman said. ``We certainly didn't mean to offend anyone,'' Hoffman said. ``I guess if she never comes to session I'll never be able to apologize.''

DOC.HEAD: President Invites Algerian Exiles to Return
DOC.TEXT: President Chadli Bendjedid told a Cabinet meeting that all political exiles are free to return to Algeria without fear of retribution from authorities, the official news agency said Thursday. The president ``reaffirmed that the exercise of political freedom will be respected in favor of all, without any exclusion, notably concerning the freedom to come and go as they please, including those who have exiled themselves,'' the agency said in a report about Wednesday's meeting. It was assumed the statement was addressed to the founder of the Movement for Democracy in Algeria (MDA), former President Ahmed Ben Bella, in exile since 1981. Ben Bella was overthrown by the late Houari Boumedienne in 1965 and spent more than 10 years in Algerian prisons. MDA spokesman Hocine Guermouche expressed satisfaction at this ``good news.'' MDA leaders said ``certain attitudes of the government'' prevented Ben Bella's earlier return, referring to a statement by Bendjedid last year saying Ben Bella remained subject to police prosecution because of violence alleged to have been committed by MDA supporters in Algeria.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Asks for Tougher Charge Against Ceausescu Associates
With AM-Romania
DOC.TEXT: The prosecution asked on the fourth day of their trial Thursday that the charge against four associates of ousted Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu be increased to ``co-authorship of genocide.'' They have pleaded guilty to complicity to commit genocide, and admitted supporting Ceausescu's orders to shoot demonstrators during the revolution that overthrew the Romanian dictator. The prosecutor, Col. Aurel Cosma, told the military court Thursday in requesting the more serious charge: ``It is not complicity but co-authorship to genocide.'' Col. Andrei Nitoiu, the court president, said the five-judge panel would decide Friday whether to grant the request. Lawyers said both co-authorship and complicity are punishable by a maximum of life in prison at hard labor but the minimum terms are different. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, who was the second most powerful person in Romania, were convicted in a secret trial of genocide and destroying the economy. They were executed by firing squad Dec. 25. Those being tried in the military court are Emil Bobu, 62, former secretary of the Communist Party Central Committee and third in the government behind the Ceausescus; former Interior Minister Tudor Postelnicu, 59; and former Politburo members Manea Manescu, 74, and Ion Dinca, 62. The trial, the first of ranking Ceausescu aides, has shed new light on the last days of his 24 years in power. Paul Niculescu Mizil, the only member of Ceausescu's Politburo not under arrest, testified Thursday that the dictator's offer to the Politburo on Dec. 17 to resign as Communist Party chief was ``a trap'' to discover ``foreign agents'' in the leadership. At the Dec. 17 meeting, Ceausescu demanded the resignations of Postelnicu, Defense Minister Vasile Milea and Chief of Security Iulian Vlad for not carrying out his orders to shoot demonstrators in Timisoara. Milea told Ceausescu he had studied the military regulations and found nothing to justify the shooting of civilians. Dinca testified earlier that he and four other Politburo members protested the demand for resignations, and he then offered to resign. It was the first time Ceausescu had faced opposition in the Politburo. Niculescu Mizil said that, by offering to step down, Ceausescu believed he could identify the ``agents'' by noting who did not support him. ``The people who didn't stand up would be considered like traitors,'' he said. ``They would have been killed.'' He said the four defendants were among about 15 Politburo members who stood up, some crying, and ``didn't allow Ceausescu to give up'' his post. Cosma, the prosecutor, said 25 people attended the meeting. Prosecutors claim the four defendants could have prevented the killing or wounding of nearly 2,000 people by asking Ceausescu to resign. Instead, they supported his order to shoot demonstrators. Niculescu Mizil confirmed a shorthand transcript of the meeting that said Gen. Ion Coman, appointed by Ceausescu as commander in Timisoara, ``gave an order to shoot'' demonstrators there. Coman is said to be under arrest. A defense lawyer said Milea, the defense minister, was not executed after the Dec. 17 meeting and was not forced out of the army. Milea, who died Dec. 22, hours before Ceausescu tried to escape, has become the hero of the revolution. There is controversy over whether he committed suicide or was assassinated on Ceausescu's orders for refusing to shoot demonstrators. Capt. Nicolae Matei of Ceausescu's feared Securitate secret police testified that he heard Dinca say: ``For 3,000 demonstrators, we shouldn't give up the socialist society. We must open fire.'' Matei, who is under arrest, provided a surreal moment. He said he was ordered to go from Primaverii Palace to Central Committee headquarters the night of Dec. 21, while protests raged in Bucharest, to take two of Ceausescu's dogs back to the palace.

DOC.HEAD: Government Asks Special Prosecutor for Pierce
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Reorganizes throughout; adds background
DOC.TEXT: By JAMES ROWLEY=

Attorney General Dick Thornburgh asked a special court Thursday to appoint an independent counsel to investigate allegations of criminal wrongdoing by former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. and other former federal housing officials. The independent counsel, if appointed, would be asked to probe allegations that Pierce and other Department of Housing and Urban Development officials ``may have violated federal criminal law'' in the administration of the HUD Moderate (income) Rehabilitation Program. In a letter to the House Judiciary Committee, Thornburgh said the special counsel was being sought to investigate allegations that Pierce and other HUD officials ``may have committed the crime of conspiracy to defraud the United States or any other crime'' in administering that program between 1984 and 1988. Thornburgh's formal application to a special court cited reports of a ``widespread perception among developers'' and local officials that ``funds were being disbursed in a disproportionate amounts to projects backed by prominent Republicans acting as consultants or by former HUD officials.'' But the attorney general said he ``found no reasonable grounds to believe that further investigation is warranted'' of allegations that Pierce lied during congressional testimony when questioned last May about political favoritism in the awarding of HUD grants. Thornburgh signalled his reluctance to use the independent counsel law, saying he had ``very little latitutde in making this determination. I must apply to the court for an indepedent counsel unless I can determine that there are no reasonable grounds to believe that further investigation is warranted.'' The attorney general's application to the Special Division of the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia was released by the department after the three-judge panel approved Thornburgh's motion to make it public. Pierce's successor at HUD, Jack Kemp, promised to cooperate with the investigation, once the appointment is made by the special court. ``This is a tragic situation for all involved,'' Kemp said in a statement. ``However, the department will provide whatever cooperation and assistance is required for full and fair disposition of this matter.'' Robert Plotkin, one of Pierce's lawyers, said, ``We continue to believe that Mr. Pierce has not violated any federal laws and we are confident that, at the conclusion of an independent counsel investigation, that will be determined.'' The attorney general's move came after the Justice Department's criminal division conducted a preliminary inquiry into allegations that Pierce lied to a House subcommittee when questioned last spring about political favoritism in the awarding of grants during his tenure in the Reagan administration. The preliminary investigation was triggered last fall by the 19 Democratic members of the House Judiciary Committee, who requested appointment of an independent counsel to investigate allegations of political favoritism and perjury by Pierce. Thornburgh, an outspoken critic of the special prosecutor law, said his decision to seek appointment of an independent counsel was compelled by the severe restrictions on his ability to conduct an investigation that were placed upon him by statute. ``A determination that no further investigation is warranted is virtually forclosed'' despite a review of ``voluminous information'' compiled by the HUD inspector general, the House subcommittee and Justice Department interviews with HUD officials, the attorney general said. ``Such a determination at this time is made especially difficult here by the breadth of the allegations and the fact that a number of figures central to the alleged conspiracy, including Secretary Pierce, and his executive assistant, Deborah Dean, have declined to be interviewed,'' the attorney general's application said. But Thornburgh disclosed that Pierce had provided written answers to questions the department submitted to him during the preliminary inquiry, which began in Dec. 4. Ms. Dean also invoked the Fifth Amendment protection against self-incrimination in refusing to testify before the House subcommittee. Pierce also took the Fifth when called back to testify last fall. ``We will have no comment at this time until we have an opportunity to see the letter, which, of course, we have not seen,'' said Joseph diGenova, who represents Ms. Dean. The attorney general noted that under the law he was barred from using the traditional prosecutorial tools, such as issuing grand jury subpoenas or granting immunity to witnesses, to conduct the preliminary inquiry. Nor was he able to base a decision to drop the investigation on a person's state of mind ``unless I can determine by clear and convincing evidence that the person lacked the requisite state of mind for criminal liability.'' Thornburgh said there was no reasonable basis to continue an investigation of the perjury allegations because the questioning by lawmakers and the answers Pierce gave were too ambiguous. The attorney general said Pierce's statement that he did not have ``hands on'' involvement in the award of moderate rehabilitation grants ``is fundamentally ambiguous, which makes a perjury prosecution essentially impossible.'' ``The terms is readily susceptible to countless interpretations,'' Thornburgh said. Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., chairman of the subcommittee that investigated allegations of wrongdoing at HUD, said, ``I welcome the attorney general's decision and believe that an independent counsel is in the best position to fully investigate and resolve questions of possible criminal wrongdoing.'' Rep. Bruce Morrison, D-Conn., called Thornburgh's decision ``a very important step'' for those involved in the HUD scandal ``to be held accountable by the criminal justice system.'' Morrison, one of two Judiciary Committee members who pushed the drive for last fall's congressional request, said it was important that the independent counsel be authorized to pursue other officials too. Pierce was a New York lawyer before taking the secretary's post in 1981. Plotkin declined to say what Pierce is doing now.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Kill Three Saudi Embassy Employees
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen killed three employees of the Saudi Arabian Embassy within minutes of each other Thursday afternoon, attacking two in a car and one outside his apartment, police said. Authorities could not immediately determine a motive in the slayings of the three male Saudis, and descriptions of the assailants were sketchy _ one was described as Arab-looking and the other Thai. One gunman hiding in a parked car killed Abdullah A. Al-Desri, 32, a consular official, as he walked toward his apartment near the embassy at about 3:30 p.m. He was shot four times, police said. Interior Minister Banharn Sipla-archa told reporters the killer was ``Arab looking'' but had no further details as to his identity. A few minutes after the first shooting another assailant shot dead Fahad Az Al-Bahli, 35, a second secretary at the embassy who was traveling in an embassy car about a half-mile away, police said. Killed with him was the driver, Ahmed A. Al-Saif, 26, an embassy telex operator, they said. The gunman had pulled open the door of the parked car and shot Al-Saif twice and Al-Bahli three times, police said. Shell cases from a 6.35mm weapon were found nearby, they said. A witness told police the assailant appeared to be a Thai national. Early last year, gunmen fatally shot a third secretary of the Saudi Arabian Embassy, Abdullah Al-Maliki. He was also shot near the embassy on Sathorn Road, a busy thoroughfare in central Bangkok. Maliki was responsible for processing visa applications from the tens of thousands of Thais who work in Saudi Arabia each year. The crime has not been solved, but police investigators said some job placement agents were unhappy about the diplomat's strict application of regulations when processing visas for Thai workers. Workers going to the Middle East pay agents a fee for securing jobs and the necessary paperwork.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets, Hungarians Open Talks on Troop Pullout
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 2nd graf, `The delegations...' to ADD comments by Somogyi. Pickup 3rd, `The talks...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Troop Cuts, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Talks began Thursday on withdrawing all Soviet troops from Hungary by the end of the year, the state news agency MTI said. The delegations, headed by Secretary of State Ferenc Somogyi from the Hungarian Foreign Ministry and Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Ivan Aboymov, will meet for two days. ``The talks are aimed at setting a definite timetable (for the withdrawal). We are thinking in terms of this year, or into next year at the very latest,'' Somogyi said in an interview Thursday night. Concerning a proposal Wednesday by President Bush to further lower troop levels in Europe, Somogyi said his initial impressions are that its ``significant lowering of the foreign-troop level ceiling is a positive development from the aspect of the Vienna talks.'' The talks are the second of their kind in Eastern Europe since a wave of democratization started loosening the Soviet grip over its Warsaw Pact allies. The first such negotiations, held in Prague on withdrawing troops from Czechoslovakia, ended inconclusively in early January. A second round of Soviet-Czechoslovak negotiations is set for next week. The estimated 50,000 Soviet troops in Hungary and 70,000 in Czechoslovakia are stationed on the basis of ``temporary'' agreements the Kremlin reached with the countries after quashing revolts in 1956 in Hungary and in 1968 in Czechoslovakia. The call for removing the Soviet troops has been echoed through the new leaderships of the East bloc. In Poland, Solidarity leader Lech Walesa made the appeal to the Soviet ambassador, although the non-Communist-led government has not started negotiations. Moscow began reducing its troop presence in Hungary in April as part of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's program of cutting 50,000 soldiers from the Red Army in Eastern Europe. While Moscow has signaled willingness to discuss the demands from Prague and Budapest for withdrawal, it is not clear whether the Soviets want the pullouts coordinated with cutbacks due for agreement later this year at the Vienna talks on reducing conventional forces in Europe. The Hungarian talks will be attended by senior military figures from each side, MTI said.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Ordered in Michigan; Complaint Dismissed in Wyoming
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for Muskegon, Mich. datelined story on AM-News Advisory and includes development in Wyoming case. Fredric is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A Michigan woman accused of smoking crack cocaine 13 hours before giving birth was ordered Thursday to stand trial, but in Wyoming a judge dismissed a child-abuse complaint brought against a woman because she drank alcohol. In Michigan's Muskegon County Circuit Court, District Judge Fredric Grimm ordered Kimberly Hardy, 22, to stand trial on charges of second-degree child abuse and delivering cocaine to her newborn baby after he was born, but before the umbilical cord was cut on Aug. 20. In Laramie, Wyo., Albany County Judge Robert Denhardt dismissed a child abuse complaint against Diane Pfannenstiel, saying the state did not produce probable cause that her fetus had been injured. Pfannenstiel, 29, was about four months pregnant when she was arrested Jan. 4, two months after another judge ordered her to remain alcohol-free. A blood test revealed she had a blood alcohol level of 0.1 percent, the level at which a person is considered intoxicated under state law. Drug use, particularly cocaine, has led to arrests of pregnant women or new mothers in some states. Crack-cocaine use by pregnant women has led to several arrests in Florida on charges of delivering cocaine to newborn babies since the first successful conviction in August. But that case is still on appeal. A grand jury in Rockford, Ill., refused late last May to indict a young mother for involuntary manslaughter in the Feb. 4 death of her 2-day-old daughter, who succumbed to oxygen deprivation attributed to her mother's alleged use of cocaine during pregnancy. In a separate case in Rockford, an unidentified juvenile mother was convicted last May of prenatal child abuse for allegedly using cocaine a few hours before the birth of her daughter. About a dozen pregnant women who tested positive for drugs or whose newborns had cocaine in their systems have been charged in South Carolina with criminal child neglect. Prosecutors say they will recommend probation and treatment _ not jail time _ for any woman who is convicted. In the Michigan case, Hardy was charged in November after voluntarily undergoing treatment for substance abuse. She admitted smoking crack about 13 hours before giving birth, Sheriff's Detective Al Van Hemert testified. ``I certainly wish you well, but I don't think the court can turn its back on the situation and say we don't care. ... I think that would be the biggest travesty of all,'' the judge told Hardy. Dr. Dan Mikesell testified that Hardy's son suffered from low birthweight, poor gastrointestinal functions and frequent spitting up in the hours and days after birth at Muskegon General Hospital. He said drug screening turned up cocaine in the baby's urine. Conviction of delivery of cocaine is punishable up by to 20 years in prison and $25,000 fine, while second-degree child abuse carries a top penalty of four years in prison. The baby and Hardy's other two children, ages 4 and 1, have been placed in foster care. Hardy is free on personal bond. In the Wyoming alcohol case, the judge noted that the state's child abuse statutes require that an injury be demonstrated. ``The key as I see it is that the child already has to have suffered,'' Denhardt said. Dr. Gary Lang, a pediatrician, testified that studies have shown pregnant women who drink excessively are prone to give birth to children suffering from fetal alcohol syndrome, which is exhibited by physical and mental developmental defects. But Lang could not say definitely that the defendant's fetus had been injured by its mother's drinking. Another judge had ordered Pfannenstiel to remain alcohol-free following a previous pregnancy that produced a baby suffering from fetal alcohol syndrome, according to court records.

DOC.HEAD: South African Human Rights Group Says Police Upset With Reforms
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
By GREG MYRE
DOC.TEXT: A human rights group on Thursday praised the government's decision to look into alleged police death squads, but said the security forces appear increasingly unhappy with President F.W. de Klerk's reforms. De Klerk refused to call for such an inquiry in December but reversed himself Wednesday and named a Supreme Court judge to probe the charges. He also asked for a separate inquiry into the death of a 20-year-old black man, found hanged Tuesday in his police cell. Anti-apartheid groups long have alleged that the security forces were involved in the more than 60 unsolved killings of activists during the 1980s. The Human Rights Commission, a private group led by anti-apartheid activists, said de Klerk's reversal ``illustrated clearly that sustained pressure both internally and internationally against the system of apartheid continues to have its effect.'' It said de Klerk was ``bringing to heel the security apparatus,'' but added, ``The erratic performance of the security forces suggests that there is disagreement and even rebellion against the government's new survival-motivated policy of presenting a clean image to the world.'' De Klerk has allowed peaceful protests since shortly after assuming power last August. Police, however, recently have resorted to tear gas, rubber bullets and baton charges to break up peaceful demonstrations considered illegal. Police Gen. Herman Stadler on Tuesday blamed an upsurge in unrest on the government's more relaxed attitude toward political dissent. De Klerk told top 500 police officials recently that the force would no longer fight the government's political battles and should stick to fighting crime. According to reports, police morale has suffered since the controversy over the purported death squads broke out late last year. Three former policemen have said they took part in killing government opponents under authorization of their superiors. Police have denied that assassination squads exist. But last Oct. 19, the night before he was due to be hanged, black former policeman Butana Almond Nofomela swore in an affidavit he was part of a police death squad. Armed with the affidavit, human rights activists obtained a stay of execution so Nofomela could help in investigations of death squad activity. Nofomela, on death row for a killing with no apparent political overtones, named two former policemen he said also participated in the killings. The men, Dirk Coetzee, a white former captain, and David Tshikalanga, who is black, fled South Africa and admitting taking part in at least 10 killings. Coetzee is in Zimbabwe, and reportedly has joined the African National Congress, the main black group fighting South Africa's white-dominated government. In an interview with the Star newspaper of Johannesburg, Coetzee was quoted as saying he welcomed a full investigation _ ``I hope the whole thing will come out into the open now.'' Nofomela recently pleaded guilty to the 1981 stabbing death of black anti-apartheid attorney Griffiths Mxenge. Arrest warrants were issued for Coetzee and Tshikalanga in the same case. Police meanwhile said Thursday that Pieter van der Merwe, a 20-year-old white soldier, has been arrested in connection with the murders of three blacks who were abducted in a minibus, shot dead and left at intervals along a highway near Klerksdorp, a mining town 100 miles west of Johannesburg. He was identified as a conscript serving in an army artillery brigade. Police gave no indication of a possible motive.

DOC.HEAD: Alaska Parish Administrators May Officiate at Weddings
DOC.TEXT: The Vatican has granted the far-flung Roman Catholic archdiocese of Alaska permission for six female parish administrators to officiate at weddings when priests or deacons are not available, church officials said Thursday. The National Conference of Catholic Bishops had asked for such permission at its November meeting, responding to a request from Archbishop Francis T. Hurley of Anchorage. The bishops, in announcing the approval from Rome, quoted Hurley as saying, ``The church and canon law are not as rigid as some are prone to think.'' The Catholic Church ``has a history of adjusting to extraordinary situations,'' Hurley was quoted as saying in Friday's edition of his church newspaper. The extraordinary situation in Alaska, Hurley had said, was a land area bigger than many nations and served by only a few priests. Hurley pilots his own airplane in order to travel the great distances between Alaskan parishes. In presenting his request last November, he told fellow bishops that bad weather can hold him up, upsetting long-scheduled wedding plans. Officially, the Vatican Congregation for Divine Worship granted permission for Hurley to delegate authority for weddings to nuns or lay people otherwise qualified _ knowing how to perform the ceremony, licensed by the state and so forth. Hurley's newspaper said the ruling in this case applies to five nuns and one lay woman currently serving as parish administrators in his archdiocese. The permission applies only to Alaska for now _ for a trial period of five years _ but could be extended to other U.S. dioceses in similar situations pending requests to the Vatican by other bishops. Hurley said, ``There is no intention to take the priest or deacon from the scene. Rather this permission will remove the uncertainty that at times hovers over a planned wedding when fog, rain or snow ... makes the arrival of a priest or deacon questionable.''

DOC.HEAD: ANC Cancels Appearance of Death Squad Defectors
With AM-Death Squads
DOC.TEXT: The African National Congress on Thursday canceled plans to produce in public a white defector who says he was the leader of a South African death squad. Four hours after former police Capt. Dirk Coetzee was scheduled to appear at a news conference in Harare, ANC information director Pallo Jordan said the event was called off ``because of circumstances beyond our control.'' Asked if the guerrilla-backed organization had bowed to pressure from the Zimbabwe government, Jordan said, ``It would be incorrect to put it that way.'' He did not elaborate and declined to give further comment. Earlier Thursday, ANC officials said the Zimbabwe government expressed disquiet over the appearance in Harare of Coetzee and a black former policeman, David Tshikalanga, said also to have been a member of a police hit squad authorized to kill anti-apartheid activists in South Africa. The officials said the two men were to reveal details of killings they were involved in and had compiled a dossier alleging the activities of death squads were sanctioned by former South African law and order minister Louis Le Grange and his successor Adrian Vlok. A senior ANC official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said colleagues met at the Zimbabwe Foreign Ministry late Wednesday and again early Thursday. ``There are hurdles. We were waiting for a permit from the authorities to go ahead,'' he said of the scheduled news conference. Coetzee was in a private suite at a Harare hotel and information on his immediate plans was not known. He was expected to have announced a wish to join the ANC if given the approval of the organization's leaders. In a brief written notice canceling the news conference, the ANC referred all further inquiries to its external headquarters in Lusaka, Zambia. In the past, Zimbabwe has allowed the ANC to maintain offices in Harare but denied the presence of armed guerrillas on its territory. Several ANC facilities in Zimbabwe have been the target of bombings and sabotage attacks blamed on South African agents. Coetzee, who fled South Africa in November, has been implicated in more than 10 killings, including the 1981 death of black attorney Griffiths Mxenge. The ANC says Coetzee and Tshikalanga allege the widespread involvement of South African security officers in unsolved killings over several years.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Throws Bomb at Army Post; Lowest Fatality Toll in January
DOC.TEXT: A Palestinian hurled a homemade bomb at an army outpost in the occupied Gaza City on Thursday and suffered serious wounds in the explosion, military officials said. An Israeli soldier was slightly injured in the blast. An army official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the soldier was only ``scratched'' in the attack and treated on the spot. The assailant was taken to Barzilai Hospital in the southern Israeli town of Ashkelon, he said. Officials at Gaza's Ahli Arab hospital said they treated Mohammed El Batneij, 24, a Gaza City resident who suffered multiple wounds and was later taken away by troops. Arab journalists said they believed El Batneij was the attacker in the incident reported by the army, but the military had no comment. In other violence, two Palestinians were reported shot and wounded in a clash between soldiers and stone throwers in the West Bank city of Nablus. A Palestinian suspected of collaborating with Israel died of head wounds after reportedly being beaten by fellow Arabs. Also Thursday, an Israeli human rights group said eleven Arabs were killed by Israelis during January, matching the lowest monthly fatality toll since the Palestinian uprising began nearly 26 months ago. An Israeli army spokesman said, however, that the lower toll did not necessarily mean the revolt against Israel's occupation in the West Bank and Gaza Strip was over. ``There have been ups and downs in the amount and the extent of violence,'' said the spokesman, Maj. Moshe Fogel. During January, Israelis killed nine Palestinians in the West Bank and two in the Gaza Strip, according to the Israeli Information Center for Human Rights in the Occupied Territories. The organization, founded by liberal Israeli politicians and academics, said that matched the lowest monthly death toll of Palestinian victims in the uprising, 11 in November 1988. It noted 21 Palestinians were killed in December 1989 and the highest monthly toll of the uprising was 44 killed in April 1988. In the West Bank, a Palestinian man suspected of collaborating with Israel died Thursday of massive internal hemorrhaging after being clubbed by masked Arab assailiants, hospital and Arab reports said. Wahid Abdalla Rashid, 29, died at Ramallah hospital after he was severely beaten in Jammala, a village 14 miles northwest of Jerusalem. The army confirmed the death and said it was under investigation. Rashid's death brought to 176 the number of Palestinians killed by their fellow Arabs on suspicion of assisting Israel during the revolt that began December 1987. At least 651 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians during the ``intefadeh,'' Arabic for uprising. Forty-three Israelis have also died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: HCFA Head Confirmed
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Thursday voted unanimously to confirm the nomination of Gail Wilensky, a health policy analyst, to head the Medicare and Medicaid programs. Wilensky, 46, will take the reins of the Health Care Financing Administration, which oversees a $137 billion budget for the two federal health-care programs, in the Department of Health and Human Services. She was vice president of Project Hope, a foundation based in Chevy Chase, Md., that trains medical workers and provides emergency care in poor nations and analyzes health issues inthis country and abroad. The Health Care Financing Administration has been without a permanent director since Bill Roper left a year ago to become an adviser to President Bush.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sentences Sims to Life, No Chance of Parole
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with prosecutor's comment, defense planning appeal, jurors' comments, county attorney saying investigation remains open. Edits to tighten. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A woman was sentenced to life in prison with no chance of parole Thursday for murdering the second infant daughter she reported abducted in less than three years. A Peoria County jury ruled out the death penalty for Paula Marie Sims after three hours of deliberation. The same panel convicted Mrs. Sims on Tuesday of first-degree murder, obstruction of justice and concealing a homicide in the death of 6-week-old Heather Lee, whose suffocated body was found May 3 in a Missouri trash barrel. Madison County Judge Andy Matoesian immediately sentenced her to natural life in prison, meaning no chance for parole. Mrs. Sims sat ashen but impassive. ``Justice was done,'' the prosecutor, Assistant Madison County State's Attorney Donald Weber, told reporters outside the courtroom. Defense attorney Donald Groshong said he would appeal the verdict. Earlier, he argued for a lesser sentence. ``Natural life does not take into consideration the possibility of rehabilitation, the fact that all life has worth,'' he said. But Madison County State's Attorney William Haine said Mrs. Sims should spend the rest of her life behind bars. Mrs. Sims, 30, of Alton, had told police Heather Lee was abducted by a masked gunman from her home in the Madison County city of Alton on April 29 _ a story nearly identical to the one she told after the 1986 disappearance of her firstborn daughter, Loralei. Heather's body was found across the Mississippi River in nearby West Alton, Mo. An autopsy indicated she had been suffocated and her body subsequently frozen. Thirteen-day-old Loralei was reported abducted June 17, 1986, from the Simses' former home in the nearby rural Jersey County town of Brighton. Police found a baby's body 150 yards from the Sims home a week later, but no positive identification was ever made. No murder charges have been filed in Loralei's death, but Mrs. Sims faces trial in Jersey County on charges of obstruction of justice and concealment of a homicide. Prosecutors argued that Mrs. Sims and her husband, 37-year-old Robert, had wanted only male babies. Sims, who has not been charged in either case, has custody of the couple's 2-year-old son, Randy. After sentencing, Haine, the county's top prosecutor, said the investigation into Heather Lee's death remains open. ``There will be some other charges filed,'' he said, without elaborating. Juror John Joplin said the panel decided against the death penalty in the hope that Mrs. Sims would lead authorities to others involved in the crime. The jury foreman, Peoria engineer Harold William Ryan Jr., said jurors didn't buy Mrs. Sims' description of the child's abduction. ``Her story was well-prepared on the witness stand but I guess we just didn't believe it,'' Ryan said after the sentencing. The trial was moved to Peoria County because of pretrial publicity in southern Illinois. Under Illinois law, death penalty hearings have two phases: the first to determine whether the crime warrants the death penalty; the second to determine whether the death penalty should be imposed. Jurors on Wednesday had found Mrs. Sims eligible for death by lethal injection. Thursday's decision followed additional testimony and arguments. Groshong fought unsuccessfully for a delay in Thursday's proceedings, saying his client had lost the will to live and needed psychiatric evaluation. ``She still maintains her innocence, but says, `I don't have any reason to go on, I don't have any reason to live. Whether I'm innocent doesn't matter _ they can go ahead and execute me,''' Groshong said. Matoesian said he considered Mrs. Sims capable of proceeding.

DOC.HEAD: Venezuelan Prostitutes Join Bar Owners to Protest Alcohol Ban
DOC.TEXT: About 1,000 hotel, bar and restaurant workers and owners marched on the mayor's office Thursday to protest the ban on alcohol sales after midnight he imposed last month in the center of the capital. Joining them were dozens of prostitutes in tight jeans, who complain their trade also is being hurt. Mayor Claudio Fermin decreed that alcohol sales be prohibited in Caracas's federal district after midnight as an anti-crime measure. The prohibition cuts across the center of Caracas, with the eastern and southern sectors of the city not affected. ``It's ruined my business. How can I tell a client he has to leave after he's just sat down with a beer?'' asked Joao Sosa Abreu, owner of a restaurant-bar in downtown Caracas. Several bar owners insisted that the liquor curfew has done little to fight crime. ``They're clamping down on my business, and all it does is it makes people go drink up in the hills and shoot each other up there,'' Sosa Abreu said. National guard and police units in charge of enforcing the decree make life difficult for the prostitutes who abound in the center of the city at night. Many of the women call themselves dancers and models. One bar worker, Carmen Guzman, complained, ``Why should they stop me from making a living? I've got four kids.'' Ms. Guzman said her minimum wage paid by the bar had been cut in half, to about 25 cents a night. Most women who work in Caracas bars as entertainers or barmaids can bring home from 70 cents to slightly over a dollar a night, depending on tips, said Ms. Guzman. Bar owners estimate they are losing an average of about $1,200 a month in business from the prohibition. The mayor did not meet with the marchers. A merchants' association sent him a letter demanding that the liquor ban be imposed at some later hour than midnight, but no response was received, said owners in the march. During the protest march, a dozen metropolitan police in riot gear stood guard in front of the municipal palace which contains the mayor's office. Fermin is the first mayor of the federal district elected by direct vote. About 70 percent of eligible voters didn't cast ballots in the Dec. 3 election.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Defendants Ordered to Pay Federal Prison Costs
DOC.TEXT: Three men accused of supplying 75 percent of the city's heroin were ordered to pay the costs of keeping them in federal prison for terms ranging from two to 6{ years. The defendants will be charged $1,200 a month, in addition to $91 a month for the cost of supervised probation once they're out of prison. ``It's the just thing to do,'' said Chief U.S. District Court Judge Francis J. Boyle. ``To the extent that a defendant is able to pay for it the defendant should be required to.'' The men pleaded guilty to a variety of drug charges and were sentenced Friday by U.S. District Judge Ernest C. Torres, who ruled after reading a presentencing report that found the men able to pay. The defendants are Oscar Tillett, 38, sentenced to 6{ years and fined $60,000 on three counts of selling heroin; Luis Cepeda, 39, sentenced to 27 months and fined $15,000 for selling heroin, and Esteban Colon, 39, sentenced to 2 years and fined $40,000 for selling herion and possessing the drug with intent to distribute. Federal prosecutors alleged the men were responsible for distributing 75 percent of the city's heroin. Federal judges in Providence have ordered defendants to pay for their own incarceration ``a couple of dozen times'' since the the option was opened to them in November 1987, said Donald Wyatt, the U.S. Marshal in Providence. An attempt to adopt a similar sentencing option at the state level failed in the Rhode Island General Assembly in 1988. Opponents, including the local chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union, argued the practice would unfairly take money from convicts' families. Florida had a similar law on the books from 1979 through 1981, but it was repealed because annual administrative costs were $89,673, compared to total collections of $7,636 over the three years.

The decision by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh to seek an independent counsel investigation of former HUD Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. and other former department officials is the latest development in nearly a year of disclosures about Reagan-era problems at the agency. Here are highlights:

Pierce, the only Cabinet member to serve for the entire eight years of the Reagan administration, told Congress early in its review of the agency's problems that he was not a ``hands on'' manager and that he took no direct role in contract awards. Later testimony and HUD documents, however, showed Pierce intervened to assist a North Carolina development supported by a former law associate and that he personally lifted sanctions against a HUD lender after being lobbied by former HUD Secretary Carla Hills. Numerous other accounts have demonstrated that Pierce intervened in numerous cases, suggesting a more active role than he indicated in his initial congressional testimony. Pierce refused testify later, citing his constitutional protection against self-incrimination.

It was an audit of this program by HUD's inspector general that set off the investigations of Pierce's tenure. The audit said former agency officials and developers who hired prominent Republican consultants won the lion's share of subsidies under the program. The audit also said that many participants had bloated mortgages and because of that were receiving excessive subsidies, costing HUD _ and taxpayers _ hundreds of millions of dollars. Among the GOP consultants called before Congress was former Interior Secretary James Watt, who made more than $300,000 lobbying HUD, and Fred Bush, who is no relation to President Bush but was a major fund-raiser for his election campaign. President Bush withdrew an ambassadorial nomination of Fred Bush after GOP senators told the White House it was doomed because of the HUD hearings.

HUD Secretary Jack Kemp has canceled this program, blamed for $900 million in just six years. A key Reagan housing program, co-insurance allowed private lenders to commit the government to insuring mortgage loans. HUD's inspector general said co-insurers often issued mortgages well in excess of property values, earning themselves higher fees but increasing the chances for default. Defaults leave HUD liable for 80 percent of the loan.

The moderate rehabilitation audit was the first of several reports and investigations alleging widespread favoritism at HUD during the Reagan years. Documents showed Deborah Dean, Pierce's former top aide, on at least one occasion allowed a close friend who was a former HUD official-turned housing lobbyist to see a confidential document affecting a client. The report also questioned the conduct of then Assistant Secretary Thomas Demery, saying many of the recipients of the lucrative subsidies were donors to a charity Demery helped found. But the Justice Department declined to prosecute Demery. The Senate Ethics Committee also is investigating whether New York Republican Alfonse D'Amato used his influence to steer HUD contracts to campaign donors and other associates.

Lax agency management left HUD unable to account for millions of dollars. The most publicized example was HUD's relationships with the private escrow agents hired to handle sales of HUD properties. One, Marilyn Harrell of Maryland, was dubbed ``Robin HUD'' after she admitted withholding more than $5 million owed HUD and said she gave some of the money to the poor. She pleaded guilty to theft and other charges this week. In all, a dozen such agents are being investigated. The entire leadership of the Washington, D.C., field office was fired and a dozen other managers have either resigned or been transferred in a management shakeup.

Among the other embarrassing disclosures since the Mod Rehab report was issued last April were the use of one HUD program to build luxury developments such as a golf course-condominium development and the use of money from a program designed to benefit low- and moderate-income elderly for a pricey apartment development near Palm Beach, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: PLO to Send Delegation to Moscow on Israeli Jewish Emigration
DOC.TEXT: A senior PLO official said Thursday his organization will send a delegation to Moscow to ask that Jewish emigration to Israeli-occupied territories be restricted. The plans were revealed after Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir suggested last month that Israel needed to keep the occupied lands to settle the expected wave of immigrants, which Israel says may total 300,000 in the next three years. Azzam al-Ahmed, the Palestinian ambassador in Baghdad, told The Associated Press the delegation will include leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization's various factions and members of the PLO executive committee. He said the PLO leadership, which discussed the problem in its latest meeting in Tunis, decided to send the delegation to put the request to the Soviet leadership. No date was mentioned. Israeli officials have said 4,700 Jews left the Soviet Union in January, and 4,600 of them came to Israel. The PLO fears the influx will eventually change the balance of population in the occupied territories. Presently about 70,000 Jews live in more than 120 settlements in the West Bank and Gaza. About 1.5 million Palestinian Arabs live in the territories seized by Israel in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. Al-Ahmed did not say exactly what the PLO wants the Kremlin to do to stop the influx. Arab diplomats said the PLO wants Moscow to pressure Washington to allow more Jews to settle in the United States, following recent measures by Washington to restrict the influx of Soviet Jews. Al-Ahmed said Moscow can take political and administrative measures to discourage its Jewish population from emigrating to Israel. He did not elaborate. Palestinian officials also have been complaining that Soviet news media do not give wide coverage to the 26-month-old ``intefadeh,'' or uprising, in the occupied territories. They say more coverage would highlight problems that would-be Jewish emigrants could face if they chose to go to the occupied territories, and discourage such emigration. In Tunis, a top Soviet diplomat told the PLO Wednesday that Moscow shares ``the same concerns'' over possible settlement of Soviet Jews in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Gennadi Tarassov expressed his views to the PLO's executive committee.

DOC.HEAD: Castro Praises Crew's Bravery in Face of `Yankee Attack'
DOC.TEXT: Fidel Castro greeted the crew of a freighter fired upon by the U.S. Coast Guard when they arrived Thursday in Havana, praising their courage in the face of a ``Yankee attack,'' the official Cuban news agency said. Prensa Latina said the Cuban president met the crew of the freighter Hermann at the stairs of the plane that brought them home Thursday afternoon from the Mexican port of Tampico. The news agency said the crew was then taken to downtown Havana, where ``hundreds of thousands of people had gathered'' in tribute to them near the U.S. interest section, which handles U.S. diplomatic affairs in Cuba. A U.S. Coast Guard cutter opened fire on the Hermann with a machine gun and cannon after the freighter repeatedly refused to stop and be searched for drugs. The Hermann was escorted to Tampico Wednesday by the Mexican Navy and searched by Mexican officials, who said they found no drugs. Cuba has filed a protest with the United States over the incident, whcih took place as the freighter crossed the Gulf of Mexico between Cuba and Mexico. ``This deed demonstrates once more that the United States intends to behave as owner of the world and with its proverbial barbarism appears willing to obstruct normal commerce between Cuba and Mexico,'' a Cuban official in Washington said, according to Prensa Latina. The Coast Guard ended its attempt to stop the Hermann when the freighter entered Mexican waters. Mexican officials searched the 250-foot freighter, which is registered in Panama, at the request of U.S. officials. Capt. Aristides Palma Palma, head of port operations in Tampico, said the Hermann was hit 50 times bu gunfire but that none of the crew was injured. A new crew arrived in Tampico Thursday and the old crew was flown home. The Hermann, which Cuban officials said carried 10 tons of chromium, was to undergo repairs in Tampico. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said the incident ``was not an attack and a provocation. We were engaged in a legal law enforcement activity.'' But Cuba's ambassador in Mexico, Jose Fernandez de Cossio, said in Tampico that Cuba will file a complaint about the incident with the U.N. Human Rights Commission. The incident, Prensa Latina quoted Castro as saying, ``was a demonstration of the courage of our people. It's what I would have expected in the face of a Yankee attack.'' Capt. Diego Sanchez Serrano filed a damage claim with Tampico harbor authorities saying the Hermann, owned by the Cuban Guamar Shipping Co., and its crew had been the victims of a terrorist act, the Excelsior news service in Mexico City said.

DOC.HEAD: Greensboro Marks 30th Anniversary of Lunch Counter Sit-ins
