DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `McCain, Richmond...,' to clarify that servers are still employees. SUBS 18th graf, `Geneva Tisdale...,' to conform. SUBS 23rd graf, `Bellow, 64...,' to CORRECT spelling of name.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto GBO1, LaserColor GBO1C
DOC.TEXT: The dramatic lunch counter sit-in 30 years ago that helped ignite the 1960s civil rights movement surprised everyone, even the four black participants who re-enacted it Thursday at Woolworth's. ``We were scared,'' recalled Franklin McCain, one of the four college students who staged the first lunch counter sit-in on Feb. 1, 1960. ``All I wanted was a Coke and a doughnut.'' ``If someone had come up behind me and said boo, I probably would have fallen off the stool,'' said another protester, David Richmond. When McCain and his three college friends took their same seats Thursday, they were treated like celebrities. A black Woolworth executive greeted them before they sat down to a breakfast of eggs, grits, bacon and coffee. McCain, Richmond, Joseph McNeil and Jibreel Khazan, formerly Ezell Blair Jr., were surrounded by dozens of reporters and spectators when they ordered food from two female employees who worked there on Feb. 1, 1960. Woolworth Vice President Aubrey Lewis, noted that 30 years ago he, too, would have been denied service. ``I'm proud you had the courage to open the doors for a movement,'' Lewis said. While they waited for their meals, some spectators began singing ``We Shall Overcome.'' Outside there was more singing, directed by the NAACP, and some bystanders carried placards saying ``Feb. 1, 1960. It seems like only yesterday but it could be tomorrow'' and ``The only thing that's worthwhile is change _ Remembering Feb. 1, 1960.'' One thing that hasn't changed much is the lunch counter, which looks about the same as it did in 30-year-old news photographs about the sit-in. But now, black and white customers sit side by side on the chrome and red vinyl seats, ordering food and discussing sports and events of the day. When the four North Carolina A&T State University freshmen refused to leave the whites-only counter 30 years ago, their sit-in touched off similar protests across the South. During their sit-in, which began about 4 p.m., a policeman stood near them and slapped his billyclub in the palm of his hand a few times, but they were not threatened with arrest. The store was closed at 5 p.m., a half-hour early, and they left peacefully. ``We did get some encouragement on the first day and we got it from quarters you wouldn't ordinarily expect it to come from,'' McCain said. ``There was a little old white lady of oh, 75 years of age, who came over and placed hands on our shoulders and said to us, `Boys, I'm so proud of you. The only thing I regret is that it didn't happen 20 years earlier.'' ``People took us for granted because we were poor youth, freshmen in college,'' Khazan said. ``In America, people don't really believe young people can do anything to make positive change in society. ``We've achieved some rights, but there's many more rights that haven't been achieved.'' Elizabeth Koopman, an education professor at Guilford College, recalled reading about the protests back in Michigan. ``It shook the world,'' she said. ``You knew it was coming, like the Berlin Wall bursting open.'' Geneva Tisdale, who is black, was one of those working at the Woolworth's lunch counter on Feb. 1, 1960. She remembers the four students coming in that day. ``I thought they were joking,'' she said Thursday. ``I never thought they were serious.'' Another counter worker, Ima Edwards, who is white, said she didn't ``see it blossoming into this.'' After Thursday's breakfast, the four went outside, where the street in front of the store was renamed February One Place. A plaque and their footprints were dedicated to commemorate the anniversary. Other events are planned through Sunday to mark the occasion. Bill Bellow, who said he was seated at the counter when the students took their seats back on Feb. 1, 1960, embraced Khazan outside the store. ``I was right there in the middle, two on each side,'' he said. ``I wouldn't leave. I told the lady to serve them. These kids had a right to sit down to a cup of coffee.'' Bellow, 64, said his support for the students did not sit well with many of his friends in Greensboro. ``They got on my side two or three years later,'' he said. The four said they had targeted Woolworth because it was a well-known national chain that allowed its lunch counters to be segregated only in the South. The sit-ins quickly spread to more than 50 cities in nine states. ``All of us were surprised that it spread so rapidly to other cities,'' said McNeil. `Six months later it began to wane, but we hung in and persevered. We saw it to the end.'' On July 25, 1960, Woolworth agreed to allow blacks at the lunch counter. Later accounts reported the chain lost about $200,000 in business during the sit-ins.

DOC.HEAD: Mexico Plans No Charges Against Latest Suspects In Camarena Case
DOC.TEXT: Mexico said Thursday it will not charge five Mexican citizens, including two former top-echelon lawmen here, who were indicted in Los Angeles in the torture-slaying of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena Salazar. ``We are not going to file any complaints at this time,'' a spokeswoman for the Attorney General's office told The Associated Press. ``They were members of the past administration.'' Manuel Ibarra Herrera, former chief of Federal Judicial Police, and Miguel Aldana Ibarra, who headed the Mexican branch of the international policy agency Interpol, live in Mexico City and served in the administration of former President Miguel de la Madrid, who left office 13 months ago. They were indicted Wednesday by a federal grand jury in Los Angeles that is continuing a five-year investigation into the deaths of Camarena, a U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agent, and his Mexican pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar. Camarena and Zavala were killed after Camarena led raids on marijuana plantations allegedly run by Guadalajara drug kingpin Rafael Caro Quintero. Camarena's body was found March 5, 1985, on a ranch 65 miles southeast of Guadalajara. The DEA pledged it will prosecute all connected to the case. A Mexican judge in December sentenced Caro Quintero to 40 years in prison for his role in the Camarena slaying. He is one of a dozen people convicted in the case in Mexico. The Los Angeles indictment also named Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros, who was extradited from his native Honduras in 1988 and sentenced to a life term in prison by a Los Angeles federal judge. A Foreign Ministry spokesman said authorities have no information about any U.S. plans to request extradition of the Mexican citizens indicted Wednesday. One, reputed druglord Miguel Angel Felix Gallardo, has been in jail in Mexico on narcotics charges since April. The whereabouts of two, Humberto Alvarez Machain and Antonio Vasquez Ochoa, are unknown. Vasquez is charged with violent crime in aid of racketeering in the Guadalajara slayings of U.S. citizens John Walker and Alberto Radelat in January 1985. Neither Aldana or Ibarra could be reached at their Mexico City telephone numbers on Thursday. But Aldana, 44, was quoted by the independent Excelsior news service in Mexico as saying he is considering ``a countersuit through Foreign Ministry channels.'' Aldana resigned from his Interpol post on Jan. 2, 1986, after 28 years as a law enforcement officer. He said he wanted to write books and do criminology research. He resigned after the weekly newsmagazine Proceso said a drug defendant had testified that a shipment of Colombian cocaine seized at the Mexico City airport was for Aldana. The defendant later recanted, claiming his testimony was made under duress. Aldana alleged in recent interviews that Camarena was corrupt. He told Excelsior his only involvement with the Camarena murder were ``investigations ordered by the Attorney General's office in 1985.'' The former Interpol chief in Mexico now is top man in one of about a dozen lawyers associations in Mexico City and runs a private consulting business called Desarollo Empresarial, S.A. de C.V. Ibarra, 58, dropped out of public life in 1988 when he retired from the judicial police, Mexico's equivalent of the FBI. Newsweek, the U.S. news magazine, said in a 1985 report that when Ibarra led the force, the DEA gave him a tip that Matta Ballesteros was in a Mexico City hotel. But the magazine said that it took Ibarra's men 36 hours to reach the hotel and by the time they arrived, Matta Ballesteros had fled, . The Attorney General's Office told Excelsior that both Aldana and Ibarra have been called before federal magistrates since retiring, but only to testify as investigators.

DOC.HEAD: Former Rose Associate Gets 5-year Sentence on Drug, Tax Convictions
A version moving on sports wires.
LaserPhoto CS2
DOC.TEXT: Tommy Gioiosa, a friend of banned baseball star Pete Rose, was sentenced Thursday to five years in federal prison for transporting cocaine and for conspiring to hide Rose's racetrack winnings from the IRS. Gioiosa's allegations about Rose's betting habits have been widely reported, though he refused to give information to the investigation that led baseball officials to ban the former Cincinnati Reds player and manager from the game for life. U.S. District Judge S. Arthur Spiegel didn't fine Gioiosa, saying Gioiosa didn't have the money to pay one. Gioiosa, 31, had faced a maximum 28 years in prison and $1.5 million in fines. Spiegel ordered Gioiosa to begin serving his sentence immediately, rejecting defense requests that he remain free on bond while he appeals. Gioiosa was convicted in September of claiming all of a $47,646 winning Pik Six bet at a Kentucky racetrack for tax purposes, when Rose actually owned part of the ticket. Prosecutors argued during the 13-week trial that Rose had Gioiosa claim the ticket because the Rose was in a higher tax bracket. Gioiosa admitted during trial that he drove cocaine shipments from Florida to Cincinnati for operators of a gymnasium where he and Rose worked out. Rose has been cleared by the FBI of any involvment in drugs. Gioiosa was sentenced to five months each on two tax-evasion charges and to five years on the cocaine charge. The terms are to be served concurrently, making the total term five years. Gioiosa had little to say before sentence was imposed, telling the judge, ``I'm sorry for what I've put my family through.'' In an interview broadcast Thursday, Gioiosa repeated earlier allegations that Rose bet on baseball games, including Reds games. ``I've sat in his office and watched him bet on baseball games, including the Reds and many other baseball teams,'' Gioiosa said in an interview broadcast on WKRC-TV in Cincinnati. ``That's a closed issue as far as I'm concerned,'' Rose said in response to Gioiosa's claim. He spoke at news conference before a speech Thursday night to students at the University of Florida. ``I can't prove I didn't,'' Rose said. ``Obviously you can't prove a negative.'' Asked about Gioiosa's jail sentence, Rose said, ``I feel sorry for him, but if you break the law, bad things are going to happen to you.'' Another former Rose associate, Paul Janszen, told baseball investigators that he placed bets for Rose on Reds games when Rose was manager of the team. Gioiosa, a bodybuilder, lived with Rose for about five years in the late 1970s and early 1980s, and testified during the trial that he regularly placed bets for Rose with bookmakers. He didn't provide details of the bets. Rose, who holds the major league record for most lifetime hits with 4,256, accepted a lifetime ban from baseball in August when confronted with evidence of illegal gambling. A federal grand jury in Cincinnati is has been trying to determine if Rose paid all the taxes due on his racetrack earnings, memorabilia sales and autograph appearances. One of Gioiosa's lawyers, Martin Weinberg, said Gioiosa continued to decline to talk to those investigating Rose. ``He has not wanted to invade his private relationship with Pete Rose,'' Weinberg said. Since his conviction in September, Gioiosa has been living with his parents in New Bedford, Mass., and managing a gym.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Approves Six-Month Extension of Expired Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Parliament passed a law Thursday extending the May deadline for the United States to dismantle its military installations in Greece. The deputies approved a bill limiting the bases to staying in Greece until Nov. 21, unless a new defense agreement is reached with the United States. Elections are scheduled for April 8, leaving the next government to carry on negotiations. Under terms of an agreement that expired in December 1988, the United States had until May 21 to remove personnel, property and materiel from four major bases and several smaller installations. The conservative and socialist parties supported the bill extending the deadline and want to continue negotiations with the United States. Together they have 276 seats in the 300-member Parliament. A Communist-led alliance voted against extending the deadline on the bases' removal and called for an end to negotiations on their future. U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on Monday proposed closing two of the four major installations in Greece. They are the Hellenikon Air Base and Nea Makri, a naval communications base. Both are near Athens. The bases are among 14 U.S. foreign military installations and more than 60 in the United States which Cheney announced he wants to close or restructure to save money.

DOC.HEAD: Service Cuts, Tax Hikes Proposed in $27.8 Billion City Budget
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins proposed a record $27.8 billion budget Thursday and said he had no choice but to seek $550 million in new taxes and to cut city services ``to the bone'' to balance it. The city faces a budget shortfall of $445 million for the current fiscal year, which ends June 30, and a gap of more than $1 billion in the 1991 budget, said Dinkins, who took office Jan. 1, replacing Edward Koch. ``Let me be very plain,'' Dinkins said at a City Hall news conference, ``service reductions are inevitable, higher taxes are necessary, sacrifices will be required. On this, we have no choice.'' He said the $226 million in service cuts will include eliminating one fire battalion for a savings of $425,000, cutting $4.5 million in funds for libraries and cultural institutions and scaling back training of new math, science and computer teachers. Worst of all, he said, would be a delay in hiring 2,708 additional police officers until sometime in fiscal 1991. The department has 26,000 officers. The mayor blamed the city's budget squeeze on falling revenues, a reduction in aid from Washington, and a variety of items the state requires the city to fund. Under the Dinkins budget, $180 million in new property taxes would be raised. Homeowners would pay an average $33 a year more than they presently do and property taxes on midtown Manhattan office space would be raised 19 cents per square foot. A three-year, 7.5 percent surcharge in the city's personal income tax would raise $200 million and cost the average taxpayer $70 annually. He also proposed raising city gasoline taxes and a variety of other levies. Depending on the levy to be changed, the proposals would require action by the state Legislature, the City Council or both bodies.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Clashes with China and Cuba at Annual Meeting
DOC.TEXT: The United States on Thursday clashed with China and Cuba at the annual session of the U.N. Human Rights Commission after the two Communist countries criticized the U.S. invasion of Panama. Morris Abram, the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations in Geneva, called on the hard-line leaderships in Beijing and Havana to test their ``totalitarian regimes'' by following the recent examples of Chile and El Salvador and hold elections. Abram criticized China for saying it regretted civilian deaths during the U.S. action last December in Panama while remaining silent on the loss of hundreds of Chinese lives at the hands of the army in Tiananmen Square last June. Diplomats expressed surprise at the strength of the criticism against Beijing because of the Bush administration's recent conciliatory moves and restoration of high-level contacts with China after Washington's initial outrage at the violent suppression of pro-democracy demonstrators. In a speech to the 43-nation commission, Chinese delegate Zhan Daode said his country was ``shocked at the large-scale armed invasion and military occupation of Panama by the United States.'' ``The Chinese delegation strongly calls on the United States to put an immediate end to its acts of aggression and to withdraw unconditionally all its troops from Panama,'' Zhan told the meeting. The head of the Cuban delegation, Raul Roa, called on the U.N. body to condemn the U.S. action, saying the meeting must respond to the ``denial of fundamental rights and freedoms for the Panamanian people.'' ``This commission can not remain silent in the face of this monstrous aggression or of the specious and cynical arguments advanced to justify it,'' Roa said. Defending the U.S. intervention, Abram criticized Cuba and China for saying nothing about the human rights abuses perpetrated by deposed Panamanian leader Gen. Manuel Noriega, now in Miami facing drug trafficking charges. ``How do these representatives (of China and Cuba) explain the enormous outpouring of support for the restoration of Panama's rightful rulers,'' he said, citing an opinion poll that showed 95 percent support for the new government of Guillermo Endara. ``When did Cuba last have an opinion poll?'' he added. The United States has said Cuba should be placed on the U.N. list of countries causing special concern because of their human rights record. The delegation head at the six-week meeting in Geneva is former Cuban political prisoner Armando Valladares. The human rights meeting, which started Monday, lasts until March 9. In addition to the national representatives on the commission, the meeting is attended by observers from most other U.N. member states and about 150 private rights groups.

DOC.HEAD: Suit Filed Over Derailment, Pipeline Explosion
DOC.TEXT: Residents of a neighborhood that was devastated by a train derailment and subsequent gas pipeline explosion sued Southern Pacific railroad and the pipeline company for negligence Thursday. The suit, filed in Superior Court on behalf of 349 plaintiffs in San Bernadino, alleges ``negligence and conscious disregard of safety'' by the railroad and Calnev Pipe Line Co. in the fatal accidents, said attorney James H. Davis. The amount sought for general, compensatory and punitive damages was not specified, Davis said. Others named in the suit include the city and county of San Bernardino, the chairman of Southern Pacific and other individuals. Four people died and 30 were injured on May 12, 1989, when a freight train roared out of control down a mountain pass and derailed, throwing rail cars into the neighborhood. Brake failure and a flawed estimate of the load carried by the train contributed to the derailment, according to testimony at federal hearings held last summer. Thirteen days after the derailment, an underground fuel pipeline near the accident site exploded, killing two people and injuring 31. Calnev had examined the pipeline _ which supplies 90 percent of Las Vegas' gas _ after the derailment and declared it safe. Federal investigators have said they believe either the impact of the train accident or heavy equipment used to clean up debris from it weakened the buried pipeline, ultimately causing it to explode. However, testimony during the hearings held by the National Transportation Safety Board failed to establish a causal link between the two disasters. An NTSB report on the hearings is pending. Most of the 90 families represented by the lawsuit lived on Duffy and McDonald streets, Davis said. A total of nearly 20 homes were destroyed in the derailment and pipeline explosion, and the area remains a ``total desert,'' he said. ``Twenty years of my life I've lived there, and it all went up in smoke,'' Nancy Fricks, a former Duffy Street resident, told a news conference Thursday. ``And they don't even want to compensate us for anything.'' She claimed that Calnev has offered her $43,000 for her lost home, but she contends it was worth $87,000. Other plaintiffs in the lawsuit live on adjacent streets and alleged that their property values have dropped and they have suffered emotional distress, Davis alleged. ``We were aware there were numerous claimants damaged or injured as a result of the derailment,'' responded Southern Pacific spokesman Bob Taggart. He said 200 claims have been settled so far, and that the railroad remains anxious to reach a ``mutually satisfying settlement'' of others. ``If we're unable to do that, a jury will decide,'' he said. Calnev spokesman Richard Kline said the company hadn't seen the lawsuit yet and couldn't comment on it. But he said the company has worked to help residents recover from the accident by providing financial and medical assistance and offering to pay market value for homes destroyed in the blast. Davis also criticized Southern Pacific and Calnev for what he said was their failure to take steps to ensure against similar accidents in the future. Southern Pacific spokesman Robert Taggart called the allegation ``irresponsible and inaccurate'' and said procedures had been changed.

DOC.HEAD: Venezuelan Congress to Investigate Former president
DOC.TEXT: Congress has agreed to investigate former Venezuela President Jaime Lusinchi over charges he spent nearly $400,000 in secret funds earmarked for the state security to buy 65 jeeps, congressional sources said Thursday. The investigation will be conducted by a special committee to be appointed next week, said the sources, speaking on condition of anonymity. The decision, made late Wednesday, was supported by opposition representatives from the Social Christian and Movement Toward Socialism (MAS) parties, the sources said. Observers view it as a step forward in an drive to impeach Lusinchi. Lusinchi has been the target of a almost ceaseless campaign charging some of his aides of alleged corruption crimes during his 1984-89 administration amounting to billions of dollars. Lusinchi, 67, is in the United States and recently announced he was prepared to return to Venezuela to defend his administration. Lusinchi's former Interior Minister Jose Angel Ciliberto, who ordered the purchase of the vehicles, claims he acted under instructions of Lusinchi. Last week Ciliberto was stripped of his congressional immunity to allow a public court to begin a legal inquiry on the case. The Interior Ministry's secret funds are traditionally assigned to cover security matters and are discretionally spent by the president and the Interior Minister. The jeeps were allegedly used during the 1988 election campaign and most of them ended in the hands of state governors and members of the Social Democratic Party, according to congressmen investigating the case.

DOC.HEAD: Minister Threatens to Expel Miners by Force from Indian Lands
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of gold miners, some smashing windows and beating passers-by, rampaged in a remote northwestern city Thursday against a government order to stop prospecting on Indian land, officials said. Justice Minister Saulo Ramos, who arrived under guard at an Air Force base in Boa Vista, about 3,000 miles northwest of Rio, said the government is prepared to drive the prospectors off the Indian lands if necessary. ``We will carry out our objective, at any cost,'' said Ramos in a televised interview from the city, which is the capital of Roraima state bordering Venezuela and is the main supply point for miners. The government Thursday ordered 40,000 miners to move off the Yanomami Indian reservation they have illegally mined since 1987 in exchange for a 247,000-acre chunk of virgin Amazon rain forest bordering it. Environmentalists called that agreement a defeat for the 9,000-member Yanomami tribe, one of the world's most primitive, who lost their claim to traditional lands and have no safeguards against disease and pollution caused by miners. Early Thursday, thousands of chanting miners with stones and clubs converged on the city's main square demanding a meeting with Ramos and a new agreement allowing them to mine more Amazon territory. The miners took over the business district, town hall and airport, battering pedestrians and breaking windshields of passing cars, said police Capt. Wellington Silva dos Santos. ``The miners are very agitated and the situation is a powder keg,'' said Santos by phone from Boa Vista, a city of 43,000 people. Globo TV, the nation's largest network, showed riot police with submachine guns and clubs pushing back stone-throwing crowds of miners from airport landing strips. The miners contend the Santa Rosa cooperative, 12 miles northeast of the mineral-rich Yanomami reservation, was far less than what the government agreed to give them three weeks ago. Under the former agreement, the prospectors were to receive three tracts of National Park land totaling 1.6 million acres. ``We were tricked by the government,'' said Elton Ronehlt, owner of the Gold Amazon company and a miner representative. ``It promised us one thing and gave us another.'' Federal police still controlled some 100 clandestine jungle airstrips and were supervising the withdrawal of the miners to the new area, said Ovidio de Araujo, of the Justice Ministry's Human Rights Defense Council, in Brasilia, the capital. But, he added, ``Force will be used against those miners who do not leave the area immediately.'' Environmentalists warn the miners will spill off into Indian reservations in neighboring Amazon states and decimate other tribes. The showdown between the miners and the government over Indians rights came to a boil in early January when international pressure prompted the goverment to announce a $4 million campaign to expel the prospectors, by force if needed. There are about 220,000 native Indians left in Brazil, down from an estimated 5 million when the Portuguese first landed here in 1500.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecution Rests in Assault Trial of Alleged Mob Boss
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Contents of 12th graf, `When Featherstone...,' may offend some readers.
DOC.TEXT: The prosecution rested in the assault trial of John Gotti on Thursday after jurors heard members of a gang say on tape that they had shot a union official as a favor to the reputed mob boss. The secretly recorded tapes seemed to contradict an 11th hour defense suggestion that John F. O'Connor, former business manager of Carpenters Union Local 608, might have been shot in the buttocks by rival union members May 7, 1986. Prosecutors allege that Gotti, reputed boss of the Gambino crime family, commissioned the Irish-American gang, called the Westies, to shoot O'Connor because the union official led the trashing of a mob-affiliated restaurant being constructed with non-union labor. Gotti, 49, and Anthony Guerrieri, 60, an alleged Gambino soldier, are on trial in state court on charges of assault and conspiracy in the non-fatal shooting. The prosecution rested after the jury heard the tapes. Bruce Cutler, Gotti's lawyer, said the defense would decide Thursday night whether to call character witnesses and a tape recording expert. The tapes were recorded at Rikers Island jail during a visit by Westies member Kevin Kelly and his friend, Larry Palermo, to Francis ``Mickey'' Featherstone, a former Westies leader. Transcripts of the tape, the accuracy of which are in dispute, show that Featherstone was the first to mention O'Connor's shooting. Kelly and Palermo were unaware Featherstone was an informer and that a microphone was hidden behind a picture on the wall near them. Featherstone says, ``I knew you guys did it.'' Kelly refers to Westies member Joe Schlereth, identified as the gunman in trial testimony by Westies informer James McElroy. ``I recommended Joe the Lather,'' Kelly tells Featherstone. ``Joe Schlereth. You know Joe.'' At another point, Kelly says, ``The guy was there. And he popped him.'' When Featherstone asks who requested the shooting, Kelly replies it was done ``for the greaseballs.'' He says the Westies volunteered their services to Gotti at the funeral of Gambino family underboss Frank DeCicco. A principal defense tactic has been to challenge the quality of the tapes and the integrity of the transcripts. Gerald Shargel, Guerrieri's attorney, has introduced transcripts used in a federal case and made from the same tapes as those heard by the Gotti jury. The state and federal transcripts each contain things that aren't found in the other. Acting Justice Edward McLaughlin told jurors that what they hear on the tapes and how they interpret it is what counts. He said he was unsure he would allow them to take the transcripts into the jury room during deliberations. McLaughlin told the jurors they would hear closing arguments Monday and begin deliberations Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Aide Sees Mideast Meeting This Month
DOC.TEXT: A senior aide to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Thursday he believes a meeting of U.S., Egyptian and Israeli foreign ministers will take place this month to pave the way for Israeli-Palestinian talks. Yossi Ban-Aharon, Shamir's office director, said Israel had not received a U.S. invitation for such a meeting. He said it was not likely to take place before next Wednesday's showdown in the right-wing Likud bloc between Shamir and hawkish party rivals opposed to peace concessions. ``Personally, realistically, I think it will not happen before that. I think it will take place shortly afterward, during this month. The timing is not important,'' Ben-Aharon said on Israel Television. Israeli newspapers earlier Thursday suggested that Foreign Minister Moshe Arens rebuffed U.S. efforts to schedule a meeting within the next week. Israeli sources, speaking on the condition of anonymity, confirmed that U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III called Arens Wednesday and raised the subject. But he proposed no date, they said, only the possibilities of convening such a meeting, and Arens did not reject the idea of a meeting in the near future. Baker, Arens and Egyptian Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid would attend. The Maariv daily said Baker said Baker made the call after the Palestine Liberation Organization reportedly agreed to U.S. compromise proposals concerning Palestinian negotiators. The liberal daily Haaretz quoted political sources in Jerusalem as saying that Baker considers the meeting to be the ``moment of truth'' and wants to come out of it with a date for the start of Palestinian-Israeli talks in Cairo. He will reject any attempt by Arens to ask for additional U.S. assurances concerning the Palestinian-Israeli talks, Haaretz quoted the sources as saying. Israel has asked for iron-clad U.S. guarantees that the PLO be kept out peace talks, but Washington only promised that the PLO would not participate in negotiations ``at this stage.'' Israel calls the PLO a terrorist organization and refuses to negotiate with it.

DOC.HEAD: HUD Suspends Major Developer; Cites Investigation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 6-9 bgng: ``Meanwhile, The,'' with report of unreported contribtuion to Jackson's 1988 presidential campaign.
DOC.TEXT: One of the nation's largest subsidized housing landlords has been suspended from future government work because of a fraud investigation, the Department of Housing and Urban Development said Thursday. HUD, in a letter to one of the company's affiliates, said the government ``has information indicating irregularities of a serious nature'' and that the company and its affiliates were being investigated. The more than 40 affiliated companies are led by Associated Financial Corp. of California and together control nearly 50,000 units of federally assisted housing. AFC's president is A. Bruce Rozet, a prominent Democratic fund-raiser who in 1988 was a Jesse Jackson delegate to the Democratic National Convention. Rozet, in a statement and additional comments issued through a spokesman, called HUD's action ``pure harassment for political reasons'' that ultimately would harm the low-income families the agency is supposed to serve. He denied any wrongdoing and vowed to fight the suspension and accused HUD of taking the action to avoid a hearing scheduled for next week on lesser sanctions against an AFC affiliate. Meanwhile, The Washington Post said in Friday editions that a hotel partly owned by Rozet wrote off a $30,000 debt owed by Jackson's 1988 presidential campaign. Under federal election law, the campaign would have to report the sum either as an outstanding debt or as a contribution. In this case such a contribution would be illegal because it comes from a corporation. Individual contributions are limited by law to $1,000 per election per candidate. Jackson's campaign reports to the Federal Election Commission made no mention of the bill owed to the Hollywood Roosevelt Hotel in Los Angeles, and James Hewitt, a lawyer for the campaign, told the newspaper that the debt should have been listed. The newspaper reported that the debt was written off after the hotel was able to collect just $45,000 of an overall debt of $75,000 and cited an internal memorandum saying the unpaid balance was a ``gift'' from Rozet. HUD General Counsel Francis Keating said AFC and its affiliates were being investigated by the department's inspector general. Law enforcement sources also said the U.S. attorney's office in Los Angeles was investigating the companies. Those sources, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said Charles Bazarian, a man Rozet used as a property scout who later was convicted of skimming money a from HUD-assisted project, was cooperating with investigators. But the sources declined to discuss the substance of the probe, and the Los Angeles prosecutor handling it, Lee Weidman, declined comment. Rozet and AFC have had a number of run-ins with HUD over the past decade, including several in the last year, and Rozet has said first-year HUD Secretary Jack Kemp has allowed bureaucrats with old grudges against the company to dictate HUD policy toward AFC. Kemp visited one AFC property shortly after taking office last year and termed conditions there ``scandalous.'' Kemp's top deputy also has called Rozet and his companies ``slumlords.'' But community leaders in several areas with AFC properties have defended the company, and Rozet often is called on by Congress as an expert on housing policy. One of Rozet's biggest defenders in Congress is Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., for whom Rozet has been a major fund-raiser. HUD announced the suspension in a letter to an AFC affiliate, Housing Resources Management Inc., which is controlled by Rozet partner Deane E. Ross. Also affected by the suspension are AFC and more that 40 related development and investment companies involved in the purchase and management of government-assisted housing and the syndication of tax credits developers of such projects receive from the government. AFC, speaking on behalf of its affiliate, denied that Housing Resources Management was involved in any improper activities. Even if those allegations were true, AFC said a suspension was unwarranted because the allegations involved about $35,000. AFC's properties generate $80 million a year in rents, the company said. The suspension will have no impact on existing properties owned and managed by AFC and its affiliates but will block the company indefinitely from trying to buy or manage any additional HUD-assisted properties or from seeking any new government work. HUD's letter was sent to Ross on Friday and released by HUD officials Thursday. In addition to the investigation, HUD said it had ``adequate evidence'' that Housing Resources Management was involved in ``irregularities'' involving alleged misuse of security deposits and reserve funds at apartment complexes it managed in New Orleans, Oklahoma and Washington, D.C. HUD also alleged that the company was involved in requesting rental subsidies for vacant units and submitting false repair invoices at two Oklahoma properties. Among the allegations HUD made in the letter was that HRM misused security deposit accounts at Southgate Apartments in Watonga, Okla. That is the same project involved in the HUD-related case against Bazarian. Bazarian is serving a sentence on an unrelated bank fraud conviction and as part of a plea agreement admitted skimming government funds from Southgate. Bazarian is scheduled to be sentenced in that case next week.

DOC.HEAD: Former Guam Governor Wraps Self In Flag, Commits Suicide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf, `Bordallo, a ...' to CORRECT years of his first term to 1974-78, sted 1976-80.
DOC.TEXT: Hours before he was to leave the island to begin a prison term, a former two-term governor of Guam chained himself to a public statue, wrapped himself in Guam's flag and fatally shot himself in the head. Found at the base of the statue were four handwritten placards, one of which said, ``I regret I only have one life to give for my island,'' according to police Lt. Phil Dennis. Former Gov. Ricardo ``Ricky'' Bordallo, 62, shot himself Wednesday less than four hours before he was to fly to Los Angeles, where he was to visit his daughter before reporting to the federal correctional facility at Boron, Calif., to begin a four-year prison term for witness tampering and obstruction. ``I choose death before dishonor,'' Bordallo wrote on another placard. ``My loving wife ... has my message which she will impart to the people of Guam in due time.'' An aide to his wife, territorial Sen. Madeleine Bordallo, said the senator had not found such a message. Reporters who attended a farewell party for Bordallo earlier in the day said he had appeared to be in good spirits. ``I didn't think this would happen,'' Congressional Del. Ben Blaz said from Washington. ``Ricky Bordallo always seemed to bounce back from his many adversities.'' At a busy downtown intersection, Bordallo shot himself with a .38-caliber pistol while chained to the statue of Chief Quipuha, the first chief in Guam to adopt Christianity, Dennis said. He died a short time later of massive brain damage, according to a spokesman at the Guam Naval Hospital. Mrs. Bordallo was reportedly with him when he died. Territorial flags were lowered to half-staff, and Gov. Joseph Ada declared a state of mourning until after Bordallo's funeral, which is yet to be scheduled. Bordallo told the Pacific Daily News in an interview last Friday that he was facing his prison term with ``complete serenity.'' ``When a man is innocent, his conscience is clear, and he is at peace with himself,'' Bordallo said. But he also said: ``My own instincts make me believe that I will not be coming back from Boron alive. I'm not dwelling on how it will happen. I will be in the hands of people who are masters of intrigue.'' Bordallo was found guilty in February 1987 of getting engineer Johnny Carpio to lie to federal officials about a $60,000 political contribution from a group of Japanese businessmen. During his trial, Bordallo admitted accepting money from the businessmen, but contended the money was a campaign contribution. Carpio was convicted of extortion and bribery and was placed on five years' probation. Bordallo, a Democrat, served as governor from 1974 to 1978, and again from 1982 to 1986, when he was defeated by Republican Ada.

DOC.HEAD: CNN Stands By Report on Gorbachev, But Turner Says It Could Be Rumor
With AM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: CNN stands by the newsman who reported Mikhail Gorbachev was considering resigning as head of the Soviet Communist Party, a network executive said Wednesday, but CNN chief Ted Turner said the report was based on rumor. Other news organizations carried Tuesday's report, attributing it to CNN, but Turner told an Atlanta Press Club luncheon Wednesday it was no ``scoop.'' ``How can you scoop a rumor?'' he said. ``If rumors become scoops, then every media will have one.'' CNN Moscow correspondent Steve Hurst quoted a ``a well-informed and usually reliable Communist Party source'' as saying that Gorbachev was thinking of stepping down as party general secretary, but remaining president of the Soviet Union. Gorbachev on Wednesday denied the report. ``All this is groundless,'' he replied to a question about the report from reporters covering his meeting with Brazilian President-elect Fernando Collor de Mello. ``It is in someone's interest to propagate such things.'' CNN on Wednesday continued reporting that Gorbachev had thought about resigning, but added that Hurst, a 12-year Moscow veteran, said his initial information ``could be a trial balloon ... or just a rumor by people opposed to Gorbachev rule.'' Ed Turner, executive vice president of news gathering for CNN, said the network was not backing off the story but was continuing to report developments. ``We believed in Hurst's source because I have great confidence and faith in him,'' said Ed Turner, who is no relation to Ted Turner. ``You go with what you believe is the story. He knows when he thinks he has a solid story. All you can do is trust your people.''

DOC.HEAD: Cardinal Says Clergyman Misquoted, Never Condemned Governor to Hell
DOC.TEXT: Cardinal John J. O'Connor said Wednesday that a bishop never condemned Gov. Mario Cuomo to hell but instead told him his abortion beliefs were contributing to the ``loss of his soul.'' Auxiliary Bishop Austin Vaughan, 62, was quoted by news media last week as saying from the Albany County Jail in Albany that Cuomo was ``in danger of going to hell if he dies tonight.'' Vaughan, pastor of St. Patrick's Church in Newburgh, was serving a 15-day jail sentence for blocking the entrance to a Planned Parenthood clinic during an anti-abortion protest in Albany last March. Cuomo, considered a potential 1992 presidential candidate, has said he and his wife accept the Roman Catholic Church's teaching on abortion in their private life, but that abortion is a matter of a woman's own conscience. He budgets about $15 million a year in state funds to pay for abortions for poor women. O'Connor had refused to comment on the matter until he could speak to Vaughan. In a column published Wednesday in the Catholic New York newspaper, the cardinal said Vaughan assured him he had been misunderstood. ``What the bishop told me he actually said was that the governor is `quite possibly contributing to the loss of his soul.' To me that sounds significantly different from `cursing' or `condemning' the governor to hell,'' O'Connor said. The cardinal said Vaughan said he was ``well aware that he has no power whatsoever to condemn anyone to hell.'' ``He would agree with the governor completely, that such an unpleasant task is exclusively the prerogative of a much higher and wiser power,'' he said. Cuomo responded to O'Connor's column with a terse, two-sentence statement: ``The Cardinal says the Bishop was misquoted. I'm glad.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit by Ex-prosecutor in `Twilight Zone' Movie Case is Reinstated
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court on Wednesday reinstated a suit by a former Los Angeles prosecutor who claimed he was smeared after objecting to tactics in the ``Twilight Zone'' manslaughter case. Gary Kesselman, who was removed as prosecutor in the case against film director John Landis, sued Los Angeles Deputy District Attorney Lea D'Agostino, several supervisors and District Attorney Ira Reiner for defamation, wrongful firing and civil rights violations over disputes arising from the case. U.S. District Judge Dickran Tevrizian had dismissed the suit on the grounds that the prosecutors were legally immune from suit, even if Kesselman could prove all of his allegations. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals disagreed Wednesday, returning the case to Tevrizian for more pretrial proceedings. Landis and his co-defendants were acquitted in 1987 of involuntary manslaughter in the deaths of actor Vic Morrow and two children on the ``Twilight Zone'' movie set in July 1982. Kesselman, who was first assigned to prosecute the case, said he was removed before the trial at his own request, but a supervisor said he was removed for cause. His suit involved testimony by a prosecution witness, Donna Schuman, that she had disclosed certain information to Kesselman, who had replied that he had planned to conceal it and spring it on the defense as a surprise. Kesselman denied the testimony and said she had never given her the information. After that, he said, Ms. D'Agostino and supervisors in the office began a campaign to harass and discredit him. Kesselman, now a private lawyer, also contended he was fired from the office in retaliation for filing the suit. The county denied it. His dismissal came shortly after his arrest in 1987 for investigation of lewd conduct. That case ended in a no-contest plea to disturbing the peace. Gregory Petersen, a lawyer for Kesselman, said he expected to prove that the prosecutor was fired for ``refusing to go along with the program'' of the office's approach to the case. John Collins, a lawyer for the county and the prosecutors whom Kesselman sued, said he hoped the court would find them immune from suit for all matters related to presentation of evidence in the case.

DOC.HEAD: Arafat, Soviet Diplomat Discuss Jewish Emigration
DOC.TEXT: A top Soviet diplomat told the PLO leadership Wednesday that Moscow shares its concerns over possible settlement of Soviet Jews in the Israeli-occupied lands. Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Gennadi Tarassov expressed his views to the PLO's executive committee, Soviet diplomatic sources in the Tunisian capital said. The committee has been meeting since Tuesday on the question of Soviet Jewish emigration. Tarassov later visited privately with PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat and reiterated his country's support for an independent Palestinian state, Palestinian sources said. The Soviet official also was to meet with Chedli Klibi, secretary general of the Arab League, who said Monday that Soviet Jews were being forced to emigrate to Israel against their will. Neither Soviet nor Palestinian sources said whether Tarassov made any commitment to control the departure of Soviet Jews for Israel. The Soviet Union has repeatedly expressed its opposition to Jewish settlement in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, where Palestinian residents have waged a two-year uprising against Israeli rule. Israeli officials have predicted 300,000 Soviet Jews will arrive in Israeli in the next three years under relaxed Soviet emigration rules. Arafat has called on the Soviet Union to curtail the migration, while Iraqi President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has accused the United States of closing its doors to Soviet Jews to force the emigrants to settle in Israel. The United States has a global annual immigration ceiling of 270,000. Arafat and other Arab leaders fear that expanded settlement of Soviet and other Jews in the territories will make a negotiated peace settlement with Israel more difficult, perhaps impossible. Presently about 70,000 Jews live in more that 120 settlements in the West Bank and Gaza. About 12,000 Soviet Jews arrived in Israel last year but Israeli officials expect the annual number to soar to more than 100,000 in the next few years. Israel captured the territories in the 1967 Middle East war. The PLO hopes to establish an independent state in the territories, whose populations are overwhelmingly Arab.

President Bush, winning bipartisan acclaim in Congress, is proposing further deep cuts in U.S. and Soviet troop strength in Europe and declaring ``that time has come'' to swiftly conclude agreements limiting conventional, strategic and chemical weapons. ``Today, with communism crumbling, our aim must be to ensure democracy's advance,'' the president said Wednesday night in a State of the Union speech that blended his new troop withdrawal proposal with a pledge to withdraw the remainder of the U.S. invasion force from Panama by the end of the month. In a surprise overture, Bush proposed cutting military manpower in Europe to 195,000 troops on each side, down from the 275,000 figure that was the U.S. bargaining position at conventional force negotiations in Vienna. The president said he called Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev earlier in the day to inform him of the offer, which already had been endorsed by NATO allies. The move, Bush said, was a response to ``the revolution of '89'' in which he said the United States ``stands at the center of a widening circle of freedom.''

The indictment in the 1985 torture-slaying of a U.S. drug agent expanded to include two of the highest police officers in the previous Mexican administration and two powerful drug dealers. They were among six new names in a 19-person indictment Wednesday that updates charges related to the slaying of Enrique Camarena Salazar and his Mexican pilot, and the killings of two U.S. citizens in Guadalajara, Mexico. Manuel Ibarra Herrera, former head of Mexico's Federal Judicial Police, roughly equivalent to the FBI; and Miguel Aldana Ibarra, who headed the Mexican branch of Interpol, the international police agency, were charged with participating in a cover-up to protect drug smugglers in Mexico. Both were officials in the administratin of President Miguel de la Madrid, who completed his term in office in 1988. They were among 15 people named in the indictment who are not in U.S. custody.

President Bush's nominee to head the nation's troubled atomic weapons complex is faltering amid a newly disclosed investigation of an allegation that he lied to Congress. The Senate Armed Services Committee delayed indefinitely Wednesday's scheduled vote on the nomination of Victor Stello Jr., a former top nuclear power regulator, to become assistant secretary of energy for defense programs. Committee Chairman Sam Nunn, D-Ga., and ranking Republican John Warner of Virginia recommended the delay after the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's inspector general told them his office is investigating Stello. ``We did not know how serious the allegations were regarding Mr. Stello,'' Nunn told reporters after a closed committee meeting Wednesday. ``The committee voted not to come to a conclusion or vote ... until such time that we have at least an oral report from the IG (inspector general).''

Mixing the golden arches with the hammer and sickle may be a better combination than two all beef patties, special sauce, lettuce, cheese, pickles and onions on a sesame seed bun. McDonald's in Moscow is more than just the opening of another hamburger stand. It's West meeting East, capitalism flourishing in the heart of communism, an American icon dazzling ruble-paying Soviet masses. ``It represents a common ground. Soviets now have something that's quintessentially American,'' said Harriet Kuhr of the Friendship Force of Atlanta, which pioneered exchanges betweens U.S. and Soviet citizens. ``In a way, it's one of our imperialistic beliefs that everybody wants to be American but they haven't been allowed to,'' Kuhr said. ``That's not necessarily true, but it makes us feel good. It's like, `Wow, McDonald's. What's next? Maybe they'll start building Fords.' ''

For Release Monday PMs Feb. 5 or Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Dead Sea Was an Active Trade Route as Far Back as 2,300 Years
DOC.TEXT: Researchers say the Dead Sea was a lively commercial center as far back as 2,300 years ago, not anywhere near like it is today with few boats and only sparse settlement along the shores. The research may also throw new light on the Essenes who lived in the area, casting doubt on the accepted theory that they were isolated hermits. Arieh Nissenbaum, a geo-chemist, said three stone anchors and mooring ropes found recently in the Dead Sea were the ``first datable evidence'' to support the theory that the Dead Sea was an active place for commerce in the 4th century B.C. He said Carbon 14 testing at the Weizmann Institute of Science in Rehovot on well-preserved fiber rope fragments left open the possibilty that the anchors were from ships sunk in the first Middle East oil war. ``The Dead Sea was not so dead. This is a misleading name given to the lake by the British,'' said Gideon Hadas, an Antiquities Authority archaeologist. According to ancient historians, a huge naval battle was fought in 312 B.C. when Antigonus, the Seleucid ruler of Syria, tried to seize control of the trade in asphalt, which naturally forms from evaporating petroleum. He was repelled by the superior archery of the Nabateans of southern Jordan who were backed by Egypt. Although there was uncertainty about the date because of a 100-year margin of error in dating, Nissenbaum said it is possible that ``the anchors are mute witnesses to that battle.'' Hadas found the 220-pound anchors along the western shore of the lake, which at 1,292 feet below sea level is the lowest spot on earth. He said the ropes were well preserved because of the high salt content of the water and suggested other remains, even wooden boats, might also be nestling in the seabed. Asphalt, which came to the surface in large blocks from fissures in the seabed, was the prize of ancient traders. Nissenbaum said it was used as mortar for buildings, an embalming agent in the Egyptians mummification process, a medicine to treat skin wounds and as a bug-killer. In a new study of Dead Sea shipping, Nissenbaum said that up to the end of the Crusader era there was active boat traffic on the lake. Ships ferried wheat and corn grown in southern Jordan along the 50-mile length of the salt sea to the northern end where roads led to Jericho and Jerusalem. A large Israelite farming community grew at Ein Gedi on the lake shore and Hasmonean kings built a series of fortresses in the area. The Dead Sea region, surrounded by barren mountains and rocky desert, fell into economic decline after the Crusader period. Today the only boats on the lake are a few Israeli military patrol craft. Just a few small settlements occupy its shores, and foreign visitors come mostly to the health spas that promote the curative powers, especially for those afflicted with skin diseases, of the Dead Sea waters and mineral-rich mud. Robert Eisenman, chairman of the religious studies department at California State University in Long Beach, suggests today's image of the Dead Sea as a lifeless region may be the basis of a misleading view of the Essenes, keepers of the Dead Sea scrolls. Traditional theories about the sect portrays them as a small isolated community of hermits who sought refuge in a remote wilderness, but he suggests this may not have been the case. His 15-member surveying and mapping expedition recently completed a study of the Qumran caves at the northern end of the Dead Sea. It was there that the scrolls dating to the second century B.C. were discovered in 1947. Eisenman said his survey explored 282 desert caves along a 13-mile stretch of coast and found pottery as well as other evidence of man living in 62 of them. He said a 1952 survey found only 230 caves in the area and suggested man could live in only 17. Eisenman added that his findings indicated there could be more scroll-bearing caves in the area and that many more had been inhabitated that originally suggested. ``There was a lot of habitation,'' he said, pointing to pottery shards in front of a large cave half-way up the side of a cliff of brittle rock shale. ``This means it was not isolated like a lot of people think. The idea of hermetic Essenes contemplating their navels in isolation is rather peculiar.''

DOC.HEAD: He's Got a Strange Beat for Network Television: Jazz
DOC.TEXT: Early in its life, ``CBS News Sunday Morning'' aired a profile of jazz pianist and educator Billy Taylor, which led to a job that made him somewhat of an anomaly in today's network television. ``Sunday Morning'' hired him to regularly chronicle other jazzfolk and singers, and he pretty much had the field to himself until last year, when NBC's ``Sunday Today'' hired Jonathan Schwartz for reports that include jazz. This Sunday, Taylor starts his eighth year on CBS' Sunday program with a report on Marcus Roberts, the pianist for jazz and classical trumpeter Wynton Marsalis. Like more than a few of the people the two-time Emmy winner has interviewed, Roberts may not be well-known to viewers. ``But it's my job to say, `Well, look, here's a guy who's interesting' _ and they might go and check him out,'' Taylor said. Taylor, whose better-known subjects have included Ella Fitzgerald, Quincy Jones, Maynard Ferguson and Max Roach, was well-known in musical circles but also no stranger to broadcasting when hired by CBS. In 1958, he was musical director on NBC's ``The Subject Is Jazz'' series (the band included a pretty good trumpet man name of Doc Severinson). Taylor's other air credits: a jazz history of sorts on ``Captain Kangaroo''; two National Public Radio series, ``Taylor Made Piano'' and ``Jazz Alive''; musical director on the long-ago ``The David Frost Show''; a cable series several years ago, ``Jazz Counterpoint''; and several PBS specials. He stays busy. In addition to performing and composing, he also lectures at colleges and still oversees New York's Jazzmobile program, which he founded 25 years ago to bring jazz to those who perhaps can't afford to pay to hear it live. He also has recorded extensively, including an album last year with fellow pianist Ramsey Lewis. That Taylor landed what has proved to be his longest-running tour in television is due, he says, to Shad Northshield and Bud Lamoreaux, the first executive producer and a senior producer of CBS' Sunday show, respectively. After his appearance on the program, he recalls, ``They said, `Would you be interested in doing something along those lines with other people for us?''' Oddly enough, Northshield hadn't specifically been looking for a jazz specialist. The program had a classical music critic and ``it occurred to me that we should have somebody who does contemporary music,'' he says. ``But we weren't specific about the kind of music. Then someone did the piece on him, and he was terrific.'' Taylor credits the two producers and the broadcast's anchor, Charles Kuralt, with providing the opportunity for features on jazz, a subject rarely seen or heard on the major networks these days. Why so? ``Well, most people who produce those kinds of shows are not as aware as Bud and Shad,'' Taylor says. But it also helped that the folksy Kuralt knew the world of jazz, he adds. ``He plays my straight man,'' Taylor says, ``but to be a good straight man, you really have to know what the answer is.'' Taylor estimates he averages 14 to 15 jazz features a year on the CBS program. One, he chuckles, was about NBC's Schwartz, the son of a famous Hollywood composer and a radio cult figure here; in his WNEW-AM Sunday show, Schwartz learnedly discusses and airs the work of such singers as Frank Sinatra, Tony Bennett, Linda Ronstadt and Maureen McGovern. Most of those Taylor interviews consider him a colleague, he says, and that helps. But he also has faced the interviewer's classic nightmare _ a subject who is extremely shy, withdrawn and generally no fun at all. Those can be trying times, he concedes: ``You elaborately set up a question and think you're going to get a good answer. And then he just says, `Yeah.''' __ Elsewhere in television... ANOTHER REASON TO CONTINUE LIVING: Boxing champ Mike Tyson, in his second prime-time network appearance since Barbara Walters interviewed him, will be a referee in the Feb. 23 telecast of what you might call NBC's version of ``Great Performances'' _ a wrestling match between Hulk Hogan and ``Macho King'' Randy Savage. NBC calls the tiff ``The Main Event.'' NBC, noting that this is its third such gripping event in two years, quotes Tyson as saying he fears neither Hulk nor Macho Man, and that, in fact, ``There aren't two men on the planet that I can't handle.''

DOC.HEAD: Cartoonists Become Hong Kong's Conscience
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Cartoonists have become the conscience of Hong Kong as they acidly etch the desperation felt by a people destined to live under the flag of Communist China in seven years. With politicians bickering and editorial writers anxious not to irritate the leaders in Beijing, comic strips have become one of the few platforms where Hong Kong's fears are expressed with often brutal clarity. Just after the crackdown June 4 in Beijing on the democracy movement, cartoonist Juan Tze drew Premier Li Peng in a bathtub of blood. ``Is it hot enough?'' asked a soldier holding a bucket of steaming ``people's blood.'' After Sir Geoffrey Howe, then the British foreign secretary, told Hong Kong that Britain could not guarantee the territory's future, Larry Feign, an American expatriate, summed up the feelings of many. ``I don't know who to hate more, Deng Xiaoping or Margaret Thatcher,'' says one of his comic strip characters. After 149 years of British rule, Hong Kong returns to China in 1997. Although Beijing has promised to retain the territory's free-wheeling economic and social system for 50 years, many of Hong Kong's 5.7 million people lost faith in that promise after the June 4 crackdown. Many also have little confidence in faction-ridden local politicians, says Joseph Y.S. Cheng, a leading educator and writer in the colony. Newspapers also practice self-censorship in their criticism of Beijing, he said. ``People look to comic strips as an outlet for their frustrations,'' Cheng said. ``Their popularity demonstrates that we have a solid groundswell of anti-communist, anti-China feeling, especially after June 4.'' Adds Feign: ``Cartoons appeal to the Chinese because you can get your meaning across indirectly.'' Cheng said that only in the last few years have comic strips become an important political outlet in Hong Kong. A recent exhibition of cartoons at the Hong Kong Arts Centre drew 40,000 people over several weeks. Feign and Juan are perhaps the two best known cartoonists in the colony. Frenetic and balding, Feign, 34, is author of a comic strip for the English-language South China Morning Post called ``The World of Lily Wong.'' For the five years since he moved to Hong Kong from Orange County in California with his Chinese wife, Feign has charted the lives of Lily, a smart, sexy Hong Kong woman, and Stuart Wright, a bumbling but good-hearted American. Stuart wants to marry Lily and give her the passport she covets but Lily isn't in love and so far has refused him. Through their relationship, Feign explores the often blatant racism inflicted on Chinese by Westerners. He also pokes fun at the ways Chinese view Westerners, known as ``devils'' in Cantonese. A tall man, with the comportment of a Mandarin official in old China's imperial court, Juan is more self-consciously political than Feign. He grew up during Hong Kong's most turbulent times and remembers watching the bloody anti-British riots in 1967 from a rickety balcony on his tenement home. He began drawing comics as an art student at the Chinese University of Hong Kong in the 1970s. He took a page from early 20th century Chinese history, during which cartoons were a popular form of political agitation, and decided to use comics to fight for Hong Kong's common man. He went to work at the Chinese-language Ming Pao. ``My generation is different from my parents','' said Juan, now 33. ``They came from China and are concerned with basic things like food and money. We are searching for other things, from the spirit.'' When China recently announced its opposition to a British plan to give passports to key Hong Kong professionals and officials, Juan drew a man sitting on his bed, his birth certificate, identity card and passport scattered beneath him. ``Who am I? Who am I?'' the man screamed as his wife snored beside him. ``We have an identity crisis in Hong Kong,'' Juan said. ``London and Beijing are deciding our fate and we can't influence them. I wanted to describe our feeling of hopelessness.'' Following the crackdown in Beijing, Juan drew Chinese Premier Li Peng explaining why tanks were used to put down the rebellion. ``We ran out of cars,'' Li tells a visitor. Another strip shows an Englishman offering Hong Kong on a fork into the drooling mouth of a corrupt Chinese cadre. ``Be a brave Chinaman,'' the Englishman says. Juan, who hopes to stay in Hong Kong after 1997, has recently published a book of his work, ``Black Goods.'' ``I guess the Chinese might call me a counterrevolutionary,'' he said with a wry smile. ``I'm just helping them gather proof.'' If Juan expresses the desperation of Hong Kong, Feign captures the absurdity of its life. Living on the cusp of two worlds _ Hong Kong Chinese and Western expatriate _ Feign has a unique vantage point. ``In the beginning, my position gave me a chance to pull off a lot of good gags,'' said Feign. ``But now as things get serious I find it harder to draw. It's becoming a tragedy.''

DOC.HEAD: Guerrilla Sabotage Putting Peru's Lights Out
DOC.TEXT: Almost every night, in a deserted field or on a mountainside, a charge of dynamite goes off and Peruvians' lights go out. The sabotage of high-tension pylons by leftist guerrillas who call themselves, ironically, the Shining Path is plunging Peruvians into darkness and cutting dangerously into the nation's industrial output. Power rationing has become a daily headache for millions of people in Lima and other major cities that depend on hydroelectric power that is brought over the Andes. Lima has a new sound _ the almost constant hum of thousands of portable gasoline generators. Its streets are in almost constant gridlock because traffic lights are out. Restaurants and housewives complain of food spoiling because refrigerators aren't working. Landlords are slashing rents for the upper floors of highrise apartment buildings to entice renters worried about climbing the stairs when elevators stop. Since July 28, 1980, when the first high-tension pylon was blown up in the mountains near Ayacucho, 235 miles southeast of Lima _ as President Fernando Belaunde Terry was giving his state-of-the-union address _ 1,205 towers have fallen, according to the state power company Electroperu. A total of 335 were felled last year alone and more than 100 have been toppled since municipal elections in November, when the rebels blew up 80 in one week in an effort _ largely unsuccessful, as it turned out _ to disrupt the voting. The rainy season that lasts from January to May in the highlands is making it difficult for repair crews to reach toppled towers, and Electroperu says it does not know how long power rationing, which began in mid-November, will continue. ``The whole system is in a shambles,'' said Jose Dibos of the National Industrial Society. ``We are running into an almost continuous situation where power outages have to be accepted as a way of life.'' The Shining Path took up arms in 1980 to bring down Peru's elected government and install a peasant-worker state patterned on the ideas of Mao Tse-tung of China. The government says more than 17,500 people have died in the violence and economic costs have surpassed $15 billion. Damage to the electrical system has cost the country more than $600 million, including repairs and lost electrical output, according to Electroperu. The company says it costs about $20,000 to replace a tower. The Industrial Society's Dibos said the electric company has been able to maintain a ``precarious balance'' only because industries are operating at 50 percent of capacity due to the country's economic problems, which included 2,775 percent inflation last year and a 12 percent drop in the gross domestic product. But he said the damaged power grid is a ``time bomb'' that is costing industry millions of dollars in lost production and ruined materials and equipment. One of the hardest hit areas is the glass industry, whose ovens need a continous supply of power to allow for the slow heating and cooling required to make glass. The Industrial Society says glass production has dropped by half. ``It's almost impossible for an industrial user to predict when he is going to get power and for how long,'' Dibos said. Most of the power supplied to Lima, where a third of Peru's 22 million people live, comes from Electroperu's hydroelectric dam on the Mantaro River in a mountain valley 165 miles east of Lima. Three interconnected lines carry power over the Andes to the coast, each passing through guerrilla country. One of the three has been down since 1987, when Electroperu withdrew its repair crews after guerrillas burned 10 company trucks and threatened to kill workers if they returned. An Electroperu spokesman, Jose Acevedo, said repair crews on the other two lines know they are being watched. ``They watch them from a distance, and as soon as they finish raising a tower, the terrorists come in and blow up another one,'' he said. Acevedo said one tower was felled six times before the army strung barbed wire and planted land mines around it.

DOC.HEAD: Underpinnings of U.S. Military Jolted by Breakup of Soviet Empire
DOC.TEXT: The cracking of the communist East bloc has opened a path to profound change in U.S. defenses, and the fallout for military chiefs and soldiers, weapons makers, political leaders and taxpayers is just coming into view. ``A revolution in military affairs could be in the making,'' says William Kaufmann of the Brookings Institution think tank and a frequent consultant to the Pentagon. The precise features of this transformation are fuzzy but the direction is clear: smaller Pentagon budgets, fewer troops and a shrinking pipeline of new weapons. The most frequently asked questions now are how radically will the military be reshaped, and will Congress switch defense dollars to social programs such as housing and education that were squeezed during the Reagan administration's military buildup? Military planners already are rethinking traditional defense strategies _ while trying to hold together the North Atlantic alliance _ since few now believe the fractured Warsaw Pact armies pose a major threat to Western security. The glue that has kept NATO together for 40 years is fear of a surprise Soviet invasion of Western Europe. With those fears now fading, will NATO come unstuck? While even the Pentagon's biggest supporters in Congress see more relaxed East-West relations, some caution against assuming that democratic reforms and moves toward free-market economies in Eastern Europe would last if Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was ousted. ``A return to past Soviet behavior is the biggest risk we must consider in reordering our priorities and restructuring our own defenses,'' Sen. John Warner of Virginia, the ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee, said recently. Even so, the new world order means running a new-look U.S. military on less money _ perhaps a lot less. President Bush proposed to Congress a slight trimming of defense spending, to $292 billion, for the budget year starting Oct. 1. Pressures are great on Capitol Hill to wield an even heavier ax. ``The reality is that we must plan on our defense budget going down several percentage points every year for the foreseeable future,'' says Gen. Colin L. Powell, the top U.S. military officer as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Kaufmann says military spending by 1999 should be cut to half today's level. The new austerity, in turn, translates to tougher times for military contractors. The arms industry boomed during the Reagan administration and now employs one in five of the nation's manufacturing workers and one-third of scientists and engineers. The boom may not bust, but some industry workers and their communities already see reason to worry about layoffs and pay cuts. ``There can be a dark side'' to the outbreak of peace, Ohio Gov. Richard Celeste said at a special conference of small- and medium-size military contractors Jan. 24. The jobs of about 200,000 Ohio residents depend on the defense industry. Other states, including California, Virginia, Washington, Maryland and Missouri, are even more closely linked to the health of military contractors. The bright side, in the view of many economists and defense analysts, is that the expected Pentagon savings during the 1990s could be converted to a ``peace dividend'' _ money to combat homelessness, build new schools, repair old roads and bridges, intensify medical research, combat drug abuse or cut taxes. The Bush administration, however, sees two holes in the ``peace dividend'' theory. First, it says, no major savings should be expected until new arms control deals are struck and the pro-democracy movement in Eastern Europe gains a firmer footing. Secondly, huge bills for correcting mistakes of the past, such as untold levels of contamination from nuclear weapons plants, will come due in the 1990s. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, presenting details of the proposed 1991 budget, said: ``The peace dividend is peace,'' meaning the huge military investments of the past have bought a more secure international order, but that drastically reducing future military spending could undermine that security. That line of thinking, and Bush's cautious nature, will surely face a severe test in the Democrat-controlled Congress, where debate over spending priorities in light of a retreating Soviet military menace already is under way. Some of the biggest squabbles are expected to focus on Bush's desire to preserve the expensive strategic nuclear program. The president's 1991 budget adds $900 million for research on the Star Wars missile defense project and spares the multibillion-dollar B-2 stealth bomber program and the Navy's aircraft carrier battle groups. Another likely ``big-ticket'' target for Congress is the administration's request for $363 million to start building two nuclear reactors in Idaho and South Carolina to produce tritium, a radioactive gas used to make nuclear warheads. Critics say tritium supplies already are adequate to meet future needs, so the $7 billion or more needed to complete the new reactors is unjustifiable. Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., says the administration may be forced to scrap plans to expand the nuclear bomb factories. ``This is going to put a much heavier burden of proof on those who want to spend for new facilities,'' says Wyden, who advocates opening U.S.-Soviet negotiations to ban the production of plutonium, a key ingredient in nuclear weapons. Perhaps the fiercest fight of all will be over base closings. Bush's budget calls for shutting down or consolidating about 55 bases. Cheney offered no estimate of savings but said fewer bases will be needed as troop strength is reduced. The outcome of these debates is likely to influence not only the future shape of U.S. defenses, but also the fortunes of military supply and consulting companies and their hundreds of thousands of employees. ``There is a shakeout taking place in the industry,'' says Jacques Gansler, senior vice president of Analytic Sciences Corp., a defense contractor. The prospect of large job losses has given new prominence to debate in Congress over ``economic conversion'' legislation aimed at helping defense company managers and workers switch from production of military hardware to civilian items. Critics of this approach say the economy can cope without new help from the government. They note that in the eight years following the 1968 peak in defense spending during the Vietnam War, the military budget was slashed 37 percent. ``While there was pain and suffering, we managed it,'' said Kaufmann of the Brookings Institution.
