DOC.HEAD: Bush Wins Round 1 of Political Season; Democrats Try To Shift Focus
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Bush led with his high cards, defense, foreign policy and the remnants of the Cold War. Democratic leaders praised the president, conceded the hand, and set about changing the subject. Bush's State of the Union response to the chain reaction ``revolution of '89'' in Eastern Europe foretells the American politics of the '90s. Any president has the upper hand when the issues are national defense and foreign affairs, and, for most of the past generation, those have been Republican issues. The Democrats usually make their case on domestic matters. Even with Bush's poll popularity at record highs, the voters say they think Democrats can do a better job in dealing with problems at home. With the eased threat from Moscow and the disintegration of its satellite bloc, Democrats think they can shift the voter focus, beginning with this year's election campaign and looking toward the presidential elections of 1992 and 1996. That would put the emphasis on future campaigns on their strong suit. It would, presumably, spare their future presidential nominees the kind of ridicule Gov. Michael Dukakis faced in 1988 after he was photographed with his helmeted head jutting up from the turret of a tank. At a campaign reunion, Bush jokingly thanked his 1988 advisers for keeping him out of tanks. Now, 10 days into the new session of Congress, the political advantage belongs to Bush. He won, unexpectedly, with the Senate minority he needed to uphold a veto of a bill extending the U.S. visas of Chinese students, a step he said he had taken anyhow. Then came his two major messages of the year, the new budget on Monday, the State of the Union address to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday night. Leaving budget bogymen and fine print problems for later, the president issued his surprise call to subtract an additional 80,000 soldiers each from the U.S.-Soviet troop cuts in Europe that are being negotiated. Even Democrats who had denounced his budget harmonized in praise of that proposal, outlined hours after Bush had telephoned Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to tell him about it. That is the kind of diplomatic drama a president can deliver. The Democrats have nothing to match it. The budget and domestic priorities are politically contested terrain. Nobody is quarreling about troop cuts. And the democratic upheavals that made them practical work to Bush's advantage, even though the United States was not directly involved in the changes that swept Eastern Europe. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said the conditions and commitments that led to the disintegration of the Communist empire in Europe were the work of presidents, Congresses and American servicemen from Harry Truman's time. That counts the Democrats in for a share of the credit, but Bush is the major political beneficiary, simply because he was president when it happened. So the Democratic emphasis is on change at home. ``There are new realities to be grasped, new challenges to be met, and very different battles to be won,'' Foley said in the Democratic response to Bush. ``In the 1990s, and well into the next century, the central challenge for America will be economic, not military,'' he said. ``The greatest test of our strength will be in our classrooms, not our missile silos. The gravest threat will come not from any nation's attempt at world domination, but from every nation's complicity in the worldwide destruction of the environment.'' Those are problems indeed, and there are more built into the Bush budget, deficits now, soaring federal liabilities later. Those domestic headaches may well rearm the Democrats. But Bush is in charge at a time of chain reaction international change ``so striking that it marks the beginning of a new era in the world's affairs.'' Last spring, Democrats were complaining that he was passively yielding the stage to Gorbachev, failing to respond to Moscow peace initiatives. He silenced that with his first proposal for troop cuts, delivered to the NATO summit at the end of May. Now Bush holds the initiative. The first round of the 1990 political season is his. But only the first, and it's a long season.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Dolls May Be Overrated In Child Abuse Cases
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The 5-year-old girl tossed her hair, twisted around in the chair, rolled her head, raised her arms, stood up and sat down again, all the while dutifully answering questions from the nice lady with the rag doll. A camera rolled behind a two-way mirror as the two went through a delicate procedure that has become vital in prosecution of child abuse cases. The lady told the girl that sometimes unpleasant things happen to little children and maybe they could talk about it. She pulled out a clothed, rag doll with hair of yarn _ and anatomical details such as breasts and genitals. Together, the child and interviewer pointed to the different body parts. No, no one had ever touched her there, said the child, pointing. She was sure. Despite physical evidence of abuse, the little girl wasn't talking that day. In recent years, the use of anatomical dolls has grown as more child abuse cases are prosecuted. But a new study shows that the dolls' effectiveness in aiding a child's memory may be overrated. ``These dolls have become very popular because some psychologists believe they do something magical, eliciting information they otherwise couldn't get at,'' said Bruce Forman, a University of Miami psychologist. ``But our findings indicate that's probably not so.'' Anatomical dolls became available in the late 1970s and early 1980s and now are common in social workers' and prosecutors' offices and police agencies. The dolls, costing up to $75, have evolved from crude, unclothed figures to less-threatening, more realistic ones with underwear and bright clothes. Experts agree that the dolls can help some children tell what happened to them, especially those who are very young or are embarrassed to talk about the incident. But the evidence is less clear in terms of what interview tool helps get the best information from an abused child and what is normal behavior. ``Clinically, many believe the dolls have a place in evaluating suspected abused kids that cannot be taken over by another tool,'' said Mark Everson, a psychologist and co-director of the clinical research program on childhood maltreatment at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. In a study of whether dolls' anatomical explicitness would lead a non-abused child to act out in a sexually suggestive manner, Everson found that 6 percent of more than 200 children aged 2-5 showed fairly clear sexual acts with the dolls during an interview, even when there was no history of abuse. In the Miami study, 45 children, aged 8 and 9, viewed a 12-minute film often used in sexual-abuse awareness programs. One group later told what they remembered verbally, another by drawing pictures and a third with the dolls. ``We found no significant difference in accuracy or completeness of information recalled,'' Forman said. The results of the study will be published in the journal ``Social Behavior and Personality.'' In another study, of 32 girls aged 5-8, the Miami researchers found that abused girls showed somewhat more aggression and sexual play with the dolls if an observer was not in the room than did non-abused girls. With an adult in the room, there was little difference between the two groups, Forman said. However, not all of the abused girls showed increased agression and sexual play, indicating a need for more research on what is normal behavior, he said. ``From our work, we know that children who have not been abused display some curiosity about sexual body parts, and that's normal and healthy when it appears at the appropriate age.'' It is important, he added, that aggression shown by a child doesn't necessarily imply a history of sexual abuse. ``We've only scratched the surface of how children react. There are still a lot of questions,'' he said. Although much has been made of the potential for over-interpretation of children's interaction with anatomical dolls, they have become an integral part of child-abuse investigations and the prosecution of mass child abuse cases. Videotaped interviews of children with the dolls was among evidence used to convict Frank Fuster Escalona in 1985 in one of Florida's most notorious cases, involving the abuse of children at a baby-sitting service in Dade County. The story was retold recently in the TV movie ``Unspeakable Acts.'' Fuster is serving six consecutive life sentences. His wife, Ileana, was also convicted in the so-called Country Walk case, which involved allegations of nude sex games and satanic animal sacrifices. She served about four years of a 10-year sentence and was deported to her native Honduras. Among defense criticisms was that children had been manipulated during the interviews and that using the dolls was inappropriate, said John Hogan, lead prosecutor. ``Obviously the jury didn't put much credence in that.'' In California, defense attorneys also made an issue of how children were interviewed in the McMartin Preschool molestation case. Raymond Buckey and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, were acquitted last month of almost all charges linked to the alleged molestation of 11 children at the now-defunct school in Manhattan Beach, a suburb of Los Angeles. Mary Emmons, executive director of Children's Institute International, where the children were interviewed, said defense attorneys were just doing their job in attacking the methods. ``For the most part, the methods used by mental health professionals are well-stablished clinical methods designed to aid children in telling what may or may not have happened,'' she said. Others in the field echo that sentiment. ``I have seen some criticism of use of the dolls ... and frankly it all gets blown out of proportion,'' said Patricia Toth, of the National Center for Prosecution of Child Abuse, a nonprofit group based in Alexandria, Va. ``People latch onto the dolls as if they're responsible for conviction of innocent people,'' Toth said. ``I truly don't think they have the impact people attach to them. Dolls in and of themselves don't make the case.'' At the Children's Center in Miami, run by the Dade State Attorney's Office, dolls play a prominent role in interviews. They are primarily used for showing exactly what happened after a child has already talked about an incident, said Teresa Pooler, an assistant state attorney and director of the center. The center, founded in December 1986 after the Country Walk case, has about 18 dolls in adult, child and toddler size. The females have vaginas and breasts and the males have penises. An average of 70 children are interviewed a month. ``We use the dolls for demonstrative purposes, not for diagnosis as to whether something in fact occurred,'' said Pooler, adding children often have different names for body parts and difficulty with spatial relationships. ``I think anything that can be used to elicit a statement from a child is a positive thing,'' she said, ``provided it's used properly.''

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Doctors Admit Patients' Right to Death with Dignity
DOC.TEXT: Japanese doctors, long regarded as too exalted to be questioned, are changing their guidelines to give patients more information about diseases like cancer and more say in life-and-death decisions. Under pressure from new patients' rights groups, the Japan Medical Association surveyed doctors about such ``informed consent'' issues as terminal patients' right to stop treatment. The results, showing most doctors willing to open up to patients, were released in January accompanied by recommendations that doctors should give more information to cancer patients and that terminally ill patients should have a right to refuse treatment. ``I've seen patients with uncurable disease and cancer at final stages, tied to machines and living in pain, and I refuse to be kept alive like that,'' said Keinosuke Miyaji, spokesman the Association for Death With Dignity, whose 7,300 members have signed wills expressing their wishes in such cases. ``If I had cancer, I would like to know, by all means. My own experiences with my husband made me think that knowing the truth makes a big difference,'' said Ayako Katsunuma, whose husband, Haruo, a doctor, died of lung cancer five years ago. ``Before the surgery, my husband said he wanted just six more months to live, so that he could ... complete unfinished work, and he did.'' Haruo Katsunuma asked his doctors for the truth, and that enabled the couple to make their remaining days together worthwhile, Mrs. Katsunuma said. ``It also released some of my mental suffering. Hiding the truth must be so stressful for other family members.'' Interest in patients' rights has been growing for years and was given new impetus by widespread publicity of strenuous efforts to treat Emperor Hirohito, whose final illness lasted more than three months. After his death on Jan. 7, 1989, doctors disclosed that the emperor hadn't been told he had cancer. In a country where doctors were held in awe, patients have believed they should not bother physicians with ``silly'' questions. Doctors generally didn't explain fully the treatment they provided or even how bad ailments were. However, in the medical association survey last summer of 1,607 doctors, 70.7 percent agreed they should respect patients' wishes; 16.3 percent urged the legalization of patthe right to die in accordance with patients' wishes; and 7.3 percent said they must always keep patients alive. Nonetheless, the medical association said cancer patients should be told the truth only if they are strong enough to face reality and their cancer is at an early stage. And Chairman Ichiro Kato said it is ``not illegal'' for doctors to agree to let a terminally ill patient die, they should provide information on the dangers of treatment and on alternatives to those who are less ill. The association's report also said doctors bear no legal responsibility when a patient refuses a transfusion for religious reasons; if the patient is a child and a parent refuses a transfusion for the child, a transfusion can be given against the parents' wishes. While the report said patients could refuse doctors' suggestions, it said that ``doctors and patients are not equal, and doctors should take initiative as professionals with specialized knowledge and experience.'' Shizuko Kiba, who studies terminal care, said doctors have overwhelmingly focused on medical technology and ignored patients' feelings. ``Medical care is for patients, and its purpose, especially for those at the final stage of their lives, should be to relieve pain and let them live like humans,'' she said. When patients asked if they had cancer _ the leading cause of death in Japan _ doctors almost always used to deny it, believing the truth would hurt the patients' morale. ``But patients often know that no means yes,'' Ms. Kiba said. ``The important thing is communication between patients and doctors, through which patients can learn the truth themselves naturally.'' ``Informed consent'' requires communication, agreed Kazumasa Hoshino, a medical professor at Kyoto University. ``It is almost impossible when a patient steps into the room for the first time, when we know nothing about each other.''

DOC.HEAD: Penn Biologist Helps Restore Tropical Forest ^With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: When Daniel Janzen set out to teach people to restore depleted tropical forests, he didn't think he'd be a driving instructor. ``What I'm teaching is stuff that is a combination of academic things and what we regard as the ordinary things about running an ordinary life,'' Janzen said during an interview in his University of Pennsylvania office amid tropical seed and fruit specimens, popcorn, and Pepperidge Farm cookies. ``You spend two hours in the afternoon talking about how to tell a beetle from a bug and then an hour and a half on driving lessons. You mix the biological aspects with the practical aspects.'' Janzen, 50, spends four months of the year teaching biology and the rest in Costa Rica, guiding efforts to save its dwindling tropical dry forests. He also helped raise more than $24 million to buy 158 square miles of forests that in July was formally dedicated as Guanacaste National Park. In October 1988, Janzen began training Costa Ricans to survey the park's plant and animal life and to teach others the techniques. There are 175 species of birds, 700 of plants, 3,140 of moths and butterflies and 13,000 of insects, so the inventory alone will take about 10 years to complete. Janzen practices a new field called restoration ecology, which tries to return areas to their condition before they were damaged by humans. He hopes to raise $30 million for the National Biodiversity Institute of Costa Rica. Among the biggest contributors have been the Costa Rican and Swedish governments, the Pew Charitable Trusts in Philadelphia and the MacArthur Foundation, which honored him with one of its ``genius awards'' earlier this year. The program does not use American volunteers, although some of Janzen's students at Penn have asked if they could join it; he refused, he said, because that would mean fewer Costa Ricans would be involved in the work. ``Costa Ricans develop a feeling of ownership. That's the link you want. You want the members of the society to feel that the park is actually theirs, so that when it's threatened, at some later time, they then feel the threat is a personal threat.'' The project got its start in 1985, when Costa Rican officials discovered that the Corcovado National Park was threatened by about 1,200 gold miners, who had caused widespread ecological damage. The officials asked Janzen to find out why the miners had breached the park's traditionally respected boundaries. He discovered that the miners had moved their operations into the forests because they felt the land belonged to no one. He realized if the country's resources were to be saved, Costa Ricans had to take pride in the forests. Since then, Costa Rica _ about the size of West Virginia _ has devoted more than a quarter of its area to natural parks, more than any of its Latin American neighbors. Janzen, a Minnesota native, has spent more than 26 years in Costa Rica, drawn by its diverse plant and animal life. Helping to plan a national park, however, gave the field scientist a new challenge. ``As soon as you start planning a park and thinking about its biological properties, you immediately realize that the real challenge is not the biology, but the human administration,'' he said. ``You can't just put an advertisement in the newspaper like you can here and out of the woodwork comes 25 people who've already got master's degrees in resource management.'' Janzen carefully describes his role as a guide. ``My role is teaching particular courses and being somewhat of an advisor for some aspects of the administration of the park. I become part of the process of making decisions, but I don't make decisions.'' Those decisions are made by Costa Rican officials, who Janzen said are very aware of the environmental impact their decisions could have, an awareness he attributes in large part to the country's size. Costa Ricans can't escape the problems by moving, as Americans once did, he said. Janzen credits Costa Rican President Oscar Arias with encouraging the country to put one-fourth of its natural resources aside. ``Costa Rica pretty much understands what they want to do... They know what the recipe is.''

DOC.HEAD: Antibiotic With OTC Drug Best Against Travelers' Diarrhea
DOC.TEXT: A new suggests that combining an antibiotic with an over-the-counter drug can reduce the duration of travelers' diarrhea to just an hour, from an average of 34 hours with the best known previous therapy. ``We never dreamed it would work so well. It was marvelous,'' said Dr. Charles D. Ericsson, who with Dr. Herbert L. DuPont led a team of researchers at the University of Texas Medical School at Houston. The researchers tested five different treatments _ including a placebo, or inactive medication _ among 227 U.S. college students who suffered from acute diarrhea while attending summer school in Guadalajara, Mexico. The quickest relief came from combining the antibiotic sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim, marketed as Septra and Bactrim, with the over-the-counter drug loperamide, marketed as Immodium AD, the researchers said. Subjects took the antibiotic in tablet form twice a day for three days, and an initial two-tablet dose of loperamide, Ericsson said. One additional tablet of loperamide was taken after each loose bowel movement. The average duration of diarrhea was an hour or less with the combination of drugs, vs. 34 hours using the previous best therapy, the antibiotic alone, said Ericsson. In the control group, the average duration was 59 hours. Less effective were the other three approaches tested: a single large dose of the antibiotic; two-a-day doses of the antibiotic over three days; and the over-the-counter drug alone, the researchers found. Their findings were reported in the Journal of the American Medical Association.
DOC.HEAD: Scientists Say Microchip Implant Survived a Year
DOC.TEXT: Silicon microchips implanted into rats' feet survived a year and linked with nerve tissue, a step researchers say could in several decades lead to the development of bionic limbs. ``The goal of this project is to make an interface, a direct connection, between the human nervous system and machines'' or prostheses, said Greg Kovacs, a Stanford University electrical engineer and medical student. Two quarter-sized radio transceivers, one at the stump of the severed part of the human body and connected to the chip and the other on the outside of the artificial limb, could relay information by radio, Kovacs said. The main challenge for scientists is being able to take the signals sent from the brain and interpret and process them into information that can be fed into the prosthesis' circuits, probably through a computer. Such a system is far in the future, warned Kovacs and three colleagues, who last year implanted a tiny chip between the severed ends of foot nerves in a half dozen rats. Nerve fibers regenerated through holes in the chip, and the researchers were eventually able to stimulate activity by sending signals through the chip. Kovacs said the holes in the chips were small enough that only single nerves or small clusters grew in each pathway. The chips probably will not be useful in reconnecting severed limbs or other body parts, he said, because of the irreversible damage generally caused by the cutting.

DOC.HEAD: Can Dogs Warn of Imminent Epileptic Seizure? Study Planned
DOC.TEXT: Intrigued by stories of two dogs who reportedly could sense that their masters were about to have epileptic seizures, researchers are looking for other dogs who appear to have that ability. If dogs can be trained to give warnings, they might make life easier for people with epilepsy by giving them time to take precautions to avoid injury during the seizure, said Reina Berner, executive director of the Epilepsy Institute in New York. As a result, some people with epilepsy could become less fearful of having seizures in public, and so begin to lead less restricted lives, she said. The institute hopes to find three to five dogs who appear to have the ability, so the animals can be formally tested. If it appears, researchers hope to find out how they do it, so other dogs can be trained, Berner said. The testing would involve monitoring brain waves of a volunteer to watch for the signal of an impending seizure, and noting if and when the dog senses the seizure coming. Berner said she had heard of one dog in Washington, D.C., who could sense seizures in a girl, and had met a second such dog and its owner. The owner said that while she was taking a shower, the dog had predicted an oncoming seizure by barking even though the animal was outside the closed bathroom door. Both dogs had been trained to work for people using wheelchairs, she said. In addition, both appeared able to predict not only grand mal seizures, which make a person collapse, but also complex partial seizures, in which a person becomes semi-concious and lapses into such simple behavior as walking.
EDITOR'S NOTE: The Epilepsy Institute is at 67 Irving Place, Sixth Floor, New York, NY, 10003.

DOC.TEXT: The government's main economic forecasting gauge rose in December at its fastest pace in eight months, the government said. The Commerce Department said Wednesday the Index of Leading Economic Indicators rose 0.8 percent in December, helping to move the forecasting gauge up 0.4 percent for the year. It was the weakest performance since the index fell 1.5 percent in 1984. The rise for the year compared with an increase of 3.9 percent for 1988, and suggests the economy could be more sluggish this year than in 1989.

New homes sales in 1989, held back in part by a 9.6 percent decline in December, posted their worst record in five years, the government said. The Commerce Department said Wednesday that new single-family homes were sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 629,000 units in December after jumping 9.3 percent in November.

Federal regulators seized Phoenix-based MeraBank, Arizona's largest savings institution and the latest victim of the state's real estate slump. The Resolution Trust Corp. took over MeraBank on Wednesday after the Office of Thrift Supervision declared that the thrift was operating in an unsafe and unsound condition.

Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. took steps to bolster its financial footing under tighter control of parent American Express Co. following the sudden resignation of Shearson chairman Peter A. Cohen. Nine years after acquiring Shearson, American Express removed the final high-level link to the firm's past when company chairman James D. Robinson III asked Cohen to leave amid mounting acrimony between the two executives. American Express and Shearson on Wednesday jointly announced a plan to raise about $250 million by offering stock to existing shareholders. It replaces a public offering scrapped because of the firm's slumping stock price and Cohen's resignation Tuesday.

A group of investors has scrapped a $900 million takeover bid for The Stride Rite Corp., but refused to rule out another offer for the leading shoe company. The decision Wednesday by Walsh, Greenwood & Co., a Greenwich, Conn., investment concern, came a day after Stride Rite rejected its $32-per-share offer and said it wanted to remain independent.

Members of Aristech Chemical Corp.'s board approved a $934.2 million cash takeover bid submitted by a group of the Pittsburgh company's senior managers and the Mitsubishi Corp. of Japan. But the agreement Wednesday also allows the company to solicit proposals from others. Utah chemical magnate Jon Huntsman asked Aristech to extend its bidding deadline from Monday to Feb. 14 to give him time to put top the bid.

Bank of New England Corp., scrambling for cash because of large losses from bad real estate loans, announced it had completed the sale of a vehicle leasing business for $350 million. The bank said Wednesday it had sold the U.S. portion of its McCullagh Leasing to GE Capital, a subsidiary of General Electric Co. The business leases car and truck fleets in the United States and Canada, and Bank of New England said it expected to complete the sale of the Canadian portion next week for around $100 million.

Oilworkers rejected the industry's two-year contract offer and threatened to strike some or all of the nation's largest petroleum companies. The Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union said Wednesday the contract offered by Amoco Corp., the pattern contract for the industry, fell short on pay, health benefits and environmental concerns. The company had no comment.

A federal bankruptcy judge approved Eastern Airline's request for $50 million to be taken out of escrow funds to help finance its operations through February. The approval Wednesday by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland comes a day after a committee of Eastern's preferred shareholders advocated the liquidation or outright sale of the airline and said a $40 million advance should be enough to cover the next month.

The stock market surged Wednesday, reversing a five-session slide as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 47.30 to 2,590.54. The dollar slipped against most key currencies in thin trading. Bond prices soared, posting their largest gains in nearly three months. Gold futures prices tumbled; oil futures were mixed; livestock and meat futures were lower; and grains and soybeans were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Approves Eastern's Request for More Funds
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines, struggling to rebuild as a smaller carrier under bankruptcy court supervision, has received a $50 million infusion to help fund its operations through February. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland on Wednesday approved Eastern's request for $50 million to be taken out of escrow funds, which contain around $600 million raised from recent sales of Eastern assets. Lifland's approval came a day after a committee of Eastern's preferred shareholders advocated the liquidation or outright sale of the airline and said a $40 million advance should be enough to cover the next month. Eastern's management issued a memo to its employees Wednesday dismissing the preferred shareholders' salvo and persistent rumors of a possible Chapter 7 liquidation. At Wednesday's hearing, attorneys representing the preferred shareholders raised their estimate of Eastern's current needs to $42 million, based on new data provided by the carrier. But the shareholders, to whom Eastern owes $1.175 billion, didn't soften their opposition to the airline's latest reorganization proposal. Eastern filed a new plan with the court late last week in which it proposed to pay preferred holders no more than 10 cents on the dollar in the form of new stock. Previously, Eastern had promised to repay its creditors in full. ``We think that a new direction or directions have to be explored for this airline,'' Robert Miller, an attorney for the preferred shareholders' committee, said Wednesday in a telephone interview. He said the committee might take further legal action, but declined to elaborate. In papers filed Tuesday in U.S. Bankruptcy Court, the shareholders' committee said it had lost faith in Eastern's management because it was ``cannibalizing'' the airline by selling assets. Frank Lorenzo, chairman of Eastern's parent Texas Air Corp., suggested in a private meeting Tuesday with airline analysts that he could merge Eastern and its sister carrier Continental Airlines, according to unidentified analysts quoted in the Los Angeles Times and the Washington Post. Texas Air spokesman Art Kent said Wednesday a merger between Houston-based Continental and Miami-based Eastern continues to be one of a range of possible options that could be considered. He said Lorenzo's statements to the analysts were in line with his previous public positions. Frank Ortis, president of Machinists union Local 702 in Miami, said Lifland and Eastern's creditors likely would object to a merger between non-union Continental and Eastern. ``I can't believe anybody would allow them to do that because Continental is almost as shaky as Eastern,'' Ortis said. ``The only sensible solution is to sell it to us and let us have a shot at having a profitable airline.'' In its memo to employees, Eastern said, ``We expected this type of reaction from the preferred stockholders' committee. They are trying to build pressure in an attempt to improve their position.'' The memo, obtained by NBC's Miami affiliate WTVJ, said liquidation was not in the interest of the creditors or Eastern. But some travel agents responded to the latest developments by advising customers not to fly Eastern. ``There could be a lot more people stranded this time,'' said agent Nancy Redlus of Sunshine Holiday Travel in downtown Miami. ``Right now, I don't know what's going to happen to the airline, what's going to happen to them tomorrow.'' The Machinists union has been on strike against Eastern since last March 4. It was joined in sympathy walkouts by pilots and flight attendants, forcing the airline into bankruptcy court protection on March 9. The pilots and flight attendants abandoned their strikes just before Thanksgiving, but Eastern has rebuilt as a smaller carrier and hired mostly non-union workers to replace the strikers. Lifland's approval for Eastern to withdraw the $50 million was the fourth such request granted since the Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceeding began. The three previous drawdowns totaled $210 million. In addition to paying preferred shareholders no more than 10 cents on the dollar, Eastern's new reorganization proposal also calls for paying unsecured crs only 10 percent of their debts in cash when the airline emerges from bankruptrotection, and another 70 percent over the following 10 years, without interest In return for accepting partial repayment, Texas Air would give the unsecured creditors 40 percent of Easteruity. Under Eastern's two previous plans, unsecured creditors were to be rd in full with interest at the completion of Chapter 11. Eastern owes the unseccreditors, primarily trade suppliers such as aircraft manufacturers, around $1.1 billion. The committee representing unsecured creditors so far has reserjudgment on Eastern's new plan. Adam Harris, an the committee, declined comment Wednesday on the shareholders' position and Lifland's decision to grant the $50 million. Lawyers represend striking Machinists had asked at the hearing ithdrawn by Eastern be matched by a contribution from Texas Air.

DOC.HEAD: After Turmoil, New Chief Executive Seeks Stability
DOC.TEXT: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.'s new leader plans to attack a morale problem at the Wall Street brokerage, but the sorry state of the securities industry may prove a bigger obstacle to reversing the firm's fortunes. Like other brokerages hurt by an industry-wide recession, Shearson is extending staff cuts into the ranks of its highly paid investment bankers, sources at the firm said. The cuts _ which one investment banker said could total 50 to 100 professionals by the end of May, or 10 percent to 20 percent of the division, _ were initiated before this week's tumult surrounding the resignation of chairman Peter A. Cohen. On Wednesday, parent American Express Co. took steps to bolster Shearson's financial footing amid signs that the travel and credit card giant would exert tighter control over the firm. Shearson's newly appointed president and chief executive officer, Howard L. Clark Jr., a former American Express executive, said his near-term goal is to complete an $850 million recapitalization program that will preserve the firm's credit rating. In a telephone interview, Clark said that in an effort to reassure Shearson employees that the turmoil was ending he would ``get out and see the employees and management and retail system. I will be doing a lot of that.'' That would contrast sharply with the tenure of Cohen, a brash 43-year-old executive who was ousted after simmering tensions with American Express Chairman James D. Robinson III boiled over this week. A perception of arrogance on the part of Cohen _ especially among the firm's 10,500 brokers _ has hurt morale. Other problems, including 800 recent layoffs, a senior management restructuring and slumping business, also have jolted the firm. Clark said he hoped that would change. ``I think morale is going to improve as the business environment improves because we've really compted corrected two uncertainties _ the management leadership question and the capitalization andrating,'' he said. But Clark added: ``The basic problem is financial market _ the volatility and cyclicality. That affects all firms, not just Shearson.'' Nine years after acquiring Shearson, American Express removed the final high-level link to the firm's past with Cohen's forced resignation Tuesday. Analysts predicted that the arrival of the subdued and practical Clark, who turns 46 today, could lead to a scaling down of activity in fields such as investment banking _ involving mergers and securities underwriting _ that Shearson entered under Cohen during Wall Street's expansion-crazed 1980s. ``Over the next several years you could see a swing back to the Shearson of old where the main concern was the retail side of the business,'' said Perrin Long of Lipper Analytical Services. The first order of business for Clark is the sale of about $250 million in new stock t shareholders.
