A Shearson oicial who requested anonymity cae figure of up to 100 layoffs ``way out of line'' but said some reductions had occurred. Iear how the changing of the guard at Shearson would affect the reductions. Merrill Lynch earlier this month let go about 70 investment bankers, or about 10 percent of its force, spokesman Fred Yager said. The layoffs were effective immediately. vestment bankers, who advise companies on acquisitions and sales of stock and bonds, are among the most highly paid professionals on Wall Street with six- and seven-figure salaries and bonuses.

DOC.HEAD: Broker, Father, Friend Settle Insider Trading Charges
DOC.TEXT: A Washington stockbroker, his father and a friend who allegedly tipped the father to inside information about a corporate takeover have settled civil securities charges. a civil complaint filed at federal court in Washington, the Secies and Exchange Commission alleWednesday that Richard W. Dutrisac, a board member of Pancretec Inc., tipped John E. McCullough Sr. about the San Diego company's pending acquisition by Abbot Laboratories in January 1989. According to the SEC, McCullough told his son, John E. McCullough Jr., a registered representative for a Washington, D.C., brokerage, about the proposed deal. The son allegedly recommended Pancretec, which makes drug-infusion pumps, to his customerl three settled the SEC action without admitting or denying wrongdoing. The elder McCullough, 58, of Arlington, Va., agreed to pay $35,000 in penalties and alleged illegal profits. His son, who was not accused of trading for himself, was to pay $27,768 in fines and restitution of commission fees. All but $5,000 was waived due to ``inability to pay,'' according to the settlement papers. The name of the younger McCullough's firm was not disclosed. Dutrisac, 50, of Santa Ana, Calif., agreed to pay $13,500 in penalties. The government did not seek any alleged illegal profits because there was no charge he traded on the inside information, SEC attorney Daniel A. Nathan said. Nathan said no charges have been filed against the 11 McCullough clients, who allegedly made $13,000 onretec trades. He declined to sather charges would be brought in the future, although there was no indication the clients were aware the information had been misappropriated. Dutrisac's lawyer in Newport Beach, Calif., Ronald P. Arrined to comment. Lawyers for the McCulloughs could not be reached for comment.

DOC.HEAD: The National Makes Its Debut
DOC.TEXT: The National puts opening day fanfare behind it today and begins its pursuit of a loyal following of readers for all sports seasons. The country's only all-sports newspaper made its debut Wednesday at newsstands and in vending machines in New York, Los Angeles and Chicago after six months in development and two weeks of daily tests. The first 48-page issue featured 36 pages of stories and statistics, a weather map for spectators venturing to games around the country and a short list of ``jock stocks'' for those wishing to gamble their money on more than sporting events. Early sales were brisk, and National officials said they were pleased with the startup, which is costing the paper's financial backers about $25 million. Publisher Peter Price and editor Frank Deford said they were optimistic about reaching goals of daily circulation averaging 200,000. Plans are to expand circulation of the tabloid-style paper, which sells for 50 cents, into as many as a dozen more cities by the end of the year. Deford, a former Sports Illustrated writer, said the owners also are considering mailing an early-evening edition to subscribers later in the year so that people who live and work outside major cities can get the newspaper. Price said 250,000 copies were distributed on the first day and that several newsstands in New York reported they exhausted their supply within a few hours. Some folks bought a single copy while others bought several. A man who identified himself as Jerry Ginsberg of Freehold, N.J., scooped up eight copies at a Penn Station newstand and said he was betting $4 that ``in 10 years, these will be worth money.'' Price conceded there was a ``novelty effect'' to the first-day sales but said he was convinced there was ``immense demand'' for the paper anyway. Deford said the paper would be so successful, someone else will probably imitate it by launching a second national sports daily. The first issue offered what newspaper officials said was a representative mix of local, national and international sports stories, hockey and basketball statistics and standings that included comments on each team. But some newspaper people questioned the exclusivity of the two stories touted as ``exclusives'' in the first edition _ one in which outfielder Darryl Strawberry said ``it's time for me to leave'' the New York Mets and the other reporting Florida running back Emmitt Smith's decision to turn professional. ``Strawberry says that every six weeks,'' said Vic Ziegel, sports editor of the New York Daily News. Paul Anger, executive sports editor of the Miami Herald, said several newspapers in Florida already have reported Smith was likely to turn pro. Ziegel also noted the New York edition failed to include West Coast scores. But The National did offer some unique, off-beat features. Its ``Jock Stocks'' listed stock price changes for companies with sports affiliations. The weather map noted driving conditions at game time in various cities. At a news conference, Deford said one of the only glitches in the first issue was that Charleston, S.C., appeared where Charlotte, N.C., should have been on the weather map. The mistake appeared in the New York issue but he said it was corrected in the other two editions. Each city's issue will be tailored to the local audience. The first issue had different cover stories in each city, with Patrick Ewing of the New York Knicks featured in the New York edition, Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls in Chicago and Magic Johnson of the Los Angeles Lakers in Los Angeles. The National is owned by National American Sports Communications L.P., a partnership that includes Price and Mexican media baron Emilio Azcarraga. Price said the partnership was prepared to spend $100 million over five years to put the paper in the black but may spend more and wait longer.

DOC.HEAD: Midway Airlines Rejects Suitor's Bid for Board Seat
DOC.TEXT: Midway Airlines Inc., isn't saying what it will do now that unwelcome suitor Ampco-Pittsburgh Corp. has received government clearance to acquire a bigger stake in the air carrier. Neither is Ampco, for that matter. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission Wednesday, Ampco disclosed that it sought antitrust clearance to increase its stake to more than $15 million worth of Midway's common stock. The filing also noted that Midway had rejected Ampco's bid for a seat on the Chicago-based airline's board. Ampco spokesman Ronald Hasek said the company would have no comment beyond what was contained in the four-page SEC filing. A spokeswoman for Midway, Sandra Allen, confirmed that Midway had rebuffed Ampco's request for representation on the board of directors and that a Philadelphia banker had been elected recently to fill a vacancy on the board. But she declined to discuss the anti-trust clearance or Ampco's intentions. Last September, Ampco, a Pittsburgh, Pa.-based, heavy manufacturing concern, disclosed it had acquired a 9.6 percent stake in Midway, which serves 51 cities and operates from Chicago. According to Ampco's SEC filing, it ``made an informal request'' for representation on Midway's board Nov. 13. Ampco renewed that request Jan. 2 after a Midway board member, Jeffrey H. Erickson, resigned. But on Tuesday, according to the SEC filing, Midway told Ampco ``that its request for board representation had been rejected.'' Late last week, Midway electedrank Reed, president and chief executive officer of Philadelphia's First Pennsylvania Bank Corp., to fill the vacancy. Ampco said it ``is considering what action, if any, it may take'' in response to Midway's rejection of its request. Ampco also revealed it requested anti-trust clearance from the Justice Department and trade Commission to acquire additional Midway stock which would result in Ampco ``holding more than $15 million in value of common stock but less than 15 percent of the outstanding voting securities'' of Midway. The Ampco filing said it received clearance Dec. 12.

DOC.HEAD: Beeg Mak Attack Rattles Moscow; Over 30,000 Comrades Served
Ed: Also on general news wires.
LaserPhoto NY4
DOC.TEXT: Mixing the golden arches with the hammer and sickle may be a better combination than two all beef patties, special sauce, lettuce, cheese, pickles and onions on a sesame seed bun. McDonald's in Moscow is more than just the opening of another hamburger stand. It's West meeting East, capitalism flourishing in the heart of communism, an American icon dazzling ruble-paying Soviet masses. ``It represents a common ground. Soviets now have something that's quintessentially American,'' said Harriet Kuhr of the Friendship Force of Atlanta, which pioneered exchanges betweens U.S. and Soviet citizens. ``In a way, it's one of our imperialistic beliefs that everybody wants to be American but they haven't been allowed to,'' Kuhr said. ``That's not necessarily true, but it makes us feel good. It's like, `Wow, McDonald's. What's next? Maybe they'll start building Fords.' '' The Moscow McDonald's opened Wednesday with the most fanfare of any of the 11,201 franchises in the late Ray Kroc's empire. The restaurant rang up 30,000 meals on 27 cash registers, breaking the opening-day record for McDonald's worldwide, officials said. Over 70 billion burgers have been served since Kroc flipped his first patty 35 years ago, and 22 million people in 52 countries eat at McDonald's every day. That's more people than live in Australia and New Zealand. The fascination with a McDonald's on Alexander Pushkin Square, named for the father of modern Russian poetry, went far beyond the opening of a business venture, however. It was front page news in The New York Times and was featured on all American networks. The nation somehow found it comforting to know that its former Cold War foe now is more likely to have Beeg Mak attacks rather than nuclear ones. ``It's the equivalent of selling Russian meat pies in Times Square,'' said Ethel Dunn of the Highgate Road Social Science Research Station in Berkeley, Calif. ``At the moment, it's a novelty. But Russians are getting used to the idea there's something of value to be gained from Americans. It's a chance for them to learn something from us.'' McDonald's trained Soviet farmers how to increase yields of potatoes, cattle and lettuce. It imported seeds for pickle cucumbers and shipped in some things that aren't Soviet-grown, such as mustard and sesame seeds. They also trained their burger flippers to be cheery, a stark contrast to the dour faces found in state-run cafeterias. ``We taught them what fast friendly service means, what it means to provide clean surroundings and good quality food,'' said Gary Reinblatt, senior vice president for McDonald's of Canada. ``It's going to make the world a smaller place.'' Some Soviets were suspicious of the chipper faces. ``I smile to everybody and they say, `What's wrong? Why the smile?' '' said an unidentified worker in Moscow. ``They think I'm laughing at them, because it's very unusual for Soviet people to be kind and to be polite to everybody.'' And not everyone thinks the venture can cut the mustard or lead to Soviet versions of Ronald McDonald, Mayor McCheese and the Ham Burglar. ``I would be shocked if it works out right,'' said Dimitri Simes, a Soviet emigre who works for the Carnegie Endowment for Peace in Washington, D.C. ``They've had to train people for things they are not conditioned to be: pleasant, efficiesponsible and not steal from the kitchen, the company or customers,'' Simes sai ``To deliver the stuff they need at the restaurant, they will need reliable transportation. It doesn't exist,'' Simes said. ``You have to overcome so many bottlenecks inherent in the Soviet system.'' A Beeg Mac sold for 3.75 rubles, more than two hours' wages for the average Soviet. That's a fraction of what patrons were paying in nearby Zelyeny Ogonyok, or the Green Light, a joint with green and gold signs offering meat stew, cold meatballs with beads of fat, cabbage soup and black bread. But some sociologists said McDonald's is a tangible sign that Mikhail Gorbachev's policy of overhauling the country's economic system is delivering more goods to hungryrs. ``One of the primary concerns of Soviet citizens is the food supply,'' said Louise Shelley, chairwoman of the department of justice, law and society at American University. ``If the opening to the West increases the ability to feed the population, it's really an important development. Ms a concrete benefit, a symbol that there is some economic progress under perestroika.'' Where will it end? Avon is calling at China's door. Avon Products Inc. said Wednesday its cosmetics wibe made and sold in China in a joint venture with Guangzhou Cosmetics Factory. Avon expects to have 3,000 saleesentatives working in Guangzhou within a year and hopes to appeal to 500 million Chinese women.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed in Europe, Gold Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed against other major currencies in Europe today after two days of sharp swings. Gold prices were higher. Foreign exchange dealers said there was a nervous air in the markets, with the dollar first falling and then rising during the morning. The U.S. currency had not recovered from heavy selling on Wednesday following a denial by Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev that he would resign as chairman of the Communist Party. The first resignation rumor had pushed the dollar sharply higher. Dealers in Frankfurt said the dollar was likely to test new lows over the next few days in expectation of lower U.S. interest rates and the continuing strength of the West German mark. Dealers in Milan predicted the dollar would remain in a narrow range until the U.S. unemployment figures were issued on Friday. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar closed at 144.50 Japanese yen, up from Wednesday's closing 144.40. Later, in London, it was quoted at the higher rate of 144.55 yen. Other dollar rates at mid-morning, compared with late Wednesday's prices, included: 1.6780 West German marks, down from 1.6800; 1.4945 Swiss francs, down from 1.5025; 5.7000 French francs, down from 5.7275; 1.8895 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8950; 1,247.25 Italian lire, down from 1,252.75; and 1.1862 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1856. In London, the dollar rose against the British pound. It cost $1.6830 to buy one pound, compared with $1.6870 late Wednesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $413.40 a troy ounce, up from $413.25 bid late Wednesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $413.25. In Zurich, the bid price of gold was $413.20, up from $412.50 bid late Wednesday. Gold in Hong Kong fell $3.61 an ounce to close at a bid $412.42. Silver was unchanged in London at a bid $5.22 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The dollar inched up against the Japanese yen in quiet trading today, while the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index rose marginally. The dollar closed at 144.50 yen, up 0.10 yen from Wednesday's 144.40-yen finish. It opened at 144.45 yen and stayed in a narrow range between 144.35 yen and 144.63 yen. The dollar now has gained 1.28 yen in three trading days, after slipping 3.20 yen in the previous five days. Market players were selling yen to buy West German marks, and ``the yen's decline in its cross-trading against the mark resulted in the relative decline against the dollar,'' said Yoshitsugu Hanada, a trader with Mitsui Bank. ``But straight dollar-yen dealings were inactive,'' he added. Spot trading volume totaled some $5.43 billion, down from $9.34 billion the previous day. ``Investors were just not in a mood to buy yen before the (Feb. 18) election,'' Hanada said, adding that there have been increasing reports of problems the pro-business governing Liberal Democrats face trying to keep their majority in Parliament's lower house. ``The yen could go only as high as 143 yen,'' he said. On the stock exchange, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average gained 17.47 points, or 0.05 percent, closing at 37,206.42. It dipped 26.72 points Wednesday. The index quickly rose in early trading as the market's concerns eased over Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev's grip on power and the performance of the New York stock market, said Yutaka Yoshino, a dealer with Nikki Securities Co. ``A higher opening and lower closing often happens when the market is suffering from uncertainties,'' he said, citing U.S. government bond bidding next week and the election later this month. On Wednesday, Gorbachev himself denied a rumor that he would resign as Communist Party chief. The rumor had pushed up the dollar in Tokyo, resulting in a decline in the Nikkei. The 47-point overnight gain in the Dow Jones industrial average on Wall Street also reassured Japanese investors, Yoshino said. But later in Tokyo's session today, investors stopped buying because of remaining uncertainties, he added. An estimated 500 million shares changed hands, up from 450 million the previous day.

DOC.HEAD: Sale of Bloomingdale's May Be Called Off
DOC.TEXT: More than four months after putting Bloomingdale's on the auction block, officials for Federal Department Store Inc. are now contemplating calling off the sale of the 17-store high-fashion chain. Federated is studying whether ``there would be more value ... by retaining Bloomingdale's or by selling it,'' spokeswoman Carol Sanger said Wednesday. Federated is Bloomingdale's parent and the American holding company of Campeau Corp., the troubled Canadian retailer that sought protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal Bankrupcty Code on Jan. 15 for Federated and its sister U.S. retailing chain, Allied Stores Corp. Campeau had set a February deadline for selling the 17-store chain. According to unidentified sources quoted in today's editions of the New York Times, Federated had received at least three bids for tony Bloomingdale's, but ``most'' were below Federated's $1 billion-plus asking price. ``Absent a bid for Bloomingdale's that would be so overwhelming that we'd have to act on it, the decision would be delayed pending the construction of an overall reorganization plan for the companies,'' Ms. Sanger said. Rumors have been circulating in the retail trade that potential bidders were only considering offers of around $800 million. Any sale would be subject to bankruptcy court approval as well as the approval of a committee, which has not yet been completely formed, to represent creditors. The committee probably could not meet until at least mid-February. Campeau acquired Federated in 1988; two years earlier Campeau acquired the Allied chain. The acquisitions left the retailers with more than $7.5 billion in debt.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Announces Management Shakeup
DOC.TEXT: Bank of New England Corp. has cleaned out more of its senior management as the troubled institution tries to recover from massive losses in real estate loans. The bank said Wednesday that four senior executives had left the company, including the head of the its Boston operation. The announcement came less than a week after the bank's board of directors forced out Walter Connolly as chairman, naming H. Ridgely Bullock as an interim replacement. ``These changes represent a major step in the achievement of our recovery plan for the company,'' Bullock said in a statement. ``I expect they'll have an immediate impact on our goal of strengthening credit policies, procedures and administration.'' The bank said Richard Driscoll, vice chairman of the corporation and chairman of Bank of New England's Boston operation, had retired at the request of the board of directors. Other executives to leave are M. Thomas Wilson, president of the Boston operation; Hugh M. Taylor, senior credit policy officer; and James Sweeney, executive vice president of real estate lending. Under the new organization, Bullock will also serve as chairman and chief executive of the Boston division. Leo Breitman, who was president of Connecticut Bank and Trust Co., a subsidiary, will be president and chief operating officer of the Boston operation. Earlier in the day, Bank of New England said it had completed the sale of a vehicle leasing business for $350 million, a move that would give the company an infusion of cash. The bank said it had sold the U.S. portion of its McCullagh Leasing to GE Capital, a subsidiary of General Electric Co. The business leases car and truck fleets in the United States and Canada, and Bank of New England said it expected to complete the sale of the Canadian portion next week for around $100 million. Bank of New England announced earlier this month it expected to post a loss of more than $1 billion for 1989 because of bad real estate loans, and the company has been trying to sell about $6 billion worth of assets. Earlier this week, the bank said it had agreed to sell its credit card business to Citicorp for $828 million. Bullock said completing the sale of the leasing business ``represents continued momentum in our asset sales plan as we aggressively pursue other options to downsize the company and improve our capital ratios.'' The bank last week was forced to borrow money from the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, as depositors have withdrawn millions of dollars. Tom Lavelle, a bank spokesman, said the money from GE Capital could help Bank of New England avoid returning to the Federal Reserve in the immediate future. ``It is a possibility that we would not resort to the Fed, but we will be monitoring it over the next day or two,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bailout Officials Pledge Speedier Work on S&L Cases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts graf 6, On Wednesday, with seizure of MeraBank.
DOC.TEXT: Officials in charge of President Bush's savings and loan bailout, getting their second tongue-lashing in as many weeks on Capitol Hill, are assuring lawmakers they will speed up their work. ``I share your ... concerns about getting this job done,'' Deputy Treasury Secretary John E. Robson told critical members of the Senate Banking Committee, ``and we're going to break our necks to see that we get it done.'' The officials, a week after undergoing criticism from House members over the slow pace of their work, endured similar complaints from the senators Wednesday. ``Act decisively. Do what's necessary. Don't be timid,'' said Sen. Jake Garn of Utah, senior Republican on the Senate Banking Committee. ``Surely, surely there must be something you can do to speed up the process,'' he said, warning that further delay by the Resolution Trust Corp. will increase costs to the taxpayers. On Wednesday, Arizona's largest savings institution, Phoenix-based MeraBank, was seized by the federal government. The action by the RTC made MeraBank the sixth Arizona savings and loan to be seized by the government, leaving only four operating privately. The RTC has taken over some 350 S&Ls to date, disposing of 42 of them. However, 33 of the resolutions were completed in the agency's first three months of operation and only nine since then. ``The pace was a little slower than some of us would have liked to have seen,'' conceded Robson, acting chairman of the RTC oversight board. Sens. Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., chairman of the banking committee, and Paul Sarbanes, D-Md., were particularly critical of the administration's failure to fill many of the posts in the S&L bureaucracy nearly six months after enactment of the bailout law. ``It is impossible to understand how the thrift crisis can be successfully resolved with many of the key players not even in uniform ready to participate,'' Riegle said. The administration has failed to appoint a new Office of Thrift Supervision director, two of the five members of the RTC oversight board, an inspector general for the RTC, four of five members of a board governing the 12 regional Federal Home Loan Banks and a new member of the board of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. ``The urgency that was attached to this legislation seems to have evaporated with its passage,'' Sarbanes complained. Robson said the administration has had some difficulty finding candidates whose business activities did not pose a conflict of interest. Also, he described the FBI clearance process as ``draconian.'' However, he said the administration was ``very close'' to naming a fourth member of the RTC oversight board and said the candidate for the agency's inspector general was undergoing background checks. Robson also said if the $50 billion allocated to the RTC proved to be inadequate, the administration could ask Congress to ``reallocate to earlier periods'' $32 billion earmarked for post-1992 failures.

The stock market was mostly lower in moderate trading today after opening on a firmer note. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 2.25 points to 2,588.29 at 10 a.m. EST, 30 minutes after the opening bell. Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by about 7 to 5 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 568 issues up, 417 down and 456 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 23.14 million shares. Analysts said Wednesday's rally, which ended a five-session decline, would not necessarily carry the market higher today. ``I don't think anyone took it serious in terms of it being a reversal,'' said Larry Wachtel, analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``Nothing has changed _ quarterly earnings are still poor, interest rates are probably going higher. But from a physical standpoint you can't come down this much without a bounce.'' The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was down 0.02 to 181.48. At the American Stock Exchange the market value index was up 0.25 to 350.32. Among actively traded issues on the NYSE, IBM was up [ to 98}, Compaq Computer had risen 1] to 77[ and Hewlett Packard had gained \ to 44~. AT&T was off [ to 38~, American General had slipped [ to 28{ and Texaco had lost [ to 58[. On Wednesday, the Dow Jones industrials finished at 2,590.54, up 47.30 points. Advancing issues outpaced decliners by a margin of about 5 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,116 issues up, 449 down and 411 unchanged. Big Board volume came to 189.66 million shares, up from 186.03 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Delaware Court Gives Go-Ahead for Southern Union Merger with Metro Mobile
DOC.TEXT: Southern Union, a Texas-based natural gas utility, has won court permission to complete its $137 million merger with Metro Mobile CTS Inc. Vice Chancellor William Chandler of Delaware Chancery Court on Wednesday declined to block the merger, as requested by TCG, a privately held Texas corporation owned by Southern Union shareholder T.C. Griffith. Chandler said TCG had not proved it was likely to succeed with its case. TCG charged that the merger violated Delaware business law and that Southern Union withheld information that could affect the value of shareholders' stock. Metro, a New York-based cellular phone company that has a propane gas subsidiary, is offering $13.80 a share for Southern Union's 10.145 million shares. Chandler noted in his 28-page opinion Metro's bid ``offers Southern Union stockholders a significant premium'' over its recent market price. About a dozen companies had bid for Southern Union stock, but only Metro wanted the entire company, the chancellor said. ``Metro's bid, moreover, was at a far greater price than any other offer and was the only offer to acquire all of Southern Union,'' he said. There have been no other offers since June 1989, he said, adding, ``a delay in receiving Metro's cash offer would be injurious to Southern Union stockholders because of the time value of money.'' ``Worse still, if the merger is enjoined, Metro has indicated that it will `probably walk away' from the transaction,'' the judge said. Southern Union, based in Austin, Texas, has natural gas utilities in Texas, Arizona and Oklahoma. It also is involved in oil and gas exploration and production, markets gas to interstate pipeline systems and users, and has substantial real estate investments, according to the court filings. Southern Union and Metro are both incorporated in Delaware. In seeking the injunction, Griffith contended Southern Union did not tell shareholders that the company had a change of winning litigation against a New Mexico utility. Winning could increase Southern Union's assets by about $60 million and also increase the value of its natural gas reserves, according to Griffith's request.

The stock market was lower in moderate trading today but had bounced off earlier low levels. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 2.70 points to 2,587.84 at 11 a.m. EST. The blue-chip indicator was off 2.25 points an hour earlier but had fallen nearly 10 points in the interim. Declining issues outnumbered advancers by about 10 to 9 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 625 issues down, 588 up and 488 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 52.44 million shares. Wall Street analysts said concerns about interest rates weakened bond prices early in the day and dragged stocks lower. A report by the nation's purchasing executives suggesting the manufacturing sector weakened further in January might have contributed to a downward blip but was not having a sustained impact in early trading, analysts said. The National Association of Purchasing Management's index fell to 45.2 percent from 46.7 percent in December. A second report by the Commerce Department that construction spending fell 0.6 percent in December, also was having a minor impact in early dealings. ``I think the bad economic news is already built into the market,'' said Philip Puccio, managing director of equity trading for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Analysts also said Wednesday's rally, which ended a five-session decline, was not necessarily expected to carry the market higher today. ``Conditions are still bearish. As long as interest rates stay as high, investors are not going to rush into the market,'' said Brad Weeks, head of equity trading for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. ``We had a rally yesterday for technical reasons and technical reasons only.'' The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was down 0.30 to 181.20. At the American Stock Exchange the market value index was up 0.23 to 350.30. Among actively traded issues on the NYSE, Texaco was down \ to 58, AT&T was off [ to 38~, General Electric had slipped { to 61} and Great Western was down \ to 15{. Philip Morris moved up [ to 38, Compaq Computer had advanced 2] to 78[ and Boeing was up 1\ to 60{.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Edge Lower On Weather, Slack Exports
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices edged lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting improved crop weather and slack export demand for U.S. wheat. Rain was moving into U.S. corn and soybean areas today, which will help boost soil moisture reserves. Growing conditions also are continuing to improve in the South American soybean belt, where recent rains have relieved dryness in Argentina and Southern Brazil. Wheat is increasingly viewed as oversold and due for a rally. But the slow pace of wheat export sales is a drag on the market. In early trading, wheat futures were unchanged to 1{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $3.74\ a bushel; corn futures were unchanged to } cent lower with March at $2.38 a bushel; oats were \ cent to } cent lower with March at $1.34} a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to } cent lower with March at $5.60{ a bushel. Cattle futures were mostly higher while pork futures were mostly lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .05 cent lower to .12 cent higher with February at 79.30 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent lower to .10 cent higher with March at 82.62 cents a pound; live hogs were .30 cent lower to .05 cent higher with February at 48.55 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .27 cent to .70 cent lower with February at 49.75 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures fell across the board on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Former Chancellor Named To Barclays' Board
DOC.TEXT: Nigel Lawson, who resigned abruptly as Britain's top treasury official in October, has been named a director of Barclays Bank PLC, the bank said Thursday. His addition to the board is effective immediately and brings the number of directors to 25, 13 of whom are not executives of the bank. Lawson, who will continue as a Conservative Party member of Parliament, also will serve as a part-time adviser to the bank. Barclays declined to disclose how much he would be paid. Lawson, 57, told Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency, that the new position ``fits well with my plans to write a book and remain in politics.'' He resigned as chancellor of the exchequer Oct. 26, telling Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher that he couldn't continue as long as her economic adviser Sir Alan Walters remained. The two men had had public disputes about currency policy. Lawson had held the post for more than 6 years, making him one of Britain's longest-serving chancellors.

DOC.HEAD: Regulators Seize Arizona's Largest S&L
DOC.NOTE: EDS: RECASTS throughout to UPDATE with restructuring of debt completed; No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The government has taken control of MeraBank, Arizona's largest savings institution, in a taxpayer bailout which regulators said would be softened by a $450 million cash infusion from the thrift's parent. By coincidence, the seizure Wednesday occurred while officers of Pinnacle West Capital Corp. scrambled to rearrange the holding company's debt to accommodate extra borrowing for MeraBank. Agreements to restructure more than $650 million in debt with existing lenders were completed 15 minutes before Wednesday's midnight deadline, Pinnacle West executives said. ``It's a done deal; it's all over,'' said Keith Turley, Pinnacle West chairman and chief executive officer. ``Everything is signed, sealed and delivered.'' Turley said the agreement included provision for funds to meet Pinnacle West's obligation to give MeraBank a cash infusion of $450 million plus $12 million in accrued interest. He also said it avoids the possibility the holding company would have to wind up in bankruptcy court. MeraBank fell victim to the state's real-estate slump, said a lawyer for the Office of Thrift Supervision's regional office in San Francisco. ``Basically what they did was go heavily into some of the newer, riskier investments like construction loans and direct investments and land loans for development purposes ... (while) a number of S&Ls and banks were doing the same type of thing in Arizona,'' said Bill Black, the OTS district counsel. At the same time, Black said, Arizona's economy was beginning to slump. ``If you buy a lot and the demand falls, what has to happen to the price? It has to fall,'' he said. The OTS, a branch of the Treasury Department, determined that the thrift was operating in an unsafe manner, and the Resolution Trust Corp. took over, Black said. Regulators said all MeraBank branches will remain open for business as usual, operating under a new government-owned thrift called MeraBank Federal Savings Bank. Deposits will be insured up to $100,000 per account. Pinnacle West had been seeking a buyer for MeraBank and announced in December that it might have found one, but Henry B. Sargent Jr., the company's chief financial officer, said Wednesday that wasn't the case. ``We didn't have any prospects of selling MeraBank, but I think now that the federal government has taken over, they will have a prospect of selling it, and that is a possibility we've all considered for some time,'' Sargent said. Sargent said Pinnacle West would honor the agreement to inject $450 million into the thrift by March 31 even though it is in the government's hands. The money will not bring MeraBank close to its capital requirement, Black said. On Tuesday, Standard & Poor's downgraded the ratings of secured debt and bonds of Arizona Public Service Co., an electric utility which is Pinnacle West's only profitable subsidiary, and PacifiCorp of Portland, Ore., closed its Phoenix office. PacifiCorp offered to buy APS in November. On Dec. 1, it offered to buy Pinnacle West, minus MeraBank, and was rejected. Mike Nelson, PacifiCorp's director of financial planning, said he wasn't sure whether the takeover would spark renewed interest in Pinnacle West. ``We're still interested in entering into some sort of negotiations,'' Nelson said. MeraBank lost $209 million in 1988 and lost $190 million in the first three quarters of 1989. The extent of the red ink triggered fears by state utility regulators that Pinnacle West might sap the vigor of Arizona Public Service while trying to steady its staggering thrift. Marcia Weeks, chairman of the Arizona Corporation Commission, called the federal action ``a sad day for Arizona, but a big relief (for) the utility ratepayers.'' Under the debt restructuring agreement signed Wednesday, Turley said, Citibank, Chase Manhattan Bank, Chemical Bank and Morgan Guaranty Bank and Trust Co. went together to provide up to $312 million in interim financing to satisfy Pinnacle West's agreement with the OTC. The restructuring agreement includes $624 million of current debt and $52 million in letter-of-credit guarantees and other contingent obligations, Turley said. He said Wednesday's agreement extends original maturity dates by two years. As earlier, it also pledges APS common stock as security, Turley said. He said no APS asset is pledged and that the pledge won't affect APS. However, he also said the modified agreements restrict Pinnacle West's ability to incur new debt or make new investments. It also institutes certain financial tests that must be met if Pinnacle West were to pay cash dividends, and Turley said that made it unlikely for the foreseeable future that Pinnacle West will be able to pay any such dividend. Turley said having reached the debt restructuring agreement ``effectively eliminates the threat of a Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing,'' an action under which a company secures protection from its creditors while undergoing financial restructuring and continuing to operate. Black said the $450 million ``net-worth agreement'' wrung from Pinnacle West on Dec. 6 reduced the taxpayer cost of the MeraBank collapse far below the estimated $2 billion bailout of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif. The government took Lincoln away from American Continental Corp., another Phoenix-based holding company, last April. ``This is by far the largest recovery the government has been able to attain through a net-worth agreement,'' Black said. Pinnacle West bought Merabank for $426 million in December 1986, the year the state's real estate market hit the skids. At the end of last November, MeraBank was $337 million in the red and had about $4.5 billion in deposits in 833,000 accounts. Its $6.6 billion in assets placed it 29th nationally in a mid-1989 rating by Sheshunoff Information Services Inc., an Austin, Texas, consulting firm. MeraBank is the sixth Arizona S&L to be seized by the government, leaving only four operating privately. The second largest, Western Savings and Loan Association of Phoenix, was seized in June and put up for sale earlier this month. Kevin Shields, a spokesman for the RTC's Denver office, said it would take months to prepare Merabank for sale. MeraBank operates a subsidiary in El Paso, Texas, MeraBank Texas, which was a buyer in the 1988 government-assisted bailout of three Texas S&Ls. It got about $670 million from the government to acquire State Federal, Lubbock; First Financial, El Paso; and Brownfield Federal, Brownfield. The Texas thrifts, along with MeraBank's other holdings in the state, revert to the government's possession. MeraBank is the 32nd S&L failure so far this year. An additional 225 to 295 are likely to fail, compared with a record 328 last year and 223 in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Brady Urges Congressional Approval of Bush Savings Plan
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 8 grafs Brady testifying; picks up 5th graf pvs, bgng, In earlier ...
DOC.TEXT: Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady today urged Congress to adopt the president's proposed tax-free Family Savings Account as a way to boost America's competitive standing in global markets. Brady, appearing before the Senate Budget Committee to promote the tax aspects of the president's 1991 budget request, said the administration felt strongly that the new savings accounts, along with a proposed cut in the capital gains tax, would foster the long-term investment needed by U.S. businesses to stay competitive. ``An important goal for the 1990s is to increase the rate of growth of America's productive capacity,'' Brady said. ``More saving is needed to finance increases in our productive capacity. We believe that the federal government should foster an environment that is conducive to saving and we have a plan to achieve this objective.'' The Family Savings Account, which Bush mentioned in his State of the Union address, would allow an individual taxpayer to save up to $2,500 a year and a family to invest up to $5,000 a year with the money earning interest tax-free as long as it was held for at least seven years. The administration sees this proposal as the centerpiece of an effort to increase personal savings rates and thus expand the pool of money available for businesses to borrow to modernize production facilities. Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., however questioned both the savings proposal and the administration's renewed effort to cut the capital gains tax, saying that both measures would lose revenue at a time when the government was still facing massive federal deficits. Sasser said the Family Savings Account would provide only ``a minimal increase in private savings'' while costing the government tax revenues. Also appearing before the committee today was Michael Boskin, the president's chief economic adviser. Both Boskin and Brady defended the Bush budget against charges that it relied heavily on overly optimistic economic forecasts to reach the required deficit target for 1991. In earlier testimony before the House Budget Committee, Boskin said the economy is now going through a sluggish period, with economic growth _ as measured by the gross national product _ dropping to a barely perceptible 0.5 percent annual rate in the final three months of 1989. Boskin said that although he expects growth to pick up modestly in the first three months of this year, another quarter of growth below 1 percent is possible. Under the Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction law, two consecutive quarters of growth below 1 percent would require lawmakers to vote on suspending the deficit reduction targets for 1991. Boskin urged lawmakers not to do so, especially if the economy is showing signs of an imminent rebound. ``A suspension of Gramm-Rudman could have very unfavorable impacts on financial markets and cause interest rates to rise,'' Boskin said in testimony Wednesday. Budget Director Richard Darman denied the budget ignores the movement toward democracy in Eastern Europe, which many lawmakers view as requiring less Pentagon spending than the $292 billion proposed by the administration. ``The reality is that this is a budget which proposes a 2.6 percent real cut (in military spending after taking account of inflation) in the first year and a 2 percent real cut every year thereafter,'' Darman said. Robert D. Reischauer, head of the bipartisan Congressional Budget Office, said the CBO came up with a $37 billion higher deficit for the 1991 fiscal year than the Bush administration is assuming. CBO put the 1991 deficit at $138 billion without any changes in current policy, compared with the $101 billion claimed by the administration. Reischauer said more than two-thirds of the higher CBO figure, $26 billion, was a direct result of less optimistic forecasts on economic growth and interest rates. The other $11 billion came from higher expected spending for the savings and loan bailout and such programs as Medicare. Because of its assumptions, the administration needed just $37 billion in savings to meet the requirement of proposing a budget with a $64 billion deficit in the 1991 budget year, which starts in October, down from an expected deficit this year of $123.8 billion. But Reischauer said the CBO assumptions would double the amount of savings needed by the administration. Congress may adopt either the CBO estimate or the assumptions in the Bush budget in drawing up its own spending plan, but the administration's assumptions must be used later in the year in determining whether across-the-board spending cuts are needed to meet the deficit target.

DOC.HEAD: USX Changes Bylaws On Proxy Fights
DOC.TEXT: USX Corp. said today it has changed its bylaws to require advance notice of proxy fights, apparently in response to reports that Carl Icahn, the company's largest stockholder, may wage one. Charles A. Corry, chairman of the steel, oil and gas giant, said at a new conference he told Icahn about the bylaw change Wednesday. He declined to discuss Icahn's reaction. Icahn was in meetings today and not immediately available for comment, his secretary said. Icahn has long been unhappy with USX management and believes the company's stock price is too low. The takeover strategist, who also is chairman of Trans World Airlines, waged a proxy fight at Texaco Inc. two years ago because he was dissatisfied with that company's management. A Wall Street source, speaking on the condition of anonymity, has said Icahn was considering whether to take a similar step at USX. Corry said the company's board of directors unanimously approved an amendment to the company's bylaws, requiring anyone wanting to wage a proxy fight to inform the company at least 60 days prior to the next annual shareholders meeting. ``That is intended to prevent someone from raising havoc at the last moment,'' he said. The company's next annual shareholders meeting is set for May 7.

The stock market was drifting at slightly lower levels today, pressured by interest-rate worries and profit-taking. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 0.68 point to 2,589.86 at noon EST. The blue-chip indicator was off 2.70 points an hour earlier after falling nearly 10 points around mid-morning. Advancing and declining issues were nearly even on the New York Stock Exchange, with 679 issues down, 645 up and 471 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 73.73 million shares. Wall Street analysts said concerns about interest rates weakened bond prices early in the day and dragged stocks lower. A report by the nation's purchasing executives suggesting the manufacturing sector weakened further in January contributed to a downward blip but was not having a sustained impact in early trading, analysts said. The National Association of Purchasing Management's index fell to 45.2 percent from 46.7 percent in December. A second report by the Commerce Department that construction spending fell 0.6 percent in December, also was having a minor impact in early dealings. ``I think the bad economic news is already built into the market,'' said Philip Puccio, managing director of equity trading for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Analysts said despite Wednesday's surge, which ended a five-session decline, general business conditions remained bearish. ``As long as interest rates stay as high, investors are not going to rush into the market,'' said Brad Weeks, head of equity trading for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. ``We had a rally yesterday for technical reasons and technical reasons only.'' Profit-taking following Wednesday's rally also was pressuring stock prices, traders said. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was down 0.19 to 181.31. At the American Stock Exchange the market value index was up 0.47 to 350.54. Among actively traded issues on the NYSE, Texaco was down ] to 57~, AT&T was off [ to 38~, Texas Utilities was down \ to 33| and DuPont had lost ] to 37{. Philip Morris was \ higher at 38[, Compaq Computer was up 3{ to 79\ and IBM had gained { to 99[.

DOC.HEAD: Commission Considering Applying Anti-Monopoly Law to Foreign Firms
DOC.TEXT: Japan's Fair Trade Commission said Thursday its international committee was considering applying anti-monopoly regulations to all foreign companies whose business practices affect Japan. Japan's current anti-monopoly law applies only to Japanese companies and subsidiaries of foreign firms operating within Japan. Commission spokesman Kazutoshi Fujishiro said the commission's international committee was to report by mid-February on the feasibility of extending the law to other foreign companies. The 15-member committee was set up two years ago because of the increasingly global scale of business activities, he added. Fujishiro said small adjustments in some related laws and consultation with foreign countries would be needed to extend the the reach of Japan's anti-monopoly law beyond its borders. The newspaper Yomiuri Shimbun said the commission, a watchdog body to ensure fair business competition, would soon begin full-scale preparations for revision of the anti-monopoly law. The revision would indirectly contribute to bringing down the high prices of imported goods in Japan, it said. The paper said other nations also extend the reach of their anti-monopoly laws beyond national borders.

DOC.HEAD: Retailers Finish Fiscal Year on Modest Sales Note
DOC.TEXT: Major U.S. retailers today reported fair sales gains in January, with some having better luck than others clearing out leftover holiday merchandise. Sales at stores open at least a year rose around 5 percent industrywide from a year earlier, according to estimates by retail analysts. Chains specializing in apparel had the best growth while mass merchandisers, including the nation's two largest retailers, Sears, Roebuck and Co. and K mart Corp., tallied increases below the industry average. January is typically a slow time in the retailing trade and the month marks the end of the fiscal year for many merchants. Consumers usually have had their fill of spending at Christmas and some people enter the new year bearing credit card debts that discourage them from shopping for awhile. Widespread price cutting and other promotions this past holiday season _ particularly by debt-laden department stores desperate to raise cash _ may have left buyers more bloated than usual. Edward Johnson, a retail analyst at Prescott Ball & Turben Inc., said the first three weeks of January were sluggish for retailers as consumers nursed a bad case of post-Christmas spending blues. But shoppers began returning to stores in the last week of the month. The seasonally adjusted pace of sales quickened in the final week to about 8.5 percent from 4.8 percent in the first three weeks, he said. Jeffrey Edelman, of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., said retailers that had the leanest inventories due to brisk holiday business generally had the lowest January sales gains. The ones stuck with excess after Christmas pushed hard to move the merchandise to make room for spring lines and therefore posted higher sales results. Looking ahead, Jeffrey Feiner, a Merrill Lynch & Co. analyst, said an erosion in consumer confidence lately, reflecting uncertainty about economic conditions and weakness in financial markets, portends tougher times for retailers. ``Weakness in both the housing and financial markets makes the outlook for consumer spending in retail stores in our opinion likely to be quite sluggish, at least over the near term,'' Feiner said. The sales reports today were from general merchandise chains, department stores, specialty apparel retailers and others. Here are some of the results: Sears, the nation's biggest retailer, said sales rose 2.2 percent in the four weeks ended Jan. 27 to $2.17 billion from $2.12 billion a year earlier. Sales at stores open at least a year, called same- or comparable-store sales, rose 3.3 percent. Analysts and store executives attach greater significance to same-store tallies because the excitement of new store openings can inflate sales temporarily, providing distorted results. K mart, second in size to Sears, reported a 13.1 percent increase in sales to $1.79 billion from $1.58 billion but on a same-store basis sales were up 3.1 percent. No. 3-ranked Wal-Mart Stores Inc., which typically outperforms rival discounters, said sales grew 24 percent to $1.84 billion from $1.48 billion. Excluding newly opened stores, sales rose 10 percent. Among retailers concentrating on apparel, J.C. Penney Co. Inc. said sales increased 8.5 percent to $779 million from $718 mllion a year earlier. Same-store sales rose 7.3 percent. The specialty apparel retailer The Limited Inc. posted an 11 percent sales increase to $285.6 million from $256.7 million while sales grew 9 percent on a comparable store basis. The Gap Inc., another clothing specialist, said January sales surged 34 percent to $94 million from the year earlier's $70 million. Same-store sales jumped 24 percent. Dayton Hudson Corp., owner of department stores and the large Target discount chain, said January sales went up 12.2 percent to $711 million from $634 million. Sales at stores open at least a year rose 5.2 percent. Woolworth Corp., owner of F.W. Woolworth Co. stores plus numerous specialty retailers including the Foot Locker chain, said domestic January sales rose 8.5 percent to $283 million from $261 million. Domestic sales were up 4.5 percent at stores open for a year or more.

DOC.HEAD: Last-Minute Change Helps SCI Television Avoid Bankruptcy Protection
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 new grafs after 6th graf pvs, As the ... to UPDATE with new statement on exchange offer. Picks up 7th graf pvs, The company ...
DOC.TEXT: SCI Television Inc. avoided being placed under federal bankrupcty court protection after a judge in Delaware approved a last-minute change in the company's debt revision plan, a lawyer for SCI said. The company now faces a new deadline of Monday to complete a restructuring of its $1.3 billion debt. The Denver-based operator of six television stations, unable to meet interest payments on its debt, has been trying to get bondholders to accept stock and securities in exchange for their $507 million in outstanding bonds. As part of its planned debt restructuring, the company specified that certain minimum levels of each of three series of bonds must be tendered under its exchange offer. The requirement already had been met on two series of bonds, but SCI remained short of the minimum acceptance level of 87.5 percent for a third issue. The company faced a deadline of 4:30 p.m. EST Wednesday to certify that it had been tendered or promised at least 87.5 percent of its $100 million issue of 16{ percent senior subordinated debentures, or be placed under bankruptcy protection. As the deadline approached, SCI lawyer James L. Patton Jr. said the company requested that the minimum acceptance level be reduced to 85 percent, and the judge agreed. SCI was able to certify that it had met the reduced minimum. But in a statement today, the company said that a closer examination of the tenders and promises to tender showed that there had been some ``miscounts of tenders received and the non-tender of securities which SCI understood had been offered to be tendered'' and that it had been tendered only 83.2 percent of the bonds as of this morning. As a result, it said the court was informed and ``has taken no action to modify or rescind its previous orders.'' SCI said it was holding the exchange offer open until noon EST Friday in an effort to get the required 85 percent of the bonds. The company has been unable to generate enough cash to meet payments due on $1.3 billion in debt incurred when it was acquired in 1987 by the entrepreneur George Gillett and a group led by the buyout specialists Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. Gillett owns 55 percent of SCI while the Kohlberg group owns the rest. Under the debt restructuring plan, the bondholders will get a 39 percent equity stake in the company and bank lenders will get 5 percent. Gillett's stake will be trimmed to 41 percent and Kohlberg's stake to 15 percent. SCI Television operates stations WSBK in Boston, WJBK in Detroit, WJW in Cleveland, WAGA in Atlanta, KNSD in San Diego and WITI in Milwaukee.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at noon was 417.00 up 1.19 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Qantas, Japan Air Systems Order $1 Billion in Boeing Planes
DOC.TEXT: Boeing Co. picked up another $1 billion in business with jetliner orders from Japan Air System Co. and Qantas Airways. Japan Air System ordered four Boeing 747-400 jumbo jets and took options for four more, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group said Wednesday. Qantas ordered one 747-400 and four 767-300 widebody jets, worth about $560 million, including spare parts. The firm orders by JAS are worth more than $520 million, and the total package would be worth more than $1 billion if the options are exercised, Boeing said. The order represents the first placed with Boeing by JAS, Japan's third largest airline and formerly a domestic-only carrier. JAS will specify engine types at a later date. Qantas chose Rolls-Royce engines for its new 747 and General Electric engines for its 767s. So far this year customers have ordered 67 Boeing jetliners, valued at about $6 billion.

For release Monday Feb. 5
DOC.HEAD: Korea's Overseas Construction Eyes Middle East, Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: The overseas construction industry, once dubbed South Korea's ``golden goose,'' is gambling that new markets in Arab and communist nations will help it overcome a long slump. South Korean contractors, unfazed by political and regional differences with their homeland, are eyeing postwar reconstruction projects in Iran and Iraq, expanding business in Libya and starting projects in the Soviet Union and other socialist nations. They're even considering a cooperative venture in Siberia that would employ workers from South Korea's archenemy, communist North Korea. ``Finally, we seem to be coming out of a long tunnel of recession,'' said Choi Jae-yol, a government economic researcher, referring to a surge in South Korean overseas construction. In the past two decades, domestic contractors have won $90 billion worth of contracts overseas, earning foreign currency needed for the country's economic development. But in recent years, South Korea's overseas construction declined severely. Volume of contracts nosedived from an all-time high of $13.7 billion in 1981 to $1.6 billion in 1988. Overseas construction volume began to pick up last year, reaching $2.4 billion, and officials expect business in 1990 to top $7.7 billion, some of it in socialist and communist nations. South Koreans are expanding their business from labor-intensive civil engineering to technology-oriented projects such as powerplants but they still rely heavily on cheap labor. South Korean contractors abroad hire help from Bangladesh, Thailand, the Philippines and other Third World Asian nations. At the end of 1989, 42,000 foreigners were on Korean payrolls abroad, compared with 24,000 Korean overseas construction workers. The South Koreans are paid roughly $875 a month while other foreign workers earn only one-third of that amount, a price edge companies say is necessary for them to remain competitive. Officials say Libya will emerge as South Korea's largest market in 1990 with $5.7 billion of contracts, followed by Saudi Arabia with $820 million and Iran with $422 million. Last September, Libya picked up Dong-A Construction Co. of Seoul as a prime contractor for a $5.3 billion water project. A formal contract for the project, the largest awarded a South Korean firm, will be signed this year. South Koreans received nearly 80 percent of their overseas contracts in the oil-rich Middle East in the past, but Saudi Arabia and other Arab nations scaled down development revenues as prices for their oil dropped. Choi, who works for the government-controlled Overseas Construction Association, said the recovery pace of South Korea's overseas construction business depends partly on the ability to snare multibillion dollar rehabilitation projects in Iran and Iraq. South Korea is one of the few countrie able to do business with both Iran and Iraq. During the eight-year Persian Gulf War, South Korea maneuvered to stay neutral between the two. Iran sought South Korean assistance in getting U.S.-made jet parts for its air force but the Seoul government rejected the request, citing its neutral foreign policy. Iran retaliated by downgrading its ties with Seoul to a charge d'affairs but restored full ties with Seoul after the ceasefire. South Korea's rejection of Iran's request helped it open ties with Iraq, with which Seoul had no diplomatic relations. South Korea now maintains diplomatic relations with both Arab nations. Kim Sung-jo, a director-general in the Construction Ministry, said South Korean business in the region would increase as the two Arab nations push reabilitation projects. Several South Korean companies have sent teams of experts to Tehran to inspect a major petrochemical project at Bandar Khomeini in southern Iran, abandoned by Japan's Mitsui Corp. Iran officially asked South Korea to finish construction after the Japanese conglomerate decided the plant was too damaged by the war to be completed. The Iranian project was 85 percent completed before the war broke out in 1980 and was originally estimated in 1973 to cost $358 million. By 1981, the cost had swelled to $4.48 billion. Government sources, who asked not to be identified, said Iran is seeking a $3 billion loan from South Korea to complete construction. South Korean companies also are pursuing projects in the Soviet Union and other socialist countries, with which their anti-communist government is improving relations. Seoul has opened full diplomtic relations with Hungary, Poland, Yugoslavia and Algeria and established de facto consular ties with the Soviet Union in the last 12 months. The Daewoo group, one of the largest Korean conglomerates, is pushing hotel projects in Budapest and Moscow. Another conglomerate, the Hyundai group, has recently signed a 30-year contract to develop forest land in eastern Siberia. With approval from the Seoul government, Hyundai plans to hire hundreds of communist North Korean workers for its develpment projects in Siberia.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Monday, Feb. 5

DOC.HEAD: W.R. Grace Reports Earnings
DOC.TEXT: W.R. Grace & Co. on Thursday reported profits for the final quarter and all of 1989 rose more than 8 percent, with the company's core specialty chemicals operations putting in a strong performance. For the quarter ended Dec. 31, net income totaled $81.8 million, or 96 cents a share, up 8.3 percent from $75.5 million, or 88 cents a share in the previous quarter. Revenue came to $1.72 billion, up 4.1 percent from $1.65 billion a year earlier. Income from continuing operations jumped 50 percent to $83.4 million, from $55.5 million a year ago. During the quarter, Grace benefited from a lower tax effective rate partly due to a reduction in foreign taxes. For the full year, Grace reported net income of $253.2 million, or $2.97 a share, up 8.4 percent from $233.6 million, or $2.75 a share. Revenue amounted to $6.11 billion, up 5.7 percent from $5.79 billion in 1988. Income from continuing operations rose 34 percent, from $192.1 million to $256.6 million. Grace Specialty Chemicals Co. showed strong gains, partly due to continued growth of the company's worldwide packaging business and strong results in water treatment activities and specialty electronics materials, the company said. Grace Specialty Chemicals accounts for more than half of W.R. Grace's total sales and is the focus of its investment strategy. Specialty chemical operations received about 60 percent of $485 million Grace earmarked for capital expenditures. The company cited significantly higher results from the Pacific Rim area, which Grace predicted will continue to provide ``higher-than-averaged growth rates in the future.'' W.R. Grace also reported gains in its energy, specialty businesses and health care groups. However, the company was adversely affected in the final quarter and the full year by foreign currency translations.

For release Sunday Feb. 4
DOC.HEAD: When Loeb Lays It on The Line, Retailers, Investors Take Notice
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Walter Loeb grew up in a European merchant's family, spent two decades working for big U.S. department stores and won acclaim as the dean of retail securities analysts on Wall Street. He's retiring, but not really. ``I'm calling it a graduation,'' he said.``I don't want to stop. I want to keep going.'' The new career the silver-haired, bespectacled Loeb is starting at age 65 will be as a private consultant and newsletter publisher in a realm in which he is considered an elder statesman. One of the hot topics as he peers into the future is the prospect for global expansion by retailers. Shifting political winds traversing Eastern Europe and plans for greater harmony among European Community countries in 1992 could be a stroke of good fortune for forward-thinking outsiders. ``If retailers don't think ahead they will not have the opportunity because others will do it,'' he said. ``I think that unless we get ready it will not ever happen.'' Some prominent merchants have shown it can be done, he said. They include Toys R Us Inc., The Gap Inc., England's Laura Ashley Holdings PLC and Italy's Benetton Group. ``There are many examples of companies that have been able to do a global distribution of merchandise and I think that this will be the case more so in the 1990s,'' he said. Loeb's trans-national vision reflects is own immigrant background. He speaks English, French, German, Italian and Spanish. ``I think it's a very exciting new topic,'' he said in an interview as he was preparing to leave Morgan Stanley & Co., launch Loeb Associates and start a a monthly newsletter. Stores supplying staples that transcend cultural differences should have the easiest time venturing from home turf. The giant toy discounter Toys R Us is one of the best examples. ``Toys are toys. Kids are kids and grandparents are grandparents,'' Loeb said. With retailers worldwide looking toward European expansion, he said, the value of American properties currently for sale has fallen because the siren song of foreign markets has diverted investor attention. For instance, Loeb said the debt-encumbered Allied Stores Corp. and Federated Department Stores Inc. chains owned by Canada's Campeau Corp., which are trying to solve their financial problems in bankruptcy court, may not fetch as much as they might have if they were auctioned. Loeb said many widely publicized predicaments in retailing were caused by brash developers with no merchandising expertise. The financial drain of building retail operations, largely with borrowed money, overshadowed the core business of selling goods. ``I'm sad about developments that have been caused by developers. I believe very strongly that merchants should be running the retail businesses,'' Loeb said. ``It's not a science but it is also not easy to be a good merchant.'' After the shakeout, more stores will be back in the hands of retailers, Loeb predicted. ``Tomorrow some of these companies will again be smaller entities,'' he said. ``Entrepreneurs will run them _ maybe with high debt _ but they will be run on an entrepreneurial basis and several will be very successful as a result.'' Even exemplary retailers will have to adapt in the 1990s as consumers save more, spend less and redirect dollars toward housewares and home improvement. ``I think the consumer is going to be very conservative,'' Loeb said. Stores appealing to do-it-yourselfers stand to flourish while specialty apparel retailers _ which had been gobbling up market share from traditional department stores _ will have a tougher time, he said. Personally, Loeb said he frequents discounters because, like any savvy consumer, he likes a good bargain. But he patronizes specialty apparel stores when shopping for suits. ``I like the service. I like the attention and I like the quality of the tailoring,'' he said. Friends and acquaintances describe Loeb as loyal and self-effacing, with a ready sense of humor. He takes obvious pride in the accomplishments of his three adult daughters and of his wife of 31 years, Phyllis. Professional contacts admire his keen judgment and ferocious appetite for work. ``Underneath an affable exterior he is Germanic in work habits,'' said Isaac Lagnado, director of research at the International Council of Shopping Centers. Loeb was born Jan. 28, 1925 near Frankfurt. His father, Karl, a successful button wholesaler, moved his family and business to Italy in 1936 when Nazi Germany was in the throes of anti-Semitic political upheaval. The Loebs left Italy in 1939 for America. They relocated in Cuba for 18 months while awaiting entry into this country, where the elder Loeb established himself as a wholesaler of costume jewelry. Walter Loeb was drafted into the Army in 1943 and participated in the Normandy invasion. He was at Utah beach on D-Day. Upon his return to the United States, he studied marketing and history at New York University and graduated in 1949. He spent 20 years learning the retail business from the inside. He worked at an arm of what is now R.H. Macy & Co., at May Department Stores Co. and at Allied Stores Corp. Loeb turned to consulting in 1969, then came to Wall Street in 1972 as an analyst with the Johnson Redbook Service. He joined Morgan Stanley in 1974 as a senior analyst,was named a vice president in 1980 and a principal of the firm in 1984. Dubbed the Dean of Wall Street retail analysts by industry insiders, Loeb also has won recognition internationally. The French newspaper Le Monde, in a 1988 article on a speech Loeb made in Paris, referred to him somewhat irreverently as ``the pope of business.'' Experience in retailing has helped Loeb cultivate a rapport with store executives that few in his field enjoy. It also endowed him with special influence among institutional investors he has advised. ``I did everything that one does as you grow up in this business,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: End of Adv for Sunday, Feb. 4.

DOC.HEAD: Post-it Notes 10 Years Old
DOC.TEXT: It was in 1974 that 3M scientist Art Fry, sitting through a boring church sermon, concocted the idea of self-sticking, yellow notes that can be removed without a trace, for use in his choir hymn books. But it took him four years to convince superiors at 3M that this idea would sell commercially. Two years later, in April 1980, Post-it notes premiered, and America has been stuck on them since. ``Initial enthusiasm for a piece of note paper with adhesive on the back wasn't overwhelming,'' Fry said of his battle to persuade superiors. ``It was hard to sell the concept that people needed a note pad that would sell at a premium price comparscratch paper.'' Now, a decade after the product hit the market, many Americans wonder how they got along without the yelled to ordinary ow squares they stick to reports, folders, desks, computers, telephones and refrigerators. 3M started with two sizes of Post-it notes: 3 inches by 5 inches and 1{ by 2, available only in yellow. Today, the company says it has more than 350 varieties, a range of different sizes and colors, plus many with cartoon characters and messages. There are Post-it notes specifically made for taking phone messages, marking book pages and identifying material to be faxed. C $0.39

DOC.HEAD: Posts Sharp Decline in 4th Qtr Profit
DOC.TEXT: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., the nation's largest bottler of Coca-Cola products, said Thursday its fourth-quarter profit tumbled 88.5 percent from results a year ago that included a big gain on the sale of assets. Coca-Cola Enterprises, which is 49 percent owned by Coca-Cola Co., said it earned $6.75 million, or 2 cents a share, in the three months ended Dec. 31 compared with $58.8 million, or 40 cents a share, a year earlier. The 1988 results included a one-time gain of 43 cents a share on the sale of the Coca-Cola Bottling Co. of Mid-America and restructuring charges of 11 cents per share. The net result was that one-time items lifted earnings by 32 cents a share. Fourth-quarter revenue rose 1.9 percent to $911.8 million from $895.2 million in 1988. For the year, Coca-Cola Enterprises said it earned $71.7 million, or 41 cents per share, in 1989, down 53 percent from $152.6 million, or $1.03 a share, a year earlier. Full-year revenue inched up to $3.88 billion from $3.87 billion. ``Although 1989 was a disappointing year in terms of financial results, we believe it will prove to be an important year in CCE's development,'' said Brian G. Dyson, president and chief executive officer. ``We expect operating cash flow and earnings per common share to increase in 1990.'' The company has operations across the country, and claims it handles 43 percent to 44 percent of all Coco-Cola sold in bottles in cans in the United States.

Stock prices were slightly higher this afternoon, as trading activity slowed from earlier levels. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 2.25 points at 2,592.79 at 2 p.m. EST. The blue-chip indicator was off 0.68 point at noon after dipping nearly 10 points around mid-morning. Advancing issues lead decliners by a margin of about 9 to 8 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 801 issues up, 642 down and 452 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 111.12 million shares. Wall Street analysts said the market was wavering, with little sense of direction and with many institutional investors on the sidelines. Earlier, concerns about interest rates weakened bond prices and dragged stocks lower. A report by the nation's purchasing executives suggesting the manufacturing sector weakened further in January contributed to a downward blip early in the day but did not have a sustained impact, analysts said. The National Association of Purchasing Management's index fell to 45.2 percent from 46.7 percent in December. A second report by the Commerce Department that construction spending fell 0.6 percent in December, also had a minor impact. ``I think the bad economic news is already built into the market,'' said Philip Puccio, managing director of equity trading for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Analysts said despite Wednesday's surge, which ended a five-session decline, general business conditions remained bearish and investors were remaining noncommital ahead of next week's Treasury refunding. ``As long as interest rates stay as high, investors are not going to rush into the market,'' said Brad Weeks, head of equity trading for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. ``We had a rally yesterday for technical reasons and technical reasons only.'' Some investors also were looking to Friday's report on January unemployment to provide further clues to the economy's direction. DOC.HEAD: Grumman Earnings Down 39 Percent in Fourth Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Grumman Corp. on Thursday reported a sharp drop in earnings for the 1989 fourth quarter and year, in part because of lower sales in its aerospace and electronics sectors. In a statement, the company said it planned to reduce its work force by about 1,000 by the end of 1990, following 3,000 cuts in 1989 that left the defense contractor with 28,900 employees. An imminent decline in defense spending by the federal government because of easing East-West tensions has been blamed for a poor outlook for the defense industry. For the period ended Dec. 31, Grumman said profits dropped 39 percent to $14.8 million, or 41 cents a share, from $24.1 million, or 70 cents a share, in the same 1988 period. Sales for the quarter fell 16 percent to $867 million from $1.04 million. For the full year, net income was $67.3 million, or $1.91 a share, down 22 percent from $86.5 million, or $2.50 a share, in 1988. Sales declined 2.5 percent to $3.56 billion from $3.65 billion. Grumman said sales from its aerospace division fell 5.8 percent because of winding down of two development programs and delivery of fewer production aircraft to the Navy. Grumman's electronics sales declined 13.3 percent because of fewer test equipment deliveries, reduced requirements for Grumman aircraft and lower revenue from an Air Force and Army joint radar program. ``Even in a no-growth defense budget cycle, there will be plenty of business for Grumman and others who are efficient, reliable suppliers of quality products,'' Grumman Chairman John O'Brien said in a statement. The statement said Grumman has a backlog of $6.9 billion, while the proposed 1991 defense budget funds Grumman programs at $2.65 billion, about the same as in 1990.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Production Goes Down This Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 179,913 cars and light trucks this week, down from last week's 194,953, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is lower than the same week a year ago, in which 249,649 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 109,440 cars this week, compared with 117,646 a week ago and 155,382 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 70,473, compared with last week's 77,307 and last year's 94,267. Canadian automakers were to build 24,440 cars this week, up from 18,103 a week ago and up from last year's 20,509. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 16,624, compared with 16,781 a week ago and 21,679 in the same week last year.
