DOC.HEAD: Construction Spending at Slowest Pace in 1989 Since Last Recession
DOC.NOTE: EDS: ADDS new grafs 8-9 to UPDATE with concerns about new S&L bailout law's effects on spending; picks up 8th graf pvs bg'ng, Analysts point ...
DOC.TEXT: Construction spending advanced last year at its slowest pace since the 1982 recession, the government said Thursday. Analysts blamed the weakness on high interest rates, overbuilding and a sluggish economy. The Commerce Department said residential, non-residential and government construction spending totaled $414.7 billion, a 1.2 percent increase over 1988 but the smallest gain since a 5.1 percent decline in 1982. Contributing to the poor showing was a 0.6 percent decline in December spending, which was buffeted by record cold weather over most of the country east of the Rockies. Spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $414.6 billion in December, nearly erasing a 0.7 percent gain in November. It was the lowest one-month increase since a decline of 1 percent last June. Analysts said Federal Reserve actions that kept interest rates relatively high through most of the year not only made construction more expensive, but also slowed the economy and thus made sales more difficult. ``Plus, you had a number of good years of construction'' leading up to 1989, said David Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association. ``Eventually, you have all the houses and office buildings that you need. You run out of pent-up demand.'' Because of the lessening demand and the state of the economy, Berson said, ``1990, at best, will be about what it was in 1989 and could even fall a little bit.'' Another factor beginning to worry builders and analysts alike is the adverse effect of the savings and loan bailout law on the availability of construction financing. ``The law limits the amount that savings and loans can lend to any one construction company,'' said economist Steven Cochran of WEFA Group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa., who added that efforts are under way to resolve the problem. Analysts point to widespread vacancies in office buildings as evidence of overbuilding in the non-residential sector, which continued to grow last year. Non-residential spending was up 2.4 percent to $99.4 billion in 1989 and 4.3 percent to an annual rate of $96.7 billion in December. Residential spending, representing 50 percent of construction spending, was off 1.1 percent to $195.9 billion last year and down 0.7 percent in December to an annual rate of $191 billion. But single-family construction picked up 0.4 percent to an annual rate of $144.3 billion in December, the third straight advance after falling for eight months. Multi-family spending, which has fallen every month since July, was down 2.8 percent to a $20.6 billion annual rate. The usually volatile government sector rose 3.8 percent to $84 billion in 1989 and 2.9 percent to a $91.1 billion annual rate in December, when it was boosted by a 9.3 percent gain in highway and street projects. Government projects account for about 20 percent of construction spending.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Finish Slightly Higher
DOC.NOTE: EDS: RECASTS throughout to UPDATE with later activity, closing indices; No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Shares finished slightly higher after a dull session Thursday on London's Stock Exchange. At the London close, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 8.5 points, or 0.4 percent, at 2,345.8, just above its session low of 2,343.6. At its highest, the index briefly touched 2,355.4 points. Volume totaled 470.5 million shares, down from 574.9 million on Wednesday. Although shares were buoyed at the outset by Wall Street's robust performance Wednesday, any support for the market was withdrawn at midafternoon following an unconvincing start from New York stocks. ``The London market wants to go higher but we're uncertain over Wall Street,'' said one chief dealer. ``We're seeing many institutions checking prices, but they aren't going to order any stocks until they're convinced that Wall Street has stabilized.'' Several market watchers said a computer-driven trade at midafternoon, weighted heavily to the sell side, drove shares down from session peaks. Others said a disappointment with the early direction of the Dow Jones industrial average on Wall Street undermined the London market. By the end of the London day, the Dow Jones average was down 2.25 points at 2,588.29. In London, the Financial Times 30-share index was up 2.0 points at 1,866.0. The Financial Times 500-share index closed at 1,272.49, up 3.19 points.

DOC.HEAD: Livestock Producers Say Woolite Even Works When Wool's Still on Sheep
DOC.TEXT: You probaby won't see any commercials about it soon, but some livestock producers say they turn to Woolite to brighten up their sheep for competition. ``It's designed for wool, and they're wool,'' said Marshall Eaton as he was blow-drying a lamb recently at the 94th Southwestern Exposition and Livestock Show and Rodeo. ``We used to use Mrs. Stewart's Bluing, what your grandmother used,'' said Eaton, an agriculture teacher at Tuscola in West Texas. ``I guess people switched over at least 10 years ago, whenever Woolite came out.'' The household wool cleaner was among a number of well-known products used to help Junior Lamb Show entrants look their best, the Fort Worth Star-Telegram found. The newspaper said it found used bottles of Woolite and Ivory, Palmolive and Dawn dishwashing liquids among the containers discarded in the Sheep Barn washing area. Guy Reinarz, of New Braunfels, said he first uses a stronger soap on his sheep and ``then I go back with Woolite. It seems to leave the wool a lot softer.'' There is nothing to indicate on the product's label that Woolite can turn dingy gray Rambouillet lambs into sparkling white show creatures. ``Trust Woolite _ no shrinking, stretching, fading,'' it says. It also notes it works on ``all your fine washables ... of silk, wool, cashmere, cotton, polyester...'' But Bill McClaran, of Granbury, said he prefers Palmolive for whitening those dingy lambs. ``When you run out of Palmolive, you use Woolite,'' McClaran said. Regardless of what brand they use, livestock producers agree that it is extremely important to have lambs' coats looking their brightest when they are led before the sharp-eyed judges. Said Eaton, ``It's a little bit of a beauty contest.''
The stock market was slightly higher in late afternoon trading. About five minutes before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 0.90 point to 2,591.44.

After hitting lows at mid-morning, stocks rebounded slightly then drifted in a narrow range the remainder of the session. Analysts said despite Wednesday's surge, which ended a five-session decline, general business conditions remained bearish and investors were remaining noncommital ahead of Friday's unemployment report and next week's Treasury refunding. ``As long as interest rates stay as high, investors are not going to rush into the market,'' said Brad Weeks, head of equity trading for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. ``We had a rally yesterday for technical reasons and technical reasons only.''

DOC.HEAD: Economy Declined Sharply in January, Purchasing Group Says
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. economy fell sharply in January for the ninth consecutive month and at the greatest rate of decline since the last recession, the nation's purchasing managers said Thursday in a widely watched survey. The monthly report, which substantiated other evidence of an economic slowdown, contributed to a downward blip in stock trading early in the day but it didn't last, analysts said. It had little effect on bond trading. David Wyss, an economist for the forecasting firm DRI-McGraw-Hill Inc., said the financial markets were ``too busy worrying about the State of the Union address last night.'' The markets were preoccupied with the implications of President Bush's proposals Wednesday night for troop reductions in Europe, which could lead to a lower federal deficit and, in turn, lower interest rates, Wyss said. Alan Levenson, an economist for Salomon Brothers Inc., said the purchasing survey result was about what the markets expected, so the reaction was not unusual. The National Association of Purchasing Management said its monthly index fell in January to 45.2 percent, down from 46.7 percent in December. A reading below 50 indicates that the U.S. manufacturing economy is declining, while above 50 indicates expansion, the group said. The index has been below 50 for the past nine months. The figures were adjusted to reflect an update of the seasonal adjustment factors of the U.S. Commerce Department that are used to calculate the index. ``It confirms what we've been saying and what's been obvious for a while, which is that the economy is slowing down rather dramatically,'' Wyss said. ``But we don't see signs of recession.'' Wyss pointed out that a key part of the survey, supplier deliveries, was up in January, to 47.2 percent from 42.5 percent in December. The figure shows how fast companies receive goods they order; an increase means supplier companies are operating at a higher capacity. Wyss said this figure is important because it is a component of the Commerce Department's monthly leading indicators, the government's chief economic forecasting gauge. However, the purchasing group attributed the increase to fewer weather-related delays in producing and transporting goods. The group's new export orders figure also continued to show relative strength, said the group, based in Tempe, Ariz. The seasonally unadjusted export orders index increased to 55.5 percent from 53 percent in December. The new orders portion of the group's survey fell significantly in January, the employment component declined for the 11th consecutive month and the inventories index was the lowest since 1986. ``The manufacturing economy entered 1990 on a dismal note,'' said Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the group's survey committee. He said it was the greatest rate of decline since December 1982, when the nation was starting to pull out of the last recession. He said the group's overall monthly index averaged 48.9 percent for all of 1989. That figure is consistent with real gross national product growth of about 2.2 percent after adding 0.6 percent to reflect the rebound in agricultural output last year from the 1988 drought, he said. Bretz said the index would have to fall below 44 percent before it indicates a decline in real GNP. Doug Handler, an economist for Dun & Bradstreet Corp., said the report was weaker than he expected, but that other recent statistics show the economy's manufacturing sector is ``bottoming out in general.'' The survey is based on responses from executives who buy goods at more than 300 industrial companies.

DOC.HEAD: 4th-Qtr Profit Up at Gannett, Knight-Ridder; Loss at McGraw-Hill
DOC.TEXT: Gannett Co. Inc. reported Thursday its profit rose 8.1 percent in the fourth quarter while another media giant, Knight-Ridder Inc., posted a 31.2 percent increase in earnings from continuing operations for the same period. Meanwhile, McGraw-Hill Inc. reported a loss of $98.3 million for the quarter as a result of previously disclosed plans to take unusual charges. Gannett said its earnings increased despite a weakening economy partly because of the diversity of its holdings. The Arlington, Va.-based company, which publishes USA Today and 81 other daily newspapers, said it earned $127.4 million, or 79 cents a share, in the three months ended Dec. 31 compared with $117.8 million, or 73 cents a share, a year earlier. Fourth-quarter revenue rose 7 percent to $968.6 million from $905.3 million a year earlier. For the year, Gannett earned $397.5 million, or $2.47 a share, up 9.3 percent from $364.5 million, or $2.26 a share, a year earlier. Operating revenue rose 6 percent to $3.52 billion from $3.31 billion a year earlier. The company said the latest results reflected a gain on the sale of The New Mexican in Santa Fe, N.M., that was offset by operating losses of GTG Entertainment and costs associated with its plan to end its involvement with GTG ventures, which produced an ill-fated television show ``USA Today on TV.'' The company said advertising revenue from USA Today rose 13 percent for the quarter. It did not report earnings results from the newspaper, but spokeswoman Sheila Gibbons said it had a unspecified loss. She said the newspaper expects to post its first annual profit in 1990. Gannett's operations also include 35 non-daily newspapers, 10 television stations and 16 radio stations. Knight-Ridder, based in Miami, said its earnings from continuing operations rose to $55.1 million, or $1.05 a share, up from $42.0 million, or 76 cents a share, a year earlier. Fourth-quarter revenue rose 5.8 percent to $607.8 million from $574.7 million a year earlier. For the year, the newspaper and information services company said its eanings from continuing operations rose to $179.8 million, or $3.43 a share, up from $146.8 million, or $2.59 a share, a year earlier. The 1989 results include a gain of about $30 million from the sale of a Pasadena, Calif., newspaper. Revenue for the year rose 8.9 percent to $2.27 billion from $2.08 billion a year earlier. ``Our newspapers showed substantial profit and margin increases thanks to improvements in Miami and weaker newsprint prices,'' said Robert F. Singleton, chief financial officer at Knight-Ridder. Knight-Ridder owns 29 daily newspapers, including the Miami Herald, Philadelphia Inquirer, Detroit Free Press and San Jose (Calif.) Mercury News, and operates a growing business information services division. New York-based McGraw-Hill said its fourth-quarter loss was $2.01 a share in contrast to earnings of $55 million, or $1.13 a share, a year earlier. The latest loss reflects a charge of $152 million after taxes reflecting a realignment of operations, writedowns associated with its Data Resources and other units, the shutdown of its general books unit and reserves for severance payments associated with staff reductions of more than 1,000 positions. The company said in December that it planned to make those charges against its fourth-quarter earnings. Fourth-quarter revenue rose 8.2 percent to $518 million from $479 million a year earlier. For the year, McGraw-Hill said it earned $47.8 million, or 98 cents a share, down from $185.5 million, or $3.83 a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the year rose 6.9 percent to $1.79 billion from $1.67 billion a year earlier. The company said fourth-quarter results from educational and professional publishing benefited from the performances of college publishing, legal and international book businesses. It said Business Week magazine had a strong performance, and its financial services operations continued to show improvement depsite an operating loss at its Data Resources unit and consolidation in the brokerage industry. Its school publishing venture with Macmillan had an operating loss for the quarter, which is seasonally weak. Joseph L. Dionne, chairman and chief executive of McGraw-Hill, said he expects the company to earn $3.50 to $4 a share excluding non-recurring gains in 1990.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Really Aren't Savers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `That wasn't ...' to CORRECT year to 1974 sted 1973.
DOC.TEXT: In seeking to entice Americans to save more money, the White House is tackling a job that has been an overwhelming challenge to other American institutions, including motherhood. It begins with parents exhorting youngsters to put pennies in a piggy bank. The lesson is developed throughout schooling. The challenge is then taken on by banks, by companies with payroll savings plans and by others. To some degree, all have failed, which is why the Bush administration now wants to attack the problem with tax enticements, promising not to levy a penny against certain savings accounts left to build and age. Savings, it is sometimes contended, are the reason the Japanese have gained such economic prominence. Their high savings rate _ 15 percent to 20 percent of income, sometimes more _ finances swift industrial expansion. But using the Japanese as a model _ or European nations which recently have saved at a rate double that of Americans _ might not work. Americans are very different people with very different habits and approaches to life. In the past 60 years, the only time in which the American savings rate came close to recent Japanese levels was when, literally, they were forced to save during World War II. Payrolls were big, but there was little to buy. At the time, some officials thought they had stumbled on a truth _ that savings bonds issued by the government and carrying the full faith and credit of Uncle Sam had something to do with it. But the program faded after the war. The savings binge ended, in fact, with the war. In the five years 1941-1945, the rate averaged better than 20 percent. In 1946, it dived to 8.5 percent, and the following year to 3.1 percent, lower than the current level. Except for those years, there has never been a double-digit savings rate _ the amount saved as a percent of disposable or after-tax income. The rate has moved up and down, but the highest was 9.4 percent in 1973. Moreover, the reasons for fluctuations aren't entirely clear. Some of the evidence even contradicts pet theories, such as that economic stability encourages savings. That wasn't true in the early 1970s, when inflation ran wild. On average the first six years of that decade had the highest savings rate of any similar since the 1940s. In 1974 the rate reached 9.3 percent, inflation 10 percent. That is, the second highest one-year savings rate since World War II was accompanied by the first double-digit inflation rate in modern times. It was a tragedy for savers, since inflation exceeded the rate of interest earned. It was in the early 1980s that concern steadily mounted. In 1983, the rate dipped to just 5.4 percent, and to 4.4 percent in 1985, and from then until last year it remained under 5 percent. That decline is now seized upon by those who link it to the rise in federal budget deficits. They could be correct. In fact, when evidence developed last year that it was possible to cut the deficit, the rate rose above 5 percent. While the budget-deficit link might seem a strong one, there is another school of thought. Economist Edward Yardeni and others see a connection with an entirely different set of figures, demographic ones. According to them, the reason for low savings rates since the early and mid-1980s is the bulge of younger people working its way through the economy. As these people get older and put their big-spending years behind them, says Yardeni, they will become savers, content to sit on the couch and watch television instead of renting cars for ski weekends and other entertainment. There are still more theories. One thesis is that Americans have pensions, Social Security and large equity in homes, and so have a sense of security that allows them to forego ``saving,'' as narrowly defined. Another: Why save if inflation is just going to wipe it out? Another: In view of recent shenanigans, why entrust savings to banks and savings and loan associations that will only spend it their way? One more: Who has money to save?

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Up
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended Jan. 22, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,226.5 billion from $3,217.5 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,044.2 billion from $4,038.8 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $794.1 billion from $791.2 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,207.0 billion, a 7.3 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of increase from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,033.4 billion, up 3.1 percent, while M1 rose 6.0 percent to an average of $793.0 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $813 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $348 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $303.7 billion billion in the two-week period ended Jan. 24, up from $299.4 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Compaq's Profit Drops for Quarter, Rises for Year
DOC.TEXT: Compaq Computer Corp., which has delayed distribution of its latest desktop computer because of a faulty chip, said Thursday its quarterly profit slipped for only the second time in its eight-year history. For the three-month period ended Dec. 31, the Houston-based maker of personal computers had earnings of $79.05 million, or $1.84 per share, down 14 percent from $91.91 million, or $2.18 per share, during the same quarter in 1988. Sales totaled $788.14 million, up 18 percent from $667.67 million in 1988's fourth quarter. Compaq, which took just four years to become a Fortune 500 company, last posted a year-to-year decline in quarterly earnings in the third quarter of 1984, when profits were $1.8 million compared with $3.8 million in the 1983 period. Compaq said in November it expected its fourth-quarter profit to be off because it detected a fault in an Intel Corp. chip, causing delays in distributing new products, said Mike Swavely, president of the company's North American division. Engineers found a way to work with the chips several months ago, but Intel contacted Compaq last week saying there was another problem. The company said it had planned to ship its new Deskpro 486-25 computer Feb. 1, but the date was set back due to the new trouble. Swavely said the model should be distributed during the current quarter. Compaq also blamed the profit drop to a near-doubling of fourth-quarter research and development costs to $38 million, increased costs associated with new-product introductions, and to a softening U.S. market for personal computers. For all of 1989, Compaq reported earnings of $333.3 million, or $7.77 per share, up 31 percent from $255.2 million, or $6.30 per share, in 1988. Sales totaled $2.87 billion, up 39 percent from the $2.1 billion in 1988. President Rod Canion said the introduction of new products contributed to the company's success in 1989. Besides the delayed DeskPro 486-25, the company introduced two new desktop computers and notebook-sized laptop computers. Sales outside North America contributed 46 percent of Compaq's revenue for 1989, Canion said, helping compensate for slowing domestic sales of personal computers. To support growing international sales, two new subsidiaries were opened in Norway and Denmark.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses Utility Deposit Request
DOC.TEXT: A bankruptcy judge refused Thursday to require two big department store companies to pay as much as $20 million in deposits to utilities, which feared the retailers couldn't guarantee payment of bills. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. said that if the financial condition of the Campeau Corp. retailers Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores deteriorates, he would require a one-month deposit. But he said the 596 utilities serving Federated and Allied businesses haven't shown that the retailers are deadbeats. ``There will not be a requirement at this time that a deposit be made to any of these utilities,'' Aug said. In another development, bankruptcy court Trustee Conrad J. Morgenstern announced formation of committees of unsecured creditors for Federated and Allied. The committees, which could have broad influence over a bankruptcy reorganization plan, include representatives from Liz Claiborne Inc., Sony Corp. of America and Heller Financial Inc. Leon Mener, a lawyer for Consolidated Edison Co. of New York, said he was disappointed Aug didn't offer utilities security. Mener had argued that Federated and Allied can't guarantee their credit will last. ``What we are concerned about is what happens at the end of the process that may drag on for years and may have enormous administrative costs,'' he said. Campeau, a Toronto-based developing company that bought Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. in the 1980s with billions of dollars in borrowed money, put them under bankruptcy court protection Jan. 15 because of rising difficulties in repaying the debt. It was the biggest bankruptcy filing in retail history. Both Campeau subsidiaries are based in Cincinnati. Federated and Allied store chains include Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Strauss, Maas Bros. Jordan Marsh, Lazarus and Rich's. Utilities represented at Thursday's hearing included New York Telephone Co., Florida Power & Light, AT&T, Cincinnati Gas & Electric Co., and Puget Sound Power & Light. Aug also approved a request by Federated and Allied to renew a $300,000-a-year contract with the recruiter who is finding a chairman and chief executive officer to replace John W. Burden III, who retired Wednesday. Aug approved resumption of severance pay and about $20,000 in monthly retirement benefits that had been suspended.

DOC.HEAD: Sununu Flails Democrats as White House Offers Capital Gains, Savings Plans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 5 grafs after 17th graf pvs bgng, Although Bush, to UPDATE with comment from Conrad. DELETES 18th graf pvs bg'ng, Sununu predicted, and trims from bottom to shorten; Also moved on general newswires
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration opened a heavy lobbying campaign for its initiatives to cut the capital gains tax and boost personal savings on Thursday, with chief of staff John Sununu accusing Democrats of being ``the party of taxes.'' Sununu rebuked Democrats for failing to join Republicans in giving Bush a standing ovation during the State of the Union address Wednesday night, when Bush declared the federal budget could be balanced ``with no new taxes.'' ``What I was surprised at last night was how stark the definition between the two parties was in terms of the applause,'' Sununu told a White House briefing. Democrats bristled at Sununu's attack, coming barely 12 hours after Bush told Congress in the nationally broadcast address that Americans ``did not send us here to bicker'' and ``once again, I offer my hand to all of you.'' ``I would hope that Mr. Sununu would convince the president to reverse his views on opposition to lowering taxes on working Americans,'' Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said in reference to a Democratic plan to cut Social Security payroll taxes. Meanwhile, Bush renewed his push for a lower capital gains tax by sending it to Congress wrapped in a package containing two proposals designed to provide tax breaks to middle-income Americans. One would establish so-called tax-free ``family savings accounts.'' The other would allow up to $10,000 to be withdrawn without penalty from Individual Retirement Accounts to help finance first-time home purchases. Bush, at a ceremony at the White House to kick off the lobbying effort and send the legislation to Congress, said his package would provide ``economic benefits for all citizens.'' He vowed to work closely with the Democratic-led Congress on the package, which the administration hopes will help sidetrack a politically appealing plan by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., to lower Social Security taxes. On Capitol Hill, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady presented the administration's case on the tax proposals to the Senate Budget Committee. ``We believe that the federal government should foster an environment that is conducive to saving, and we have a plan to achieve this objective,'' he testified. But Sasser later told reporters that Bush's ``family-savings account'' plan was little more than ``window dressing'' and would be rejected by Congress. ``It is simply a crumb that they appear to be tossing in the direction of middle class people as a way to cover their flank'' because of administration opposition to Moynihan's plan to roll back last month's Social Security tax increase and to provide an additional tax cut next year. Social Security taxes rose to 7.65 percent from 7.51 percent on Jan. 1. Sununu defended the Bush economic proposals and was sharply critical of Democrats. ``The Democrats, by refusing to stand up when the president suggested that you didn't need new taxes, was (making) a party statement,'' Sununu said. ``That ought to make the American public ask whether or not they might be trying to tell them that they really still want to be seen as the party of taxes,'' he added. Although Bush was applauded many times during his State of the Union address, and received standing ovations from all on four occasions, when he promised to balance the budget ``with no new taxes,'' Republicans rose en masse to applaud him. Democrats remained seated. At the Senate hearing, Brady and Michael Boskin, the president's chief economic adviser, were criticized by Democrats for presenting Congress with an unrealistic spending plan which failed to adequately attack the budget deficit. ``The president and those of you who advise him are guilty of a failure of leadership,'' said Sen. Kent Conrad, D-N.D. ``We are finding ourselves in a weakened position internationally and we don't seem to be able to summon the poltiical courage or the political will to fashion a game plan that really has much merit.'' Elsewhere, House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., told reporters that his party agrees something needs to be done about America's plummeting savings rate, but rejects Bush's tax cut. ``The capital gains tax reduction would give people who are in the highest 1 percent of the nation's income 80 percent of the benefits,'' Foley said. ``That's not the idea we have about encouraging savings.'' Democrats instead would prefer to talk about individual retirement accounts that can be used used to protect up to $2,000 a year from taxes for later use in retirement or as a down payment on a first house. The administration's ``family savings account'' proposal would allow couples to save up to $5,000 a year and individuals up to $2,500 and not pay income tax on the interest if the deposits are held for at least seven years. The other ``sweetner'' in the capital-gains package is a proposal to permit up to $10,000 to be withdrawn prematurely from an Individual Retirement Account, without penalty, to help finance first-time home purchases. Although Bush initially proposed reducing the capital gains tax to 15 percent, his new proposal would exclude from taxation up to 30 percent of the capital gain from the sale of an asset held three years or longer. That works out to an effective tax rate of 19.6 percent for taxpayers in the 28 percent bracket.

DOC.HEAD: Drexel Settles With Massachusetts for $1 Million
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvsm, `Under the... to CORRECT that settlement with federal government sted state; PICKS UP 6th graf pvs, `The settlement...
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. agreed to pay Massachusetts $1 million in a settlement announced Thursday, the latest settlement arising from the Wall Street firm's guilty plea to securities fraud charges. Massachusetts became the 41st state to reach such an agreement with Drexel. The amount was the largest settlement ever paid to the state in a securities matter, according to Secretary of State Michael J. Connolly. Drexel pleaded guilty last September in U.S. District Court in New York to six felonies and paid $650 million to settle a range of fraud allegations stemming from the government's lengthy investigation of insider trading on Wall Street. Drexel also agreed to dozens of administrative changes and unprecedented federal supervision in settling civil charges with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Under the settlement with the federal government, Drexel paid $300 million in fines to the government and set aside $350 million for investors who can prove they were harmed by the firm's actions. Those who may be entitled to restitution include people who bought stocks in about 20 allegedly fraudulent transactions cited by the SEC. The settlement with Massachusetts is one of the largest the firm has reached with states so far. Drexel paid Illinois about $1.2 million and Missouri announced a $1 million settlement on Wednesday. With the Massachusetts agreement, Drexel has paid states settlements totaling $8.3 million. ``We're pleased we were able to settle it and now we can go about our business,'' said Steven Anreder, a Drexel spokesman. The $1 million settlement will go into the state's general fund, Connolly said. Connolly said the $275,000 originally offered by the firm was inadequate. Settling with the states relieves Drexel of possible litigation and frees state regulators from having to investigate the firm's trading activities from 1984 to 1986, when the SEC alleged the fraud occurred. The settlements also generally preserve the firm's ability to underwrite securities and do other business in the states. Most states can revoke a company's right to do business if the firm is convicted or admits to committing a felony. Drexel abandoned the retail stock brokerage business last year. In Massachusetts, the agreement includes a stipulation that Drexel must not solicit any new retail trade without first notifying the state Securities Division and demonstrating that compliance procedures are in place. The firm also cannot sponsor private placements to individuals and must work with the Securities Division to identify any state investors injured by the illegal sale of Drexel junk bonds. Victims would be entitled to place claims with the $350 million compensation fund Drexel established. In addition, Drexel must hire an independent consultant to scrutinize company policies and submit compliance reports; hire an ombudsman to receive and investigate complaints; finance annual audits by the state Securities Division and establish an oversight committee to review its internal procedures. Connolly said he did not know whether any Massachusetts residents were hurt by Drexel sales. Drexel has been working with state regulators for the past eight months, and Connolly said officials monitoring the firm during that time have given them high marks.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Futures Rebound As Traders Rethink IMF News
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices rose sharply Thursday, nearly erasing the previous session's losses as traders reconsidered the significance of a U.S. proposal that the International Monetary Fund sell some of its gold stockpile. Silver futures also posted strong gains in trading on New York's Commodity Exchange. On other commodity markets, sugar futures rose in volatile trading while energy, livestock and crop futures were mixed. Gold futures settled $5.40 to $6.20 higher with the contract for delivery in February up $5.60 at $418 a troy ounce. Silver futures finished 10 cents to 10.5 cents higher with February at $5.297 a troy ounce. The February gold contract fell $5.70 Wednesday in reaction to a Dow Jones News Service report that the United States had proposed the IMF sell $4 billion worth of gold to help some Third World countries make past-due loan payments. The Treasury Department later said the proposal was for the IMF to ``mobilize'' about $1.2 billion worth of gold. That would not necessarily mean the metal would be sold on the open market but might be swapped for U.S. dollars and other hard currencies in deals with governments and central banks. The haziness of the proposal and the lack of overt support for the idea among the IMF's 151 other nation-members were keys to Thursday's rally, analysts said. ``Even if the United States makes this proposal and even if the IMF agrees to do it, it's going to be a long time before they actually sell any gold,'' said analyst James Steel of Refco Inc. Anne Orten, a vice president of Deak International Inc., a large dealer of currencies and precious metals, said gold traders ``probably overreacted'' to the IMF news. She said that when the market opened Thursday with no further sell-off, many traders who had sold contracts on Wednesday bought back those contracts, which pushed the market higher. Sugar futures rose moderately on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange in a volatile session where the market rallied strongly on rumors of Cuban-related buying, only to collapse into the minus column before struggling back near the close. Some market watchers speculated there could be a sell-off Friday in reaction to a Brazilian federal court decision, announced after the close, clearing the way for some large shipments of Brazilian sugar that the Brazilian government had sought to divert to its alcohol fuel program. Sugar futures finished .07 cent to .14 cent higher with March at 14.8 cents a pound. Energy futures finished mostly higher on New York Mercantile Exchange with support stemming from a threatened strike by U.S. oilworkers against individual companies if contract negotiations fail. West Texas Intermediate crude oil was 6 cents lower to 8 cents higher with March at $22.70 a barrel; heating oil was .82 cent lower to .54 cent higher with March at 56.74 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .75 cent lower to .12 cent higher with March at 62.70 a gallon. Corn and soybean futures ended lower and wheat finished mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade after a midday rally failed. Wheat settled { cent lower to 1} cents higher with March at $3.75\ a bushel; corn was { cent to 1 cent lower with March at $2.37{ a bushel; oats were { cent lower to 1 cent higher with March at $1.35} a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 2} cents lower with March at $5.59} a bushel. Cattle futures ended mostly higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in positioning ahead of Friday's semi-annual cattle inventory report. Pork futures weakened in line with soft cash markets. Live cattle futures settled .35 cent lower to .22 cent higher with February at 79 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .13 cent lower to .30 cent higher with March at 82.62 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .40 cent lower with February at 48.30 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .20 cent lower to .03 cent higher with February at 50.20 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Murphy Plans to Step Down as Cap Cities-ABC Chief Exec in June
DOC.TEXT: The chairman and chief executive of Capital Cities-ABC Inc., Thomas S. Murphy, said Thursday he plans to step down as chief executive on June 1 and will recommend that President Daniel B. Burke succeed him. Murphy, who will stay on as chairman, and Burke have worked together at the giant media company for nearly 30 years and it had been expected that Murphy would turn the chief executive post over to Burke at some point. ``That's not a surprise,'' said one securities analyst who spoke on condition that he not be identified. ``Burke has appeared with Murphy at every corporate presentation Murphy has made over the past 10 years. They always refer to each other as partners.'' The analyst said he did not expect any change of direction at Capital Cities-ABC if the board of directors approves the recommendation, as is expected. The next board meeting is in March. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Capital Cities-ABC rose 37{ cents a share to $515.37{. The company owns the ABC Television Network, eight television stations, six radio networks and 21 radio stations and has publishing interests. Murphy has been chairman and chief executive since 1966 and has been with the company since it was created in 1954. Burke has been president and chief operating officer since 1972 and joined the company in 1961. Murphy disclosed his plans Wednesday night at a meeting of the company's senior managers in Phoenix, Capital Cities-ABC said in a statement. A company spokeswoman, Julie Hoover, said Murphy and Burke both were traveling and were unavailable for comment. It was expected that Burke would retain his current titles for the time being. Typically, the chief executive maps a company's plans for growth while the president oversees day-to-day operations. In a memo to employees, Murphy noted that he turns 65 on May 31 and wrote, ``I have long felt that successful companies grow most effectively under the leadership of younger management.'' Burke turns 61 on Sunday. ``I would continue to be involved, but Dan would be the final decision-maker,'' he said. Murphy joined Capital Cities Communications Inc., the predecessor company to Capital Cities-ABC, when it was founded in 1954. The company started with a UHF television station and an AM radio station in Albany, N.Y. The company operated principally in broadcasting for 13 years until moving into the publishing business in 1968, starting with trade publication and then newspapers. Murphy became president in 1964. The company's most ambitious move came in 1986 when it acquired the American Broadcasting Companies Inc. for $3.5 billion. Before joining Capital Cities, Murphy had worked as an industrial oil salesman, an advertising account executive and a product manager for a consumer products company. Burke joined the company in 1961 as general manager of WTEN-TV in Albany and was named general manager of WJR-AM and WJR-FM in Detroit in 1964. He served as president of the company's publishing division from 1969 until his election as president and chief operating officer in 1972. In addition to its broadcasting interests, Capital Cities-ABC publishes nine daily newspapers, numerous weekly newspapers and shopping guides and various periodicals and books. It has an 80 percent interest in the ESPN cable network and smaller stakes in the Arts & Entertainment and Lifetime cable networks.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Finish Mixed
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 3rd graf to DELETE erroneous reference to erasing previous gain; picks up 4th graf pvs bg'ng, The March ...
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures finished mixed Thursday as crude oil and wholesale gasoline prices succumbed to profit-taking. Home heating oil futures fell amid selling tied to reduced demand expectations. Analysts said volume was mostly low throughout the session with sporadic bursts of trading. The selling to collect profits mostly was confined to late in the day after various contracts had broken through psychologically significant levels. The contract for March delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, ended 2 cents higher at $22.70 per 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Later contract months also posted small changes, mostly declines. The March contract for No. 2 heating oil lost 0.82 cent to 56.74 cents a gallon, adding to Wednesday's decline of 1.64 cents. The April contract ended down 0.14 cent at 55.75 cents a gallon while delivery contracts farther into the future settled higher. March unleaded gasoline, which fell 1.02 cents on Wednesday, settled 0.9 cent higher at 62.70 cents a gallon. Later contracts also rose modestly. A bearish weekly report released late Tuesday by the American Petroleum Institute continued to be a drag on futures prices, analysts said. The API figures showed supplies of refined petroleum products were more plentiful than previously believed.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-SEC-Congress, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of a Senate panel said Thursday that he wants to hold hearings into the jurisdictional dispute between the Securities and Exchange Commission and the agency that regulates the futures industry. ``I'm fully aware of the hornet's nest one can hit here,'' said Sen. Christopher J. Dodd, D-Conn., about possible opposition from farm area congressmen who oversee the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. A long-simmering rivalry between the SEC, which regulates the stock and bond markets and the CFTC, which oversees the nation's futures markets, heated up last year when a federal appeals court ruled in favor of the CFTC. The 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals held that financial products that contain any aspects of a futures contract should be regulated by the CFTC _ not the SEC. SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden, who testified before Dodd's securities subcommittee of the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee Thursday, has been very vocal about resolving the dispute which he says is driving new financial products out of the country. ``We are the only country in the world that has a separate agency to regulate the cash market and the derivative market,'' Breeden said in response to a question by Dodd. ``I would very much like to see us debate this issue in this Congress,'' said Dodd. ``I realize it's one that will raise some feathers in certain quarters but it needs to be addressed.'' The subcommittee's ranking Republican, Sen. John Heinz of Pennsylvania, said he supported Dodd's suggestion for a public airing of the issue. In the past, members of committees in both the House and Senate have been careful not to tred outside their bailiwick, as a sign of professional courtesy and political expediency, despite occasional calls to resolve the dispute. ``It is still a critical issue,'' said Heinz. ``We shouldn't be deterred from examining even the most fearful subject _ politically fearful _ in this case.'' Heinz added that he hoped Dodd will ``brave the wasps, hornets and spiders _ and probably a few snakes as well _ that are likely to crawl out of the woodwork.'' The 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Chicago last summer ruled that the SEC overstepped its authority in authorizing three securities exchanges it regulates to trade in a hybrid financial instrument known as a stock basket. Technically called an ``index participation,'' the product resembles a basket of stocks because it allows investors to buy or sell something with a value tied to broad stock market indexes, such as the Standard & Poors 500. But the appeals court held that such products come under the CFTC's supervision if they have any element of a futures product. The appeals court refused to rehear the SEC's arguments and now it's up to the solicitor general to decide if the dispute should be brought before the U.S. Supreme Court for a possible hearing. ``We would defend our exclusive jurisdiction, at the same time it doesn't mean we're against innovative products,'' a CFTC spokesman said in a telephone interview. ``We'd like to see some alternative worked out without litigation. There are a lot of ramifications that have to be carefully considered,'' said the spokesman, who asked not to be named.

DOC.HEAD: Restaurant Should Weather Jefferson Avenue Closing Just Fine
DOC.TEXT: Bob Coleman figures his Wendy's restaurant, next to Chrysler Corp.'s Jefferson Avenue assembly plant, will weather the factory's closing Friday. He, like some of the 1,700 workers who will be laid off when Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon production stops, has been through factory shutdowns before. ``It closed down for a couple of weeks before,'' Coleman said of the plant on Detroit's east side. ``It won't make too much of a difference.'' The Jefferson Avenue plant, one of the industry's oldest, eventually will be demolished, and part of the land under it will be incorporated into the Jefferson North plant, now being built next to the old plant. Many of the laid off employees will be offered jobs at the Jefferson North plant in a year and a half or so, when training begins for workers who will begin production of a new sport-utility vehicle in late 1992. And while the Jefferson North plant will offer some money for the workers in late 1991, it's providing income for Coleman and his employees now. ``We have the construction workers,'' the restaurant manager said. When the Jefferson Avenue plant officially closes with the end of its only shift Friday afternoon, no one is going to look back, get a little misty-eyed and turn off the light. Hundreds of workers will show up Monday and beyond, cleaning up, salvaging some equipment and getting the buildings ready for razing. The United Auto Workers union, nonetheless, says it was betrayed by Chrysler. A hand-painted sign taped on the door to UAW Local 7, across the street from the Jefferson North construction site, takes a swipe at Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca: ``Lido said: Trust me. He lied _ UAW Local 7.'' Just over a year ago, Chrysler closed its Kenosha, Wis., assembly plant and put 5,500 workers on layoff with no new factory to employ them. It was a move union, state and local officials decried, saying Chrysler, and Iacocca specifically, had promised that the plant would stay open longer. The Kenosha plant was closed when Chrysler moved Omni-Horizon production to Jefferson Avenue. Now, the company says it can't sell enough of the small cars to keep the Detroit plant open. On Thursday, Chrysler announced it would close its St. Louis car plant Sept. 21, seven months after it cuts production there in half. The company will lay off 3,700 workers in all. The UAW has contested the Jefferson Avenue plant closing, saying the company could have done a better job of marketing or redesigning the cars to boost sales. For months, workers at the Jefferson Avenue plant have walked to and from their jobs past a moonscape of barren land slowly being transformed into the Jefferson North plant. For some workers, like Walt Harris of Detoit, Jefferson North is the future. During the time he's laid off and the time he hopes to report for retraining, he plans to take law classes at Wayne State University in Detroit. ``Then, hopefully, I'll be back at Jefferson North,'' said Harris, who has worked for Chrysler for 23 years. Closing an assembly plant is like an H-bomb in an automaker's arsenal as it fights to hold profits in a fickle industry. With demand for new cars slipping and competition from U.S.-built Japanese models growing, it's a tactic American companies have resorted to increasingly. Since 1987, U.S. automakers have shut down 13 assembly plants, laying off tens of thousands of workers in assembly and component plants. Laid off union workers can qualify for a variety of benefits designed to get them up to 95 percent of their take-home pay before overtime. But some workers, like Local 7 member Eddie Jordan, a veteran at Jefferson Avenue, doubt whether the benefit funds have enough money to maintain that level as more workers draw from it. Still, he said the Jefferson Avenue closing is different than the others because of the job possibilities offered by Jefferson North. The Jefferson Avenue plant began making cars in 1907 and the first vehicle bearing a Chrysler nameplate rolled off the assembly line 17 years later. Nearly 9 million cars and trucks have been built at the plant. Chrysler spokesman Doug Nicoll said the company will keep the 41 acres north of Jefferson Avenue and incorporate them into Jefferson North. The future of another 104 acres south of the original complex is undecided. Chrysler plans other cutbacks in its drive to trim $1 billion from its $26 billion budget by 1991. Beginning Feb. 12, the nation's No. 3 automaker will cut one shift from its St. Louis car plant, putting 1,900 people on indefinite layoff. The company also is indefinitely laying off hundreds of workers as part of other production cutbacks nationwide. Some analysts have predicted the St. Louis factory and some Canadian plants may have to close entirely or be consolidated to cut costs. The cuts aren't unique to Chrysler. General Motors Corp. in mid-March will shut its Lakewood assembly plant in Atlanta, putting 2,500 workers on indefinite layoff. The nation's largest automaker also is cutting a shift each from its Doraville, Ga., and Linden, N.J., assembly plants. About 15,400 workers will lose or have lost their jobs at 11 GM or Chrysler assembly plants because of indefinite layoffs between January and September.

DOC.HEAD: Deadline Passes for Completion of American Health Magazine Buyout
DOC.TEXT: American Health Partners has been unable to satisfy the conditions set for the sale of its American Health magazine to Reader's Digest Association Inc., a spokesman for Reader's Digest said Thursday. But the seller told Reader's Digest it expects to meet the conditions shortly, and the contract has not been termninated, Reader's Digest spokesman Bruce Trachtenberg said. Reader's Digest, a privately held publishing company based in Pleasantville, N.Y., announced earlier this month that it had agreed to pay $29.1 million for the health and fitness magazine, provided that certain unspecified conditions were met by Jan. 31. Trachtenberg said no new deadline for completion of the deal was set after Wednesday's deadline passed, and said his company had made no commitment on how long it would wait. He declined to disclose what conditions were not met. ``We will be monitoring developments closely,'' he said. A call placed after business hours to American Health Partners went unanswered. The New York-based partnership owns and operates several other magazines, including Psychology Today and Mother Earth News.

DOC.HEAD: Securities Professionals Praise Phelan
With AM-NYSE-Chairman
DOC.TEXT: When John J. Phelan Jr. was 16 years old, he spent a summer working for his father's firm as a ``runner'' on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. He hated it. ``I thought it was just a frightful place to be,'' he said. As he grew older, Phelan changed his mind about the NYSE, working as a ``specialist'' on the crowded floor managing the trading activity and rising through the executive ranks to become chairman and chief executive officer. Phelan announced Thursday he would retire at the end of 1990 after nearly seven years as chairman of the nation's largest stock exchange. He guided the exchange through a period of explosive growth, championed new sophisticated technology and introduced controversial safeguards following the 1987 market crash and a near-repeat performance in 1989. Securities industry officials said they were not entirely surprised by Phelan's announcement and praised his tenure. ``I think he's been marvelous,'' said Alan C. ``Ace'' Greenberg, chairman of the investment firm Bear, Stearns & Co. ``He came from the floor. He was a specialist. He understands the business. It helped.'' ``We've seen everything from electronic trading pressures to the market crash to new products and innovations to congressional pressure,'' added Wall Street veteran Jack Barbanel, president of First Global Asset Management Inc. ``I think he has done a very superb job addressing most of the issues.'' Speaking candidly in his unabashed New York accent, Phelan tackled difficult issues quickly and publicly _ including the 1987 crash, computerized program trading and competition from other foreign and domestic markets. After the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 508 points on Oct. 19, 1987 in a disaster compared to the Great Crash of 1929, Phelan pulled no punches, calling it what it was _ ``the worst market I have ever seen in my lifetime or would hope to see again.'' Phelan, 58, also has come under intense congressional pressure to reform the stock market and criticism from some fronts that the exchange has not adapted to a competitive threat from fully automated markets that can trade all day and night. He always has had an answer, and it usually has been without rancor or apologies. ``He has been a calm and steadying influence as he steered the markets through both good and bad times,'' said Rep. Edward J. Markey, D-Mass, who has pressured for market reform since the crash, often at odds with the exchange. Merrill Lynch & Co. Chairman William A. Schreyer, the NYSE's vice chairman, said: ``John Phelan will be best remembered for the strong, steady leadership he has provided for the entire securities industry during one of the most turbulent periods in its history. ``He has been a voice of reason, calm and integrity, not only guiding the NYSE's member comunity but providing a broader public service by reassuring the investing public as well.''

DOC.HEAD: Group Calls for Rear-Seat Shoulder Belts in Older Cars
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Deletes extraneous material after 6th graf pvs bg'ng, Curry said ...; Also moved on general newswires
DOC.TEXT: The private Institute for Injury Reduction said Thursday that rear-seat lap belts, when unaccompanied by shoulder belts, cause more than 1,000 serious injuries a year. The organization, founded by a group of lawyers who specialize in representing accident victims, urged a campaign by government and industry to equip millions of autos with back-seat shoulder belts. Benjamin Kelley, the institute's president, said that many victims of serious lap belt injuries are children because they tend to be in the rear seats of automobiles when crashes occur. The administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Jerry Ralph Curry, said his agency is already urging auto manufacturers and car dealers to prepare to retrofit older cars with rear-seat shoulder straps. Under a rule adopted last year by the agency, new cars must be equipped with rear-seat shoulder belts. Curry said he was concerned that the safety institute's report may cause parents not to strap their children in while driving. When properly adjusted, seatbelts save lives, he said. Kelley noted that last year's regulation does not apply to 140 million older cars on the road. ``Neither government nor the car industry are vigorously acting to see that existing cars are rapidly equipped with safe, effective rear-seat lap-shoulder belts,'' Kelley said. ``The harmful consequences of such indifference are summed up in the injury cases we have learned about to date,'' Kelley said. ``The majority of the victims are children. The most common fatal injuries are head injuries and internal bleeding.'' ``Non-fatal, permanently disabling injuries are most often spinal cord damage resulting in permanent paraplegia and massive trauma to the abdominal organs,'' he said. Kelley said that in a typical crash other passengers in the car, even those not wearing seat belts, tend to be less severely injured than a person seated in the rear and wearing a lap belt. Kelley called on manufacturers, safety groups and the highway safety administration to launch an advertising campaign ``to ensure that all motorists know the hazards of rear-seat lap-only belts, especially to children'' and the benefits of installing shoulder belts. At a separate news conference, Curry said that while he is delighted that Kelley's institute is focusing on rear-seat accidents, they are ``small potatoes'' compared to the 340,000 annual accidents involving front-seat passengers, especially those not wearing seat belts. He advised parents concerned about the issue to obtain a good child safety seat and keep their child buckled up. If the child no longer fits the seat, put in a booster seat, he said. If that no longer fits, place the child in the front passenger seat with the shoulder strap fastened, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Standard & Poor's Lowers Rating on Some Texas Air Debt
DOC.NOTE: EDS: ADDS new 16th graf to UPDATE with Texas Air statement on possible merger; picks up 16th graf pvs bg'ng, In a ...
DOC.TEXT: Standard & Poor's Corp. said Thursday it downgraded its rating on $400 million of Texas Air Corp. senior debt because of heavy losses at Texas Air's subsidiary Eastern Airlines and a new reorganization plan proposed by Eastern. The credit rating agency said the $400 million in Texas Air senior debt remained on its surveillance list with negative implications. Art Kent, a spokesman for Texas Air at its headquarters in Houston, said the company had no immediate comment on Standard & Poor's action. On Tuesday, a committee of Eastern's preferred shareholders suggested the liquidation or outright sale of the Miami-based airline, which has been in Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization since last March. In papers filed in U.S. Bankruptcy Court, the committee said it had lost faith in Eastern's management because it was ``cannibalizing'' the airline by selling vital assets. The preferred shareholders criticized Eastern's latest reorganization plan, unveiled late last week, which proposes to pay them no more than 10 cents on the dollar in the form of new stock. The new plan also calls for paying unsecured creditors only 10 percent of their debts in cash when the airline emerges from bankruptcy protection, and another 70 percent over the following 10 years, without interest. In return for accepting partial repayment, Texas Air would give the unsecured creditors 40 percent of Eastern's equity. Under Eastern's two previous plans, unsecured creditors _ primarily trade suppliers such as aircraft manufacturers _ were to be repaid in full with interest at the completion of Chapter 11. Eastern's ``heavy losses and revised reorganization proposal, which foresees a reduced cash payout to unsecured creditors, will result in additional demands on Texas Air's resources and severely constrain financial flexibility,'' Standard & Poor's said in a statement. ``The parent company is already paying interest and dividends on some Eastern secured debt and preferred stock, and funded part of Eastern's September pension payment.'' The rating agency stressed that Texas Air's cash reserves should prevent any liquidity crisis and that Continental Airlines, its other major subsidiary, is recovering from earlier financial problems. However, Standard & Poor's said, ``credit strength is damaged by Eastern's continuing difficulties.'' The statement also referred to reported remarks Tuesday by Texas Air Chairman Frank Lorenzo that a merger of Eastern and Continental is a possibility. ``While a combination has long-term potential, it would risk reversing the substantial progress made at Continental,'' the agency said. Texas Air, in a statement issued late Thursday, said it has studied the merger option but ``no consolidation of Eastern and Continental is currently being planned, or being proposed by Texas Air to Eastern's creditors.'' In a related development Wednesday, U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland approved Eastern's request for $50 million to be taken out of escrow to help fund its operations through February. Also on Wednesday, Eastern's management issued a memo to its employees dismissing the preferred shareholders' criticisms and persistent rumors of a possible Chapter 7 liquidation.

DOC.HEAD: Centel Agrees to Pay $1 Million to Government
DOC.TEXT: Centel Cellular Telephone Co. has agreed to pay $1 million to the government over a 1989 accident in which two people died when their helicopter crashed into a radio tower under construction in North Carolina, a Federal Communications Commission official said Thursday. Chicago-based Centel, which is not admitting any liability in the accident, also will conduct a 2-year educational safety awareness campaign within the cellular industry on antenna marking and lighting as part of an FCC-approved consent decree, said Greg Vogt, chief of the commission's mobile services division. The consent decree resolves an FCC complaint that Centel allegedly had failed to comply with FCC requirements for tower marking and lighting. The consent decree stemmed from a 1989 collision of a Medivac helicopter with a tower at Coinjock, N.C., that was owned by a Centel subsidiary, the commission said. Two people in the helicopter were killed. Following an investigation of that accident and another 1989 incident involving a Centel tower in Portsmouth, Va., the FCC's field operations bureau cited Centel for possibly violating FCC rules. Vogt said the consent decree, which was issued Tuesday, ``resolves any pending sanctions that we might impose on Centel for the violation of our rules.'' However, Centel will have to pay $1 million within five days and ``conduct an education campaign within the industry to make sure other licensees know their obligations to light towers during construction,'' Vogt said. ``There has been some concern at the commission that licensees haven't been diligent enough to make sure their lights are on and working,'' both during construction and afterwards, he said. Two civil suits claiming wrongful deaths also were filed in the North Carolina case, Vogt said.

DOC.HEAD: First Interstate Reveals SEC Probe Connected to Huge Texas Losses
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission is conducting an inquiry into a $400 million charge that First Interstate Bancorp reported Dec. 7 for loan losses, mostly at its Texas subsidiary, the bank has disclosed. First Interstate said SEC staffers made an ``informal inquiry'' last month, requesting and receiving documents from the bank holding company, the nation's 10th largest. The $400 million writedown against fourth-quarter profits followed a similar $350 million charge the bank took in the third quarter for losses at its Arizona bank. Last week, First Interstate reported a fourth-quarter loss of $344.3 million because of problems at the Texas bank, the former Allied Bancshares, which First Interstate acquired in early 1988. First Interstate revealed the SEC inquiry in a filing related to its plan to issue 7.5 million new shares of stock to bolster its capital, which was depleted by the writedown. The Wall Street Journal said the inquiry likely was aimed at exploring whether First Interstate had violated disclosure laws by not reporting its Texas problems more promptly. The Journal also reported that federal regulators have placed First Interstate's Arizona unit under strict supervisory controls, and that First Interstate may need regulatory approval to continue paying its 75 cent quarterly dividend. The bank's filing also contained a warning that the big losses may not be over. ``As a consequence of general economic conditions in the operating regions of the corporation's subsidiary banks, particularly the Southwest United States, however, there can be no assurance that further substantial additions to the corporation's allowance for loan losses will not be required,'' the filing said. First Interstate is the nation's 10th largest bank holding company with $58 billion in assets. The bank has been trying to cut costs through layoffs and selling businesses outside of its core consumer and business banking divisions because of the Arizona and Texas losses. The bank's problems also led to an announcement last month that longtime Chairman and Chief Executive Joseph J. Pinola would be succeeded as operating head of the company by President Edward Carson on June 1. In his 12 years as First Interstate's chief, Pinola pursued an agressive expansion policy that backfired in the southwestern banking losses.

DOC.HEAD: Austin, Monk Agree to Merge
DOC.TEXT: Two of the largest privately held tobacco dealers in the country have reached an agreement to merge and form a holding company, officials said. The announcement was made jointly on Wednesday by Austin Co. Inc., which is based in Greeneville, and A.C. Monk & Co. Inc. of Farmville, N.C. A name for the new company has not yet been selected, according to Sam J. Calvert Jr., the chairman of Austin. Monk shareholders would own a majority of the stock of the holding company and have a majority representation on the board of directors, company officials said. Both companies will maintain separate operations. Calvert said the new company would be the fourth-largest tobacco dealer in the world in total sales. Both Austin and Monk sell only leaf tobacco. Officials for both companies on Thursday declined to give any information on annual sales. Clyde Austin III, the vice chairman of Austin, said Thursday that the two companies jointly own Mashonaland Tobacco Co. of Zimbabwe.

DOC.HEAD: SmithKline Cuts Dyazide Price By 11 Percent
DOC.TEXT: SmithKline Beecham Thursday cut the price of its popular high blood pressure drug Dyazide by 11 percent, one day after its sole generic competitor removed its version of the drug from the market. The pharmaceutical giant said the move was in response to a request by U.S. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce investigations subcommittee, who feared some patients wouldn't be able to afford the brand-name drug. SmithKline's move, effective Saturday, will lower the price from about 36 cents a capsule to an estimated 32 cents, company spokesman Jeremy Heymsfeld said. Bolar Pharmaceutical Co. Inc.'s generic version had cost about 25 cents a capsule, he said. A typical patient takes one capsule a day. Bolar recalled their capsules Wednesday following disclosures that the company allegedly gave false test data to the Food and Drug Administration for its version of Dyazide. ``It is a welcome gesture in the direction of price equity,'' Dingell said in a statement responding to the price cut. Dingell had said Wednesday that if SmithKline did not cut the price, the FDA should consider requiring SmithKline to reformulate the drug so it would be easier to copy. Frederick Kyle, president of SmithKline Beecham Pharaceutical-U.S., said the decision to cut the price took into consideration the needs of stockholders, employees and patients. ``We recognize that for some patients the unavailability of a generic version will represent an increase in their health care expenditures. To help minimize the impact, we are decreasing the price of Dyazide,'' Kyle said. In 1988, the first full year of generic competition for Dyazide, sales in this country were $153 million, a 52 percent drop from 1987. The FDA said patients taking Bolar's generic drug should continue taking the drug until their prescription runs out and arrange with their physicians to take another medication. Last spring, Vitarine Pharmaceuticals of Springfield Gardens, N.Y., took its version of Dyazide off the market after it admitted cheating on FDA tests.

DOC.HEAD: Company Reports Smaller Loss; Financing Arranged for LIN Broadcasting Offer
DOC.TEXT: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc., the nation's largest cellular telephone company, said it reduced its losses in the fourth quarter of 1989 and boosted revenues by 67 percent. McCaw also announced Thursday it has completed negotiations with its agent banks on a credit agreement to finance its tender offer for 21.9 million shares of LIN Broadcasting of New York. The $3.38 billion deal will give McCaw control of LIN, a major step in the company's drive to serve the nation's largest population centers. McCaw also said it expects to close in February the pending sale of its south-central cellular systems to Contel Cellular Inc. for approximately $1.3 billion. For the quarter ended Dec. 31, McCaw lost $58.4 million or 36 cents a share on revenues of $152.2 million, compared with a loss of $92.2 million or 70 cents a share on revenues of $91.3 million a year earlier. For the year, McCaw lost $288.5 million or $1.95 a share on revenues of $504.1 million, compared with a loss of $297 million or $2.39 a share on revenues of $310.8 million in 1988. ``Our growth in revenues, cash flow and subscribers continues to meet or exceed our expectations,'' said Craig McCaw, chairman and chief executive officer. Cash flow, representing income from operations before depreciation and amortization, rose to $19.1 million in the latest quarter from $500,000 a year earlier. McCaw Cellular has been developing major regional systems that are important to the creation of a national cellular network. The deals with LIN and Contel will give McCaw and LIN a strong concentration in California, Texas, Florida, New York and Pennsylvania, McCaw said. McCaw credited the improved fourth-quarter performance to reduced losses from operations, gains on sales of securities and some cellular interests, and a significant rise in interest income from the money received from British Telecom's purchase of a 20 percent interest in McCaw Cellular. The number of cellular subscribers in its markets, as well as markets where it has the right to buy a controlling interest, rose 68 percent to 434,000 at year-nd from 258,000 at the end of 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Paramount Signs Producers Simpson, Bruckheimer to 5-year Deal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release 12:01 a.m. Thursday PST, Time set by source.
DOC.TEXT: Don Simpson and Jerry Bruckheimer, the producers of ``Top Gun'' and ``Beverly Hills Cop,'' signed an exclusive five-year deal with Paramount Pictures to make at least five films, the studio announced. The terms of the partnership were not disclosed. But the arrangement is likely to make Simpson and Bruckheimer, the most successful movie producers in Hollywood in the `80s, also the most highly compensated. Furthermore, the pair will enjoy the independence to make any movie, any way they want. ``They (Paramount) put up the money. We put up the talent. We meet at the theater,'' Simpson said Wednesday. In recent years, the producing duo have made some of the biggest-grossing films in movie history. Their box-office hits include 1983's ``Flashdance'' ($209 million worldwide box-office gross), 1984's ``Beverly Hills Cop'' ($312 million), 1986's ``Top Gun'' ($351 million) and 1987's ``Beverly Hills Cop II'' ($281 million). Their only flop was 1984's ``Thief of Hearts.'' The two have produced films for Paramount for the last seven years. The deal was struck after months of negotiations with Paramount and other studios. Simpson and Bruckheimer said they also considered taking their production company public, but declined to do so because they wanted to be hands-on producers. ``We ended up with what we were after from the beginning _ freedom,'' Simpson said. Said Bruckheimer: ``We have the right to make a certain number of pictures under certain limits, but very broad limits.'' Unlike most producers under contract to a studio, Simpson and Bruckheimer will develop and make motion pictures without the advice and consent of Paramount executives. Paramount will provide financing in the range of $20 million per film and then market and distribute the finished products. ``We're not compelled to do anything,'' Simpson said. ``We're not serving management's needs. ... We don't have any bosses.'' Paramount will continue to negotiate contracts for the producers, and Simpson and Bruckheimer do not expect to have to hire additional personnel. While neither Paramount nor Simpson and Bruckheimer revealed the terms of the deal, it is almost certain that the pair will collect a substantial share of their films' profits. On top of that, they will earn a producer's fee for the films they make. To make big money, though, they have to make popular movies. The two also will be allowed to direct movies, and plan to co-direct their next project. Directing, Bruckheimer said, ``is another horizon to tackle. It's always been important to conquer new goals. And it's more control over the creative process.'' The pair said they have no aspirations to run a studio, as producers Jon Peters and Peter Guber did last year when they exited Warner Bros. to assume management of Columbia Pictures. The Simpson-Bruckheimer production company, located on the Paramount lot, is now filming the auto racing movie ``Days of Thunder,'' starring Tom Cruise, Robert Duvall, Nicole Kidman and Randy Quaid. Simpson himself will play an Italian race-car driver in the movie. It is directed by ``Top Gun's'' Tony Scott. Before joining with Bruckheimer to produce ``Flashdance,'' Simpson was Paramount's president of worldwide production for two years. Bruckheimer, as an independent producer, has worked on ``American Gigolo,'' the remake of ``Cat People'' and ``Thief.''
